HEADLINE: It's Sunday Afternoon and Here Come the Blahs

BYLINE: By JON NORDHEIMER

 BODY:
It is Sunday afternoon, sometime past 3 o'clock.
The weekend hourglass is spilling its treasure. Only Sunday night remains before the Monday-morning blahs -- return to the office, school or work. 
 Imperceptibly at first, then unmistakably, there is company.
The Sunday blues have dropped by for a visit.
 
Flip Side of TGIF
 It's the flip side of TGIF (thank God, it's Friday). The weekend, which started with such bright promise, is now inexorably rolling toward a conclusion. Even if things are going right, those Sunday blues have mysteriously reappeared, bringing mild depression, echoes of loneliness, or a twinge of malaise or melancholy.
Not everyone gets them, and it is impossible to quantify how many people do, but the anecdotal evidence is there. If people are asked whether they have a downward mood swing by late Sunday afternoon, chances are they will recognize the symptoms and confess that the visitation shows up like clockwork.
Some researchers say the problem result from the resetting of internal biological clocks after weekend disruptions of sleep patterns and activity.
Unsure that something as vague as the Sunday blues is a verifiable complaint, scientists nonetheless can extrapolate from weekend behavior to try to explain its occurrence.
The most likely culprit, they speculate, is the imbalance between weekend sleep-wake cycles and the internal biological clock set by evolution to the cycle of day and night. These scientists, chronobiologists, say that mood shifts on Sunday afternoon or blahs on Monday are not surprising because people usually stay up later and rise later on weekends. Such disruptions can confuse the control center in the brain that is wired in some primordial shop.
"The demands made upon the circadian pacemaker by weekend behavior and sleep-wake cycle changes may affect mood," said Dr. Charles Czeisler, a professor at Harvard who specializes in sleep disorders. "No one knows the mechanism or, in fact, if it occurs at all, but there is a lot of writing in medical literature that it may take place."
With some people, sleep-wake cycles over the weekend are so altered that by the time the alarm goes off Monday at 6 A.M. the brain (and therefore the body) reacts as if it were 4 A.M.
 
A Sense of Dread
 With the end to summer vacations, the opening of school, and the excitement or gloom that accompanies turning Sundays over to doubleheader and tripleheader football, comes a deepening awareness of this phenomenon.
For some the answer to Sunday blues may be all too obvious.
They hate work. They hate school. They hate housework. Like Garfield, the cartoon cat, they loathe Mondays and a sense of dread envelops them by Sunday afternoon.
Dr. Herbert J. Freudenberger, a Manhattan psychoanalyst who has written books on situational anxiety and job burnout, said: "I hear about it from patients who are very unhappy in their jobs, who fear going to the office on Monday morning to prove themselves all over again. It has increased in recent years because of the unpredictability of what's happening to the economy."
 
Blues Come to Happy People, Too
 That doesn't explain why Margery Komninos, a 36-year-old computer programs manager in Denver who loves her job and her husband, slips into a Rocky Mountain low on Sunday afternoons.
"I never really thought about the reason for the Sunday blues, but there's no question something happens to me that drags my energy and mood down even when I'm having a good weekend," she said. "It doesn't happen on Saturday -- just Sundays."
Mary Aloe, a 29-year-old publicity agent in Los Angeles, gets it too. "People need to know they're not alone in this," she said. "I've mentioned to my friends what happens to me on Sundays and they say: 'Oh my gosh, is that what it is? I've got the same thing.' "
"Things might be going real well in life, and this empty feeling grips you, a form of depression or sadness or stress, and you can't shake it," she said. "I have no scientific evidence, but it seems more prevalent among women. I ask men if they experience it and they say, 'What are you talking about?' "
 
At Nap Time, a Window
 Highly organized personalities, like nature, abhor a vacuum, and such people may feel lost noodling around in unstructured expanses of time. Sunday may be the longest stretch of unscheduled time they encounter in a week.
Saturdays in most American households tend to be filled with shopping, errands, chores, exercise and socializing. Sundays bring a more leisurely pace. Some people sleep in. Some go to church. Many drift through brunch, the newspapers and try to plan the rest of the day.
Midafternoon, when thoughts of a nap beckon, is the window of opportunity for the blues. Subtle memories, perhaps from childhood, slip past the drowsy veil as defense mechanisms falter. Or the mind may track ahead to the week's burdens. Or back to the triumphs or disappointments of the weekend.
"Some people have difficulty being alone with their memories or can't stand mulling over their lives," said Dr. Thomas Wehr, a psychiatrist at the National Institutes of Mental Health. "They suffer a form of existential angst."
Other researchers suggest that those in stressful jobs suffer withdrawal after two days of weekend rest. The body may relax, but the brain is demanding adrenaline, they say.
Still others say the Sunday letdown has all the earmarks of withdrawal from caffeine by workers who taper off their coffee intake on weekends.
Those who stay up and drink too much on weekends do not need expert advice on why they feel out of sorts on Sunday. Abuse of alcohol and other drugs can turn Sundays into a land of the living dead, compounding any existing physical or emotional complaint.
 
A Price for Weekend Leisure
 While scant scientific study has been made of the Sunday blues and Monday blahs, a suspicion has lingered that weekend leisure carries a price. Monday's reputation is supported by statistics showing that suicides peak on that day, 12 percent higher than the average for the rest of the week, according to figures compiled by the United States Public Health Service in 1989. Saturday is usually the low and Sunday is about average.
Sandor Ferenczi, a Hungarian psychiatrist, in a 1919 paper entitled "Sunday Neuroses" reported a weekly resurfacing of repressed memories among his patients. Others over the years have noted neurotic behavior associated with the weekend and have attributed it to the new leisure won by the working classes, declining church attendance or loss of faith.
The biblical proscription against work on the Sabbath in the Judeo-Christian tradition made Saturdays or Sundays special through the centuries, but that did not always translate into a day of rest for the faithful.
Modern trends have elevated the weekend to a special status separate from relgious observance.
Witold Rybczynski in his book "Waiting for the Weekend" (Viking Press, 1991) says: "The weekend has imposed a rigid schedule on our free time, which can result in a sense of urgency that is at odds with relaxation. The weekly rush to the cottage is hardly leisurely, nor is the compression of various recreational activities into the two-day break."
Those who escape cities for the country on a summer weekend may find the thought of clawing their way back through Sunday night traffic depressing.
Rory Stockel, a 34-year-old production assistant for Home Box Office in New York, said she and four friends formed a club to have dinner, play games or go to the movies together on Sunday evenings to avoid the blues. "I thought it was a condition of being single and living in a studio," she said. "Now I'm married and I still have it. I know part of it is anxiety about the coming week and if I have enough clothes to wear, things like that. But it is also a lonely, empty, sad kind of thing that grabs me every Sunday about 3 o'clock."
People have been routinely disturbing their circadian rhythms ever since the light bulb was invented a century ago. Instead of going to sleep when the sun sets, as humans did through the ages, modern workers stay up late, then roust themselves from bed with an alarm. Most visibly affected are shift workers, who radically alter their sleep patterns, but even 9-to-5 workers pay a price in sleep deprivation.
On weekends the tendency is to stay up even later on Friday and Saturday nights and catch up on sleep Saturday and Sunday mornings. The body clock resets to the new timetable, but not completely, according to chronobiologists.
Daylight is still a potent signal to the internal body clock that regulates hormones, temperature, blood pressure and other functions.
 
Rhythms for the 7-Day Week
 Perhaps the most intriguing thought comes from Dr. Franz Halberg of the University of Minnesota's Chronobiological Laboratories. Dr. Halberg, 73 years old, who is considered the father of chronobiology, says he has found significant evidence, yet to be published, of seven-day rhythms in humans.
The seven-day week, alone among the components of the calendar, has always been thought to be a product of divine instruction or social convention, not set by natural phenomenons as the day, month or year are.
Dr. Halberg said he is convinced that body rhythms of approximately seven days might be the force that impelled mankind toward the seven-day week.
"I believe we can now demonstrate, with the help of computer analysis, overwhelming evidence that there are seven-day rhythms produced by nature," Dr. Halberg said. "They are in our genes, and it is very big news."

(Eric Lars Bakke for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: AREA JOBLESSNESS CONTINUES TO RISE

BYLINE: By NICK RAVO

 BODY:
August unemployment in New York City neared double-digit levels and reached its highest mark in seven years, 9.3 percent, according to the Labor Department.
The number of unemployed was 50 percent higher than the level a year earlier and was also significantly higher than the city's July jobless rate, 8.8 percent. 
 Unemployment in all of New York State rose to 7.5 percent in August from 7.1 percent the month before, and in New Jersey to 6.7 percent in August from 6.3 percent. The state figures are seasonally adjusted; the rate for the city is not.
August unemployment rates were not available for Connecticut; the July jobless rate was 6.6 percent, up from 5.9 percent in June.
Nationally, the seasonally adjusted unemployment rate for August was 6.8 percent, the same as in July.
Unemployment in New York City rose to 306,000 in August, from 205,000, or 6.2 percent, in August 1990, according to the Labor Department. Three-fifths of the jobless said they had lost their jobs. A year ago, that margin was about one-half.
 
Women and Teen-Agers
 Meanwhile, the New York City employment rate, another key factor for measuring economic health, dropped by 100,000 people in the last year.
Declining employment across the state reflects a leveling off in the number of women entering the job market, the Labor Department numbers showed. Women were the largest-growing segment in the market during the 1980's.
"It's not the statistics that trouble us; it's our worries about the people behind those statistics," said a spokesman for Mayor David N. Dinkins, John H. Beckman. "Each month that we hear discouraging or bad news about unemployment offers more compelling reasons for Federal anti-recession legislation, and we hope that the Congress and the White House, will be attentive and responsive."
Another factor for the employment drop was the number of teen-agers in the job market. That number fell by 60,000 this year, a sign that members of the post-Baby Boom generation is moving into their late teens. The summer job market for the state was also the weakest in nine years.
In New Jersey, unemployment increased from 4.9 percent a year ago, up by about 200,000. Employment levels in the state also dropped by about 100,000 people.

HEADLINE: Dinkins's Plan to Incinerate Draws Environmentalists' Ire

BYLINE: By ALLAN R. GOLD

 BODY:
Environmental groups in New York City are reacting to Mayor David N. Dinkins's decision to build trash incinerators with a sense of betrayal and a determination to fight any waste disposal plan that includes the burning of garbage, leaders for the groups say.
The groups are saying that they will do whatever they can legally and politically to block the move to incinerators. Given their track record of holding up projects that they oppose on environmental grounds, this shift almost guarantees a continuation of the stalemate on solid waste policy that occurred during the Koch administration, which wanted to build as many as eight new incinerators. 
 Even leaders of environmental groups that were willing to support a limited amount of incineration say they have now changed their minds because they no longer believe the Dinkins administration's promises about recycling. Instead, the administration must first introduce a broad recycling program and prove that recycling alone cannot address the city's trash problems, they say.
Influential environmental groups like the Natural Resources Defense Council, the Environmental Defense Fund and the New York Public Interest Research Group have banded together to oppose the incineration proposal. Borough Presidents Ruth W. Messinger of Manhattan and Howard Golden of Brooklyn were among several elected officials who expressed bitterness and disappointment at the Dinkins administration's decision.
 
'Cynical Politics'
 They all said that the Mayor's credibility on this issue has been greatly eroded, although his campaign speechespromised only to delay a decision until 1993.
"This plan repudiates everything that had been told to us by mayoral candidate Dinkins and suggests that cynical politics as usual is the engine driving this decision," said Rabbi David Niederman, executive director of United Jewish Organizations of Williamsburg, where the construction of an incinerator at the Brooklyn Navy Yard has long been under consideration.
The groups also complained that the Sanitation Department wasted the time of citizens who advised it on developing a solid waste disposal plan. After months of consultation, "the department has decided that it knew the answer all along -- resurrecting from its files an ill-conceived conclusion reached long ago by the Koch administration: burn it," the three environmental groups said in a statement.
Any plan that includes incineration that fails to maximize recycling is "dead in the water," said James T. B. Tripp, counsel for the Environmental Defense Fund, a group that has previously been open to incineration.
 
'People Are Livid'
 In particular, what has infuriated many elected officials, community groups and environmentalists is a sense that the city is prepared to make incineration its main disposal approach before giving recycling a fair try. The current recycling program has been enfeebled by budget cutbacks and a host of management and operating problems.
"At a time when recycling is getting peanuts, people are livid that the administration would even float the idea of a billion dollars worth of incinerators," said Eric A. Goldstein, a lawyer with the Natural Resources Defense Council, an environmental organization.
The conflict over solving the disposal problem is occurring while space at the only remaining city landfill is running out and other states are increasingly reluctant to allow imports of other people's trash.
The environmentalists' backlash came about after a statement last Thursday by Sanitation Commissioner Steven M. Polan that the city could recycle only 25 percent of its residential trash and would eventually have to burn about two-thirds.
In testimony before a state legislative hearing on solid waste, Mr. Polan said additional recycling would prove too costly because markets had not developed enough to absorb some kinds of trash and the city did not have enough space for the necessary recycling-related operations. In addition, incineration is the least costly disposal technique, he said.
 
29 of 59 Districts
 Two and a half years after the city's mandatory recycling law took effect, just 29 of 59 community districts have some curbside recycling. Budget cuts beginning last November froze expansion into the remaining districts and have left a barebones program with a 6 percent citywide recycling rate. Also, the Sanitation Department failed to meet its legal daily average tonnage target for recyclables last April.
The program barely survived budget cuts last July, and questions remain about whether money will be found to save it for the second half of the fiscal year.
Under the Mayor's proposal, which Mr. Polan described as preliminary, two or three incinerators would have to be built, and three existing plants would be expanded. In total, the incinerators would handle 10,000 tons a day, about two-thirds of the city's residential tonnage.
But the environmental groups say a fully financed recycling program must be allowed to operate for several years before a conclusion should be reached on incineration. Residential recycling levels can easily exceed 25 percent, they say, and can reach 60 percent or higher.
 
Open to Other Strategies
 Building incinerators "puts a ceiling on the amount of recycling the city is willing to do," said Larry Shapiro, toxics project counsel for the New York Public Interest Group, a longtime opponent of incinerators.
In an interview on Friday, Mr. Polan said he would be open to other strategies before the city's solid waste plan is submitted to the state's Department of Environmental Conservation after public hearings in November and December. Acceptance of a plan is a prerequisite for building any incinerator or recycling center.
"If there's a way to do this with more recycling and less burning that is feasible and cost-effective, I'd be all for it," he said.
For now, though, the department has concluded that there must be somen incineration.
"Whether you recycle 25 percent or 35 percent or more, there's still going to be a residual that needs to be burned," he said.
Those who advocate delaying incinerator construction to see how far recycling can go are pretending a problem does not exist, Mr. Polan said.
"We cannot afford to risk the economy of New York on uncertain markets and uncertain projections," he said.

HEADLINE: Study Finds Sex Bias in Connecticut Legal System

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Sept. 7

 BODY:
A task force study has concluded that sex bias pervades the Connecticut legal system, extending to judges who whistle at female lawyers, offend them with suggestive remarks and sometimes make sexual advances on them.
Three years in the making, the 200-page report is replete with insulting remarks reported by female members of the Connecticut bar. The task force, commissioned in 1987 by Chief Justice Ellen A. Peters of the Connecticut Supreme Court, also said that female lawyers are less likely to get lucrative case referrals or judicial appointments than men. 
 "Women are treated differently from men in the justice system and, because of it, many suffer from unfairness, embarrassment, emotional pain, professional deprivation and economic hardship," the study concluded.
 
Wolf Whistling
 One judge publicly complained about the "feminization of the public defenders' office" and said that women are unable to handle criminal clients roughly, pushing them up against a wall, for example. As a result, the judge said, these cases are not handled properly.
The report said that another judge had "wolf whistled" at a passing female lawyer during lunch break.
A prosecutor responding to a female defense counsel's request to examine a rape victim's clothing said, "Do you want to try them on?"
And a judge speaking to a female lawyer in a courthouse hallway, in front of several male colleagues, used crude language in stating that the woman would be as busy on a certain case as a bride "on her wedding night."
The report also said that female lawyers are sometimes subjected to sexual advances by judges, other lawyers and court personnel.
None of these instances resulted in disciplinary action because the task force did not ask for names from the lawyers who reported the remarks.
Superior Court Judge Francis X. Hennessy, a co-chairman of the task force, said the group feared that lawyers would be reluctant to come forward with instances of improper behavior or remarks if they were asked to give names. Judge Hennessy said future complaints of such behavior could result in punishment.
 
Loss of Credibility Seen
 "Treating a woman in this manner undermines her ability to function properly in the system because the woman loses credibility in the eyes of her client and even in the eyes of the court," Judge Hennessy said at a news conference at the State Supreme Court building on Thursday. "Gender bias breeds unfair treatment and unfair results."
Justice Peters said that some of these instances of offensive remarks were the result of ignorance and insensitivity rather than maliciousness.
"This problem is pervasive throughout our society," Justice Peters said. She added that the task force's conclusion that bias pervades the judicial system was "no surprise."
Today, 18 of 150 trial judges on the Superior Court are women. Women have 1 of 9 judgeships on the Appellate Court, 1 of 7 on the Supreme Court and 42 of 133 on the Probate Court.
Sex bias in the judicial system is not confined to the courtroom, the study said. A lawyer in the New Haven area told the task force that the Judicial Selection Commission routinely asked female candidates: "How does your husband feel about you seeking a judgeship?" and "How will you handle your children or having a baby if a judgeship is given to you?"
A survey of lawyers and judges confirmed a tendency -- documented in other studies -- to give women lighter sentences. One exception was among female juvenile delinquents, who tend to spend more time in detention than boys because judges believe they need more protection, the report found.
Recommendations by the task force include: changing the language in judicial rule books and codes of conduct to make them "gender-neutral"; providing courses on sex bias for judges, lawyers and other participants in the judicial system, and condemning and punishing sexist conduct by judges, lawyers and other court officials.

HEADLINE: Fortress Cuba, Lonely Cuba

 BODY:
Stunned by events in Moscow, Fidel Castro now talks of a "zero option": Cuban socialism will carry on alone, even without Soviet aid. "Whatever happens in the Soviet Union," blusters the party newspaper, "we will not move away from the path we have chosen. We will continue with our independent, Cuban, socialist line."
But who is "we"? Not once since seizing power in 1959 has Mr. Castro submitted his reign to electoral judgment. Like other Communist fortresses in China, North Korea and Vietnam, Cuba has scorned democratizing reforms. And who is the "we" responsible for Cuba's colonialist dependence on a no-longer-willing foreign partner? Mr. Castro. 
 For three decades, Cuban socialism has been propped up by Soviet subsidies, roughly $3.5 billion last year. Under complex barter arrangements, Moscow has overpaid for sugar, while providing nearly all of Cuba's oil and three-fourths of its imports. Now fuel shipments are lagging and a collapsing Soviet state can no longer afford what Boris Yeltsin describes as foreign charity.
During fat years, Cuba did little to anticipate this eventuality. In the 1960's, a French journalist, K. S. Karol, asked whether the Russians might someday cut back on Cuban sugar. Mr. Castro saw no reason why Moscow would not buy Cuban sugar "when their own sugar used to sell for three times the price of ours. Of course, political factors may come in, but so far the Russians have never resorted to economic blackmail."
Other Cubans with more foresight urged diversification. When the first sugar agreement with Moscow was signed in January 1964, Nikita Khrushchev promised to provide a miraculous cane-cutting machine; it proved comically unworkable. The reality of the sugar pact was tersely expressed by Carlos Franqui, a defecting veteran of the Sierra Maestra:
"In the old days, the difference between the market price and the price the United States paid for sugar was called the differential, and what it did was to guarantee a market for our product. Now we were doing the same thing; we were tied to the same monoculture and the same single market, only this time with the Russians."
By then, Mr. Castro had reshaped Cuban politics on the one-party Soviet model, eliminating the check of independent criticism. Slogans and incantation replaced debate as Mr. Castro played the world leader, sending armies to Angola and Ethiopia and backstopping Soviet policy everywhere. Now, with the collapse of Communism, slogans can no longer conceal Cuba's poverty, isolation and humbling dependence.
For Cubans, the cruel result is hardship and hunger even if Moscow buys sugar at reduced prices. Some U.S. cold warriors remain eager to meddle in Cuban affairs in an effort to topple Mr. Castro. But the Cuban dictator has painted himself into his own corner. Fidel Castro's reign deserves to end in home-grown failure, not martyrdom.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: Judge Thomas Takes the Stand

 BODY:
After a summer of wrangling over what Clarence Thomas believes and what his Supreme Court nomination portends, the judge will present himself on Tuesday to the Senate Judiciary Committee. On political grounds alone, his prospects for approval are thought to be good. But his voluminous written record leaves him with much to explain and the burden of proving that he will protect some treasured civil rights and liberties.
The senators, too, will be on public trial; the quality of their questions will reveal whether they are both eager and competent to fulfill their constitutional role as a full partner in the appointment process. Contrary to theories that the Senate's "advice and consent" role is limited to measuring a nominee's technical fitness, the confirmation power is as broad as the President's power to nominate. No less than the chief executive, the senators can weigh policy and ideology. 
 Here are some key areas to explore:
Legal qualifications. The senators can test for themselves whether Judge Thomas, an accomplished, personable lawyer who now sits on the Federal Court of Appeals in Washington, is the best-qualified candidate in the land, as President Bush claims, or simply "qualified," as the American Bar Association concluded. If the latter, they must ask themselves if "qualified" is good enough.
Family background. The senators can give great or little weight to the fact that Judge Thomas has experienced both poverty and prejudice against black Americans. President Bush rightly boasts that his nominee would bring racial and economic diversity to an upper-middle-class institution. Yet senators must explore the significance of his experience. Does his background suggest a special understanding of poor blacks and empathy for their needs? Or does it suggest that he has distanced himself from their problems?
For example, why did Mr. Thomas cite his sister, still stuck in rural Georgia, as a prime example of the national problem of welfare dependency? "She gets mad when the mailman is late with the welfare check," he was quoted as telling a conference of black conservatives. "That's how dependent she is."
Civil rights. Senators may legitimately ask whether the nominee's repeated challenges to some forms of affirmative action -- the kind of stand that made him attractive to the White House -- make him the right person for the high court in its current turmoil over civil rights issues.
As chairman of the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, Mr. Thomas rightly stressed the need to do justice to individual victims of race, sex and other discrimination. But he also disparaged attempts to provide broad-based relief that would efficiently bring more minorities into the work force without requiring each beneficiary to prove that specific acts of bias had held him or her back.
His posture is mystifying because Mr. Thomas himself appears to have been a deserving beneficiary of an affirmative action program at Yale University that expedited his entry into the law school and gave him a chance to earn his degree. The senators must ask how Judge Thomas really feels about group remedies for discrimination and whether his approach fits the needs of the nation at this point in its social development.
Natural law. It is crucial for the Judiciary Committee to discover what Clarence Thomas means by his frequent praise of "natural law" as a judicial resource for constitutional review. He has commented many times in favor of applying a "higher" law than the written Constitution to judicial decisions. In one controversial speech he praised an article that opposed abortion as a violation of natural law.
Does Mr. Thomas adhere to a coherent natural law philosophy, whose tenets and bedrock values he can describe to the senators? Or does he mostly search for natural law on an ad hoc basis when dealing with a particular legal issue? Whichever the case, how will his philosophy shape his judicial judgments?
Personal liberty. Those who fear for the continued vitality of Roe v. Wade, the landmark case granting women the right to abortion, which is now under attack within the Court and hanging by a thread, are not paranoid. Judge Thomas has disparaged the legal reasoning behind the Roe decision. Will his views threaten a broad range of personal liberty and privacy rights that many Americans hold dear?
Conservative ideology. The senators need to examine where Judge Thomas fits on the ideological spectrum. Is he a radical rightist who will push the court's majority even further to the right, as critics fear? Or is he a more moderate and unpredictable jurist, as some analysts suggest? The Senate has every right to consider the balance and direction of the Court, not just the qualifications of this particular nominee.
Clarence Thomas may prove a strong witness for his own cause. If so, he will dispel the cynicism surrounding Mr. Bush's claims and his choice of a black whose philosophy has forced some liberals and minorities to choose between ideology and racial loyalty. These are momentous hearings for the judge, the Senate, the Court and the country.

HEADLINE: Can Jefferson Make It in Moscow?

BYLINE: By David K. Shipler; David K. Shipler is a former Moscow bureau chief for The New York Times and author of "Russia: Broken Idols, Solemn Dreams." He writes on Soviet affairs for The New Yorker.

DATELINE: CHEVY CHASE, Md.

 BODY:
As exhilarating and revolutionary as the events in the Soviet Union have been, they have failed to break that society's most troublesome governmental tradition -- the habit of anti-constitutionalism.
Boris N. Yeltsin rallied tens of thousands by condemning the coup as "anti-constitutional." When the plotters were defeated, Mikhail S. Gorbachev was restored to the presidency in the name of constitutionality. But this was only lip service to an idea that has never taken root in Russia. 
 In truth, the coup and the victory over the coup have combined tragically to sweep away the fragile structure of constitutional democracy that Mr. Gorbachev and liberal reformers erected 18 months ago. The urgent task now, which some key democrats understand, is to draft a new constitution in an effort to institutionalize political pluralism.
Drawing on the French and American models, the reformers amended their constitution in March 1990 to provide what the Soviet Union had never had: the separation of legislative and executive powers, a procedure to override presidential vetoes, a limited term for the President, a succession mechanism and other checks and balances.
Significantly, Mr. Yeltsin did not attend the session of the Congress of People's Deputies where this Western system was painstakingly negotiated and approved. And Mr. Gorbachev -- although trained as a lawyer and possessed by a noble vision of his country under the rule of law -- did not follow through afterward to nurture the legislative process and bolster the separation of powers.
On the contrary, finding himself pressed by hard-liners to address the twin crises of economic catastrophe and nationalist separatism, Mr. Gorbachev undermined his own endorsement of a constitutional system by ruling increasingly by decree. He often evaded the standing legislature, the Supreme Soviet, which rarely resisted him. Ironically, his decrees went largely unheeded as power spun wildly away from the center and into the republics.
His extra-constitutional step last week, taken in a frantic attempt to hold the tattered union together, further diminished the legislative branch even as it decentralized power to the republics. He browbeat the Congress of People's Deputies into voting itself essentially out of existence, reconstituting the Supreme Soviet into a republic-dominated body with limited authority and creating a strong State Council comprising republic presidents and himself. Granted, the Congress was only quasi-democratic; when it was formed in 1989, fewer than half of its 2,250 members were chosen by popular vote in competitive elections, with the rest running unopposed or assigned by the Communist Party and other organizations. But as the only nationally elected body, it leaves a vacuum, with no timetable for new elections.
The failure of constitutionalism has not surprised reformers, many of whom have warned that the cultural patterns of a long history could prove more powerful than words on paper. "In pre-revolutionary Russia, the decree of the czar was the real law," Aleksandr N. Yakovlev, a legislator and legal scholar, has said. "The bad Russian tradition of vesting legislative powers in the executive, dating from the old times, bothers me."
Successive Soviet constitutions were widely regarded as mockeries. Article 56 of the one adopted under Leonid I. Brezhnev stated, "The private life of the citizen, the secrecy of letters, telephone conversations and telegraph communications are protected by law." Article 52, providing that "the church in the U.S.S.R. is separate from the state," was used to bar the church from doing anything that the state did, such as running schools.
Nor have the tumultuous six years of perestroika taught the Soviet public to respect the constitutional process. This is dangerous, for democracy is not just a policy. It is a culture and a structure. Unless the liberty that was defended in the streets is now codified in a constitutional system, and then honored for a long time, the country will not succeed in securing its freedoms.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Who Is Hurt the Most By Defense Dept. Cuts

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"So Far, St. Louis Handles Arms Cuts" (Business Day, Aug. 8), the fifth and last article in your "Military-Industrial Upheaval" series, well describes the severity of Defense Department cuts in St. Louis. But your accompanying map rates Missouri as relatively unaffected by cuts. 
 The map omits two key factors:
(1) The level of state unemployment. This helps predict how quickly laid-off arms-industry workers will find new jobs. Unemployment in your map's three most affected states (Alaska, Hawaii and Virginia) averages 5.3 percent, whereas in Missouri it's a worrisome 7 percent.
(2) The mix of cuts in Defense Department contracts in the state and cuts in base personnel. This helps predict the effects on the local economy. Cuts in the high earnings of Pentagon-contractor employees can have double the local impact of cuts in relatively transient base personnel, who shop at their PX. Procurement in the map's most affected states averages only one-third of Pentagon income; in Missouri, it's 84 percent, almost all going to St. Louis.
The dislocation index for Defense Department cuts of the Council on Economic Priorities includes the two missing factors and shows Missouri is truly the worst-hit state, followed by Texas and Arizona. New York State ranks No. 6; the cuts will hurt most in Long Island, where Bethpage (Grumman) by itself gets 28 percent of the state's Defense Department income.
 
JOHN TEPPER MARLIN
New York, Aug. 15, 1991
 
The writer is an economist and project director for defense conversion, Council on Economic Priorities.

HEADLINE: Can't We Also Save Backyard Animals?

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Our little town's first rabid raccoon has been detected, to our collective dismay. My wife and I are also dismayed at the lack of action by government agencies and wildlife organizations. In five years since this problem was identified, those supposedly protecting the welfare of citizens and wildlife alike have done nothing but take defensive actions like vaccinating pets. Now they are going door to door making people prove their pets have been inoculated. (I suppose they confiscate your cat if you can't find the receipt from the vet.) Meanwhile, people must worry about the safety of their pets and children. 
 This could have been avoided if our elected officials (whom we support with taxes) and wildlife organizations (which we support with contributions) took action to try and stop the spread of rabies among the raccoon population. Instead, they sat in their offices issuing warnings or chasing that brave upstate New Yorker who fled with his raccoon friends.
When rabies broke out among foxes several years ago, the French developed an oral vaccine, put it in fish balls and dropped them by helicopter. This rapid if scattershot response stopped the spread of the disease. Our "experts" have done nothing but conduct experiments on islands off the Carolinas and report that efforts to develop a raccoon vaccine are proceeding. Are they going to wait until every raccoon in the East is dead before finding a vaccine?
I'll admit to a personal interest, because my wife and I enjoy our Candlewood Isle raccoons. They visit us on our deck to take food out of our hands with their mouths. (Yes, we know feeding wild animals is discouraged, but these aren't wolves that will lose their hunting ability. Raccoons won't forget how to scavenge any more than the birds we feed sunflower seeds forget how to find wild seed.) Never once has one of these gentle and entertaining animals so much as scratched us. The current kits (raised in our chimney) even let us pet them.
We had hoped to protect them. We planned to trap them one at a time and take them to be inoculated. Our local vet, an animal lover, was sympathetic, but since the dog and cat vaccine had not been tested on raccoons, he could not legally inoculate ours. We tried to obtain the vaccine the French used to protect their foxes, but it cannot be brought into this country. We're about ready to round up the three babies and keep them inside until this passes.
As a people, we've put tremendous energy into saving such esoteric species as snail darters and spotted owls, at a cost of millions spent and economic opportunity lost, protecting animals only a handful of people will ever see. But we can't muster any effort to help the animals who share our backyards.
 
RALPH C. AIKMAN
New Fairfield, Conn., Aug. 16, 1991

HEADLINE: The Nation;
Light at the End of the Elevator Shaft

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL

 BODY:
WANT to rent an office cheap? How about 10 offices -- or 10,000? From downtown Los Angeles to the suburbs of Boston, buildings sit half filled, monuments of an era in which commercial lenders traded their green eye shades for tinted aviators and the word thrift took on a whole new meaning.
"This cycle is the worst since the 1930's," said Anthony Downs, a specialist in real estate economics at the Brookings Institution. Some analysts now worry that what The Economist called "growth's dead weight" will dog the economy for a decade, helping to stretch the recession deep into the 1990's. 
 But this water glass could prove half full. While everyone agrees that tens of billions of dollars were wasted on see-through office buildings in the 1980's, many economists believe that the commercial real estate crisis is, at most, a precipitating factor in the overdue downsizing of the bloated construction, development and financial services industries.
And while the agony of banks, life insurers and their regulators will take years to play out, it need not slow economic growth or inhibit future gains in productivity.
Real estate in general and office buildings in particular have always ridden a roller coaster; the last cycle bottomed in the mid-1970's with overall office vacancy rates of 13 percent. But this downturn has been especially severe, and seems built to last.
In most big city and suburban markets, one of five square feet of office space is empty. David Shulman, a real estate analyst for Salomon Brothers, notes that the figures do not include a lot of underutilized space leased in the 1980's in anticipation of business expansions that never took place. Were a moratorium placed on all new office construction, he reckons that it would take 11 years to absorb the backlog.
Average rents in central business districts, where markets are most clogged, have fallen by half in real terms since the last peak in 1982. In many cases, projected revenues will not come close to covering mortgage payments. In some, they will not even cover operating expenses and taxes.
What happened? The manic growth of savings and loans in the early 1980's played a part, particularly in Texas. New rules liberated the thrifts to expand their investments beyond boring old home mortgages, while Federal deposit insurance allowed them to tap the vast pool of personal savings with no questions asked. Construction deals -- even patently bad deals -- were irresistible because loans were larded with fat fees, paid in advance. And financial regulators accustomed to dealing with lenders more interested in their golf handicaps than their balance sheets proved utterly incapable of keeping the razzle-dazzle in check.
But the super-boom in office construction would not have been possible without the support of more experienced, more conservative lenders. Banks, unable to hang onto blue-chip corporate customers who had discovered ways of borrowing directly from money markets, tried to recoup their losses by plunging into commercial real estate. The 100 heaviest bank lenders have over $120 billion tied up in commercial mortgages.
Life insurers had their own reasons for taking more and bigger risks. Eager to shed their image as the Ozzies and Harriets of high finance, they aggressively marketed new products ranging from annuities to guaranteed investment contracts for retirement accounts. Success left them with more money than they could profitably place in low-risk securities -- and much of the surplus ended up in office buildings. During the 1980's the amount life insurers invested in commercial real estate rose to $250 billion from $100 billion.
Many developers ignored signs of sagging demand in the late 1980's because they could afford to. Unlike in the past, lenders were often willing to put up 100 percent of construction costs without a single signed lease in hand. Mr. Shulman notes, moreover, that when revenues failed to meet expectations, owners no longer had a tax crutch to support property values: The 1986 Tax Reform Act effectively eliminated the market for commercial real estate as an income shelter for the rich.
A compilation by Barron's magazine of giant banks with problem real estate loans in excess of half their net worth reads like a Who's Who of American finance: Citicorp, Security Pacific, Chemical, Chase Manhattan, Bankers Trust. Many lenders, it seems, dove into real estate just as they got their heads above water on third world debts.
Investments in commercial real estate represent about a quarter of the life insurance industry's total assets of $1 trillion. Real property losses have already forced the closure of one multibillion-dollar insurer, Mutual Benefit Life.
All this is obviously bad news for developers, banks and life insurance policy holders -- and just about everyone else who works or invests in commercial real estate. It also bodes ill for taxpayers, who backstop the Federal bank deposit insurance system. Mr. Downs of Brookings said he worries that the pressure on banks to reduce further exposure to risk will make it difficult for otherwise creditworthy businesses to raise money.
But Lawrence White, an economist at New York University's Stern School of Business, cautions against exaggerating the social cost of the crisis. From the perspective of the economy as a whole, he said, the only irretrievable loss from the real estate bust is the steel, concrete and labor wasted on unwanted buildings. "It's as if we had built a bunch of pyramids," he said, and thus had less to invest in bridges, factories and high-tech research.
The cost, a reduction in the average productivity of America's capital, is not trivial. But Mr. White argues that this toll should be distinguished from the transient trauma of streamlining the industries that grew flabby on commercial real estate. Banks are expected to shed thousands of branches and hundreds of thousands of employees over the next few years as they merge and consolidate operations. Life insurers will follow suit, albeit in less spectacular fashion.
 
Temporary Grief
 The changes will cause a lot of grief for the people consigned to the unemployment lines, Mr. White acknowledged. But the grief will almost certainly be temporary, as workers are absorbed elsewhere. And the economy will be left with a financial services industry that is leaner and more efficient -- and, perhaps, less prone to lemming-like rushes into risky businesses.
Construction will be slammed equally hard. And Mr. Shulman suggests that the part of the industry specializing in office buildings may never come back to mid-1980's strength because businesses are discovering ways to expand without increasing white-collar payrolls. But the $20 billion office construction industry just isn't big enough to block the recovery of the $6 trillion American economy. Indeed, the overhang of unrented space should aid the recovery a bit by dampening inflation, much as the oil glut did in the 1980-82 recession.
The boom and bust in commercial real estate reveals the worst about capitalism, American style. Markets failed to channel valuable resources to their most productive uses. Regulation, which was supposed to be part of the solution, became part of the problem. People who would never dream of gambling with their savings will bear a good chunk of the multibillion dollar loss.
But the story also offers hints of the system's resiliency: The capitalist phoenix is rising from the ashes, as it has countless times before.

CORRECTION-DATE: September 22, 1991, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Sept. 8 about the effects of the commercial real estate glut on the economy included an erroneous generalization about loans causing problems for five large banks. Problem loans of all types exceed half the adjusted net worth of each bank -- Citicorp, Security Pacific, Chemical, Chase Manhattan and Bankers Trust -- but the proportion of such loans committed to real estate varies widely among them.

HEADLINE: FOCUS: Chicago;
A Housing Surge Gives Tenants the Edge

BYLINE: By CHERYL KENT

DATELINE: CHICAGO

 BODY:
WITH the addition of nearly 4,000 units in six new downtown rental apartment complexes in the last 18 months, tenants are now dictating the terms here.
Competition is forcing leasing agents to offer a variety of inducements, from free health-club memberships to months of free rent and guarantees of limited increases at renewal time. 
 The new apartment buildings are all within the orbit of Cityfront Center, a 52-acre mixed-use development that has opened an area at the juncture of the Chicago River and Lake Michigan to residential and commercial development, and two are within Cityfront's boundaries. Concessions are being offered at all but one of the buildings.
The Chicago situation is unusual from a national standpoint.
Few cities have developed as much new downtown housing in the last 15 years. A total of 18,900 units were built between 1979 and 1991, according to Chicago's Department of Planning. Absorption has been high until recently, say industry experts.
But the latest crop of towers suggests the city's appetite may have been sated. The six apartment buildings were built without subsidies or tax write-offs and thus face hurdles to profitability. And all aim for the same target, forcing them to compete against one another for a share of the market.
The management of each buildings describes its tenants as young professionals and "empty nesters."
Among the projects is Cityfront Place on North McClurg Court, a complex with one 39-story building and two 12 stories tall with a total of 906 units.
Two of the three buildings have opened within the last four months. So far, they are less than 50 percent occupied.
The second is North Pier Tower, a 61-story, 529-unit building completed in January at 474 North Lake Shore Drive. It is 55 percent occupied.
When it was devoted to shipping, Cityfront's land was covered with rail lines and warehouses. The property is now prized for its proximity to the lakefront and the downtown business and retail districts, features that developers say will help to attract professionals in their 30's with incomes of $60,000 or more.
Construction of Cityfront, whose site is owned by Chicago Dock and Canal Company and Equitable Real Estate, was begun in 1986. In addition to the three apartment houses, a 40-story, 850,000-square-foot offfice tower and a 7-story, 451,000-square-foot office-retail building have been completed and a 1,125-room convention hotel is now going up.
Irving Markin of the Markin Group said his decision to build a 41-story apartment tower at 420 East Ohio Street had a great deal to do with Cityfront's beingjust two blocks from his site. His tower, completed 10 months ago, has 263 units ranging from studios to three-bedroom apartments.
Mr. Markin, who said his tower is 55 percent occupied, is not offering special incentives. He declined to give a range of rentals, but a leasing agent said one-bedrooms range from $1,020 to $1,100.
THE sudden addition of so many units within a mile of Cityfront has attracted bargain hunters. Newspaper ads spelling out rates and offering "August Rental Specials" have led prospective tenants to think haggling will be rewarded. They are right. Donna Morgan, leasing director for one of the new buildings described the spiralling effect of concessions.
"They make the market tough," she said. "People walk in here with their hands out. I don't want to offer incentives but I have to."
The significant reductions tenants have won mean these apartment buildings are producing less revenue than expected when they were conceived. Most of the buildings were planned at least three years ago when the prime lending rate went from 8.5 percent in February to 10.5 percent in November 1988. Under the dual pressures of operating costs and financing charges, developers are working hard to bring in what cash they can by filling the apartments they have built.
Many leasing agents said they are giving one month rent-free on 13-month leases and two months on 26-month leases. But it is easy for prospective tenants to get substantially better offers by calling a leasing office.
The Park Shore, a 56-story high rise at 195 North Harbor Drive that opened nine months ago, is offering two months' free rent on a 14-month lease for a one-bedroom apartment costing $990. The building has 1,382 units and is 20 percent leased. North Pier Tower is giving free cable television and two free months for an 18-month lease on a one-bedroom renting for $1,052.
At the 49-story, 406-unit 401 East Ontario Street apartment house, new tenants are offered a half-month's free rent. One-bedrooms there rent for $1,000 to $1,407.
Four months' rent on a 26-month lease for a one-bedroom renting for $728-850 is available at Cityfront Place.
The 37-story, 221-unit Chicagoan has been open 18 months, making it the oldest of the new apartment buildings. It is 85 percent leased. The first renewals are coming and the leasing manager says 90 percent have signed again. Murray Wolbach, a vice president of Draper and Kramer, a partner in the Chicagoan, says he is offering the standard one free month on a 13-month lease.
DRAPER AND KRAMER may feel less pressure partly because there is no mortgage on the Chicagoan. "With the new tax laws in effect you can't leverage by offsetting losses in real estate with gains elsewhere," Mr. Wolbach said. "You can only offset losses in real estate with gains in real estate. I didn't want a mortgage on this building."
The Chicagoan was developed in conjunction with the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers pension fund.
The $70 million North Pier Tower is owned by Broadacre Development Company and the General Electric Master Retirement Trust. The 420 East Ohio Street building is a joint venture of the Markin Group and an unidentified pension fund. Others would not discuss the financing of their projects.
With many lease packages guaranteeing renewals will not rise more than 3 to 7 percent within one year, rents are likely to remain a bargain in this part of the city for at least a year. Even so, rents in these new buildings are, on average, substantially higher than in other parts of the city. In Lincoln Park, a favored neighborhood for young professionals, one-bedroom apartments in the walk-ups most characteristic of the area rent for $550 to $800. High-rise rents average $900 a month.
Building managers and leasing agents for older apartment buildings around Cityfront Center say their tenants are moving out. To combat this, managers in older buildings -- the 10-year-old Doral Plaza and the 19-year-old McClurg Court, an apartment building as well as a street -- are offering concessions, too.
At McClurg Court, new tenants are given 8 or 12 rent certificates, depending on the size of the unit they have taken. Each is worth $100 and can be used towards rent in any combination the tenant chooses. All of them can be used at once to pay for one month or they can be spread over the year.
Young professionals in their 30's or middle-aged couples with adult children are consistently described as the target tenants for the new buildings. Income levels, according to these profiles, start at $60,000. Several building managers say that roughly 30 percent of the tenants who have moved in are new to Chicago. One-third are single men and another third are single women.

HEADLINE: Colleges Aim Courses at Older Students

BYLINE: By PENNY SINGER

 BODY:
SCHOOL BELLS start ringing this week for 12 million students older than 25 returning to school, and thereby helping themselves and their colleges.
College enrollments for traditionally aged students have fallen. Last year, the number of 18-year-olds entering college fell 44 percent compared with those entering college in 1979. So colleges have been forced to seek other sources of students, particularly older ones, said Joseph Cullen, director of public relations at Iona College in New Rochelle. 
 At Iona, executive-education programs have been created for adults seeking to do better work at their jobs or hoping to make career changes, Mr. Cullen said. "In many instances, a good part of their tuition fees are paid by the companies they work for."
And this year, enrollment in one such program, the Certified Employee Benefit Specialist program for trustees, administrators, actuaries, corporate benefit and union benefit managers, is high, said Teresa R. Gallo, the coordinator of Iona's School of General Studies.
"We feel it's because benefits have become so complicated and so expensive that those who administer corporate-benefit plans have to have a very specific knowledge of their structure today," she said. "The course, which is sponsored by the International Foundation of Employee Benefit Plans and the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania, also gives students the opportunity to earn professional accreditation."
For adults re-entering the job market or making a career change, Ms. Gallo said, Iona offers certificate programs in legal assistance, word processing, travel and tourism and fund-raising. "And our School of General Studies also offers baccalaureate programs in the evening and on weekends for those who want to earn a degree," she said.
Adults who have earned at least 60 semester academic hours and who have at least five years of practical work experience can now enroll in a new accelerated-degree program at Concordia College in Bronxville, said Lois Mills Chianese, assistant professor of business administration and co-director of the accelerated-degree program.
"The program is the first of its kind in Westchester specifically designed for the working adult," Ms. Chianese said. "By attending school one night a week and one Saturday a month, adult students can finish a New York State-accredited bachelor of science program in business administration in as little as a year." The accelerated-degree program has been available at four affiliated Concordia Colleges nationwide, which have reported having great success with it, Ms. Chianese added.
 
Global Perspective Stressed
 "A lot of people left college without getting a degree, and at some time or another in their career feel that the lack of a degree is a handicap toward advancing in the workplace," said John W. Westerman, co-director of the Concordia program and an associate professor in business administration.
"And there are other people who, perhaps because of the recession, are realizing that a degree is essential if they are going to compete successfully in jobs in this tight economic climate," he added.
The Concordia program was developed to provide each student with a well-rounded, global perspective of the business world, Mr. Westeman added. He said 50 percent of the corporations in the area have offered tuition reimbursement to employees enrolling in the program.
Mr. Westerman, who recently met with some potential students from the human resources department at the Philip Morris Corporation in Rye Brook, said they liked the program's structure.
"We have made it very convenient for adults," he said. "We're holding the program on our campus in Bronxville over the span of 12 months, with class meetings held once a week in four-hour blocks of time. It also includes 10 mandatory Saturday seminars."
The curriculum of the Concordia program is based on the work of the traditional junior and senior years of business majors, Ms. Chianese said. "Students will earn 42 semester hours toward a bachelor of science degree in business administration." The degree requires a total of 122 hours.
 
Tuition Is All Inclusive
 The cost of the accelerated executive education degree program has been set at $9,000 and includes tuition, lab fees, books and parking for the entire year. "We have structured it so there are no hidden costs," Mr. Westerman said. "Even lunches at the 10 Saturday seminars and evening snacks are included. All textbooks for each course will be available the first night of each class, because we don't think adult students should have to make special trips to the college book store in the middle of a workday."
In White Plains, the new Mercy College weekend program, also designed for working adults, will begin Friday.
Dr. John J. McGrath, dean of the White Plains campus, said: "We've been working on the program for a year, and after a year of market research plus our own experience of nontraditional student populations, we think we've designed a sensible program for those whose work schedules or personal commitments make it impossible for them to enroll in a traditional program. We've taken adult life styles into consideration.
"For instance, every third weekend is off for professional or family obligations. And our location in downtown White Plains makes the school convenient for a lot of students. Our enrollments are running well, just about as we predicted."
 
Credit for Experience
 Tuition for the Mercy weekend program, Dean McGrath said, has been reduced to $185 a credit from Mercy's $276 a credit. "This gives our weekend program the lowest tuition for any bachelor's degree program within any independent college in Westchester," he said.
Students in the weekend program can take one to five classes each semester to help them earn a bachelor's degree in accounting or business administration with a specialization in management or office information systems in about four years, said Dean McGrath, who added that under Mercy's life-experience credit program, students may also be given college credit for work experience.
At Manhattanville College in Purchase, Rae Fischetti, assistant dean of adult special programs, said adult students are often turning toward liberal arts studies.
"This fall semester in our registrations, we are seeing out-of-work men and women who can afford it coming back to college to retrain," Ms. Fischetti said. "There are others who are looking for intellectual stimulation and are taking courses in the humanities, literature, philosophy and psychology."
 
Employers Give Aid
 And many adult students enrolled in liberal arts master's degree programs are there with some financial support from their employers, she added.
"We find that corporations are giving employees tuition reimbursement for courses that develop critical-thinking skills and writing skills," she said.
Thomas N. Schappert, an International Business Machines human resources executive, has taken courses in the humanities one night a week at Manhattanville for three years. Mr. Schappert, who said he majored in business as an undergraduate and later received a master's degree in business administration, said he wanted to earn a master's degree in humanities through the Manhattanville adult program.
"I am back in college because I want to be there," he said, "I'm 48 years old, and I felt it was about time I rounded out my background. There are so many things I wanted to learn more about. The three hours I spend in class one night a week have opened my eyes to other worlds. And I think that's what learning's all about."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Lois Mills Chianese, top at left, and John W. Westerman, above, co-directors of the accelerated-degree program at Concordia College, with prospective students. (Photographs by Suzanne DeChillo for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: THE VIEW FROM: ESSEX;
As Banking Failures Increase, A New Bank Opens Its Doors

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON

 BODY:
A RECORD number of banks in Connecticut are going broke, but a new one has opened in the town of Essex, which already had almost one bank for every 1,000 residents. Maritime Bank and Trust Company, the first new bank in the state in more than a year, opened its single office on Route 153 in the lower Connecticut River Valley town.
"We started this project three years ago and quickly found out that timing is everything," said the chairman of the bank, Richard R. Manning, who also heads City Coal Inc., in nearby New London. "We'll probably be the only bank to start up for a long time." 
 Plans for at least two other eastern Connecticut banks in Windham and Canterbury, which were organizing at the same time as Maritime, have been abandoned. And Maritime's president, William R. Attridge, said there were some nerve-wracking moments over the last couple of years for his bank as well.
 
Good Mixture of Accounts
 "There was somewhat of a risk involved," Mr. Attridge said. "When I joined them, they were still raising money, and it was not a good environment to be trying to raise money for a bank."
But Maritime raised $4.6 million from 300 stockholders as seed money, and the bank said it has been steadily attracting $600,000 to $700,000 a week in new deposits since its May opening. In one week in July Maritime brought in $1.2 million in deposits, bank officials said, and the mixture has been good, with a higher percentage in checking and savings accounts than expected.
"If all your money is in certificates of deposit, that money can disappear tomorrow, if the bank across the street offers a higher rate," Mr. Attridge said. "If it's in checking and savings accounts, it implies the money is there to stay for a while."
In Mr. Attridge's case, "the bank across the street," is not merely a figure of speech. Across the street is the former Chester Bank, now taken over by Connecticut National Bank. But having such a close competitor does not seem to have harmed Maritime. "We expected an initial rush of deposits from directors and their friends," Mr. Attridge said. "What we didn't expect was how consistently the influx of deposits has continued. It really hasn't trailed off."
Banks in Connecticut lost a total of $649 million in 1990, which was worse than 1989, when $505 million was lost. But Dr. Lewis Mandell, a professor of finance at the University of Connecticut, said the market is ripe for banks like Maritime.
 
'Only Time to Start a Bank'
 He recalled his efforts to help a group that was starting the first minority-owned bank in Texas in the 1970's, just before the banking collapse there. When he went back to Texas several years later, he called the lawyer for the group to apologize for such poor timing, he said.
"He said the bank was fine, that they opened just as real estate prices collapsed, and every loan they had on the books was made after the collapse, so they had no bad real estate loans," Dr. Mandell said. "That made me realize the only time to start a bank is when things are at their worst."
But it is also the time when people are least likely to invest in a new bank, he acknowledged, and when regulators are scrutinizing new charters.
"You need to put in a lot of capital now," Dr. Mandell said. He noted, however, that investors would be scrutinized closely, and that if any of a bank's organizers "even spit on a public sidewalk in their youth, the F.B.I. is going to knock them out of the roster."
Mr. Attridge said the poor economy hurt Maritime a little when it was raising capital. The planned stock offering of $5.1 million had to be scaled back to $4.6 million, he said, and the investors do not expect to double their money soon. The sole stock transaction since the bank opened was at $10 a share, the price the shares brought during the public offering.
"People who bought stock in this bank didn't buy it for the quick flip," Mr. Attridge said. "They knew they were getting in for the long haul."
With parking in the rear and a decidedly residential facade, the bank looks more like an elegantly restored sea captain's home than a commercial establishment. Inside the front door a plate of cookies and pitcher of lemonade greet visitors, and in the waiting area, a cherry-wood coffee table holds banking and finance journals along with the local Main Street News.
 
Profit in Second Year Seen
 The interior is done in white and forest green, with brass lighting fixtures and plush carpeting. Customers exchange pleasantries with the tellers, who often find no need to check their identification. Maritime has gone out of its way to make people comfortable, Mr. Attridge said.
He said that if the bank's goals are reached, it will be the second year before it turns a profit, and perhaps two years or more before it reaches the $40 million in deposits it would need to make a second stock offering.
"It's not appropriate, 10 weeks out of the box, to be talking about where your next branch will be or potential mergers and acquisitions," Mr. Attridge said. "But we are looking around."
The bank's 11 directors include people in the oil business, accounting, computers, restaurants, finance, and retail, and none draw a salary, Mr. Manning said. Among them they own more than 50 percent of the stock.
Mr. Manning said with no bad loans on the books, and with $600,000 or more coming in every week in new deposits, Maritime should be able to avoid the pitfalls that have claimed so many other banks.
"Obviously, if we're bringing in that kind of money, people are saying there's a need for community banks, and community bankers," Mr. Manning said. "We've been inundated with new business, particularly from medical professionals, because a lot of people are concerned about other banks."
The people at Maritime "really did their homework," said the executive director of the Middlesex County Chamber of Commerce, Lawrence D. McHugh. "I think they're going to do very well, because they're filling a void." Middlesex County, while it has been affected by the recession, has still seen some expansion, Mr. McHugh said. His organization is taking in an average of 15 members a month, with only 6 or 7 dropping out.
 
A Positive Message
 In Essex, he said, several businesses have expanded, and the bank's opening will send a positive message to businesses looking to relocate.
"The older banks have no money to give out," Mr. McHugh said. "Maritime is going to pick up business, because they're new, and they can write loans without regulators climbing up and down on them."
John A. Johns, the First Selectman of Essex, said he is not surprised Maritime's directors chose the town.
"At the time they started the bank, construction was doing well, particularly the construction of costly new houses, which I'm sure would be attractive to any bank," Mr. Johns said. "And our tax structure is attractive, the third lowest taxes of the 169 towns in Connecticut."
Mr. Johns said it might seem that Essex had too many banks. The town, with 5,800 residents, is home to the Essex Savings Bank and has branches of four regional banks.
"But for myself, if I were seeking a mortgage, I'd want to go to a place where I know the people I'm dealing with, and where I know the stockholders," Mr. Johns said.

GRAPHIC: Photos: William R. Attridge, president of Maritime Bank and Trust Company in Essex, the state's first new bank in more than a year, with Kathleen Bauer, a teller. (Photographs by Gale Zucker for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: What Went Wrong With the S.&L.'s

BYLINE: By Lawrence S. Ritter; Lawrence S. Ritter is the John M. Schiff Professor of Finance Emeritus at New York University.

 BODY:

HIGH ROLLERS
Inside the Savings and Loan Debacle.
By Martin Lowy.
321 pp. New York.:
Praeger. $24.95.  
 Among the general public, the savings and loan mess arouses at least as much puzzlement as anger, probably because most people aren't sure exactly what happened and are even less sure who is to blame. In "High Rollers," Martin Lowy, a banker and lawyer with 25 years' experience in finance, chronicles the savings and loan calamity and comes up with reasonable explanations that shed light on many aspects of the most expensive financial disaster in American history.
Unhappily for those who want a scapegoat, the thrust of Mr. Lowy's analysis is that no single person, institution or incident is wholly or even largely responsible for the shocking disintegration of what only a short while ago was an apparently thriving industry. "The real causes," he writes, "were and are far more fundamental and far more frightening. This wasn't a bank robbery; it was a fundamental economic failure of a substantial part of our financial system, and the same forces are threatening other parts of the system today."
Mr. Lowy traces the roots of the savings and loan collapse to the double-digit interest rates that erupted in the late 1970's in the wake of double-digit inflation. Savings and loan associations suffered severe losses because most of their income was derived from long-term fixed-rate mortgages acquired when interest rates were much lower, whereas they had to pay out high interest rates to prevent depositors from withdrawing funds in search of better yields elsewhere.
Infatuated with the then-popular siren song of deregulation, Congress responded, as Mr. Lowy recounts, with a rescue operation that abolished many of the rules under which savings and loans had traditionally functioned. They were authorized to offer new kinds of deposits and given enhanced power to make loans. In addition, several states relaxed restrictions on direct investments and permitted state-chartered savings institutions, including savings and loans, to invest in real estate developments and other business ventures.
In the end, Mr. Lowy explains, these measures only made matters worse. Many oil and real estate loans and investments turned sour in the 1980's, when the price of oil nose-dived and regional oil-producing economies encountered hard times. Other risky investments, like junk bonds, went up in smoke. The problem was further compounded by widespread fraud, embezzlement and mismanagement on the part of high-flying savings and loan officials. As a result, hundreds of savings and loan associations became insolvent: their liabilities, mostly deposits, exceeded the market value of their assets, so that their net worth became negative.
Holding the bag was the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation, the governmental agency responsible for reimbursing insured depositors or failed institutions. When its well ran dry -- which, Mr. Lowy notes, didn't take long -- it was the taxpayers' turn to foot the bill. The cost to the general public will eventually amount to some $400 billion, half of which is bailout money and half interest payable by the United States Treasury because the necessary funds are being raised not by tax collections but by borrowing through the sales of Government bonds.
Because managing large sums of money invariably breeds temptation, examination and supervision of financial institutions by honest and independent government regulators has always been an indispensable ingredient of a sound financial system. However, as Mr. Lowy says, all regulation was viewed as superfluous in the naive fervor that sparked the initial wave of deregulation. On the basis of the simplistic premise that government can never solve social, economic or financial problems, but can only make them worse, the examination and supervision of financial institutions was disparaged, ignored, impeded and obstructed.
Since vested political and ideological interests are at stake in the savings and loan debacle, the story usually differs depending on who is doing the telling. Republicans like to blame former President Jimmy Carter for the inflation that caused the high interest rates that got the savings and loan associations into trouble in the first place. Democrats blame former President Ronald Reagan for spreading the gospel that deregulation plus free markets will cure all our economic ills. Some blame the Federal deposit insurance system, because insurance premiums paid to the Government by financial institutions are not adjusted for the riskiness of their portfolios. And just about everybody -- except Mr. Lowy -- blames the former House Speaker Jim Wright; Charles H. Keating Jr., the former head of Lincoln Savings and Loan; and the United States senators known collectively as the Keating Five -- Alan Cranston, Dennis DeConcini, John Glenn, John McCain and Donald W. Riegle -- for insinuating themselves where they didn't belong and undermining the integrity of the supervisory process.
"High Rollers" tends to overemphasize the trees at the expense of the forest. A good editor would have cut about 20 percent. But such criticism borders on nitpicking. In fact it is hard to find a clear, knowledgeable and impartial analysis of the savings and loan mess, and Martin Lowy has done us all a favor by providing just that.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Review
