HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
As Publishers Cut Costs, Book Packagers Thrive

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN

 BODY:
Book packagers have traditionally had an image problem. Their role has been dimly seen as having something to do with mail rooms and wrapping works of literature.
"We have labored under our tawdry and non-literary name," said Carter Smith, the president of Media Projects Inc., a New York packager. 
 Other names have been considered as a way out of this problem: book producer, book developer, even "booklisher." But none have stuck.
Now, after years of relative anonymity, this unglamorous niche in the publishing industry has been rescued by the economy.
 
Surrogates for Publishers
 Packagers are thriving. While publishers struggle, squeezed by sagging sales and soaring advances to writers, packagers are finding their services in increasing demand. They act as surrogates for publishers -- conceiving, writing, editing, illustrating, indexing and even sometimes manufacturing books. Because they have small staffs and low overheads, they are able to work more cheaply than conventional publishers.
As a result, publishers are turning to them to produce books on everything from women's health to American history. By commissioning books from packagers, whose role is generally only discreetly mentioned on the book itself, publishers save on their own staff's time and the costs of their overhead.
For example, Prentice Hall's successful "Best Vacation Rentals" guides are in fact written, illustrated and manufactured by the Philip Lief Group, a packager.
"Our problem is no longer selling our ideas to publishers; it is keeping up with their demands on us," said Mr. Lief, the company's president. "We used to have to originate all projects, but most are now initiated by publishing houses."
 
Soaring Revenue
 Among Lief's recent projects are a new thesaurus to be published by Dell, an encyclopedic guide to gardening for Macmillan and a complete guide to bartending for Berkley Books. The company's gross revenue has soared by 30 percent, to well in excess of $1 million in the last year, and its profit margin is more than 10 percent, Mr. Lief said.
Mr. Smith of Media Projects said that his company's revenue had risen 20 percent in the last year and that "business has never been better."
"We have lower overheads than publishers, we hustle, and we're ready to do anything," he said. "In hard times, we thrive."
Packagers like to compare themselves to independent film producers. Less cumbersome than big houses, just as the independents are more flexible than the big movie studios, packagers will provide publishers with anything they need: an idea, writers, editors, manuscripts that are ready for production and even finished books to which the publisher merely adds its name.
Indeed, the packager effectively removes from the publisher the responsibility for much or all of the time-consuming and costly editorial work that goes into a book, allowing the publisher to be just a distributor.
 
'They Need Us'
 "Publishers are trying to do more books with less overhead, so they need us," said Stephen R. Ettlinger, president of Ettlinger Editorial Projects and of the American Book Producers Association, a trade group for packagers. The group has grown to 63 members from 50 last year. In all, there are an estimated 160 packagers, compared with 10 in 1980.
The total volume of the packagers is not known because most companies are private. But analysts believe that perhaps 15 percent of all books are produced by them.
The most recent project for Mr. Ettlinger is "Everything Sold in Garden Centers," published by Macmillan. And he is working for Addison-Wesley on a book about how to dispose of garbage. His company's staff consists of himself and an assistant, and he hires freelance help as needed. This is typical of the means by which packagers keep costs down.
 
Avoiding 'an Enormous Strain'
 The advantages of a packager to a publisher are illustrated by Roget's New American Thesaurus, currently being produced for Dell by Lief. Leslie Schnur, the editorial director of Dell, said such a book would "have put an enormous strain on us, and it's much easier to get a good independent packager to do it."
Lief contracted with Dell to produce the work, found a lexicographer, Barbara Ann Kipfer, to compile it, and will provide the book to Dell for publication next summer.
"Publishers are simply overwhelmed with all the books they are acquiring and editing," Ms. Schnur said, "so this sort of arrangement makes sense."

GRAPHIC: Photo: With their low production costs, book packagers like Philip Lief are seeing an increasing demand from publishers for their services. (Nancy Siesel for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
11.6% Decline Is Expected For Corporate Campaigns

BYLINE: By STUART ELLIOTT

 BODY:
CONFIRMING the belief that corporate advertising has fallen victim to the recession, an annual survey of members of the Association of National Advertisers has found that budgets this year are expected to drop 11.6 percent from 1990. The consultant who conducted the survey says the decline is the largest since he began tracking spending on such campaigns during the 1975 recession.
Executives participating in the survey, which is known as the association's corporate advertising practices study, reported that they intended to spend $404.4 million this year, compared with $457.4 million last year. Another sign of the spending slowdown was a finding that only 52.8 percent of the respondents sponsored corporate ad campaigns within the last three years, compared with 62.8 percent who did so from 1988 through 1990 and 70.4 percent who did so from 1987 through 1989. 
 The study is scheduled to be released by the association at its annual corporate communications conference, to be held Wednesday through Friday in Atlanta. Thomas F. Garbett, the consultant who conducted the survey, offered an advance look at the results during a telephone interview from his office in Waterford, Conn.
These days, "corporate advertising is almost an afterthought," said Mr. Garbett, who has served as a consultant in the field since 1984, after 23 years at the Doyle Dane Bernbach agency (now DDB Needham Worldwide) in New York. Increasingly, he added, the executives responsible for corporate advertising "are having a hard time selling their budgets" to financially hard-pressed top management.
The survey considers corporate advertising as embracing all sponsored messages meant "not to result in an immediate sale," Mr. Garbett said, "but to position a company for better sales." That includes campaigns usually referred to as image advertising, he added, as well as so-called issue or advocacy advertising, which discusses or takes stands on social and political topics, and what is known as financial or investor advertising, which addresses the investment community, from brokerage firms to shareholders.
The survey indicates that the effect of the recession, which began in July of last year, has intensified as tough economic times have continued; the expected 11.6 percent drop in spending from 1990 to 1991 compares with a drop of six-tenths of 1 percent from 1989 to 1990. Spending in 1989 totaled $460 million.
Another trend affecting corporate ad budgets, Mr. Garbett said, is a trend that he playfully termed "Nimbo," for "Not in my budget, out!" He described it as a tug-of-war between the executives at the head of a large company with many subsidiaries and the executives in charge of those subsidiaries. Each side insists that the other commit its increasingly scarce dollars, he added, to any advertising "that has to do with enhancing the corporate reputation."
Apart from an end to the recession, one factor that might aid a turnaround in corporate ad spending, Mr. Garbett said, is that "foreign companies are stepping up their activities a great deal" in the United States. That is partly a result of their perceived need "to develop reputations in this country," he said,
In addition, Mr. Garbett said, companies based overseas, particularly in Japan, generally place a higher value on burnishing a corporate image than do domestically based companies.
The association has been surveying its members on their corporate advertising plans since 1975; the survey became an annual undertaking six years ago. Members of the association, which was founded in 1910, account for almost 80 percent of all regional and national ad spending in the United States.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Need Is Seen for the Fed To Consider Consumers

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Private economists say that now that the Federal Reserve has engineered a turnaround in the manufacturing sector, it should devote its energies and attention to consumers.
Unless relief comes soon and demand picks up, the production gains recorded so far in the third quarter could taper off in the final three months of the year and into 1992, they say. 
 The Fed has no direct link to consumers, whose spending constitutes two-thirds of the country's economic activity. But at this juncture, lowering the interest rates that the Fed does control would in all likelihood prompt banks and other lenders to cut their prime lending rate, and cause mortgage rates to decline.
 
Restoring Consumer Confidence
 "One of the problems the economy faces is a consumer sector that is not feeling very good about itself," said Steven A. Wood, director of financial markets research at the Bank of America. "One way to help restore that confidence is to get rates that consumers identify with, like the prime and mortgage rates, lower. If the Fed can do something to get those rates down it would help."
Analysts are concerned about the consumer because recent data indicate that the pickup in manufacturing activity over the last few months is little more than a restocking of inventories.
Car sales remain at very low levels. Sales of new and existing homes appear to be slowing again. And, as leading chain stores reported last week, back-to-school shoppers were in short supply in August.
"The conventional wisdom is that if back-to-school shopping is bad, then Christmas will be bad," said Sandra Shaber, a vice president and economist at the Futures Group Inc. in Washington. "I am not so sure that will happen, once we get some improvement in the job market," she said. "But retailers are going to be pulling their hair out."
 
Little Optimism Over Jobs Data
 The August employment report offered some basis for optimism, but not much.
Goods-producing businesses generated their first employment gains since May. But many service-sector companies, which account for three-quarters of all jobs, continued to cut back. More chilling: During the last two months the number of workers who gave up even looking for work rose by 750,000.
The results of a quarterly survey of more than 15,000 employers conducted by Manpower Inc., the supplier of temporary help, do not provide much basis for optimism in the near term.
In its current survey, to be released today, Manpower said that 21 percent of the employers polled said they planned to add to their work force in the fourth quarter, down from 22 percent in the third. Twelve percent said they planned to cut payrolls, compared with 10 percent in the third quarter.
 
Recovery 'Depends on Christmas'
 Seasonal factors are largely responsible for the lower hiring numbers, the Manpower survey said. Nevertheless, the survey notes that hiring projections in areas like services and public administration are at their lowest since the 1982-83 recession. Meanwhile, manufacturers reported they intended to raise hiring in the fourth quarter.
Nevertheless, "the recovery in manufacturing depends on Christmas," said Neal M. Soss, chief economist at the First Boston Corporation. "And a successful Christmas depends on domestic demand holding up. A cut in interest rates would make the continuance of demand more assured."
A cut in the prime rate, currently at 8.5 percent, would lead to lower rates on loans like prime-based home equity loans. But a lower prime would almost certainly have no effect on rates charged by credit card issuers. Despite the sharp declines in market interest rates during the last year, rates on credit card balances are currently at their highest levels in more than a decade.
 
No Rate Cuts Seen in Credit Cards
 As of Sept. 3, the national average for credit card interest rates stood at 18.94 percent, according to the Bank Rate Monitor, a newsletter that tracks bank interest rates.
In addition to the rate's being high, the interest paid on these cards is no longer tax deductible. But these two disincentives to running up credit card debt have not had much effect, said Robert Heady, the Bank Rate Monitor's editor.
"The convenience of the cards makes users insensitive to the high rates," he said.
 
Retail Sales Data Due This Week
 Evidence of the consumer's weakened state is likely to be visible in August retail sales data, which are expected to be released Friday.
Based on the poor chain store and auto sales reports, many analysts are projecting that retail sales, which rose by half of 1 percent in July, may have actually declined in August.
Based on recent statements by some Fed officials, the central bank still seems confident that the recovery is well in place.
On Thursday a Fed governor, John P. LaWare, said growth in the second half of the year should average 3 to 4 percent. The same day, Robert Parry, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco, forecast that the economy would expand at a 3 percent rate over the next 12 months.
 
Fed Forecasts Are Questioned
 A weak retail sales report, in conjunction with other recent reports showing that final demand is not building strength, may alter that view somewhat, analysts said, and prompt the Fed to engineer a further reduction in short-term interest rates.
"We find it difficult to see" the type of growth described by the Fed officials, said Maria Fiorini Ramirez, president of Ramirez Capital Consultants. "We still believe that growth will be positive in the second half, but only because inventories have stopped being pared.
"And if the consequent upturn in consumer spending doesn't occur," she added, "and we don't expect it to, then shouldn't there be inventory shedding in the beginning of 1992?"

HEADLINE: Regulatory Overhaul Advancing

BYLINE: STEPHEN LABATON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 8

 BODY:
Momentum is building rapidly in Congress and among Federal regulators to repudiate and rewrite many laws and economic regulations that were pillars of the New Deal of the 1930's.
The changes, advanced by the Bush Administration and moving quickly through Congress, which returns from its summer recess on Tuesday, represent a fundamental shift in the philosophy of regulation. Earlier in this century, rules were formulated to restrict the growth of financial powerhouses; the new view holds that conglomeration is better for the economy and helps the nation to compete internationally. 
 The House and Senate Banking Committees have already adopted important legislation to repeal Depression-era regulations that restrict the ability of banks to grow and enter new businesses, and other legislation making its way through Congress would overhaul laws restricting the growth of utilities.
 
Sweeping Changes Seen
 Already the Banking Committees have approved legislation that would eviscerate the Glass-Steagall Act, which broke up the House of Morgan by restricting commercial banks from underwriting corporate securities. The committees' swift approval of the legislation has been taken as a sign by many officials and lawmakers that Congress will adopt sweeping banking legislation this fall.
"We think it's very likely that there will be Glass-Steagall reform this year," Treasury Under Secretary Robert R. Glauber said. "The only question is whether it's good reform or bad reform," he added, referring to the Administration's preference for the Senate version, which would permit commercial banks to lend money to affiliated investment banks.
The final legislation is likely to constitute a refutation of the progressive populist movement that arose after the market crash of 1907. The movement, whose intellectual father was Louis D. Brandeis, sought to decentralize economic power through laws that established a central bank and ultimately broke up the House of Morgan, the leading trusts of the day, and the public utilities that dominated economic life. For more than a half century, those laws and regulations have framed the nation's financial system.
But now the Bush Administration, many lawmakers and the regulators themselves have concluded that these laws are outdated and that they inhibit the United States' ability to compete. The new philosophy, which is rapidly gaining widespread support, is that the Depression-era rules have lagged behind the realities of the marketplace, contributing to the crisis in the banking industry and hindering energy policy by restricting industrial companies from the power business.
"In the 1930's, we assumed that decentralization was the way to prevent mischief, and there was a basic mistrust of bigness, fueled by a period of populist upheaval," said Robert B. Reich, a professor of political economy at the John F. Kennedy School of Government at Harvard. "Now the world has changed fundamentally, through advances in technology and the globalization of the marketplace.
"As a result, the concerns of the 1930's are not on anyone's mind. Washington is acting as if the Great Crash and many of the excesses of the 1920's never existed."
 
Reasons for Change
 Lowell L. Bryan, head of the banking group at McKinsey & Company, the management consulting group, said the change reflects a shifting view from "the fear of bigness in the 1930's to the new fear that American institutions in the international sphere have become pygmies."
As a consequence, such cornerstones of the New Deal and its aftermath as the Glass-Steagall Act of 1933; the McFadden Act, which was amended in 1933; the Bank Holding Company Act of 1956, and the Public Utilities Holding Company Act of 1935, are coming under assault. Another product of the Depression, the Investment Company Act of 1940, which regulates the enormous mutual fund industry, is also in the process of undergoing a thorough re-examination by the Securities and Exchange Commission, although changes in that law are not likely to be as radical as those in the other laws.
At the same time, a movement has been gaining ground to overhaul the Public Utility Holding Company Act of 1935, a law that gives the Securities and Exchange Commission jurisdiction over certain kinds of conglomerates that generate power. The law has not only kept industrial companies out of the power business, but has also kept utilities out of the business of building generating plants outside their territories and selling the power on the open market.
In a letter this year to House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, Democrat of Washington, Energy Secretary James D. Watkins wrote that "regulatory structures that were appropriate in the 1930's are no longer appropriate" for public utilities.
 
Bank Fund Is Threatened
 Paradoxically, many of the same forces that led to the laws in the 1930's are contributing to their demise: a banking system in turmoil and securities markets plagued by scandal. By 1933, half of the $50 billion of securities sold in the nation during the prior 13 years were worthless. More than 5,000 banks failed from 1930 to 1932, resulting in depositor losses of almost $800 million, or more than $6 billion in 1990 dollars. Four thousand banks failed in 1933.
The fund that insures bank deposits is now at its lowest level since it was created in the Depression, and by many accounts it will be out of money by year's end. In the last few years, an annual average of about 200 banks have failed, a rate that is significantly higher than that of previous decades. Lawmakers and the Bush Administration are using the plight of the fund as the political vehicle for a trainload of changes that would tear down many barriers erected during the Depression.
"The new view stems from a deregulation ethic and a belief that it will cost the Government less if the industry is able to consolidate," said Representative Jim Leach, Republican of Iowa. "The banks have come in demanding legislative changes with the clout of weakness, rather than strength. They are coming plaintively, saying survival is at issue."
The emerging political forces for change also reflect a fundamental shift in the debate.
"There is a different focus in the debate in Washington now," Professor Reich said. "The major voices are those of the securities industry and the banks. The concerns of the consumers, the small investors and the depositors that had been essential to the New Deal have been brushed aside. We are not in a period of populist upsurge. Most of America is quiescent."
There is significant empirical data to suggest that the fragmentation of economic power has contributed to the crisis. A report to be released on Monday by the staff of the House Banking Committee has found that the bank insurance fund's precarious position is largely a result of the failure of small banks.
 
Fears of New Dangers
 The study said 99 percent of the 1,009 banks bailed out by the Government in the last six years were smaller than $1 billion in assets, resulting in net losses to the fund of more than $9.2 billion. By comparison, only 18 medium-sized and large banks failed, at a net loss to the fund of about $3.1 billion.
While the new view is likely to lead to significant new legislation over the coming weeks, some skeptics in Congress have raised concerns about its effect on the economy.
"The Administration is tying together the collapse of the banks, of which they are participants, with new powers that will lead to new losses," said Representative John D. Dingell, the Michigan Democrat who heads the Energy and Commerce Committee and is fighting to block many of the proposed changes. "It's the most ludicrious thing I've ever heard of."
He added, "I'm not going to attack my sister committees," referring to the action by the House and Senate Banking Committees. "But I am also not going to tell you that Congress always acts wisely."
Mr. Dingell's committee is expected to begin drafting an alternative bill this month that is less comprehensive than the House banking measure, but how the two will be reconciled remains to be played out.
Other members of Congress insist that while the legislation making its way through Congress does remove many of the Depression-era barriers, it also has adequate regulatory safeguards to prevent the catastrophic excesses of the 1920's.
"They have very careful safeguards and limitations," said Senator Donald W. Riegle Jr., the Michigan Democrat who is chairman of the Banking Committee, referring to the legislation's new capital standards and requirements that regulators intervene earlier when an institution shows signs of trouble. "The legislation is intended to allow consolidation to occur, but only when it makes sense."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
For Once, Thin Look Is Out at Fashion Magazines

BYLINE: By DEIRDRE CARMODY

 BODY:
As the recession hits home in the fiercely competitive world of fashion magazines, the buzzword is now "partnering."
"You become involved in your clients' business and become partners with them more so than ever before," said Julie Lewit-Nirenberg, publisher of Mirabella. "The attitude is very different now. It's no longer selling the page; it's selling the relationship and saying to them, 'What can we do for you?' " 
 Publishers of fashion magazines are helping department stores around the country to woo shoppers. Magazine fashion directors are flying to San Francisco, Cleveland, Dallas and Boston to assist with store promotions and conduct fashion shows. The hope is, of course, that bonds formed with advertisers during lean times will be firmly in place when better times return.
 
Decline in Ad Pages
 Unlike some previous recessions, this one has come down hard on the rich, making itself particularly felt by advertisers of real estate, travel, cosmetics and expensive clothing.
Industrywide, magazine advertising pages were down 10.4 percent for the first seven months of 1991, the most recent figures from the Publishers Information Bureau show.
But the drop at fashion magazines is more severe. At Vogue, advertising pages were down 12.8 percent for the first nine months, as tracked by Media Industry Newsletter. For the same period, Elle was down 23.5 percent, Harper's Bazaar 24.6 percent And Mirabella 11.4 percent.
Even more significant was the drop in pages in each magazine's September fall fashion issue, which is one of the fattest of the year. Vogue was down 12.2 percent, to 423 pages; Elle was down 22.6 percent, to 257 pages; Harper's Bazaar was down 43 percent, to 130 pages, and three-year-old Mirabella, the youngest of the four, was down 14.8 percent, to 132 pages.
"Business simply doesn't exist; people are not buying at retail and stores are not putting in the inventory," said Anne Sutherland Fuchs, publisher of Vogue.
In addition to the unrest brought about by the advertising slump, Vogue, Elle and Harper's Bazaar have brought in new publishers in the last year, creating still more stir in the fashion field.
"The most constant of the bunch has been Mirabella, but there is a sense that the other publications are still groping and feeling their way to finding their identity," said Claude Fromm, executive vice president and media director of TBWA, the ad agency that represents Carillon Importers' Absolut vodka.
"The one that has it most together is Elle, in terms of where they are going," Mr. Fromm said. "Vogue is still considered the leading fashion publication, but there is a sort of ambivalence in terms of identity: Are they going younger? Are they making a fashion statement? And Harper's is still trying to get its act together."
Lean times, however, breed innovative and sometimes controversial ploys. "They are all being incredibly creative," said Matthew Rubel, president of Revlon's speciality-store unit. "Business is tough to come by and they have to work harder to get it."
Elle, for instance, packaged a videotape commercial and scented blotter card for Estee Lauder's Spellbound perfume, which were attached in plastic to the covers of 14,000 copies of the magazine in 10 cities.
"It's a new and different way for Estee Lauder to reach customers," Elle's publisher, Lawrence C. Burstein, said. "This is a way to reach people who were not in the stores."
 
Calvin Klein's Supplement
 But Ms. Fuchs of Vogue said called it "inappropriate to use the cover for commercial value."
"We do feel the cover is sacrosanct," she said. "We simply will not do it and we did turn it down."
One of the most innovative advertising efforts of the year came from Calvin Klein, a stalwart advertiser in fashion magazines, but the ad was not offered to them. Instead, the 116-page ad supplement for Calvin Klein Jeans, estimated to have cost more than $1 million, is being sent out with the October issue of Vanity Fair.
Mr. Klein said he had chosen Vanity Fair because it was "the hot book."
What no one wants to talk about on the record is which magazines give special discounts on their advertising rates. While most publishers deny discounting pages and most media directors or advertisers decline any comment on the subject, it is generally accepted that Conde Nast, publisher of Vogue and Vanity Fair, sticks to the rates listed on its official rate cards, while the others are what is usually referred to as "flexible."
"The other magazines will tailor their business to a client's needs," Mr. Fromm said. "There is nothing wrong with that. The whole idea is to have advertising work. My hunch is that if business continues the way it is going, Conde Nast is going to have to become a little more flexible."
In the meantime, however, the magazines are wooing advertisers as hard as they can. Recently, Harper's Bazaar teamed up with the Emporium, a San Francisco retailer, for a luncheon for 500 people.
Jade Hobson Charnin, the creative director at Mirabella, was the host of a fashion show at high tea at the Ritz Carlton in Cleveland.
Elle is including a miniature shopping bag in its October issue that will be filled with "Parisian chic" if presented at the Galeries Lafayette store in New York, which is scheduled to open in the fall.
And Vogue will be the host to 30 fashion shows with charity tie-ins around the country.
"We are seeding prospects for the future," said Carl Portale, Harper's Bazaar's publisher.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The severe ad slump has been especially painful for fashion magazines like Mirabella, Elle, Harper's Bazaar and Vogue, all of which have been taking innovative steps to strengthen their bonds with advertisers. (The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Radio Outlet In Boston May Be Sold

BYLINE: By EBEN SHAPIRO

 BODY:
The Emmis Broadcasting Corporation, whose seven radio stations include WFAN-AM and WQHT-FM in New York, may sell its Boston jazz station to help pay off $150 million in debt, its chairman, Jeffrey H. Smulyan, said yesterday.
Mr. Smulyan, who bought the Seattle Mariners baseball team with partners in 1989 for $75 million, also said he was considering selling the team. "Baseball has never been successful in Seattle," he said yesterday in a telephone interview. 
 But Mr. Smulyan said Emmis had no plans to sell WFAN, the country's first all-sports station. Crain's New York Business reported in its current issue that Emmis, based in Indianapolis, might be forced to sell WFAN.
 
Pressure to Cut Debt
 "We are not going to do that," Mr. Smulyan said . "You never say 'never,' but it is not something we are considering." He said WFAN had annual revenues of more than $20 mllion and was one of the top three stations in New York in billings.
Saying "Boston is on the block," Mr. Smulyan acknowledged that Emmis was losing money and was under pressure from banks to trim its debt, which consumes $16 million a year in interest payments. The Boston station, WCDJ-FM, is likely to sell for about $10 million, he said, adding that no other deals were pending.
Emmis borrowed heavily in the 1980's to acquire stations, including five that it bought from NBC in 1988 for more than $100 million. By 1989 Emmis owned 11 stations and had $230 million in debt, but has since sold 4 of them to reduce the debt by $80 million. The company also owns stations in Los Angeles, St. Louis, Chicago and Indianapolis.
 
Effect of Interest Payments
 Mr. Smulyan said that although cash flow from the stations was enough to cover interest payments, they were not profitable after paying interest.
He said the company's financial problems were caused by a downturn in the radio market. Radio stations, along with newspapers and other media, have been hurt by a drop in advertising amid the recession.
"The world has changed," Mr. Smulyan. "It is not the best of times for the communications industry."

HEADLINE: Regulation, Japan Style

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Sept. 8

 BODY:
For American trade negotiators and other outsiders who complain that Japan's economy is closed and indecipherable, two weeks of parliamentary hearings here about the continuing stock market scandals have offered fresh evidence of how difficult it can be to figure out what is permitted or prohibited in Japan and how foreigners might compete on equal terms.
In their testimony, the barons of Japan's securities industry offered no new bombshells about the unfolding financial scandals, in which 21 securities firms have acknowledged that they compensated their largest customers for trading losses. 
 But the unusual hearings have proved a milestone of sorts by exposing what many people regard as the most opaque feature of Japan's stock market regulation: the administrative guidance provided by the powerful Finance Ministry.
The agency's guidance has no solid legal basis and is often given orally, but securities firms are expected to follow it rigorously. Some foreign and Japanese experts have complained that this guidance is formulated, disseminated and enforced in such a secretive manner that outsiders are often left in the dark.
The testimony has provided ammunition for United States trade negotiators, who have promised they will renew their assault next month on what they consider a barrier to foreign participation in the financial markets. American officials have been pressing the Japanese Government to issue all regulatory guidelines publicly, in writing, and to apply them equally to all market participants.
"The problem of transparency has been an issue for a long time, and this just means it will continue to be a keyand important issue," one American official said.
At the heart of the issue is a seeming contradiction that emerged from the hearings: The top executives of major securities houses admitted that they explicitly permitted their brokers to violate a Finance Ministry ban on covering trading losses of customers. This brought an apparently unprecedented wave of improper behavior, with the 21 securities houses making at least $1.3 billion of compensation payments.
At the same time, it has also been disclosed that the ministry knew about this practice but did nothing to halt the violations or punish the firms until the tax authorities uncovered the violatons earlier this year.
Clearly, many experts agree, the Finance Ministry appears to have tacitly approved of loss-compensation. In other words, the ministry issued an order explicitly banning loss compensation but secretly permitted it because of unusual circumstances that existed at that time. The ministry had issued an order forcing the securities firms to close a kind of corporate stock-trading account. Since many of those accounts appeared to be in the red, it was widely expected that some kind of compensation would have to be provided to avoid alienating major customers.
"The visible guidance was clearly just a pose to the public -- to try and show the ministry did not approve," said Takaaki Wakasugi, a professor of finance at Tokyo University and co-head of a research institute at the University of Michigan. "They are just pretending to be in the right. They must have known that this was going on and quietly permitted the compensation. That's why these hearings were not testimony, they were ceremony."
 
Whose Scandal Is It?
 Chalmers Johnson, a professor of Japanese political economy at the University of California at San Diego, observed: "What this underscores is that this is not a securities industry scandal as much as a Finance Ministry scandal. In this case, the real administrative guidance was camouflaged. They're just playing grand Kabuki and pretending their dictates were violated."
Perhaps the key moment in understanding what happened came in June, at the annual meeting of the Nomura Securities Company. The firm's president at the time, Yoshihisa Tabuchi, startled his own firm and the Finance Ministry by proclaiming somewhat angrily that the ministry had approved the payment of compensation.
Mr. Tabuchi later resigned, and Nomura tried to erase his outburst by calling the remark inappropriate. But most Japanese seemed to accept that Mr. Tabuchi's sin was candor.
Nobody would be questioning Japan's regulatory system, of course, if the ministry relied on laws rather than guidance. Japan has securities laws, many of them patterned after American statutes and written by the American Occupation forces after the war. But they are rarely if ever invoked.
 
No Formal Charges
 For instance, although a variety of penalties have been meted out for the improper compensation -- from pay cuts and resignations to fines and suspensions -- there has yet to be a formal charge of wrongdoing or an open legal process in which evidence was presented.
Some Japanese have justified relying on guidance by arguing that theirs is such a harmonious society and that bureaucratic dictates are so respected that the most efficient means of regulating the huge financial markets is not through cumbersome legislation and the courts, but with extra-legal commands.
Left unstated is the fact that when guidance is employed there is no check or counterbalance and no means of airing the dictates in public debate.
Nearly all the improper compensation payments were made to cover losses in a type of corporate account known as an eigyo tokkin, roughly translated as a money trust. These are discretionary accounts where corporations put spare cash, with the brokerage firms making all the investment decisions.
 
Phase-Out Ordered
 Several years ago the ministry decided to reduce conflicts of interest by forcing brokerage houses to do all their management of stock-market funds through independent asset management subsidiaries. The idea was to insure that investment decisions were made out of professional judgment and not to generate commissions or to push up the prices of stocks through heavy buying.
But when the brokerage concerns were instructed to phase out the eigyo tokkin accounts, it was well understood that those accounts in the red would require some compensation, several experts said. Nonetheless, the ministry issued its public guidance that compensation was prohibited.
"There was an understanding that the securities firms could not comply at once," said Michiya Matsukawa, chairman of the Nikko Research Center and a former top Finance Ministry official. "There had to be some time to handle this situation in an orderly way."
 
Inadequate Warning
 Making matters worse, brokerage-house customers were not given ample warning of the rule change or ample time to prepare for the shift, some experts said.
"The real problem was that the ministry issued two incompatible guidances," said Yukio Noguchi, an economics professor at Hitotsubashi University and a former ministry official. "That is why I don't think defiance is the appropriate word for what the securities firms did in paying the compensation. The issue was that formally speaking, the ministry could not admit it created a situation where there was loss compensation."

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 6; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 2194 words

HEADLINE: SOVIET TURMOIL;
Soviet Georgia Chief, In Quest of Freedom, Sees Only Enemies

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TBILISI, U.S.S.R., Sept. 7

 BODY:
For the beleaguered and increasingly insecure leader of Soviet Georgia, who has struggled for decades to get the Soviet Union and the world to recognize the independence of his fiercely proud republic in the Caucasus Mountains, the victory in Moscow of the forces of democracy after last month's failed coup was nothing to cheer about.
President Zviad K. Gamsakhurdia says he wants nothing to do with the Soviet Union any more, whether it is a democracy or a dictatorship. All he wants is real autonomy for Georgia, which he rules like a freely elected despot, preoccupied with plots, real and imagined, to do him in and keep his land under Moscow's domination. 
 Since Georgia declared independence on April 9, only Romania has recognized it, and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev has ignored it.
Mr. Gamsakhurdia, as if paralyzed, has let the Georgian economy go to ruin until the republic is free, and last week his government forbade the export of meat, milk, vegetables, building material and most other goods, all in acute shortage.
His government's price controls and tax laws discourage private enterprise, seemingly a natural tendency for a land known over the centuries for its traders. Mr. Gamsakhurdia blames a Soviet "embargo" for the shortages, and said on Saturday that Georgia could not even begin to make economic progress until Moscow let it go its own way.
The difficulties of this republic of five and a half million people seem to show that autonomy is hardly the end of trouble for the long-unwilling partners of the Soviet Union; independence for the Soviet republics also raises new problems.
Mr. Gamsakhurdia's behavior has puzzled many former friends, even those who know that Georgia is the land of Medea and the birthplace of Stalin -- an old, querulous mountain country where intrigues are as gnarled and thick on the ground as the grapevines in people's backyards.
On Saturday, speaking of plots against his leadership by Georgia's enemies in Moscow, Tbilisi and even in the United States, he said that his recently dismissed Prime Minister and Foreign Minister, the head of the national guard, and the leader of the opposition in the republic's Parliament had all betrayed him.
He recently suspended publication of the most critical Georgian-language opposition newspapers, setting off nightly demonstrations in the streets of the capital calling for his resignation. And a small-scale civil war continues in the South Ossetian Autonomous Region north of Tbilisi, where separatists want to secede from Georgia and join a similar region just north of the Caucasus, in Russia.
 
All a Plot
 To Mr. Gamsakhurdia, all this is part of a conspiracy to thwart Georgian independence.
"Moscow wants to create civil war here," he said Saturday, and he held little hope that things would change. "I believe Gorbachev continues this usual line against Georgia," he added. He said that Boris N. Yeltsin, President of the Russian federated republic, had promised to consider recognition, but so far had done nothing.
Anti-Georgian provocateurs in the United States are keeping Washington from extending diplomatic recognition, he said, and Moscow and its agents are waging a whispering campaign in the West: "Here is a fascist dictator, and the people are against him. You must not recognize Georgia."
These hardly sound like the words of a man who was elected with 87 percent of the popular vote in May. Now, in early September, his power seems to be waning prematurely.
Last Monday, a violent clash between demonstrators and special police units in Rustaveli Square, near the center of Tbilisi, raised fears that there might be a macabre replay of the events of April 9, 1989, when Soviet troops used entrenching tools, and allegedly poison gas, against demonstrators, killing 20 of them.
This time it was Georgian versus Georgian as gunshots were fired, by policemen and perhaps also by demonstrators. Twenty people were wounded, four seriously.
Protesters have been out in the streets every night since. But the police, instead of charging them with shields and nightsticks, have sealed off part of the area with buses drawn up in front of the pink stone neo-Classical government headquarters. Down a winding boulevard, demonstrators and onlookers ambled under trees, listening to recorded speeches demanding Mr. Gamsakhurdia's resignation and new elections.
 
The Coup
 Treading Carefully, And Getting Burned

The 52-year-old President, dignified in a dark suit and a thin mustache, sounded irritated, chopping the air with impatient gestures.
Surrounded by bodyguards and journeying back and forth from his home in the hills above Tbilisi in a cavalcade of armored black Mercedes limousines, Mr. Gamsakhurdia seems increasingly distant from his dissident past.
The son of the pre-eminent writer of modern Georgia, Konstantin Gamsakhurdia, he was first jailed for nationalist activities in 1956, at the age of 17. He finished his last prison term in 1980, after three years behind bars for "anti-Soviet activity."
His latest troubles have intensified since the failure of the coup in Moscow.
By his own account and those of others, President Gamsakhurdia trod a tightrope during the revolt, agreeing to cause no trouble in Georgia and appealing to his people to remain calm, while calling on the world to show its support for the forces of democracy -- in Georgia and elsewhere.
Defying an order by the coup leaders, he said, he also refused to dissolve his 15,000-member national guard, a group created in November from the ranks of Georgians who objected to service in the Soviet Army.
Gen. Valery A. Patrikeyev, the Soviet troop commander of the Caucasus Military District, appeared on Georgian television during the coup and said his relationship with Mr. Gamsakhurdia was "excellent." Mr. Gamsakhurdia later carefully distanced himself from the putsch attempt, saying it had not been clear to him that it might not have been a charade.
But his opponents seized upon the events and charged that he had been ambivalent. Last Monday's rally was called by Georgi Chanturia, the head of the National Democratic Party, one of a coalition of groups that boycotted Parliament elections last year and the presidential voting in May.
"We wanted to expose his links with the coup leaders," Mr. Chanturia said in an interview, saying he had proof of the President's complicity. The proof turned out to be an assertion, made by the dismissed Prime Minister, Tengiz Sigua, that a Deputy Prime Minister "must have" discussed plans with the coup makers during a one-day trip to Moscow on Aug. 18, the Sunday the coup began.
Before last Monday's rally began, Mr. Chanturia said, the President's commandos charged the crowd with batons, firing pistols into the air. A videotape of the incident was broadcast on Soviet television the next evening. Mr. Gamsakhurdia's officials say the police were attacked first, but the President said they should not have used their weapons in any case.
On Wednesday, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, the former Soviet Foreign Minister and a Georgian, commented on the violence. He said on television that it was a direct result of Mr. Gamsakhurdia's refusal to talk with the opposition.
People here remember Mr. Shevardnadze as their Interior Minister and Communist Party leader, the job he held in Tbilisi when Mr. Gamsakhurdia was being prosecuted for nationalist activities. Now, in the President's eyes, Mr. Shevardnadze is in league with those who want to bring him down.
The violence also split the Georgian national guard, whose commanding officer, Tengiz Kitovani, broke with Mr. Gamsakhurdia and said the force would "resist any activity directed against the people."
Mr. Gamsakhurdia said Saturday that he no longer recognized Mr. Kitovani as being in charge. Now he groups him among his enemies -- along with Mr. Sigua; his former Foreign Minister, Georgi Khoshtaria, dismissed in August for "wanting to make his own foreign policy," and Nodar Notadze, another longtime former comrade of the President's, who is now the leader of the opposition in Parliament.
"He is very close with the armed opposition now," Mr. Gamsakhurdia said of his onetime colleague in the dissident movenment, "and he protects them in Parliament -- also now these criminals."
 
Home and Abroad
 Little Recognition; Rebellion Aplenty

At the empty and echoing Foreign Ministry, a former Communist Party school and agricultural institute up one of Tbilisi's steep hills, Deputy Foreign Minister Nodar Gabashvili complained about how difficult it was to get foreign nations to recognize Georgian independence.
"The extra-parliamentary opposition wants the world to see Georgia as a Soviet colony, and not to recognize us until the Soviet Army is forced out and new general elections are called," he said. "Under our former Foreign Minister, our ministry didn't make much effort at counter-propaganda."
Mr. Gabashvili said he hoped that the new minister, Murman Omanidze, would have better luck. Mr. Gamsakhurdia said the new Prime Minister, Vissarion Gugushvili, would meet with Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d in Moscow on Monday to plead Georgia's case for recognition by the United States.
"We have more democracy than in your countries," Mr. Gamsakhurdia told a group of Western correspondents. "Nobody can stop traffic in the streets in your country and make rallies, can they?" But, he added, "When you are in war, you cannot think of democracy. Now we are in war."
The struggle in the South Ossetian Autonomous Region, which has been formally abolished by Mr. Gamsakhurdia, has taken perhaps a hundred lives so far this year, and sent 50,000 Ossetians fleeing north across the mountains.
On Thursday, the government says, four Georgian partisans there were killed and a herd of sheep was stolen by the Ossetian rebels, who have vowed to continue the struggle for their own independence. The Soviet press agency Tass reported that more Ossetians and Georgians were killed in shootings on Saturday.
Mr. Gamsakhurdia refuses to give independence to the Ossetians because, he said, the separatist leaders are agents of Moscow, which hopes to divide and continue to rule Georgia. He has declared a state of emergency in what he calls "the former southern Ossetia" and issued orders to arrest its leaders. They have gone underground.
"The leaders of South Ossetia officially supported the coup in Moscow," he said, reading from statements published in their Russian-language newspaper, Sovetskaya Ossetiya, on Aug. 20. "This territory belongs to Georgia. National minorities have only cultural rights in every country, not political autonomy."
Mr. Chanturia, once Mr. Gamsakhurdia's friend, said of him, "He is a pathological coward, and a coward who holds power is very dangerous."
The Georgian leader is a complex character, a man who told the court at his sentencing in 1978, "I sincerely regret what I have done and condemn the crime I have committed." The statement, taped and edited, was broadcast over Soviet television at the time, and made many people wonder what had come over Mr. Gamsakhurdia.
In an interview with this correspondent in January, he explained that he had bargained with the K.G.B. and expressed regret for distributing "anti-Soviet propaganda," books and materials on the United States that had been provided by an American diplomat and several journalists. "I never renounced my Georgian nationalistic activities," he said, but added he feared that if he did not compromise, he would lose his citizenship and be expelled.
He said he had also agreed to testify as a prosecution witness against this reporter and Harold Piper, then a correspondent for the Baltimore Sun, in a July 1978 case charging the American reporters with slander. The Soviet State Committee for Television and Radio brought charges against the reporters for writing articles reporting friends' and relatives' doubts about the genuineness of his televised confession and apology. The correspondents did not take part in the trial in Moscow, where Mr. Gamsakhurdia testified that the broadcast confession had been accurate.
His three-year sentence was later reduced to two years, since he had been held in solitary confinement for a year before his arrest. And instead of being exiled to Siberia, he was released after serving the two years in jail and allowed to work in Georgia.
Despite all his troubles, Mr. Gamsakhurdia remains popular among many Georgians. Crowds of supporters who gather in front of his headquarters every day do not want him to go.
"Those people just want disorder so the West won't recognize us," said Gabunia Daredzhali, 40 years old, a Tbilisi office worker. "They want the world to think we're killing each other. Our President is not a dictator; he's a good Christian believer."
Mr. Gamsakhurdia addressed a rally of several thousand in front of the government buildings on Saturday afternoon, to cheers. But the police had barricaded the square with buses yet again, giving the event an almost claustrophobic air.

HEADLINE: Using Books Instead of Brooms to Escape Welfare

BYLINE: By JASON DePARLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TULSA, Okla.

 BODY:
Each weekday morning, Alica Kimble, a single mother of four, joins what is meant to be a revolution in the nation's welfare system.
She takes her 3-year-old son to a community center, where he attends a preschool class while she studies for her high school equivalency degree. She is one of hundreds of thousands of welfare parents newly required to leave home and take steps toward self-support. Like many others, she is hoping that the investment in education can rewrite a life story so far filled with the sad endings of dead-end jobs and welfare office waiting rooms. 
 Three years after Congress pledged sweeping changes in the welfare system, the question that arises is this: Do the experiences of Ms. Kimble and others like her represent welfare's promising future? Or will their experiences repeat its discouraging past?
The law, which took effect last November, requires states to place a rising percentage of their welfare recipients in work, training or education programs. But it gives states much discretion in designing those programs. And in a policy shift that carries great but untested hopes, many states are urging people to return to the classroom rather than seek immediate, low-paying jobs.
The move from brooms to books is especially striking in Oklahoma, which has a long history of promoting work programs. Administrators here, as across the country, herald the change as a hopeful one, meant to respond to changes in the labor market.
"You've got to have some skills to be competitive," said Paul Walker, programs supervisor for the Oklahoma Department of Human Services. "If we don't do it, we'll be a Third World country like Mexico."
But some critics worry that the trend sets up welfare parents for further failure by putting them back in classroom settings where they have already had problems.
 
Avenue of Escape?
 "My biggest fear is that they're going to put people into a never-ending stream of self-esteem classes," said Mickey Kaus, who is writing a book on the welfare system and who advocates replacing it with a system of public jobs. "It becomes an excuse for not coming to grips with the labor market."
Nationwide, only about a quarter of the welfare parents participating in the programs are working or looking for work, while the rest have returned to some sort of classroom.
The choice between education and work flows from the Family Support Act, the heralded 1988 law that sought to impose a new social contract on the world of welfare. Calling on the poor to do more to help themselves, the law threatens to reduce the aid of those who refuse to seek training, schooling or work.
But it also pledges society's help in new ways -- by creating more programs to help parents off welfare and providing them child care and transportation. The law also allows parents to keep receiving child care and Medicaid a year after they leave public assistance and promises to make more absent fathers pay child support.
 
Earlier, Modest Results
 When the act passed, Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, the New York Democrat and the law's chief architect, said it would "bring a generation of young American women back into the mainstream of American life."
In lobbying for the law, its supporters pointed to research by the Manpower Demonstration Research Corporation, which showed that experimental welfare-to-work programs begun in the early 1980's had increased parents' earnings and decreased welfare expenses. But most of those programs emphasized quick work-oriented activities, like job search clubs, intended to put parents immediately to work. Few stressed education.
Many of those who left welfare found only low-paying jobs and remained poor. And the programs did little to reach the most disadvantaged. States are now gambling that education can make a bigger difference.
While evaluation data is still years off, those on either side of the work-versus-education debate might find their views confirmed in Ms. Kimble's past. One of 11 brothers and sisters raised on welfare by a single mother, Ms. Kimble, who is 28 years old, left school at age 14 and had her first child two years later. Since then, her life has followed a hopscotch pattern of dead-end jobs, pregnancy, adult education classes and welfare.
It is possible to argue that, with an eighth-grade education, she has never had the skills to make it on her own. She has worked as a hotel dishwasher and housekeeper, a Burger King counter attendant and a washwoman at a commercial laundry. But she quit each job. "I didn't want to be on my knees cleaning the tubs and making up the beds," she said.
It is also true that past educational programs have not seemed to help. She has attended two other programs to help her get a general equivalency degree. She joined a job club meant to give her the confidence to handle employment. And she attended a private trade school, where she dropped out and accrued a $2,500 student loan debt. Is this program different?
Ms. Kimble gives conflicting answers. "I think it's about the same," said Ms. Kimble, a pleasant woman who has painted the letters of her first name across the five shining red nails of her left hand. But then she added that having the associated preschool classes for her son puts her mind at ease by having him nearby as she studies. And he is so eager to attend, she said, that he gets angry if she wants to stay home.
"If he didn't motivate me, I wouldn't get here half the time," she said.
 
States Stress Classroom
 In a recent interview, Senator Moynihan said he was encouraged by reports from state officials who have lauded education as the missing welfare link. "Gee, I wish people wouldn't knock this until we have 10 years to find out," he said.
Under the 1988 law each state was required in November to have 7 percent of its welfare population enrolled in a job or education program.
The programs can be expensive, especially in a recession. Congress offered states $800 million for the program in 1990, but states, short on the necessary matching funds, spent only $272 million of it.
Reports from the Department of Health and Human Services bear out the emphasis on education. Nationwide, 4.5 million families were receiving welfare in March, and 510,000, or 11 percent, were said to be participating in a job or education program.
Of them, 33 percent were enrolled in a basic education course, 11 percent in a post-secondary school and 16 percent were learning a technical skill. Another 15 percent were in miscellaneous school programs. By contrast, only 4 percent were in an actual work setting, and another 21 percent were in programs to help them quickly find work.
In Oklahoma, Mr. Walker said that the shift toward education also allows states to save money by piggybacking onto programs with independent financing.
Oklahomans now have a cornucopia of programs. One of the most creative is at Parkview Terrace, a south Tulsa housing project, where a nonprofit group teaches welfare recipients to run day care centers from their homes.
At Tulsa Junior College, Project Esteem tries to prepare welfare parents for high school degrees through special counseling and computerized lessons.
Sarah Battle, a 30-year-old mother of six who joined the program in mid-August, said she had dropped out of about a half-dozen basic education programs. But she says now that walking college hallways "does something for my self-esteem." After the course ends, she said, she plans to study accounting at the college rather than immediately seek work.
Mr. Kaus, the advocate of a public jobs program, said some education programs encourage unrealistic expectations. "You're not going to get the $25,000-a-year job unless you start with the $15,000 job," he said.
Administrators at Oklahoma State University in Okmulgee, an hour south of Tulsa, provided 22 promising welfare parents with free housing, tuition, food, books, child care and counseling as they studied technical trades like air-conditioning repair and computer programming.
About 16 months into the two-year program, 12 have left. Bob Klabenes, the campus director, says, "I was a little naive," but argues the program can still work for the right kind of person. He offers as an example Connie Brunk. The salutatorian of her high school class in rural Muldrow, Ms. Brunk, 35 years old, said she has often held two jobs at a time and was never on welfare until a recent divorce.
She brought her two children, and a Norman Vincent Peale book, to the campus. "I got out of a dead-end job, a dead-end life," Ms. Brunk said. But, she added, "I'm not the typical one."

HEADLINE: Grateful Dead: Alive and Thriving

BYLINE: By PETER WATROUS

 BODY:
In a recessionary pop music environment in which tours keel over and die and radio and MTV stars hit the road only to cancel their tours, the Grateful Dead, 26 years old and counting, are doing better than ever. So far this year, their gross for live shows has been higher than any other band's. For the first six months of the year, the Dead earned $20 million. Playing stadium-size venues -- something no other tour has dared do this summer -- the band has sold out virtually every show it has played, and the prediction is that for the rest of the year, it will sell out everything that's left.
Yesterday the Grateful Dead arrived in New York to play nine sold-out shows at Madison Square Garden. 
 "If I knew what made us popular, I'd bottle it," one of the group's leaders, the guitarist Jerry Garcia, said in a telephone interview. "Whatever it is, it invented us, we didn't invent it. The audience thinks we're providing more than music, but we don't let on what we're providing, intentionally. We're elliptical. Someone once wrote that we're a real cheap vacation to Bermuda, which is kind of right. But insofar as we're providing a safe context to be together with a lot of people who aren't afraid of each other, which is real valuable in New York, I'd guess, we're important."
Part of the Grateful Dead experience is its audience. However the baby-boom generation has ended up making a living, it still likes to go to concerts, perhaps dreaming of California freedom and San Francisco bohemia. People sliding in from a hard day on Wall Street sit next to people two generations younger in tie-dye whose glazed eyes don't come from staring at a computer all day and who have been following the tour, showing up at every concert. Standard parts of the scene are the Grateful Dead A.A. chapter, out in force, and the officially sanctioned bootleggers, who sit beneath a forest of microphones taping each precious drop of music. And unreconstructed older hippies, role models and mentors to the teen-agers in the audience, also show up in tie-dye but with streaks of gray in their hair.
Each show is an event, a spectacle that draws meaning from itself as much as it does from the music.
"With all the kinds of people that come, old-timers and kids, it's a little hard to tell what makes them all have a valuable experience," Mr. Garcia said. "I used to wonder about it and worry. Suppose we're misleading all these people? But it's not really like that, I realized, because we're not selling a point of view. We stay away from advocating much at all, so people are left on their own to imagine who we are."
Though the core of the band -- Mr. Garcia and Bob Weir on guitars, Phil Lesh on bass, and Mickey Hart and Bill Kreutzmann on percussion -- has been together since 1968, the loss of its pianist, Brent Mydland, to a drug overdose last year and the subsequent inclusion of Vince Welnick and Bruce Hornsby on keyboards have meant that the band has been changing its sound. Though it still does its standard two-set shows, with a long drum interlude, and though it still performs many of its classic songs -- playing without a set list, the band can do six nights without repeating itself -- it is developing a thicker and harder sound. Not that this has changed the audience's experience too much; the shows still feature people dancing in the aisles, performing a particularly arrhythmic dance that's specific to Grateful Dead shows.
"The band is basically a new band with the two new guys," Mr. Garcia said. "Those guys have to catch up with 25 years of stuff, and we have to learn to hear what their unique capabilities are. In the short run, it's a setback, but in the long run it's an advantage. The band is more solid now; it's lost some of its lightness but there's a little more rhythmic precision, which we could always use."
 
Going Out Separately
 Mr. Garcia has been busy recently, putting out two albums, including one, "The Jerry Garcia Band," (Arista) culled from a tour he did with his own band, featuring songs like "The Way You Do the Things You Do," "Dear Prudence" and "Tangled Up in Blue." Typically, the songs are completely remade, as much a comment on the tunes' potential as about the original version of the songs. The other album, "Jerry Garcia/David Grisman" (Acoustic Disc), is a series of acoustic pieces by Mr. Garcia and his old mandolinist friend, David Grisman.
"I can afford to be more selective now, and I have the luxury to pick and choose that I haven't always had," Mr. Garcia said. "I worked as a studio musician in the late 1960's and early 70's, without that much concern for who I was recording with. Everything I've done recently is something that I wanted to do."
Mr. Garcia mentioned possible projects with Paul Kantner, the former Jefferson Airplane and Starship guitarist, and with Mr. Hornsby. And he has just appeared in some ads for Levi's jeans: "Me, Hornsby and Branford Marsalis," Mr. Garcia said. "Spike Lee directed, and I figure if Spike can sell out, so can I."
Of all the major rock guitarists to arrive in the 1960's, Mr. Garcia is arguably the most musically literate. He's just as at home talking about Indian improvisation as he is about John Coltrane or about Brazilian mandolin players. Taking bluegrass and jazz as a conceptual framework, his solos, shifting easily from harmonic color to harmonic color, always sidestep cliches. And his improvisations swing and crest the same way a jazz musician's might, with an intensity that isn't predicated on volume. He's one of the few rockers, in fact, who can sustain a lengthy improvisation.
"I'm still learning," he said. "As long as I'm still learning I can keep playing, and it's going to be fun. There's a certain problem-solving aspect to improvisation that I like, it's thinking on your feet. There's an intellectual and emotional side to it, and the emotional side I can't quite articulate. It's one of those things you feel or you don't. The intellectual is easer to grasp, it's the bead game, with infinite ways a solo can go. Freezing the choices in time and choosing, that's the satisfaction. As I get older I'm starting to perceive a greater sense of composition, a sense of contour and development that is missing in my early stuff. The earlier stuff, truthfully, is embarrassing."
It is the improvisational aspect of the Grateful Dead's music that keeps it fresh, even as the band's members reach an age that at one time would have been thought impossible for a functioning rock group. (Mr. Garcia is 49 years old; Mr. Lesh is the oldest at 51.)
"If Benny Goodman and Pablo Casals could do it, so can we," said Mr. Garcia. "I keep playing and touring because I enjoy it. But it can be labor intensive. Rehearsing the Grateful Dead is major work. It's one of the reasons we don't come up with new material every tour. The band is evolutionary, and where everybody learns a new tune right away, deciding what to play goes on for years. Everybody in the band is so amazingly idiosyncratic, nobody plays a formula. From a writer's point of view, there's two years' worth of discomfort performing a new tune. About the second year it starts turning into something.
"But, you know, everything is always subject to change."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The Grateful Dead, which earns more in live shows than any other band, last night began nine sold-out shows at Madison Square Garden. (Angel Franco/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: In Japan, Mostly Mozart Plays Well, or Even Better

BYLINE: By STEVEN R. WEISMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Sept. 8

 BODY:
Mozart in the department stores. Mozart coins. Mozart on television and radio. Even a Mozart brand of rice wine, or sake, has been produced in this bicentennial year of the great composer's death, as Japan has taken what in other countries was a preoccupation and made it an obsession.
Last week Japanese audiences flocked to a nine-concert version of the Mostly Mozart Festival, imported direct from Lincoln Center, the first time that the popular New York City ensemble has traveled abroad. 
 Under the baton of Gerard Schwarz, Mostly Mozart has been a hit, drawing enthusiastic applause and large crowds -- though not a sold-out hall. A reviewer said today that opening night "made one well understand the festival policy of enjoying Mozart to the utmost with the best performers."
Festival promoters are so pleased that they have already announced plans to bring Mostly Mozart back to Japan next year.
The annual festival in New York City finished its 25th season two weeks ago. After a day off and a day of rehearsals, the orchestra left for Tokyo, where it has been at Orchard Hall at the Bunkamura (Culture Village), a sleek complex established two years ago by the Tokyu department store.
"Of all the places we could bring our festival, this is the place I would choose," said Mr. Schwarz. "One reason for Japan's great economic success is its respect for culture. We as artists want to play for a sophisticated and appreciative public. That exists here."
 
Consumers of Classical Music
 To which might be added that Japan, because of its growing economic clout, also accounts for an enormous percentage of classical music sales on tapes and compact disks. Thus the festival's coming here is testimony to the power of Japanese consumers in the classical music world.
"When I say cultural capital, I mean that careers can be made in this city, just the way they can be made in New York," said Mr. Schwarz.
Vladimir Feltsman, who performed the Concertos No. 23 and 24 to great applause this week, agreed. "Let's face it, Japan sells more classical CD's than any other single country in the world," he said. "Japanese are always striving for the best -- and fortunately for them, they can buy it."
Although the festival began Aug. 30 and ended on Saturday night, after nine concerts, only one review has appeared so far. It was extremely favorable. The Japan Economic Journal singled out the performance of two arias from "The Marriage of Figaro" by Cecilia Bartoli, a mezzo- soprano.
"She showed a kind of Oriental beauty and sensitivity," the paper said. "Schwarz's conducting offered good assistance to her excellent performance."
The Japanese music season generally does not begin until late September, so no one seems disappointed that the festival has sold only about 70 percent of its tickets in the 2,150-seat hall, a shoebox-shaped auditorium with a high ceiling and swept-back balconies.
Uzuhiko Tanaka, managing director of the Tokyo Bunkamura, said ticket sales were defraying only about half the $1.5 million it cost to put on the festival. Part of the problem, he said, was that at the request of Lincoln Center, the Bunkamura has lowered the price of tickets.
 
Appealing Prices
 Ticket prices range from $22 to $58, whereas the minimum price of a normal ticket for an international orchestra is usually about $88. Mr. Tanaka said he admired Lincoln Center's philosophy of keeping prices low to appeal to an audience of students and tourists, and readily agreed to its request.
"If we succeed with the Lincoln Center philosophy, we'll be getting a new kind of audience accustomed to going to concerts," he said.
It has been an arduous time for the orchestra, Mr. Schwarz said. Mostly Mozart has toured upstate New York and a few other places and had a shortened version for several years in Washington, but nothing like the Tokyo trip has been attempted before.
"At Lincoln Center, we do about 45 concerts, including repeats," Mr. Schwarz said. "It's actually 14 orchestra programs in 28 performances. Here we're doing seven different programs -- in essence, half our season in a very condensed fashion. It's a great testament to the orchestra."
The festival has performed a smattering of symphonies, concertos, arias and other works, including an evening devoted entirely to music for winds, supplemented by a few dozen bassoonists, oboists, horn players and other Japanese players based in Japan.
Mostly Mozart is hardly the only Mozart observance in Japan this year, however. Most of Tokyo's orchestras are slating special Mozart programs, and on Jan. 27, Mozart's birthday, there was an unusual concert of Mozart music conducted by Norio Ohga, president of Sony. Mr. Ohga is famous for making a personal commitment to the quality of the Sony Walkman and other audio equipment.
There was a Salzburg Mozart Week last March, and Hiroshi Asakawa, editor of a leading classical music magazine, said the amount of Mozart music being heard here was extraordinary. "Within two years, I think we'll see every piece of Mozart music played in Japan," he said.
Various city governments have held Mozart festivals. Mozart books have sold well, partly because of the phenomenal success of "Amadeus," the movie and the play, a few years ago. The Japanese production of the Peter Shaffer play featured a popular Kabuki actor as Mozart's rival, Salieri.
And recently Toshiba got into the act by capitalizing brazenly on the popularity of the shy and smiling daughter-in-law of Emperor Akihito, Kiko Kawashima, who is pregnant. The company has put out a cassette of Mozart music billed as something to help "Kiko-san" enjoy her pregnancy.
At the other extreme, a sake brewer from the coastal area west of Tokyo is marketing a Mozart brand of sake, asserting that Mozart is regularly played at the brewery. "It seems that the malt grows well especially with Mozart music in the background," the company director told a newspaper.
"Japanese have always loved Mozart -- but this much?" asked the Asahi newspaper in a recent editorial. "The fuss that surrounds the 200th anniversary of his death makes us wonder what is going on."

HEADLINE: HOCKEY;
Islander Takes Time Out as Negotiator

BYLINE: By JOE LAPOINTE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LANSINGBURGH, N.Y., Sept. 8

 BODY:
For the first phase of training camp, the 64 Islanders on hand here are divided into four teams that play one another in a round-robin scrimmage tournament. One of those teams is called "Baumgartner's Heavy Metals." The captain is Ken Baumgartner, a veteran with a shaggy blond mane. The team is called "Heavy Metals" because he enjoys that brand of rock music and a rugged style of play.
On an as-yet unspecified day later this week, Baumgartner will travel to an as-yet undisclosed city in Canada to play yet another leadership role among another group of co-workers.
 
The Goal Ahead
 He is one of nine players on the committee of the National Hockey League Players Association that is trying to negotiate a new collective- bargaining agreement with team owners to replace a five-year pact that expires next Sunday.. 
 Never in its history has the players' union called a strike, nor have the owners ever ordered a lockout. But this summer's negotiations have progressed more slowly than any before. The season begins on Oct. 3. Is a strike a possibility?
"More than in any other year," said Baumgartner, who also serves as team player representative. "A work interruption can work both ways: a lockout or a strike. We've made considerable preparations for either in the last year. But our one goal is to work out a collective-bargaining agreement by Sept. 15."
Coming into the negotiations, the main aim of the union was to increase free agency. A limited version now exists, but in many cases a team that signs a free agent takes a severe risk because an arbitrator can award compensation in return.
Last week, because Brendan Shanahan left the New Jersey Devils to sign with St. Louis Blues, an arbitrator shocked many around the league by ordering Scott Stevens of the Blues to move to the Devils. Stevens had moved the previous summer as a free agent from the Washington Capitals to St. Louis. Although no arbitration was involved in that case, the Blues have to give Washington five first-round draft choices in exchange for Stevens.
Will the arbitrator's ruling have a chilling effect on teams trying to sign free agents?
"It certainly will," Baumgartner said. "A lot of people say it's a fix. But the arbitator was a judge, he wasn't appointed by just John Ziegler and the league. When you have to uproot Scott Stevens, he becomes a martyr for the system."
The harsh ruling against the Blues underscores how hockey players have less mobility than their colleagues in baseball.
"We'd love that," Baumgartner said of the free agency enjoyed by many baseball players. "The owners feel an open market would ruin hockey. They say they can't bid against each other and how could the Winnipegs survive against people like New York and Detroit?
"We feel that free agency hasn't hurt baseball teams like Minnesota. Baseball has enjoyed great prosperity under free agency. In hockey, in the past, we've made lots of concessions to keep jobs. We have given up some economic aspects for job security. It's our turn to be rewarded."
 
Boss Sits Across Table
 Bill Torrey, Baumgartner's boss, is president of the Islanders and a member of the negotiating committee for the board of governors. With his management colleagues, he sits across the table from Baumgartner and the other player negotiators -- one of whom is Bryan Trottier of Pittsburgh, the former Islander, who is president of the players' association.
Torrey said he couldn't speak about the bargaining issues because only Zieglerhas that authority. When asked last week about the talks, Ziegler, the league president, offered no details.
A new factor in this round of negotiations is the presence of Bob Goodenow, the deputy executive director of the union, who is soon to replace Alan Eagleson, the executive director, who established the union in the 1960's. Eagleson's critics have charged, in increasing volume, that the players have been too timid in their demands because Eagleson is too close to many team owners and to Ziegler, the league president.
"No extreme action needs to be taken on the 15th," Baumgartner said, referring to the current contract's expiration date, "but both sides would be susceptible to it. We're not asking for the world. We have the good of the league in mind. But we want to grow with the league. The owners are successful businessmen. They thrive on these negotiations. It's a little different for the players. It's a real-life experience you won't get in any classroom."
