HEADLINE: Awaiting Congress in Capital: Soviet and Israeli Aid Questions

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 8

 BODY:
Congress comes back from vacation this week to face all the domestic problems it left behind five weeks ago and two major foreign policy questions it had not seen coming.
Hearings on the nomination of Clarence Thomas to be a Justice on the Supreme Court will begin Tuesday morning. Floor action on issues like abortion and unemployment will soon follow. 
 The lawmakers have had weeks, sometimes months, to make up their minds on those matters and on other domestic measures, among them banking, cable television, crime, gasoline taxes, energy policy and civil rights. But neither the upheaval in the Soviet Union nor the question of putting off $10 billion in loan guarantees for Israel was on their minds before they left Aug. 2.
A few lawmakers have been at the Capitol for at least some of the recess, but most scattered to their home states, took trips abroad or even went on old-fashioned family holidays, so there is nothing approaching cohesion on either issue.
 
A Mixed-Media Approach
 The lawmakers have talked more about the Soviet Union, arguing by news conference and fax machine about sending food, technical assistance and long-term aid to whatever government or governments have asked for help. There is a general expectation that food, at least, will be shipped, but there is uncertainty about where in the budget the money will come from.
One simpler step involving the Soviet Union is likely to be settled first, with both chambers expected to approve favored trade status in a relatively inexpensive move that would encourage change and unity. Its most noticeable impact on the low level of current trade would be to cut the price of imported vodka by about $1 a fifth.
Late last week another international issue -- one with important domestic political implications -- was dumped in their laps when the Administration said it would ask that action on a request for loan guarantees to Israel to help settle Soviet Jews be postponed until after a Mideast peace conference in October.
The initial reaction from those leaders who had anything to say was agreeable, but the rank and file, and the Israeli lobby, had not been heard from.Earlier this year they combined to overcome opposition in the Administration and the leadership to emergency aid for Israel during the Persian Gulf War.
Underlying how Congress will proceed on those issues is an insistent Democratic charge that President Bush cares more about foreign policy than domestic policy and would be quicker to justify enlarging the deficit for foreign emergencies than for American suffering.
That is the case lawmakers expect to make again in the next few days when they try once more to legislate additional benefits for workers who have been out of a job for at least half a year. On the day they adjourned for vacation, they passed a $5.8 billion bill to provide an additional 5 to 20 weeks of benefits for three million people.
 
Another Debate on Benefits
 Mr. Bush signed the bill in Kennebunkport, Me., but blocked the actual benefits by refusing to declare an emergency, a step required under last year's budget act if the deficit is to be increased. The lawmakers are likely to pass the measure again, and they may structure it so that Mr. Bush has to veto it to block benefits. "Congress will not allow the Bush Administration to ignore the plight of the unemployed," Representative Thomas J. Downey said Friday. Mr. Downey, Democrat of Long Island, is the bill's chief sponsor in the House.
Another immediate issue will be abortion, as the Senate votes Tuesday on cutting off debate on taking up the appropriation bill for the Departments of Labor and Health and Human Services. It now includes provisions that would allow Medicaid to pay for abortions in cases of rape and incest (abortions to save the life of the mother are the only ones now allowed under Medicaid) and it would keep the Administration from denying money to family planning clinics that provide information on abortion. The provision on clinics is more likely to survive, and Mr. Bush has threatened a veto if it does.
This is one of several appropriations bills likely to take up most of September in the Senate. Foreign aid may be postponed to keep the issue of loan guarantees from being forced to a vote, but appropriations for the Departments of Defense, Interior and Transportation will come up this month in the Senate. The appropriation for the District of Columbia that was vetoed by Mr. Bush over a provision allowing it to spend its own money on abortions is due for another vote in both chambers without that provision.
Mr. Thomas is not the only major appointment awaiting Senate confirmation. Hearings on Robert Gates's nomination to be the Director of Central Intelligence will begin Sept. 16, with the Intelligence Committee still seeking to determine just what he knew about the Iran-Contra scandal.
Another possibly stormy confirmation will be the Senate Banking Committee's examination of Robert L. Clarke, who is up for a second five-year term as comptroller of the currency beginning Sept. 26. His own investments and his office's supervision of the banking industry are among the issues.
There seems to be little doubt about the confirmation of Alan H. Greenspan to another term as chairman of the Federal Reserve or of William Taylor as chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, but the hearings are likely to develop into examinations of problems of the economy and of the banking and savings and loan industries.
 
Issues of Bank Business
 Legislation on issues of bank ownership and investments and interstate branching will probably reach the floors of both houses this fall. Replenishing the nearly insolvent F.D.I.C. is a major element of the legislation.
The House is expected to deal with broad anticrime legislation, which was passed by the Senate in July. It is also expected to contend with the highway authorization bill that was pulled back from floor action just before the recess when sharp opposition developed to the bill's nickel-a-gallon gasoline tax. The tax will probably be dropped, along with billions of dollars in projects it was intended to pay for, but the bill would still be quite different from the companion measure in the Senate that allows much more flexibility for states to spend "highway" money on mass transit and other projects.
A major civil rights battle is ahead for the Senate sometime this fall. In dealing with a bill that would make it easier to sue and collect damages in job discrimination cases, Administration supporters oppose a compromise effort by Senator John C. Danforth, the Missouri Republican who is also Mr. Thomas's chief sponsor. The Democrats are expected to line up solidly with Mr. Danforth, hoping he can bring enough Republicans with him to override a threatened veto.
And besides the bills that actually get voted on in committees or on the floor, there will be large-scale Democratic efforts to discuss health insurance and health care and tax cuts for the middle class. Some limited health care legislation, intended to make it easier for small businesses to get health insurance coverage, may come to the floor, but most of the discussion of health and taxes will be more political than legislative in purpose.
Capitol Hill generally may regard Mr. Bush as an almost certain winner in his re-election effort, but that is not the contest they care most about. The elections that matter most to them are their own, the balloting for 35 senators and all 435 members of the House.

HEADLINE: For Family Of Builders, Brick Walls

BYLINE: By ANDREW L. YARROW

 BODY:
Joshua and Stephen Muss may not be the closest of cousins, but they do have several things in common. Each is part of a legacy of builders in the New York area, and each feels frustration over separate construction projects planned for Brooklyn.
Joshua, the head of the Muss Development Company, is trying to build a 31-story office building and hotel complex in downtown Brooklyn, while Stephen, the head of Alexander Muss & Sons, has plans for a five-building, 1,600-apartment complex in Brighton Beach. 
 Both projects are stalled despite support from many Brooklyn politicians and community leaders who say the projects are of particular importance to the borough.
The hotel, the leaders say, would be Brooklyn's first in half a century. The apartments, at the site of the Brighton Beach Baths in Brighton Beach, would be the first unsubsidized complex in the borough in about 20 years, they say. Each would help to revitalize a borough that has been seen as in decline for several generations, leaders say.
"Here you have a family long invested in real estate and development in Brooklyn," said Edward T. Rogowsky, the Brooklyn member of the City Planning Commission, "and you have two projects at different ends of the borough -- one commercial and one housing -- and both are symbolic in re-invigorating Brooklyn."
The projects are stalled in part because some real-estate experts and Brooklyn residents question their economic wisdom, as well as the sociological and environmental impact of Stephen Muss's Brighton-by-the-Sea complex. And in part because of the recession.
"A hotel would be a great symbol for Brooklyn," Irwin Fruchtman, a former city Buildings Commissioner, said of Renaissance Plaza, the complex that Joshua plans between Jay and Adams Streets at Myrtle Avenue. "But I can't see that much office space being built when Metrotech is begging for tenants and Manhattan has an 18 percent vacancy rate." Metrotech, a partially completed office complex nearby, was conceived in the 1980's as part of the revitalization of downtown Brooklyn.
Mr. Fruchtman, who is a member of the Committee to Preserve Brighton Beach, which has been opposing the apartment complex for five years, added: "There's no market there for luxury housing. But our main objective is to preserve the open space of the baths, and we want a smaller-scale residential development."
The Musses see things quite differently, of course.
 
Projects Throughout the Country
 "We were born into a building family," said Hyman Muss, who is the only surviving son of Issac Muss, who immigrated from Russia via South Africa 85 years ago.
"My father came to Brooklyn in 1906, and built himself up by his bootstraps," added Hyman, who is Joshua's father. "He made it through the Depression by saying, 'There are always so many children born each year, and they'll always need homes.' "
The Muss family dynasty is not as well-known as other New York families involved in development, like the Trumps, Helmsleys and Zeckendorfs, although Isaac Muss and his descendants have built 120,000 housing units and countless shopping centers and office buildings in New York City and throughout the country.
But building in the New York City of Issac Muss and his sons -- Charles, David, Alexander, Louis and Hyman -- was quite different than building in the New York City of Joshua and Stephen.
Joshua has been planning Renaissance Plaza since 1983, while Stephen has been trying to carry out Brighton-by-the-Sea since his father first envisioned it in 1954. The slow progress on the projects illustrates what many builders say is the undue complexity of the public-review process in New York, which can deter developers from even considering to build in the city.
The Muss family began its building dynasty in Brooklyn, when Issac Muss started building homes in the Brownsville and East New York sections of Brooklyn. Over the last 85 years, the family has built mostly in Brooklyn and Queens, and on Staten Island and Long Island.
Issac Muss's sons collaborated on only one project, though, the Northridge apartments in Jackson Heights, Queens, in the 1950's, and passed on the tradition to just three sons -- Joshua, Stephen (Alexander's son) and another Joshua (David's son), who has been a builder in Illinois and Washington.
A fourth generation of Musses -- Joshua's daughter Robin and son Joseph -- has recently started work at the Muss Development Company's headquarters in Flushing, Queens. While maintaining a Brooklyn office, Stephen Muss followed his father in the 1960's to Miami Beach, where Alexander Muss & Sons is now based.
 
Disappearing Tenants
 Muss Development is also involved with projects in Flushing and on Staten Island, but the company's top priority has long been Renaissance Plaza. The complex, which was conceived in by Joshua and many Brooklyn politicians as a linchpin in the rebirth of downtown Brooklyn, has yet to be built because several prospective tenants have bailed out.
Joshua said he expected the Brooklyn District Attorney to soon sign a lease for about half of the building's 750,000 square feet. If that happens, because the city has already approved the project, it could be completed by late 1993, he said. The building will also include a 380-room Hilton hotel.
"We've had a long, frustrating process trying to convince users to come to Brooklyn," he said, adding that two potential tenants had agreed to lease space in the building, but each pulled out after months of negotiations and planning. Joshua pursued other possible tenants, but settled for the district attorney's office. He would rather have had the insurance company than the District Attorney, the 50-year-old developer said, "but it's almost as important for Brooklyn for the D.A. to function properly as to get a new tenant."
If Joshua has been frustrated and angered by his eight-year ordeal with Renaissance Plaza, Stephen has been even more exasperated.
"In 1954, we leased this land with the dream of building 3,000 apartments," the 63-year-old Stephen said during a recent visit to the site.
Stephen said he decided to revisit that plan after the community began to change with the influx of Russian immigrants and the baths' membership dwindled to barely 2,000 in 1980, from 13,000 in the 1950's.
The plan was eventually scaled back to the current 1,600 apartments to win approval from the community and the city. But it was killed in January 1990, although the Planning Commission voted 3-to-2 in favor of the plan. The project needed four votes to proceed and because there were two vacancies on the commission then, Stephen was unable to garner that deciding vote.
He said he was persuaded this spring by Mayor David N. Dinkins, Howard Golden, the Brooklyn Borough President, and the Planning Commission to re-file a proposal for the project.
The $300-million, luxury apartment complex is currently navigating its way through the approval process, and Stephen said he hoped to begin construction next year and to complete the project by 1995. But he must still overcome opposition from groups that say the project would block public access to the waterfront.
Joshua understands his cousin's feelings.
"The gestation period for building can be so long because of the city-approval process," Joshua said. "So, when you're working with projects that take 20 or 30 years, you wouldn't be able to see them through without more than one generation in the business."

HEADLINE: Ferry Terminal a 'Banal Portal to Joy'

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS

 BODY:
The American Institute of Architects calls it "the world's most banal portal to joy," a squat, pale sea-green hulk that is "a blight on the celebration of arrival and departure at a great city."
The South Ferry terminal of the Staten Island ferry has over the years endured decay, derision and, most recently, the collapse of a development project that would have seen it topped with a 60-story, pink and gray granite and glass tower. 
 A four-alarm fire may now do what all of that had failed to do: replace or remodel what one angry delayed ferry passenger yesterday called "a cavernous urinal" that had fallen on hard times.
"The building has never had much esthetic appeal," said Joseph De Plasco, a City Department of Transportation spokesman. "But it does function."
 
A Cherished Symbol
 The terminal, officially the Whitehall Street Ferry Terminal, represents the beginning or, depending on whom one asks, the end of one of the most recognizable and most cherished symbols of New York City. The ferry, which has existed by name since the 1840's and by fact well before that, shuttles 22 million people each year between the city's most famous borough and the least.
For hardened commuters, the ferry ride is a chugging, shuddering, 20 minutes of oil fumes and boredom, in which the best view is the newsprint held in front of their bleary eyes.
For thousands of wide-eyed tourists, it is a spectacular harbor cruise, taking in Governors Island, Ellis Island and the Statue of Liberty, Brooklyn's waterfront, New Jersey and the stunning Manhattan skyline -- all for about the price of the paper in the commuters' hands.
The original South Ferry terminal and the adjoining Battery Maritime Building, which was undamaged by yesterday's fire, were built in 1907, two years after the city acquired the ferry from the B.&O. Railroad and turned it into the nation's first publicly owned mass-transit system.
The terminal was rebuilt in 1957, using the steel framework of the original, but little else, though the huge waiting room retained parts of the original.
 
An Urban Renewal Plan
 In the mid-1980's, during the height of the downtown real-estate boom, the administration of Mayor Edward I. Koch began to see within the tired terminal the possibility of a lucrative urban renewal project and sought proposals from anyone interested.
In 1986, the city chose a proposal by six developers, headed by William Zeckendorf Jr., for a $384 million commericial and cultural center with a library, a church and a museum. A 60-story tower, topped with a glass dome that would when illumated be a symbolic lighthouse over the harbor, was to have risen above a rebuilt ferry terminal.
But as the economy collapsed, dragging the real-estate market with it, the glowing project, called South Ferry Plaza, foundered. Last January, it died.
The project's failure left the terminal adrift. Mr. De Plasco said that "given the age and the needs of the building" the Transportation Department has considered ways to revive some sort of rehabilitation but has so far found scant interest.
Meanwhile, the ferries have continued to dock and debark, and commuters have grown increasingly irritated by what they see as deteriorating conditions, an increase in the number of homeless people making the terminal their home and talk of a fare increase only a year after the fare doubled to 50 cents.
 
'Lifeline to the City'
 On July 1, the city reduced the ferry service in an effort to save money, but, facing a court order and the wrath of ferry riders, restored it 18 days later.
"It's Staten Islanders' lifeline to the city," Rena Singer, a regular ferry rider, said yesterday, trying to explain the depth of emotion attached to the ferry. "Staten Islanders take this boat very seriously."
Another rider, Sonia Kramer, sardonically suggested that perhaps the fire was not a bad thing. "I hope they take this opportunity to improve both terminals," the 27-year-old passenger said. "I wish the Staten Island side had burned down, because it's in worse shape."
The only possible consolation for those beleaguered commuters is that as long as the ferries use the United States Coast Guard dock in the Battery Maritime Building, the fare will be free.

SECTION: Section A; Page 14; Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 507 words

HEADLINE: Stop Trifling With the Jobless

 BODY:
Almost two million out-of-work Americans have exhausted their unemployment benefits during 1991. For them, the recession, mild by historical standards, is a personal horror. Before adjourning in August, the Democratic leadership pushed a bill through Congress that would extend benefits for as many as 20 additional weeks, depending on a state's unemployment rate.
That might seem a humane response. But the bill was a hoax. Congress refused to raise taxes to pay for the promised benefits, making it impossible to provide the promised relief without violating last year's budget law. The new benefits could be released only if President Bush declared a budget emergency. And Congress knew that Mr. Bush, to his credit, would commit no such chicanery. So the unemployed remain hungry. 
 This tragedy has a simple, honest solution: Upon its return next week, Congress should repass the bill, but this time pay for it with a compensating hike in payroll taxes on higher-paid workers.
A sobering study by Isaac Shapiro of the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities estimates that a record 318,000 jobless Americans exhausted their benefits in July. In past recessions, individuals out of work for more than 26 weeks and living in states with high unemployment rates qualified for up to 13 additional weeks of benefits. During the 1970's and 80's virtually every unemployed worker was made eligible for extended benefits.
But many states, reeling from huge deficits, have recently tightened eligibility standards as a way of pruning expenditures. Mr. Shapiro estimates that only 5 percent of jobless workers whose benefits ran out in July were eligible for extended benefits. That's an appalling statistic.
Opponents of extending benefits raise two arguments, both specious. The first is that a tax hike would worsen the recession, throwing millions more out of work. But the bill wouldn't just raise taxes; it would also raise spending. Taking money out of Joe's pocket and putting it right back into Frank's doesn't diminish private consumption.
Opponents also claim that extending benefits would encourage the unemployed to turn down acceptable job offers, especially if acceptance would mean swallowing a stiff wage cut. This disturbing possibility has driven some economists to propose paying benefits retroactively, after an unemployed worker accepts a job offer. That would encourage the unemployed to find work quickly, even at lower wages, because the benefits would absorb part of the shock.
But a 1988 survey by the Department of Labor showed that 60 percent of the unemployed still did not have jobs even 10 weeks after their benefits ended. Obviously, strong forces other than benefits keep the unemployed from finding work.
Unemployment benefits were once a safety net insulating workers from a stricken economy. But during the past decade, the net has sprung gaping holes. Now Congress can plug the holes without traducing the budget law or the economy. The jobless deserve more than a legislative hoax.

HEADLINE: Candidates Crowd the Field in Primary for Council

 BODY:
MANHATTAN
 
1st DISTRICT
MANUEL S. CAVACO Jr. (D) -- Truck driver, rock musician and artist; Democratic county committee member. 
 MARGARET S. CHIN (D-L) -- Director, Chinatown Center of La Guardia Community College; member of Community Board 1 and State Democratic Committee.
JOHN A.FRATTA (D) -- Youth co-ordinator; member of Community Board 2 and district leader.
KATHRYN E. FREED (D) -- tenant lawyer and Counsel to State Assembly Consumer Affairs and Protection Committee; district leader; endorsed by Council's political action committee.
THE CAMPAIGN: This is one of the most bitterraces in the city, in a lower Manhattan district that has a white plurality but a sizable Asian population. Ms. Chin, trying to become the city's first Asian member of the Council , has been haunted by accusations of Communist affiliation. Her main challenger is Ms. Freed, a longtime TriBeCa resident.
 
2d DISTRICT
MIRIAM FRIEDLANDER (D) -- Council member for 18 years; pressed for creation of Council's Committee on Women, which she leads.
PHILIP K. HOWARD (D) -- lawyer; vice president of Municipal Art Society; former chairman of Community Board 6 zoning committee.
ANTONIO PAGAN (D) -- Executive director of Coalition Housing, nonprofit developer of low- and moderate-income housing; member Community Board 3; active in efforts to clean up Tompkins Square Park.
HYMAN DECHTER (D) -- lost bid for Assembly in 1965; works as a criminal lawyer; political maverick whose strength is based in the predominantly Jewish Grand Street housing projects.
THE CAMPAIGN: The power of money will be put to the test in this district, which stretches from the Lower East Side through Gramercy Park. The Democratic primary pits Ms. Friedlander, a longtime Council member with strong left-wing credentials against two strong opponents. The surprise is the previously unknown Mr. Howard, who has used prodigious fund raising.
 
3d DISTRICT
LIZ J. ABZUG (D) -- Vice president of State Urban Development Corporation; active in feminist and gay issues; member of Community Board 2; endorsed by Mayor David N. Dinkins.
VICTOR A. DEL MASTRO (D) -- high school science teacher; member of Community Board 4; affiliated with Lower East Side Democratic Club.
THOMAS K. DUANE (D) -- Manhattan co-ordinator for City Comptroller Elizabeth Holtzman; former broker; gay-rights advocate.
THE CAMPAIGN: With Mr. Del Mastro a longshot, the winner here is likely to become New York's first openly gay Council member.
 
4th DISTRICT
CAROLYN B. MALONEY (D) -- Council member for 10 years and chairwoman of subcommittee on City Contracts; former teacher.
STEVEN ROSEN (D) -- lawyer; has worked for Ralph Nader's Center for Responsive Law; former chairman of Community Board 6.
THE CAMPAIGN: Ms. Maloney, the veteran, is in a tough primary race in this Upper East Side district. If she survives, she should face a strong challenge in November from David A. Goldstein, a liberal Republican lawyer.
 
5th DISTRICT
CAROL GREITZER (D) -- Five-term Councilwoman; former advertising copywriter; active in women's rights and development issues.

SANDRA A. NEIS (D) President, Roosevelt Island Residents Association; former member of Community School Board 2; Manages Greenmarket on Roosevelt Island.
THE CAMPAIGN: Robert Dryfoos, the powerful veteran here, opened up a vacuum when he dropped out amid investigations of his finances. Ms. Greitzer, who represented the Village until Mr. Dryfoos's departure, is the favorite in the primary, but she, too, should get a tough challenge in November from a liberal Republican, Charles Millard.

But the racial diversity of the 7th -- with a black plurality but large white and Hispanic populations -- is most likely to benefit the white incumbent, Mr. Michels, and make life difficult for his two leading, and sparring, black opponents, the radical Mr. Mason and the more-moderate Ms. Shepard.

A voters' guide yesterday to the primary elections for the New York City Council this week omitted the 13th District in the Bronx. There is no primary in the 13th, where Michael DeMarco is the incumbent. In addition, one of the candidates in the 15th District, Jose L. A voters guide on Monday to the New York City Council elections today incorrectly described Louis Valentino, a candidate in the 38th District in Brooklyn. Mr. Valentino is executive director of the Political Action Fund of Local 1814 of the International Longshoremen's Association. He is not an officer of the local itself, which is a target of Federal civil racketeering charges.

HEADLINE: Careers;
Veterinary Jobs Grow In Variety

BYLINE: By Elizabeth M. Fowler

 BODY:
THERE are two notable trends involving veterinarians these days, according to Franklin M. Loew, dean of the Tufts University School of Veterinary Medicine. There is more interest in veterinarians working abroad and there are a growing number of displaced middle managers choosing to become animal experts.
"I know the international sector is growing," Dr. Loew said last week, explaining that many nations in Eastern Europe need medical help to increase their cattle, pig and other livestock numbers. He called the food situation in the area "a ticking bomb," with time running out for feeding populations this winter. 
 For years the Eastern European nations have been trying to build up their supplies of food animals without too much success to supplement their agricultural products and provide more protein sources for their people.
"My sense is that there wlll be a need for more veterinarians abroad," he said, "perhaps some from this country even though there are 38 veterinary schools in what used to be the U.S.S.R. We have 27 in the United States, plus four in Canada."
He said he did not know about the quality of the Russian training, or whether embarrassment might stand in the way of importing veterinary experts from the United States. Perhaps, he said, some of the major American foundations will support more programs for sending animal experts abroad after some of the current fact-finding groups return.
"There is also growing stress on endangered species of animals, especially in Africa and South America," he added.
In the United States, he said he noticed a continuing trend for more middle-aged people, sometimes those who have lost their jobs in corporate layoffs, to apply for veterinary school at places like Tufts, the University of Pennsylvania, the University of California and Purdue University, to mention a few leading schools.
"This year our class averages 26 years of age," he said, "but ranges from students 21 years old to 40 years old. Sometimes we have older ones. We call the middle-aged ones resumers."
Most of the resumers are women, who now constitute about 60 percent of the 280 students in the Tufts veterinary school.
"That is a trend that is substantially the same at all veterinary schools," Dr. Loew said. "It's a sea change, and I think the main reason is that general societal strictures against women in professions like engineering and law have eased as well as in veterinary medicine."
Veterinary school admissions officers used to argue against women in the field, saying they could not handle large animals like bulls and stallions.
"They never said that to men 4 feet tall," Dr. Loew said, explaining that nowadays tranquillizers can be used on large animals to make handling easier.
"In the early 1980's we had too many veterininarians graduating, Now it is the other way around, and there might not be enough in the the 90's," he said. In the United States, he said, $9 billion is spent on animal food each year, compared with $4 billion to $5 billion on baby food -- one indication of the size of the animal population.
There are about 55,000 veterinarians in the United States, and about 2,200 graduate from veterinary schools each year, compared with 15,000 new medical doctors and 5,000 new dentists. Veterinary training is four years, but there is no residency afterward.
As reasons for the increasing need for veterinarians, he said that in the last decade what he called the moral status of animals had been raised.
"We travel with them, we treat them kindly, we need more dogs perhaps for protection and we have more cats for companionship," the dean said. "It has been the stick of the environmentalists insisting on improving the animal quality of life, and the carrot of much better research into animal health and needs."
Also, many communities have stricter laws about animal welfare and easier acceptance of animals. In Switzerland, for example, dogs are so highly appreciated that they can travel with their masters on trains and buses in some cities and are allowed into restaurants with their masters.
Dr. Loew said that today's students tended to come from urban areas and had quite different concerns about ethical handling of animals and the environmental impact, compared with several decades ago, when most veterinarians were expected to deal with farm animals.
As might be expected, in view of the growing numbers of household animals, the curriculum offered in veterinary schools is changing, with more focus on specialized studies in the senior year, Dr. Loew said. States will probably have to revise general veterinary licensing exams soon, he added.
While the recent economic slide has affected employment of veterinarians somewhat, he thinks job opportunities are good. Today, he said, about 70 percent work in the private sector and 30 percent in research, welfare, teaching, the biotechnology industry and government, as well as for international organizations like the Peace Corps.

HEADLINE: Consumer Credit Down 1.4% in July

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, sept. 9

 BODY:
Consumers continued to pay off more installment debt than they took out in July, the Government said today. It was the seventh decline in consumer credit in eight months.
The Federal Reserve said installment debt dropped 1.4 percent, or a seasonally adjusted $838 million, after revised declines of 2.8 percent in June and 2.2 percent in May. Those declines were reported last month to have been 3 percent in June and 1 percent in May. 
Installment loans have grown this year only in April, a 1.9 percent gain.
Consumer credit includes all consumer loans except mortgages and home-equity debt. It helps to pay for much of consumers' overall spending, which represents two-thirds of the nation's economic activity.
 
Consumers Are Wary
 Many analysts contend that consumers have adopted a wait-and-see attitude toward the economy before committing themselves to more large debts.
For example, automobile loans dropped 3.8 percent in July, or a seasonally adjusted $880 million. Auto loans have fallen every month this year, although the July decline was not as steep as the 8.7 percent drop in June or the 13.9 percent plunge in May.
But revolving credit, which includes credit cards, grew 2.5 percent, or a seasonally adjusted $474 million. That was up from a 2.3 percent increase in June but was less than half the 6.9 percent advance in May.
Bank and credit union loans not secured by real estate were off 1 percent, or $173 million, after falling 1.4 percent in June and 5.3 percent a month earlier.
Mobile home loans, which rose 6.7 percent in June for the first gain in six months, plummeted 15.6 percent, or a seasonally adjusted $259 million.
The changes left consumers holding $729.7 billion in installment debt at the end of July, four-tenths of a percent less than they held a year earlier.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Below 1.70 Marks; New Weakness Is Feared

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The dollar fell below 1.70 German marks yesterday, possibly signaling a new period of weakness for the American currency.
This is the first time the dollar has moved decisively below 1.70 marks since May, and then it only paused in a rally that carried the dollar up 27 percent from 1.44 marks in February to 1.83 in July and again in August. It has now fallen 7 percent from that recent high. 
 "It looks like a decisive break," said Christopher Bourdain, the head of foreign exchange sales at Credit Suisse in New York. He said yesterday that he saw some big dollar owners selling and suggested that the new bearish mood could send the dollar to the mid-1.60's before new developments allow it to rebound or make it fall further.
In late trading in New York yesterday, the dollar closed at 1.6935 marks, down from 1.7145 on Friday and the lowest close since the 1.6940 close on May 28. The dollar also fell against other leading currencies. Against the yen, the dollar closed at 134.62, down from 135.65 Friday.
The factors that have been weighing on the dollar include the sluggishness, so far, of the recovery from recession, the expectation of another cut in short-term interest rates by the Federal Reserve Board and the apparent lack of concern about serious economic and political problems after the failure of the hard-line coup in the Soviet Union last month. A drop in interest rates here makes the dollar and dollar-denominated assets less attractive.
Some analysts also contend that the elimination of the Communist threat from the Soviet Union will make German and other European investments more attractive and divert money from the United States.
The most immediate factor in the dollar's fall was the unemployment report on Friday, which gave another murky signal about the economic recovery. Analysts say the jobs figures will still allow the Federal Reserve room to push down interest rates in its effort to assure that the United States economic recovery does not stumble.
On Friday, the dollar fell after the jobs report, then rallied to around 1.7400 marks. But in the afternoon, when no more buying occurred, many people apparently decided the dollar would rally no further and sold. And suddenly the dollar was down more than two pfennigs to close at 1.7145.
Mr. Bourdain of Credit Suisse said that before yesterday most of the selling was from people or institutions trading in small amounts. And he said that the expectation that the Fed would lower interest rates had been in the market so long that it should already be reflected in the dollar's price.
This means that much of the dollar selling could be what traders call technical. This happens when dollar owners set particular levels, based on recent moves of the dollar, for buying or selling. Because the 1.70 level has been an important level on recent dollar charts, a drop below it set off a lot of automatic selling.
But some traders think that if the Fed does cut interest rates, the dollar could rebound a little, rather than fall further.

HEADLINE: BAKER SEES MEXICO AS A SOVIET MODEL

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Sept. 9

 BODY:
On the eve of a visit to the Soviet Union, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d again praised Mexico today as a model that the United States will urge on other countries facing economic difficulties.
A dozen Cabinet-level American and Mexican officials met here today for their ninth annual round of wide-ranging negotiations. The talks focused on the three-month-old negotiations for a North American free trade agreement between the United States, Mexico and Canada, but no new deals were announced. 
 As senior Administration officials debate whether to help the Soviet Union's foundering economy, Mr. Baker held up for the second time in two days the example of the Administration of President Carlos Salinas de Gortari of Mexico.
"President Salinas's bold economic reform and modernization program is a model for countries both in this hemisphere and other countries around the world, and don't think we're not going to make mention of it as we talk to developing nations and reforming nations undergoing revolutions," Mr. Baker told Mexico's Foreign Minister, Fernando Solana.
"You have successfully reduced inflation, privatized formerly inefficient industries and you have inspired investor confidence," Mr. Baker added.
Mr. Baker told reporters on the flight here from Washington on Sunday that the Salinas Administration had introduced "the kinds of reforms, quite frankly, that we hope we see in the Soviet Union and elsewhere."
In Mexico, however, there are few checks on the power of the central Government. Mr. Salinas and a handful of aides have been able to reduce subsidies and open protected industries to international competition with limited public and corporate opposition.
By contrast, central authority has dwindled in the Soviet Union and with it the ability of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev to impose the kind of sweeping changes that Mr. Salinas has introduced here.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasuries Up in Active Trading

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities rose in fairly active trading, and bond yields fell below 8 percent for the first time since mid-February yesterday, largely on the continued belief among credit market participants that the Federal Reserve Board is on the verge of easing short-term interest rates.
Expectation that the Fed might move quickly to lower its discount rate and the overnight Federal funds rate was fueled by a report from the Labor Department on Friday that showed the job market expanded at a very slow pace in August. Those expectations pushed prices up strongly early in the session. 
 Based on the 34,000 increase in payroll employment reported for August, many analysts said the Fed would probably have to ease interest rates further to shore up what appears to be a hesitant, shaky recovery.
 
No Change in Rates
 The Fed, however, did not satisfy those hopes yesterday. Its open market operations left no question that for the time being the Fed funds rate, which banks charge each other on overnight loans, remains at 5.50 percent, traders said. And the Fed made no announcement that it was lowering its discount rate, which the Fed charges member banks, also 5.50 percent.
Prices fell back somewhat after the Fed did not act.
"I suspect the market will act in much the same manner on Tuesday," said James R. Capra, a principal at Moore Capital Management, a money management firm. "Then, if the Fed doesn't move, I think participants will wait to see the inflation and retail sales numbers later in the week."
Thomas J. Steffanci, director of fixed income at the Fidelity Management and Research Company in Boston, which manages $15 billion in fixed-income securities, said: "I think a Fed ease is imminent. They will probably wait for the inflation numbers, and move then."
On Thursday the Government is expected to release producer price information for August. The report will be followed on Friday by August consumer price data.
"If inflation looks good and the retail sales numbers continue to show weakness, that will provide a window for the Fed to lower the discount rate and the funds rate, and give an insurance policy to the economic recovery," said Lawrence N. Leuzzi, a managing director at S. G. Warburg & Company.
 
Sales Data Due Friday
 Figures from leading chain stores and automobile manufacturers suggest that a report, also expected on Friday, on August retail sales will show that the consumer remains hamstrung.
That sense received some credence yesterday, when it was reported that outstanding consumer credit fell by $838 million in July. The number was close to market expectations, and prompted no reaction in the credit markets.
In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 8 1/8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 were offered late yesterday at a price of 101 1/2, up by a quarter of a point, to yield 7.99 percent, down from 8.01 percent late on Friday. It is the first time the closing yield on the benchmark issue has fallen below 8 percent since mid-February.
Among Treasury note issues, the 7 7/8 percent 10-year notes were offered at 100 3/32, up by 7/32, to yield 7.71 percent. And the 6 3/8 percent two-year notes were offered at 100 11/32, up by 2/32, to yield 6.18 percent.
 
Short-Term Rates Off
 Rates on short-term bills fell at the Treasury's weekly auction.
At the auction, three-month bills were sold at an average discount rate of 5.29 percent, down from an average rate of 5.34 percent at last week's sale.
Meanwhile, bids on the new six-month bills produced an average discount rate of 5.30 percent, compared with an average rate of 5.39 percent a week ago.
"The fact that Treasury bill rates are trading under the discount rate certainly puts the Fed in a position to ease" monetary policy, said Edward S. Hyman, president of International Strategy and Investment, a New York money managment firm.
In the investment-grade corporate bond market, the Private Export Finance Corporation offered $150 million in securities maturing on March 31, 2000, through an underwriting group led by Citicorp Securities Inc.
The 7.90 percent notes were priced at $99.873 to yield 7.92 percent, 38 basis points, or 38 one-hundredths of a percentage point, over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 8 1/4 percent seven-year notes at the time of pricing.
The securities, which are noncallable for life, are rated AAA by Moody's Investors Service Inc. and by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
In the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds, traders said prices of most issues were unchanged to up about an eighth of a point in slow trading.
In the tax-exempt bond market, prices of most widely quoted secondary municipal issues improved by about an eighth of a point, traders said.

HEADLINE: U.S. Credit Union Fund Is Expected to Impose a Premium

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
The heavy losses from credit unions in New England have led Federal regulators to decide that the nation's 13,000 federally insured credit unions should pay about $160 million to their Government-run insurance fund. The payments would be the first made by the industry to the fund since 1985.
When directors of the National Credit Union Share Insurance Fund vote on a premium this Friday, "it's fair to say that the likelihood of an assessment is extremely strong," said Roger W. Jepsen, chairman of the National Credit Union Administration. He is recommending a premium of about 8.3 cents for every $100 of deposits, sharply lower than 23 cents that banks are charged. 
 In a speech yesterday at a conference of credit unions that serve military bases, Mr. Jepsen said the credit union insurance fund was far stronger than the fund for bank deposits. The extra money would maintain the federally backed credit union fund at slightly more than $1.25 of assets for every $100 of insured deposits. Losses over several years to the bank insurance fund operated by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation have reduced the fund covering bank deposits to about 23 cents for every $100 of deposits.
To prevent politicians from questioning the safety of the credit union insurance fund and perhaps consolidating it with the F.D.I.C., Mr. Jepsen recommended that credit union executives pay a premium, even though the fund would remain healthy without the additional money. The content of Mr. Jepsen's speech was obtained from a copy of his remarks and was first quoted in yesterday's issue of the American Banker newspaper.
The addtional financing is needed because the credit union fund expects a shortfall this year of about $40 million, mostly because of $120 million of losses at three credit unions in New England that were heavily involved in commercial real estate lending.
Mr. Jepsen did not name the three credit unions, which are in conservatorship and scheduled to be closed or reorganized soon.
Industry officials said the credit unions that caused the $120 million loss were the Progressive Consumers Federal Credit Union of Saugus, the Blue Hill Federal Credit Union in Brookline and the Barnstable Community Federal Credit Union, all in Massachusetts.
Deposits at the three troubled credit unions, like the other approximatly 13,000 credit unions whose deposits are backed by the National Credit Union Share Insurance Fund, are insured up to $100,000 each.
Since the credit union insurance fund was strengthened by a large industry contribution in 1985, the fund has reported steady earnings yearly with only low losses from payments to depositors of failed credit unions. But the downturn in the New England economy and real estate market and the push by some credit unions to lend for commercial real estate projects are leading to larger losses for the year ending Sept. 30.
The insurance premium, while a noticeable expense to individual credit unions, many of which operate on shoestring budgets, comes when credit unions are solidly profitable.
Credit union profits, which are retained as a capital surplus, totaled $900 million in 1990 and $560 million in the first six months of 1991, up 15 percent from a year earlier.

HEADLINE: SOVIET TURMOIL;
Soviet Forces Begin a Drill In Democracy

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 9

 BODY:
Three weeks after the abortive coup in the Soviet Union, 28 senior Soviet military officers entered Harvard University today for a crash course on how to help build a democracy.
At a news conference and later in interviews, the officers said the Soviet military of the future would be a smaller, professional force free from the Communist Party's control. The central army, the officers said, will work in concert with newly created militias in the former Soviet republics. 
 To help reach these goals and better understand the military's role in a popularly elected government, the officers are studying for two weeks at the Kennedy School of Government at Harvard. The program is one of the first of its kind in the United States for Soviet officers.
 
Added Meaning of Classes
 Their classes -- ranging from the American legal system to arms-control strategies to the future security role of the United States in Europe -- were planned months before the coup attempt and have now taken on an added meaning.
"The military forces of the Soviet Union together with the whole country are now being restructured," said Lieut. Gen. Anany V. Politsyn, a Soviet military planner who is leading the delegation.
Speaking from a lectern in front of a portrait of George Washington, General Politsyn told reporters that the new leadership of the Soviet military was wrestling with democratic changes that would include placing a civilian in charge of the Soviet Defense Ministry, "like in the United States."
Under the restructuring, he said in an interview later, the four-million-member Soviet armed forces could shrink to two million, and perhaps lower, in the next several years, and gradually shift to an all-volunteer force from a conscripted one, as the American military did 18 years ago.
"There will have to be a transition period," the general said.
 
'Very Rigid Measures'
 General Politsyn reiterated earlier statements by other top-ranking Soviet generals that the Soviet Union had taken "very rigid measures" to prevent the unauthorized launch of long-range or short-range nuclear weapons, and that strategic forces would remain under centralized control in the future.
Final details of the Soviet military's future shape and size hinge in large part on the signing of a union treaty, which will give the Soviet republics greater authority over their own armed forces.
Under such an agreement, General Politsyn said, each republic would contribute a mutually agreed-upon number of forces to the central military and muster its own state militia.
"If sovereign republics decide not to join the Soviet Union, they will have the right to maintain their own armed forces," General Politsyn said.
The officer said the republican militias would perform duties similar to those by National Guard units in the United States, which are called up for such tasks as quelling riots and aiding in disasters.
 
Greatest Threat Is Economic
 As the Soviet Union continues to withdraw thousands of tanks, artillery guns and other weaponry from Eastern Europe, General Politsyn said the union treaty should settle where the equipment would finally be deployed.
General Politsyn also said the Soviet Union's greatest national-security threats now stemmed from the country's dire economic woes and political problems at home.
American specialists on the Soviet military have raised myriad questions that officials in Moscow and the Soviet republics are trying to deal with.
What steps can be taken to prevent civil war? What type of future military cooperation can the United States and other Western nations expect from the new Soviet state and its former republics? What happens to the thousands of Soviet political officers who are sure to lose their jobs?
"Members of the military can join whatever party they want now, but their party activity has to be strictly extracurricular," said Col. Vladimir N. Danilov, the deputy director of information for the Soviet Defense Ministry, explaining the effort to depoliticize the military.
 
General Powell's Speech
 Dressed in coats and ties, the delegation also took a walking tour of Harvard Square today and heard from the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, Gen. Colin L. Powell.
"Democracy is not an easy form of government for military professionals," General Powell told the group at a lunchtime speech that was closed to the press. "We will subordinate ourselves totally to the will of the people and their elected representatives."
General Powell said in an interview afterward that he had just written his new Soviet counterpart, Gen. Vladimir Lobov, to reaffirm the American commitment to continuing the two countries' military-to-military exchanges.
Indeed, the head of the Soviet Navy, Adm. Vladimir N. Chernavin is scheduled to visit the United States soon, while the American Air Force Chief of Staff, Gen. Merrill A. McPeak, is to meet with officials in the Soviet Union in the next several weeks.
 
Aspirations for Democracy
 Perhaps the most poignant example of the fledgling Soviet aspirations for democracy came from Col. Vladimir V. Seleznev, a Soviet Army officer who is also a member of the Russian republic's Parliament.
Colonel Seleznev said he was one of about 200 men who had holed up with President Boris N. Yeltsin of the Russian republic in the Russian White House during the coup.
"The Soviet Union is a poor country," said Colonel Seleznev, 42, a former social sciences instructor at a Soviet military academy in Siberia. "It can be wealthy only if it becomes a free country. I want my 14-year-old son to live in a free country."

HEADLINE: MANILA SENATORS SHOW OPPOSITION TO U.S. BASE PACT

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MANILA, Sept. 9

 BODY:
A majority of the Philippine Senate declared its opposition today to a 10-year extension of the American lease on the Subic Bay Naval Station, raising the threat that the United States may soon be forced to withdraw from its largest military installation in Southeast Asia.
Although today's vote was a preliminary one, it was taken seriously in Washington, where Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said, "We obviously can't stay where we're not wanted, and we won't." 
 "It's a choice they have to make," Mr. Cheney added. "If they're not prepared to ratify the treaty and extend the agreement, then we will in fact depart."
 
Outcome Is Unclear
 The Senate's foreign relations committee, made up of all 23 members of the Senate, voted today 12 to 11 against the treaty.
But it was uncertain whether the committee's nonbinding vote and the statements in Washington represented continued diplomatic sparring, or signaled the coming end of the 90-year American presence where thousands of American forces are based.
At one time, because of the need to confront the Soviet Union and China, the American military presence in the Philippines was deemed vital to American strategic interests. But with the changed world situation, the strategic concerns have faded, although Washington professes to want still to keep the Subic base to maintain stability in the Philippines and to protect against unforeseen developments in Asia.
 
Final Vote Yet to Come
Since the 23 senators voted today only as the committee, the formal vote by the Senate is yet to come, possibly as early as the latter part of this week.
Under the Philippine Constitution, the lease extension for Subic would require a two-thirds vote of the Senate -- a margin impossible to imagine if the vote were held today, but perhaps not impossible to obtain several weeks or a year from now. A new Senate will be elected next spring.
President Corazon C. Aquino has called on supporters of the new treaty, which was hammered out this summer between her negotiators and envoys of the United States, to join in a march on the Senate Tuesday to convince the lawmakers of the political risks they face by voting against it.
Commercials broadcast repeatedly on Manila television stations tonight called for a large-scale turnout at the march as a means of "letting the voice of the silent majority be heard."
Late tonight, the Philippine left made its feelings known, as well. About 50 demonstrrators, some wearing death masks, marched outside the United States Embassy and tried to burn an American flag. The police broke up the demonstration, a common sort of protest here. There were no reports of serious injuries.
The protesters' objections to the presence of American bases runs deeper than a demand for more money to extend the leases. Opposition to the bases has spread in recent years from left-wing radicals through the middle-class establishment.
A consensus has emerged that the American military presence is a vestige of colonialism, and that the nation cannot be truly free as long as the American troops remain.
The Philippine Foreign Secretary, Raul Manglapus, the chief negotiator, has repeatedly said the Philippines must "slay the American father image" before it can be a mature nation.
Besides the $203 million in annual payments under the new lease agreement, the Subic naval base is worth additional hundreds of millions of dollars each year to the Philippine economy and thousands of jobs. Public opinion polls suggest that the majority of Filipinos support the new treaty, even if some of the nation's most prominent politicians and intellectuals do not.
American officials have taken the position that they could accept rejection of the treaty and were ready to consider establishing an installation in Singapore or other more hospitable places. But officials in Washington also say they hope that they can keep the extensive, deep-water harbor at Subic Bay, with its accompanying Naval Air Station.
 
Huge Cost of Moving
 The cost of moving would be huge, and Subic Bay possesses one of the most highly skilled local work forces in the world. They are paid considerably less than comparable workers in the United States or Guam, another possible substitute base.
The Senate foreign relations committee made its opposition to the treaty known today in the form of a resolution describing the new lease on Subic as "a one-sided, unequal agreement that does not provide for reciprocal rights" and that tends to perpetuate "Philippine dependence on the United States for defense and security."
After the vote today, the Senate President, Jovito Salonga, said, "For all practical purposes, the treaty is defeated."
Yet while the base agreement would now appear to fall far short of the required two-thirds vote, it is believed in some political and diplomatic circles that it will eventually be approved in one form or another, and that the 7,000 Americans now assigned to Subic will be allowed to remain.
 
One-Year Grace Period
 Although the current lease agreement for the sprawling base runs out next Monday, the United States could invoke a clause permitting Americans to remain at Subic for another year, allowing time to reach a new agreement on the base.
In a televised address to the nation, Mrs. Aquino -- whose term ends next year and who appears ready to make ratification of the base agreement the last great battle of her administration -- declared that it would be "ill-advised, even foolish," for the Senate to reject the treaty.
Under the base agreement, the United States will pay the Philippines $203 million annually for a 10-year extension on the lease for Subic, a huge repair and logistics center for the United States Seventh Fleet.
The United States is now in the process of abandoning Clark Air Base, the other major American military installation in the Philippines, after it was smothered by volcanic ash released in the eruption in June of Mount Pinatubo.

HEADLINE: Business Scene;
The Annual Game Of Auto Pricing

BYLINE: By Louis Uchitelle

 BODY:
THE 1992 model cars go on sale this month, and in advance of their debuts, the auto manufacturers have been announcing hefty price increases. The increases amount to 3 to 4 percent for the average car, and more -- sometimes much more -- if a car is redesigned, as the Ford Taurus or the Toyota Camry have been, or is equipped with costly new devices, like the driver-side air bags in the 1992 Honda Accord.
On the face of it, such increases in a car's list, or sticker, price are likely to discourage many Americans from buying 1992 models at a moment when the national economy is weak and people are nervous about job security. Given this reluctance to spend, the laws of supply and demand suggest that prices should fall, or at least not rise, if the industry is to sell all of the 1992 cars soon to be made. But the auto companies -- American and Japanese alike -- do not easily give ground on prices. 
 "People say, 'How in the world can you raise prices when your sales are down and times are tough?' " said Joel Pitcoff, manager of research and analysis at Ford. "But there is a fundamental philosophical issue here. If manufacturing costs go up, as they have, you must at least raise the list prices to try to cover the higher costs."
And then comes the caveat that has undercut sticker price increases since the mid-1980's. Remember, Mr. Pitcoff says, "we are talking about list prices that no one ends up paying."
So why not forgo the announced sticker price increases and sell 1992 cars at 1991 prices? The answer from the industry is that survival is at stake. Ford, General Motors and Chrysler have lost tens of millions of dollars in recent months, and the Japanese manufacturers are also watching their profits shrink or disappear. Higher stickerprices, however unrealistic they may turn out to be, are nevertheless, as Mr. Pitcoff suggests, the industry's main hope of becoming profitable again.
The goal, of course, is to sell cars for as close to sticker prices as possible. But in these times of reluctant consumers, at least half of the increase in sticker prices is likely to be given back through sales incentives intended to lure buyers and hold on to market share. These incentives include such things as cash rebates from manufacturers, an artificially high trade-in allowance on the old family car and smaller margins for car dealers.
Not all car makers and dealers offer the same givebacks. Japanese auto makers that are gaining market share are less likely to give ground than the Americans. A Honda is under less pressure to return some of its announced sticker price increases than a General Motors, which has lost customers. But taking all the companies into account, what Americans actually end up paying for 1992 cars will, on average, probably be less than 2 percent above the average price for 1991 models, many experts say. And that modest rise has been roughly the annual increase since 1988.
Even so, cars are expensive: more than $16,300 apiece, on average, representing half a year's earnings for an American consumer with a median family income. That is a daunting outlay for many Americans and a major reason the auto companies find themselves stuck with givebacks.
"They raise sticker prices to give themselves room for rebates, but they don't seem to understand the damaging psychological impact of an announced price increase," said Thomas O'Grady, president of Integrated Automotive Resources Inc., an industry consulting firm.
Still, the auto companies and their dealers think that with a little luck, 1992 might turn out to be better than usual for price increases. Many Americans, for example, are driving six-year-old cars, purchased in 1985, a big year for sales. The owners are eager to replace these aging vehicles before they break down, says Ronald Glantz, an auto analyst at Dean Witter Reynolds. If a recovery from the recession materializes, they might even be willing to pay close to the new sticker prices, or so the industry hopes.
What's more, the recession has kept many lower-income people on the sidelines. The average buyer is more affluent, more willing to pay a bit more for a car, says Terry Sullivan, a General Motors spokesman. "Price increases are possible with low sales volume, and, with fewer unsold cars in inventory these days, you don't have to be as generous in your negotiations," he said.
But too few sales, even if all are at the higher sticker prices, also wipe out profits. That has been the danger for Frank Anderson Jr., president of the National Automobile Dealers Association and owner of Sir Walter Chevy in Raleigh, N.C. He says his dealership must sell 100 vehicles a month -- new and used -- to break even. Lately, sales have fallen to as low as 110 a month from more than 200 in good years. To keep above the 100 mark, Mr. Anderson has trimmed his dealer's profit to give back some of the sticker price.
Auto manufacturers are similarly afflicted by declining volume. As Mr. Glantz puts it: "All it takes is one company saying, 'Oh, gee, we want to keep the factory running, so let's offer rebates.' One does it and the others soon say, 'We'll offer incentives, too.' "

HEADLINE: Chip Indicator Off in Month

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 9

 BODY:
Seasonally weak economic activity in the United States electronics industry caused the semiconductor industry's leading indicator to fall for the fourth straight month in August, a trade group said today.
The organization, the Semiconductor Industry Association, based in San Jose, Calif., reported a book-to-bill ratio of 0.94 for the three-month period that ended in August, down from 0.96 in July, and from a revised figure of 1.01 in June. 
 The ratio compares orders with shipments and is considered a leading indicator of the industry's performance. A ratio of 0.94 indicates that for every $100 worth of product shipped, $94 was ordered, indicating that demand had declined.
At $1.21 billion, three-month orders for August were down 2.5 percent from $1.24 billion for the period ending in July, and 1.2 percent lower than the comparable figure for a year ago, which was $1.22 billion.
Three-month average shipments for August totaled $1.28 billion, down six-tenths of a percent from July. At $1.24 billion, actual United States market shipments for August were up nine-tenths of a percent from $1.18 billion in July.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
A.T.& T. In Link to Armenia

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ

 BODY:
In a step that could provide a model for modernizing telephone communications throughout the technologically backward Soviet Union, A.T.& T. next month plans to provide long-distance service directly to Armenia, a first for a Soviet republic. Like the rest of the Soviet Union, Armenia has received its few calls through the scarce and sternly monitored lines funneling through Moscow.
But Moscow itself is able to receive fewer calls through normal telephone channels than a medium-size Manhattan apartment building, or 91 simultaneous conversations. And even that is a sharp increase from as few as 16 simultaneous calls as recently as 1987. The Communist Party kept telecommunications primitive as a means of political control. Some switching equipment, essential for completing a call, dates to before the 1917 Revolution.
 
First Direct Dialing
 The American Telephone and Telegraph Company in mid-October will provide 200 new long-distance circuits into Armenia using A.T.& T.'s flagship 5 ESS digital switching system. That would make direct-dial calls possible for the first time. Calls today go through a central operator in Moscow and can take three days or more to complete. 
 The new circuitry, a result of an accord negotiated last year, patches calls through Intelsat, a satellite network run by a Western consortium. It can be expanded over the next few years to make as many as 500 simultaneous conversations possible.
Armenian-Americans, the largest group of Armenian heritage outside Armenia, are pleased with the move. "We are absolutely elated," said Ross Vartian, executive director of the Armenian Assembly of America, a lobbying group in Washington.
 
Circuits Overloaded
 The Armenian venture, however, still makes little headway in the enormous problems confronting the Soviet Union's telephone system. Last month, during the turbulent days of the coup, circuits from the United States into Moscow were routinely flooded. Last week, with phone traffic subsiding, as many as 13,000 calls were tried every hour from the United States, A.T.& T. said.
To comfortably handle normal phone volume into the Soviet Union, A.T.& T. figures it would need enough capacity for 2,300 calls. Because of the shortage of capacity, businesses, news publications and others must often rely on expensive satellite communications that can cost $18 or more a minute. A.T.& T. service, while scarce, costs $1.70 to $2.25 a minute. Rates for the new Armenian service have not been determined yet.
If the A.T.& T. venture is successful, it could well provide a model for expanding modern phone service into the other republics that, like Armenia, have either declared or are leaning toward independence.
While the A.T.& T. deal with Armenia is structured as a joint venture, it involves only a small outlay by Armenia of scarce hard currency. Much of the $6 million expense will be borne by A.T.& T. and by American consumers paying for calls into the republic. A.T.& T., as well as other companies like United Telecommunications Inc.'s U S Sprint, say such ventures will pay off in the long run as the flagging economies of the Soviet republics eventually revive.
"It's an incredible breakthrough," said Paul G. Quinlan, A.T.& T.'s managing director of the European region, including the Soviet Union. A.T.& T. officials were worried that the recent coup might undo more than a year's worth of negotiations, but say now that the coup's failure will make possible Armenia-style arrangements with other republics.
"The situation is fluid, but we're very hopeful about our talks with a number of other republics," Mr. Quinlan said. He would not be more specific.
U S Sprint's international division had also bid for service to Armenia, but acknowledged it was at least a month behind in putting together a full proposal. "A.T.& T. beat us to the punch," said Philip M. Walker, U S Sprint's vice president of international affairs. "But there's more than enough work to go around."
Armenia has the second-busiest international phone traffic in the Soviet Union after Moscow, largely because so many Armenians live outside Armenia. A republic of 3.6 million people, 1.7 million Armenians live elsewhere in the Soviet Union or abroad because of ethnic massacres by Ottoman Turks dating to before the turn of the century.
 
Tangle During Earthquake
 Some one million ethnic Armenians live in the United States. When a devastating earthquake in 1988 killed or made homeless one out of seven Armenians, the lack of long-distance lines tangled emergency relief.
Moscow may have agreed to Armenia's independent phone service as a way of relieving congestion into Moscow. Moreover, the central Government's inability to deal with the earthquake's continuing devastation may have played a role. With improved telecommunications, Armenia is in a better position to lobby for international aid.
"Soviet telecommunications today is like the United States in the 1920's," said Mariam Nigohosian, an Armenian-speaking A.T.& T. official who helped negotiate the deal. She had previously worked with Soviet officials for three years on improving phone service in Moscow.
In August 1990, Armenia began the process of declaring independence by changing its name to the Republic of Armenia from the Armenian Soviet Socialist Republic. On Sept. 21, it plans to hold a referendum in which voters can decide whether the republic should stay within the Soviet Union.
In Leningrad, now to be known officially as St. Petersburg, U S West Inc. announced yesterday the beginning of cellular telephone service to about 750 subscribers.

HEADLINE: Dow Off 4.47, to 3,007.16, in Quiet Trading

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Stock prices fell slightly yesterday in sleepy trading, with many investors absent in observance of Rosh ha-Shanah. Smaller stocks showed gains, but over all the market was sluggish, weighed down mainly by the blue chips.
The Dow Jones industrial average drifted 4.47 points lower to close at 3,007.16. The bond market's firmness helped stocks trim some of their early modest declines. Some traders thought the market would be susceptible to futures-related program trades, but that did not materialze. 
 Big Board volume was 115.1 million shares, down from 167.5 million on Friday. It was the lowest trading level since Friday, July 5, when volume was 69.9 million. Declining issues outnumbered gainers by 803 to 732.
The New York Stock Exchange composite index slipped 0.37 point, to 213.4, while the Standard & Poor's index of 500 mostly blue-chip stocks was down 0.53 point, to 388.57.
On the American Stock Exchange, the composite index fell by 0.64, to 369.06, while the over-the-counter composite index, representing the small issues, rose by 1.13, to 518.07.
 
Lower Blue Chips
 Blue chips were under pressure throughout most of yesterday, trading lower despite a rise in bond prices. Bond traders, hopeful for an easing of interest rates by the Federal Reserve, pushed prices up, and the rate on long bonds dropped below 8 percent.
Robert C. Walberg, equity analyst at MMS International, said the stock market was awaiting a signal, either in the form of a Fed easing or a series of strong economic reports. "Until then, we may experience a modest correction, with the Dow slipping to 2,910 at the bottom," he said.
Within the last two weeks, Mr. Walberg said, there has been a decoupling of the stock and bond markets as investors shifted their focus from interest rates to company earnings.
"Steady declines in bond yields will prop up stocks," he said, "and prevent a sizable correction, unless of course the economy is much weaker than expected and company earnings have a difficult time coming back." And if a correction should come as a result of a weaker economy and softer earnings, it could be in the 5 to 10 percent range, Mr. Walberg added, although he said he did not think that would happen.
 
Gain for I.B.M.
 I.B.M., which expects to announce several products this week, rose 1 5/8, to 101. The company was also helped by reports that it would enter a second joint venture with Apple Computer. Apple gained 1 3/4, to 53 1/4.
Ameritrust fell 1/2, to 28, as analysts reported rumors that the company's board had met, or would meet, to consider possible bids for the company.
Nevada Power fell 1 3/8, to 17 7/8, as the company announced that the Nevada Public Service Commission had recommended that Nevada Power cut rates by $4.6 million annually. The utility had requested a $37.6 million rate increase.
NCR, which reported a poor earnings outlook, dropped 1 7/8, to 107 3/4. In its merger talks with A.T.& T., which fell 5/8, to 38 1/8, NCR estimated 1991 net of $386 million on revenues of $6.62 billion, both higher than 1990. The company now says the 1991 results will be lower than that projection. NCR shareholders are to vote on the proposed merger with A.T.& T. this Friday.
Volume in the three most-active stocks -- Salomon, the Limited and Pepsico -- was about two million shares each.
Salomon rose 1/4, to 24 1/4, despite news that the Federal Bureau of Investigation had entered the investigation of possible trading violations by the firm.
The Limited, a retailer, slipped by 1/8, to 24 3/4, while Pepsico gained 3/4, to 29 3/4. Both issues have been rebounding from earlier declines.
U.S. Healthcare fell 2 1/8, to 22 1/4, as Peter Grua, an Alex. Brown & Sons analyst, lowered his recommendation to neutral from a buy.

International

HEADLINE: Hoboken-Newark Rail Link Opens as Part of Multimillion-Dollar Expansion

BYLINE: By ROBERT HANLEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HOBOKEN, N.J., Sept. 9

 BODY:
Four trains carried 498 rush-hour passengers over $16 million worth of new rail line between Newark and Hoboken this morning, in the first phase of a $500 million plan to expand rail access in New Jersey to the Hudson River waterfront and midtown Manhattan.
The new commuting option, called the Waterfront Connection, is the first extension of train service in northern New Jersey since 1967. Officials of N.J. Transit, the state's mass-transit agency, said the multimillion-dollar price tag for the entire expansion project, which will connect New Jersey's 12 commuter train lines over the next decade, was justified on grounds including economic expansion, urban revitalization and the possibility of reducing the use of cars, cutting polluting emissions and improving air quality. 
 "Railroad expansion projects are cost intensive," said Rose Sheridan, a spokeswoman for N.J. Transit. "We view these projects as a commitment to the future of the waterfront area and as a catalyst for more economic development there." The waterfront attracted hundreds of millions of dollars in development in the 1980's.
This morning's four rush-hour trains attracted a ridership two shy of N.J. Transit's first-year goal of 500 rush-hour passengers, said Sandra Check, a spokeswoman for the agency. Officials expect that 1,400 passengers will ride the new service daily each way by the end of the third year.
 
Increased Connections
 By 1995, the expansion is to include a new $61 million link that will give residents from Morris, Essex, Passaic and Somerset Counties a direct route to Pennsylvania Station in Manhattan. And by the time the project is finished, around the turn of the century, it is to provide a new $400 million terminal and track system in Secaucus, near the Meadowlands, that will for the first time allow passengers from Bergen, Hudson and Passaic Counties in New Jersey and Rockland and Orange Counties in New York to travel directly to midtown Manhattan, to Newark or to points south and west in the state.
Financing for the project is to come primarily from New Jersey's Transportation Trust Fund, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey and the Federal Department of Transportation.
The new Hoboken-Newark service provides a second rail route, in addition to existing PATH trains, to New Jersey's Hudson waterfront for residents from the New Jersey shore, the Trenton-Princeton region and Somerset, Union, and Middlesex Counties.
The bulk of the $16 million for the project was used to buy and install 4,000 feet of new track and new electrical signals and track switches. The project links two track systems: the Amtrak-N.J. Transit line between Newark's Penn Station and Manhattan's Pennsylvania Station, and a Morris and Essex Line that terminates in Hoboken. New Jersey's Transportation Trust Fund and the Port Authority each paid $8 million, officials said.
Twelve trains will run daily, including four each in the morning and evening rush hours. They provide direct Newark-Hoboken service for riders on the North Jersey Coast Line, which serves Ocean, Monmouth and Middlesex Counties. In addition, riders on the Northeast Corridor line that serves the Princeton region and the Raritan Valley line that runs through Hunterdon, Somerset and Union Counties can switch trains in Newark for Hoboken.
Richard O'Day, a 24-year-old employee of the corporate banking section of Credit Suisse on Wall Street, was on the 7:54 from Newark this morning for the 19-minute run to Hoboken. Normally he switches at Newark to the PATH train for the World Trade Center.
"It seems like this might be a little quicker," Mr. O'Day said. "It'll certainly be more convenient than getting on PATH and standing all the way and getting squeezed at every stop."
At the Hoboken train terminal, Mr. O'Day took the ferry that has been operating to the World Financial Center in Battery Park City on weekday rush hours since October 1989.
Later, he reported that he got to work at 8:55, about 15 minutes later than most mornings.
"Maybe it was slow for the first day, but it was a nice trip," Mr. O'Day said. "I'm probably going to take it again, probably toward the end of next week."
