HEADLINE: Dinkins's Trip to Africa: Who Will Pay?

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
With an entourage of several dozen city officials and black business people in tow, Mayor David N. Dinkins is to leave the daily maelstrom of New York on Monday for a whirlwind tour through even more turbulent precincts: the cities and black townships of South Africa.
But less than a week before the delegation's scheduled departure, city officials have yet to say just how or from whom they will raise the $400,000 needed for the trip, which the Mayor has said would be paid for by private contributions. Last night, some mayoral aides said the fundraising was far behind pace and expressed concern about whether enough can be raised in time. 
 The Mayor's press secretary, Leland T. Jones, said yesterday that not all the money had been raised, but that he did not know how much had been. He said names of the donors would be made public eventually. Mr. Dinkins said last week that he and his wife, Joyce, would not contribute anything.
Mayoral aides have billed the trip as an effort to foster cultural and economic ties between New York and whatever post-apartheid regime emerges in South Africa, and to lend support to the black majority there. But it is also shaping up as a hectic weeklong ramble, part sentimental journey, part pep rally for the African National Congress, whose leader, Nelson Mandela, was given a triumphal welcome by the Mayor in New York last year.
The group, including the city's health and finance commissioners, the Dinkins family's Episcopal parish priest, the president of the Board of Education and the Mayor's official photographer, will fly by chartered plane to Johannesburg, Durban and Cape Town, with a brief stopover in Rome for a papal audience on the way and a night in Lagos, Nigeria, on the way home.
The city has been active in pressing sanctions against companies that do business with South Africa, and in using its pension fund investments to prod American companies to divest themselves of their holdings there. As the first black mayor of the nation's largest city, he has approached the trip with great anticipation and emotion.
"Aside from sort of going to the homeland aspect of it, that clearly is an aspect," he said yesterday. "But also in South Africa, we have the only legalized form of white supremacy in the world. It is immoral, and to be able to visit South Africa and be of some assistance in the general situation, and to help ease the transition when freedom really comes to South Africa is a tremendously satisfying thought, to be some small part of it."
Mr. Dinkins said he also hoped to meet with President F. W. deKlerk and with Chief Mangosuthu Gatsha Buthelezi of the Inkatha Freedom Party, the Zulu-based archrival of Mr. Mandela's A.N.C. Over the weekend, renewed factional fighting among blacks killed more than 40 people. But the Mayor made it clear where his sympathies lay, and said a Congressional representative would be with him wherever he went "so that there will not be any misunderstanding of what my posture is."
New York has long practiced foreign policy, and former Mayor Edward I. Koch took official or quasi-official jaunts to Japan, Ireland, China and Nicaragua, financed by both the city and private groups. But in recent days, even some of the Dinkins aides who scrambled for the ultimate expression of their boss's favor -- an invitation -- have quietly acknowledged concern at how elaborate this trip has grown, at a time when the city is facing so many problems of its own.
"It's a big list, a big list," said one aide, who spoke on condition of anonymity. The one cost the city will pay is for the Mayor's bodyguards. No one will say how many are going (since that would breach security). The charter airfare alone is $6,000 a person.
The delegation has been divided into teams, in fields from education and health, to business development and religion, and has produced some strange bedfellows. For example, the Rev. Herbert Daughtry, the fiery Pentecostal minister who has been at the center of a number of racially charged cases in recent years, will team with the Rev. Canon Frederick Williams, the staid rector of the Church of the Intercession, the Dinkins family church in upper Manhattan.
Other members of his delegation conceded that their friends had asked them some skeptical questions, but they defended the trip as important.
 
Raising Money
 "I've gotten a fair amount of it myself," said Vincent McGee, the executive director of the Aaron Diamond Foundation, who is paying his own way because the foundation supports only New York institutions.
H. Carl McCall, a vice president at Citibank and the President of the Board of Education, said: "I know we've got our own problems. I think if the Mayor were to go to Jersey City tomorrow, people would ask why. But I think it's an appropriate part of his responsibility."
The administration is raising money through the New York City Business Assistance Corporation, a nonprofit city-run corporation that has raised private money to finance other efforts, including the ticker-tape parade for veterans of the Persian Gulf war and Mr. Dinkins's "Urban Summit" meeting of big city mayors last year.
The City Charter bars officials from accepting gifts from people who do business with the city, and some civic groups have questioned whether it is appropriate for the Mayor to finance the trip this way. But past rulings from the city's Conflicts of Interest Board have found that soliciting money from private parties through the Business Assistance Corporation did not constitute a conflict.
"We will make the list of major donors public," said Mr. Jones, the mayoral spokesman. "We operate in the full light of day."
At least one member of the delegation said he was not only paying his own way, but trying to persuade friends to contribute too. Lee Dunham, the head of the Harlem McDonald's Group, which owns eight of the fast-food restaurants with 625 employees, many of them black youths, said he wanted to scout out the possibilities of bringing the Big Mac to South Africa.

HEADLINE: Where Sununu Stands

 BODY:
TO John H. Sununu, Chief of Staff to President Bush and the person who is by all accounts the single individual most responsible for the United States's wait-and-see stance on global warming, the question is a straightforward one of economic growth versus an unproven environmental threat.
And he suggests that the drive to put a cap on carbon dioxide emissions, a byproduct of growth that many scientists fear will cause the earth's climate to warm, is the latest vehicle adopted by a perennial "no-growth" movement whose roots go back at least to the early 1970's. 
 The Administration argues that when all heat-trapping atmospheric gases are taken into account, rather than just carbon dioxide by itself, actions already taken by the United States will stabilize its total contribution to the potential for global warming at 1990 levels in the year 2000. But European governments, and virtually all American environmentalists, advocate targets for capping carbon dioxide emissions separately.
This focus on carbon dioxide alone, Mr. Sununu said in an interview, "increases skepticism that some people are less concerned about climate change and more concerned about establishing an anti-growth policy." Such people "keep finding surrogates for no-growth," he said.
As Governor of New Hampshire before he became the President's Chief of Staff, Mr. Sununu gained a reputation as favoring economic growth over environmental regulation.
On global warming, he said that the Administration had "a very strong commitment toward making sure we develop a superior understanding of the reality of global climate change" before making "either national or international decisions that are multi-trillion dollar decisions in terms of impacts on the economy and jobs."
A particular concern of his, he said, is that the mathematical models that predict global warming are unrealistic and have led to assessments that are "either incomplete or inconclusive." The Administration's basic concern, he said, is that "when we do implement policies they are based on fact rather than perhaps on not-so-solid assumptions."

HEADLINE: Economic Pulse: The Southeast -- A Special Report.;
Reminders of Its Old Poverty Hit South in Recession's Grip

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SPARTANBURG, S.C.

 BODY:
It is about 70 miles from Spartanburg to Great Falls, but the distance between these South Carolina towns is the difference between the Southeast's future and its past. Spartanburg has been able to replace lost textile jobs; Great Falls has not.
Spartanburg and the neighboring communities along the Interstate 85 corridor in the northwest corner of the state are now home to companies like Michelin, Mita and Hoechst Celanese. The area boasts one of the largest concentrations of foreign manufacturing companies in the United States. 
 In contrast, Great Falls has long been a one-company town. In the 1980's, that company, J. P. Stevens, closed its three textile mills in Great Falls, eliminating 1,600 jobs in a town of 2,600 people.
 
Reminder in Recession
 "The South is still a split-level economy," said Wayne Gantt, chief economist with Interstate/Johnson Lane, an investment company in Charlotte, N.C. "When you get the upturn, you see the beauty of the New South. When you get a downturn, you sometimes see the problems of the Old South. Fortunately, the patina that's lasting and working is that the bulk of the economy is really in the New South."
After decades of outpacing the nation in economic growth, the Southeast now finds itself growing at about the national rate. The current recession has provided a chilly reminder of how close the faltering economies of the Old South are to the dynamic economies of the New.
The recession has bruised some of the South's highest fliers, like Atlanta and Charlotte, which had come to expect uninterrupted prosperity. And with the downturn has come an insistent message: The low-wage, low-skill businesses that built much of the modern South can no longer deliver prosperity in a world where the low-skill jobs once done in Great Falls can be done more cheaply in Taiwan or Mexico.
There is no perfect definition for "the South" -- indeed, the southernmost state of all, Florida, has such a huge and distinctive economy that it hardly seems part of the region. But the six other states clustered in the southeastern corner of the country -- North Carolina, South Carolina, Georgia, Tennessee, Mississippi and Alabama -- share enough economic characteristics that regional trends emerge.
Most experts expect the economies of these six states to outpace the rest of the nation in economic growth over the next decade or so. But to do that, they say, two things must happen.
First, these states will have to bridge some of the gap between prosperous metropolitan areas and the small rural towns, many of them desperately poor, that have been left behind. Second, they will have to upgrade their lagging school systems to insure that the work force has the skills employers will be looking for in the 21st century.
Many of the region's historic business advantages -- low labor and living costs, a pro-business, anti-union environment and a good quality of life -- still remain, if in a somewhat diminished form, as the Southeast's economy becomes more like the nation's. But now the region must contend with an era when employers need more than cheap, unskilled labor.
"Until the 1970's, our economy really was based on a low-skill work force; then all of a sudden the earth plates of economic life in the world shifted," said Jesse L. White Jr., an economic development consultant in Chapel Hill, N.C., and former executive director of the Southern Growth Policies Board. "All of a sudden, workers had to be skilled, they had to be flexible and our work force was completely ill equipped because we hadn't really educated them. So our human capital base was our most impoverished. That's what we're trying to overcome, and we've still got a long way to go."
 
Growth
Outsiders Supplant Regional Traditions
 The rebirth of the Southeast is most often depicted in terms of its biggest cities. There is Atlanta, where the metropolitan area grew by 600,000 persons to slightly more than 2 million in the 1980's; Charlotte, now one of the nation's banking centers, and Birmingham, once a symbol of racial division and the South's isolation from the nation, and now dominated by the medical and educational complex of the University of Alabama at Birmingham.
But the picture may be more stark in less glamorous places like Greenville and Spartanburg, once the heart of the textile industry in the Carolinas. In the 1950's, textiles accounted for 86 percent of Spartanburg's jobs, and Greenville was billed as the Textile Capital of the World. Now, textiles employ only 41 percent of workers in Spartanburg, and people in Greenville and Spartanburg are more eager to talk about international companies locating there than they are about the still-formidable textile base.
"We're not into Japan bashing here in Greenville," said Richard S. Kadzis, a spokesman for the Greater Greenville Chamber of Commerce as he stopped by a $50 million plant under construction for Mita Inc., a giant of the copying industry. Greenville, where the metropolitan area has grown from 414,000 in 1960 to 650,000 now, has an unemployment rate of 5.1 percent, the lowest in South Carolina. "In fact, all the international firms create a natural environment that encourages Asians to move in," Mr. Kadzis said.
Some defunct textile plants have been recycled for other uses, like the one that now makes all the tennis balls sold by Wilson Sporting Goods, which is now owned by a Finnish corporation.
 
A New Economic World
 What is most striking about the economy of the Southeast is that, despite the fierce attachment to the culture of the past, most of the economic bright spots reflect an utterly new economic world.
Few of the traditional industries that built the South -- tobacco in Durham, textiles in Greenville, steel in Birmingham, shipping in Mobile, cotton in the Mississippi Delta -- have figured significantly in its resurgence.
Instead, there is the new Nations Bank in Charlotte helping lead the nationwide consolidation in the banking industry; the service-driven econonomy of Atlanta; the high-tech corridors of the Research Triangle in North Carolina or in northern Alabama around Decatur and Huntsville; the modern automobile manufacturing plants run by Nissan and General Motors' Saturn division in Tennessee.
Much of the growth, as can be seen here, is fueled by foreign investment drawn to places like Dothan, Ala., or Columbus, Ga., by the Southeast's non-union work force and access to both the East Coast and and important American markets. In 1989, for example, South Carolina led the nation in per capita foreign investment.
 
No Sneers for Overseas
 Thus, Atlanta's snaring of the 1996 Summer Olympics has more to do with economics than with sports.
"Foreign investment is probably the biggest positive investment trend we have in the South," said Prof. Donald Ratajczak of Georgia State University in Atlanta. "In the Midwest, they kind of sneer at foreigners. In the Northeast, they kind of ignore them. We kind of love them. We've been geared at trying to bring in development for so long, so what if the guy coming in is Japanese or German?"
For optimists, those gains are part of a pervasive, long-term upward trend that is seeing the nation's population inexorably move south, with the Southeast's metropolitan areas the greatest beneficiaries. In the 1980's, all the Southern states except Mississippi rose in their rankings among the 50 states for per capita income.
North Carolina rose from 44th to 35th, Georgia from 38th to 30th, South Carolina from 48th to 42d. Mississippi, 50th in 1980, was still 50th in 1990.
"I run a workshop for newcomers to the South," said David R. Goldfield, a historian and expert on Southern cities at the University of North Carolina at Charlotte. "The one comment I always get is that life is so much easier here than in New Jersey or Michigan or wherever they came from. You don't have to fight the climate, you don't have to fight the people, you don't have to fight the traffic as much as in other parts of the country. You're going to continue to get that migration, and that's very important for the economy of the metropolitan South."
 
Poverty
A Dazzling Sun But Deep Shadows
 It is a measure of how far the South has come that people most often think of it now in terms of economic prosperity rather than the economic backwater it used to be.
But in vast bands of poverty like the Mississippi Delta or stretches of the South Carolina low country, and just off the interstates in the sagging mill towns of the Carolinas, the past lives.
Thus, while Spartanburg and Greenville prosper, the old mill towns nearby, with simple frame houses spreading outward from brick factories in the center of town, are trying to reinvent themselves.
Many, like Great Falls in Chester County, are still trying to recover from the recession of the early 1980's. After three mills closed in the past year and a half in the county seat of Chester, unemployment in the county stood at 15.3 percent, highest in South Carolina.
The dislocation is part of a structural change slowly making its way through the South -- a shift away from the low-wage, labor-intensive manufacturing that once defined the region but now cannot compete with workers in Taiwan, Singapore or Mexico.
 
What's Left to Close?
 "You always thought that something that was here for so long could never close down, but it did, and there's not much left here to close anymore," said Randy Campbell, as he gazed at the deserted shell of the last of the three J. P. Stevens textile mills to close here. "I don't think in my lifetime this town will ever recover to what it was."
Mr. Campbell, now 51 and working at a Mack Truck plant in Winnsboro, 17 miles away, worked at all three Stevens plants here, moving from one to the other as they closed, with the final shutdown coming in 1984.
Small producers use some of the space, but much of Great Falls's downtown is still shuttered and the town is still struggling to get back on its feet.
Similarly, the textile industry throughout the Southeast, which employs about 495,000 of the nation's 706,000 textile workers, is cutting back. Older, inefficient operations are being halted, and new plants tend to be highly automated ones that employ fewer people. In North Carolina, the largest textile-producing state, 43,000 textile and apparel jobs have been lost over the past 10 years. Textile employment has fallen from a peak of 290,000 in 1973 to 208,000 now.
"Part of what has happened in this industry over the past 10 or 11 years has been a shaking out, a survival of the fittest kind of thing," said Dennis Julian, executive vice president of the North Carolina Textile Manufacturers Association. "I think at this point, I see it stabilizing. Whether it's going to turn around to the point we would see our employment numbers go up, I can't say."
The recession has heightened the pressure on the low-end manufacturers, and it has dealt an unexpected shock to cities like Atlanta and Charlotte that had begun to feel invulnerable.
While Atlanta was basking in the glow generated by the Olympics, it found itself in its worst economic downturn since the mid 1970's.
A recent report by Salomon Brothers ranked the city 81st among 100 cities in total job growth over the past year. The report said Atlanta's labor force declined by about six-tenths of 1 percent, or 9,300 jobs. Professor Ratajczak said Atlanta had been hurt by a slump in building, the demise of Eastern Airlines, a downturn in convention business because of the Persian Gulf war and other factors.
Some $418 million in construction generated by the Olympics and a cyclical turnaround are expected to help before long. But when Atlanta, long the standard-bearer for the South's economic growth, stumbled, it was a cautionary note for the region.
In fact, as the Southeast was becoming synonymous with growth instead of poverty, the region was growing at a rate at or below that of the nation as a whole for the first time in decades. Optimists see that as a temporary lull, but many others also see it as a signal that the region has an unfinished economic agenda that could pose difficult problems.
 
Problems
Keys to Future In the Classrooms
 The very different worries of Great Falls and Atlanta merge in one area: education.
By almost any standard, the educational problems in the South are the nation's worst. During the era when industrial promoters were selling an ample, undemanding work force, the lack of education was not a problem.
Now, when even factory jobs often require skilled, adaptable workers, the major alarm sounded by public officials and industrial leaders is often about schools. But despite optimistic rhetoric, there is little sign of dramatic progress. Typical is the situation of Mississippi, where the Legislature approved dramatic educational reforms -- and then found itself unable to find money to pay for them.
Figures for 1989 show the six Southeastern states ranking near the bottom in A.C.T. and S.A.T. scores, ranking from a high of 23d to a low of 49th in high school graduation rates and from a high of 25th to a low of 47th in average teacher salaries.
In a report entitled "The South's Achilles Heel: Education Must Improve to Sustain Economic Growth," Gary W. Tapp, chief economist for the Robinson-Humphrey Company, an investment concern in Atlanta, said that over the rest of the century, an estimated 10 million new jobs could be created in the South, about half of which will require some post-secondary education and about a third of which will require college graduates.
"Education is the No. 1 obstacle that the South needs to overcome to go to the next phase of economic growth," he said in an interview. "Even someone who runs a printing press or a textile loom has to be able to read and understand a fairly complicated manual, and it's bound to be a computer-driven machine. If the South can't respond quickly enough to its educational needs, those jobs are going to go some place else."
 
Despair in the Outback
 And others worry that the South, home to half the nation's blacks, is perpetuating some of the nation's most entrenched two-tier economies, with boundless opportunity for the well educated in the cities and little more than despair in the rural outback.
Still, in a region where optimism, like football, seems to be genetically wired into the culture, most people are more sanguine. They say the region is likely to continue to import talent much as it has over the past two decades. And, as the nation ages, an influx of retirees, who already have transformed coastal areas like Hilton Head, S.C., and mountain towns like Asheville, N.C., will provide a huge boost to the Southeast, probably at the expense of communities to the north.
And, at the least, the South is still marked by a mania for development, an uncynical adherence to the ethic of growth dating back to the industrial-recruitment strategies of the first Southern economic revolution.
That could change as environmental problems grow. A recent study by the liberal Institute for Southern Studies ranked the South's environmental problems and policies the nation's worst. But for now, there is little of the no-growth sentiment of the Pacific Northwest or the skepticism about flat-out boosterism found in New England or the Northeast.
Thus, even in ailing Great Falls, the town's funeral home owner and Mayor, James R. Baker, drives around in his van with his slick "Great Falls . . . Great!" brochures and plans for the town's new city-built industrial park and sewer line linking the town to the nearby Interstate.
"We're survivors," he said. "We're not going to be defeated by a textile crunch or anything else."

HEADLINE: Food for the Soviet People

 BODY:
As the Soviet economy implodes, the Soviet people are finding it harder and harder to put food on the table. The onset of the harsh Soviet winter won't make food shipments any easier. That's why the Bush Administration is wise to act now to assess the shortages and determine the best ways to distribute food donations.
Americans in good conscience stand ready to help. That's the humane thing to do. It's also prudent. Americans have no interest in aggravating the severe economic crisis now gripping the Soviet Union. That would only intensify popular discontent and sow disorder -- unfavorable conditions for democratic politics and a market economy. 
 An Agriculture Department fact-finding mission is scheduled to visit the Soviet Union in October. That might, in compassion, be moved up. And the Administration needs to consider new ways to provide food instead of simply offering loan guarantees that banks seem reluctant to accept.
Experts estimate that this year's harvest in the Soviet Union will fall 25 percent below last year's record high. Last year, despite the bumper crop, distribution difficulties caused spot shortages. This year is almost certain to be worse. Political turmoil has interfered with planting and harvesting and disrupted the flow of food from the countryside to the cities. Food-exporting republics have embargoed sales to food-importing republics. And triple-digit inflation gives producers an incentive to withhold food from the market in anticipation of higher prices later on.
Aid from the U.S. and others could put some food on the shelves. More important, it would give producers an inducement to bring food to market by deflating expectations of price rises.
The Bush Administration needs to consider other ways to provide food. It has already given $1.5 billion in credit guarantees to banks that issue loans to the Soviet Union to import food. The guarantees provide that in the event of a Soviet default, the U.S. Government would repay 98 percent of the principal plus the first 4.5 percentage points of interest on that principal.
Even so, no U.S. bank has been willing to make a loan to the Soviet Union, with its soaring foreign debt and doubtful creditworthiness. Four European banks, under pressure from their governments, did participate in a pre-coup installment of $600 million in loans for grain purchases. Not one has responded to a post-coup $315 million installment.
Moscow has asked the U.S. Government to guarantee 100 percent of the loan, but there may be better ways to do it. Another possibility is to provide food on easy terms under Public Law 480, the law governing disposal of agricultural surpluses. A third is to declare the Soviet Union eligible for disaster relief from the U.S. However it does so, America needs to act expeditiously to relieve Soviet hunger and discontent.

HEADLINE: Israel Should Have $10 Billion Loan Guarantee

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Israel, Most of All, Needs a Just Settlement" (letter, Aug. 18), David Rubenstein's otherwise insightful response to your July 28 Week in Review analysis on the Middle East, contains a blatant misconception regarding United States aid to Israel. 
 He erroneously links United States aid of $4 billion to the requested $10 billion loan guarantee Israel is seeking strictly for humanitarian purposes. The emergency fund would aid in the resettlement of Soviet and Ethiopian emigres facing horrendous conditions in housing and employment.
The Israeli Government is asking the United States to co-sign a loan to be granted by private commercial banks. In no way does the requested assistance entail additional financial support from our Treasury, save for some standard administrative costs, which are under negotiation. And Israel has an indisputably sound record of repayment. The American Jewish community is grappling with these points to educate the American public at large.
The Jewish leadership in the United States is keenly sensitive to the economic hardships confronting our cities and communities. It is precisely this type of misinterpretation -- however unintentional -- that feeds resentment and dangerously reinforces the unjust belief that the United States dotes on a spoiled Israel at the expense of our own domestic agenda.
 
RANDI LOCKE
New York, Aug. 28, 1991
 
The writer is coordinator of social action projects, Commission on Social Action for Reform Judaism.

HEADLINE: Washington at Work;
Balancing Influence and Integrity

BYLINE: By KAREN DE WITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9

 BODY:
Frank Mankiewicz was nervous. He played with a pencil on the desk in his glass cubicle office. He took a call from his son in California. He hung up and twirled the pencil like an airplane propeller, round and round and round on the desktop.
Mr. Mankiewicz, the consummate Washington survivor, campaign manager to Robert F. Kennedy and George McGovern, now a high-priced rainmaker for America's largest public relations firm, a man whose reputation for ease with the media was legendary, was uncomfortable being interviewed. 
 He was, he explained, gun shy after last month's testimony at a Senate subcommittee by the former Customs Service Commissioner, William Von Raab. Mr. Von Raab charged that his agency's investigation of the scandal surrounding the Bank of Credit and Commerce International had been hampered by "the influence peddlers in Washington."
They included, Mr. Von Raab said, Hill & Knowlton, the firm whose Washington office is headed by Mr. Mankiewicz and Robert F. Gray, who like Mr. Mankiewicz had a successful political career before entering public relations. Mr. Gray toiled in Republican circles for the Eisenhower Administration and the 1980 Reagan Presidential campaign.
Hill & Knowlton officials did provide guidance to B.C.C.I. several years ago when the bank was indicted for money laundering, but the firm denies offering any recent counsel.
"I know people joke with me and say I've sold out, but when we get down to it, I've found my clients defensible," Mr. Mankiewicz said. A lawyer by training, Mr. Mankiewicz contended that clients had a right to good public relations, just as they had the right to a lawyer.
"I don't have a problem with it," said Mr. Mankiewicz, who is 67 and has the beefy, pleasant look and self-deprecatory mien of a seasoned politician. "I think people are entitled to their day in court. I've not represented a single client that I've been ashamed of."
Mr. Mankiewicz, who called Mr. Von Raab's allegations "incredibly irresponsible and totally false," declined to talk about B.C.C.I., but later faxed a reporter a copy of a one-paragraph letter sent to him by Mr. Von Raab. The letter stated, "I do not have any information that Mr. Gray or you spoke to or contacted any official in either our Federal Government's executive or legislative branch on behalf of B.C.C.I."
That is not the enthusiastic exoneration people once expected for a man who began his Washington career in the days when the Kennedy name evoked images of the Peace Corps, not Palm Beach, and who, when he ran unsuccessfully in 1976 for the Democratic nomination for a House seat from Maryland, proudly listed on his resume that he had been on the Nixon White House enemies list.
 
A Link to 'Citizen Kane'
 As a boy in Los Angeles,Mr. Mankiewicz played on Rosebud, the sled from "Citizen Kane"; his father, Herman Mankiewicz, won an Oscar for writing the movie's screenplay. His uncle, Joseph Mankiewicz, was the screenwriter and director of "All About Eve."
But Frank Mankiewicz chose drama on the national stage, coming to Washington, he said, because of the excitement that was in the air during the Kennedy Administration.
Mr. Mankiewicz became the head of the Peace Corps in Peru, then the director for all of Latin America. He was press secretary for Robert Kennedy, then his Presidential campaign manager. After Robert Kennedy was assassinated, Mr. Mankiewicz found work on the Washington circuit as a syndicated columnist, television commentator, author, political adviser, president of National Public Radio, and now as vice president of Hill & Knowlton's Washington office.
Mr. Mankiewicz said he did not think he had abandoned any of his principles in the process. "I think I still believe in the same things," he said. Others disagree.
 
'Knows a Lot of People'
 "He's very witty and charming, and he knows a lot of people in Washington," said Jerry Blizen, a former senior vice president of Hill & Knowlton who left the firm in 1988 and is now retired. "And because his father was a Hollywood screenwriter, he knows damn near everybody in the communications business. But I think he's a guy who has practiced being devious for quite a while now."
But Gary Hart, the former Senator who worked with Mr. Mankiewicz on the 1972 McGovern Presidential campaign, said such criticisms showed that liberal Democrats were unfairly held to higher standards than others.
"He does what he's good at," Mr. Hart said. "I think he does it honorably and well. There is this tendency among critics of liberals that if they ever take a few years out of their life to put together a nest egg that somehow they're not as pure."
Another friend, Milton Viorst, the Middle East correspondent for The New Yorker magazine, said Mr. Mankiewicz had never portrayed his current job as anything but what it is.
"He had different financial needs and went into something that would satifsy them," Mr. Viorst said. "I could quibble with him over some things, and we have from time to time, but he is the last guy in the world to be pious and self-righteous."
Others say there has been less a change in Mr. Mankiewicz than a change in the nature of public relations work. Gone are the days when public relations firms were easily identifiable as Democratic or Republican, conservative or liberal; when the cause as well as the cash was the motivating factor behind taking on a client. Nowadays, firms offer full-spectrum personnel; one-stop shopping for spin control; everyone welcome.
Since he joined Hill & Knowlton in 1983, Mr. Mankiewicz or the firm has represented Turkey, where the human rights situation is regularly deplored by Amnesty International; the National Conference of Catholic Bishops, in an anti-abortion campaign that caused an uproar among women at the firm, and Clark M. Clifford, the former Secretary of Defense who recently resigned as chairman of First American Bankshares, a Washington bank linked to B.C.C.I.
But Mr. Mankiewicz said any member of the firm could recuse himself from any project, noting that he is Jewish and does not work on contracts for Arabs. It was Hill & Knowlton that did the aggressive public relations campaign for Kuwait during the Persian Gulf war.
"I didn't participate in the Catholic bishops' anti-abortion campaign either, and threatened to resign when we were thinking about taking on the contras," Mr. Mankiewicz said. "And we turned down the Government of Libya, and Chile and Colombia and some other things."
Asked about projects he is proudest of, Mr. Mankiewicz paused a long time and told a reporter to get back to him.
When asked again several days later, he said, "I like the effort we put out for Ray Donovan when he was on trial in New York." Raymond J. Donovan, who served as Labor Secretary in the Reagan Administration, was acquitted in 1987 of fraud and larceny charges involving accusations of ties to organized crime. "I thought that was a real miscarriage of justice and obviously a jury agreed with us."
He added, "I like some of the things we did with Turkey."
He was most disappointed, he said, with his failure to control the fallout from disclosures this year that Stanford University overbilled the Federal Government on research projects. Among other things, taxpayer money was apparently spent on improvements to the university president's house and flowers and laundry for his home. Donald Kennedy, the university's president, recently announced that he would resign, largely because of the scandal.
"I can't avoid the feeling that somehow we let him down," Mr. Mankiewicz said. "That's the one I'm unhappiest about."
 
His Radio Days
 What he was probably more unhappy about, his friends say, was having to leave his job as president of National Public Radio.
Mr. Mankiewicz, whom many credit with popularizing the public radio network and raising the number of listeners, with programs like "Morning Edition," blamed the recession and a fall-off in corporate contributions for the $3.2 million deficit that threatened to put the network off the air in the early 1980's. Congress and the Corporation for Public Broadcasting blamed him.
"Frank was looking around for new sources of revenue, but the drop in revenue was so precipitous you had to be able to turn on a dime," said Barbara Cohen, Washington bureau chief of CBS, who was vice president for news and information programming at NPR during Mr. Mankiewicz's tenure. "And the people in charge of the finances did not do a good job telling Frank where the money was. He was the one out front. It was a kind of buck-stops-here performance."
Mr. Mankiewicz resigned, and a shadow hung over him as a result. It was a big fall in a little group that is fickle about its favorites. "The liberal community did not reach out and embrace him," said Cokie Roberts, Congressional correspondent for NPR and another Mankiewicz admirer. "There was a man in need ofa friend and a job, and he found one with Robert Gray."
But what Mr. Mankiewicz keeps coming back to is the past.
"I wanted to be with the group that wrought changes in the world," he said, though he acknowledged that the changes he wrought did not now seem so global. Perhaps, he said, he had altered some college students' lives through one of his speeches. He was for women's rights, he said.
"The longest pleasure and happiness I got was from my time with Robert Kennedy," he said. "I used to say -- still do say -- that I could win a Nobel Prize and be named Chief Justice of the Supreme Court and serve two good terms as the President, and they'd write in my obit, Frank Mankiewicz was an aide to Robert Kennedy, and they'd be right. And I'd accept that proudly."

CORRECTION-DATE: September 11, 1991, Wednesday

 CORRECTION:
A profile in Business Day yesterday about Frank Mankiewicz, the Washington public relations executive, misattributed a comment about working for Arabs. It was Jerry Blizen, a former Hill & Knowlton executive, and not Mr. Mankiewicz, who said he was Jewish and did not work on contracts for Arabs. The article also misidentified countries that Hill & Knowlton has refused to represent. They include Libya and Chile, but not Colombia.

HEADLINE: At Meeting on Global Warming, U.S. Stands Alone

BYLINE: By WILLIAM K. STEVENS

 BODY:
IN a contest between uncertain science and uncertain economics, negotiators from around the world convened in Nairobi yesterday for what promises to be a contentious effort to act against the prospect of a possibly catastrophic heating of the Earth's atmosphere in the next century.
The talks, aimed at hammering out a treaty to be signed next June in Rio de Janeiro, are the first major test of whether the world can unite against a threat that appears real in the long term but whose magnitude and pacing are unclear and whose remedies may exact substantial economic costs. 
 The crucial point is what to do about rising emissions of carbon dioxide, the principal man-made atmospheric gas among several that trap heat like the glass panes of a greenhouse.
On this point, the United States, the world's biggest emitter of carbon dioxide, is the odd man out.
The European Community and the Japanese strongly favor the adoption of concrete targets and timetables for stabilizing carbon dioxide emissions, specifically, holding them to 1990 levels in the year 2000. The United States just as strongly opposes such a target. The Bush Administration fears that meeting it would hurt the nation's economy in the short term for no demonstrable long-term climatic benefit. Rising levels of carbon dioxide come mainly from the burning of fossil fuels like coal and oil, on which the country's economy depends. The Administration favors waiting, and remaining flexible, until further research makes the dimensions of the threat clearer.
The Administration also says that if all the other heat-trapping gases besides carbon dioxide are taken into account, actions already taken by the United States will hold its net contribution to the atmosphere's heat-trapping capacity to 1990 levels in 2000. Besides carbon dioxide, the main heat-trapping gases are chlorofluorocarbons, methane and nitrous oxides. All of the latter are believed to be more powerful heat-trappers, molecule for molecule, than carbon dioxide, although their atmospheric concentrations are lower.
United States emissions of carbon dioxide are still expected to rise over the next decade, but at a lower rate because of the new Clean Air Act and energy efficiencies mandated by Congress. The remaining growth, according to a study by the Environmental Protection Agency, will be offset by reductions in other greenhouse gases, mainly chlorofluorocarbons, which are already being phased out under an international agreement.
Administration officials also argue that the United States's energy profile is different from that of Europe, relying more on motor vehicles to knit together vast distances and sprawling suburbs and on coal to produce electricity. Stabilizing carbon dioxide emissions, the Administration says, would therefore impose a bigger burden on the United States than on Europe. United States officials, including William K. Reilly, the administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, argue that within some broad framework, each country should be allowed to adopt a mixture of solutions that suits it best.
The Bush Administration's arguments do not cut much ice with American environmentalists and some politicians, who see the Administration as a foot-dragger that has abdicated leadership on a question of transcendent importance for the future.
"We simply don't have a vision and a policy and a plan," said Scott Hajost of the Environmental Defense Fund, who is attending the Nairobi talks and who was formerly involved in the issue as a lawyer for both the Environmental Protection Agency and the State Department.
"The President has abdicated his responsibility because he is unwilling to propose anything that might be unpopular," said Senator Al Gore, Democrat of Tennessee, who has taken on global warming as a cause. "We are increasingly isolated" on the issue, said the Senator, who also accused the Administration of "scandalous obstinacy" and President Bush of "stonewalling the world."
Environmentalists and many scientists have long contended that there is no time to waste in bringing greenhouse gas emissions under control. Atmospheric concentrations of carbon dioxide have risen to more than 350 parts per million, up from 280 before the Industrial Revolution and from 315 three decades ago. The present concentration is substantially higher than at any time in the last 160,000 years. Some climatologists argue for early action on the ground that as far as modern humans are concerned, this is unexplored climatic territory.
 
'You Have to Start Somewhere'
 They also say climatic change might not occur gradually but suddenly, as rising temperatures trip certain triggers that shift the climate system to a new state. Moreover, some scientists contend, the longer action is delayed, the greater the climatic impact will be and the more painful and expensive it will be to deal with.
The Europeans see their proposed targets as "a first, modest step" toward an eventual reversal of the buildup of carbon dioxide, said Bert Metz, an official at the Dutch embassy in Washington who is involved in the Nairobi talks. The Netherlands, as current president of the European Community, is speaking for the community in the talks. "You have to start somewhere," Mr. Metz said. "If you don't do anything, carbon dioxide will be 15 to 20 percent above 1990 levels" by 2000.
"Apparently, for political reasons, the time is not right" for the United States to adopt stronger measures, Mr. Metz said, adding that "we still hope that the U.S. will come around."
Mr. Reilly, the E.P.A. chief, is one of several current and former officials who believe that economic forces and state and local pollution laws in the United States could bring about enough energy efficiencies in the years just ahead to stabilize the country's carbon dioxide emissions even if no further Federal actions are taken.
"In my opinion, the climate policies of Europe and the United States will eventually converge," Mr. Reilly said, with "Europe relying on centralized, top-down directives and energy taxes, and the U.S. benefitting from decentralized, bottom-up decisions of electric utilities, their ratepayers and consumers to install more energy-efficient lighting and other technologies."
 
Plan-and-Review Concept
 How the negotiations in Nairobi will turn out is anybody's guess. But it is widely believed that the United States could end up signing a treaty that sets broad, general goals for stabilizing greenhouse gases, possibly in the form of some sort of pledge subject to periodic review. The Europeans and Japan might then join in a separate protocol, excluding the United States, that sets specific targets for controlling carbon dioxide.
The Nairobi round of talks is the third of at least five such rounds, but the first in which it appears that the negotiators may get down to brass tacks. The first, at Chantilly, Va., last February, was given over largely to organizational matters and heated argument. The second, in Geneva in June, brought a blizzard of concrete proposals that have since been winnowed and consolidated as a basis for whatever takes place in the next few days.
In two major developments at Geneva, the Japanese introduced the concept of pledge and review as a possible basis for an agreement, and the other industrialized countries appeared to view with more sympathy the United States's argument that all greenhouse gases, not just carbon dioxide, should be considered in devising remedies. Japan has since said that despite its advancement of pledge and review, it still favors specific commitments.
While the industrialized countries are the primary emitters of greenhouse gases now, developing countries are expected to account for a rising share in the future. The developing countries and China are proposing in the negotiations that the industrialized countries contribute to a fund that would be used to ease the poorer nations through a transition to more energy-efficient technologies. These would generate less greenhouse gas. The status of the Soviet Union in the situation, given its political and economic upheavals, is unclear.
The Europeans say their studies show that carbon dioxide emissions could be stabilized at an acceptable cost to their economies. Studies in the United States vary widely in their assessment of the economic impact. An inter-agency Government analysis published last year by the Department of Energy found that significant action to reduce carbon dioxide would reduce the gross national product by at least 1 percent. It found also that such action would have a negative impact on the economy comparable to that of the oil price shocks of the 1970's. Some subsequent studies have placed the reduction in G.N.P. lower, at less than half a percent.
Mr. Reilly says he doubts that many economic studies have taken into consideration the energy efficiencies that he and others believe are coming as a result of market forces and state and local actions. Such efficiencies, if developed, would ease the economic impact.
Earlier this year, a special panel of the National Academy of Sciences found that the average global temperature was likely to rise by 2 to 9 degrees Fahrenheit in the next century if emissions of greenhouse gases continue unabated. This, the panel said, "poses a potential threat sufficient to merit prompt responses." The costs of not taking action, it said, could be substantial and could lower the standard of living in the United States. For developing countries, it said, the impact would probably be worse.
The measured responses recommended by the panel, including a number of actions aimed at improving energy efficiency, were calculated to reduce United States greenhouse emissions by from 10 to 40 percent if all were in effect now, at "very low" net cost to the economy. Stronger actions, it said, are not now justified because the magnitude of the threat is still too uncertain.
 
Assumptions on Carbon Dioxide
 The panel declined to recommend targets and timetables for reducing carbon dioxide on the ground that they would become obsolete as scientists learn more about the threat. Once written into law, some Administration officials say, such targets would be difficult to change.
Environmentalists chided the Administration for opposing some actions recommended by the academy, including especially higher miles-per-gallon standards for automobiles. But Administration officials argued -- and the staff director of the academy study said they could be right -- that actions already taken will, over time, produce the effects the academy's recommends.
That calculation, however, assumes that the relative power of carbon dioxide and other greenhouse gases as heat-trappers remains what scientists have been saying it is. But although no details are yet available, new findings by the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change may show that carbon dioxide is relatively more powerful than has been thought. This would tend to undercut the United States position. The I.P.C.C., established by the United Nations, provides scientific advice for the treaty negotiations.
In any case, the academy report and the calculations about the effect of recent United States actions all were seized upon by Administration officials, especially John H. Sununu, the President's Chief of Staff, as support for their case. Mr. Sununu is by all accounts the most influential Administration official on climate change.
The Administration's negotiating position in Nairobi is, in essence, that a deadline of the year 2000 for stabilizing carbon dioxide emissions is artificial, with no solid basis in either science or economics.
"You know you've got a long-term problem,," said Robert A. Reinstein, a deputy assistant Secretary of State who is the chief United States negotiator. "You don't know what benefits you can expect from these short-term actions."
"Do you do these things in a way that corresponds to an investment cycle, so that you retire equipment when you would retire it anyway and replace it with new equipment with climate benefits?" he asked. "Or do you prematurely retire it to meet an artificial target by 2000, which is not a scientifically determined target?" The United States view, he said, is that "it's really premature" to be talking about short-term targets and timetables like those proposed by the Europeans.
Mr. Reinstein has been accused by Senator Gore of misleading Congress late in July, when he said in written testimony that the European countries had "diminished their insistence" on targets and timetables at the June meeting in Geneva.
Mr. Reinstein said that he was "not trying to say they had changed position," but was instead "describing the atmospherics."
But Senator Gore said the language was "misleading, and in a way intended to buttress the Administration's decision to dig in its heels and stop progress."

But U.S. emissions of carbon dioxide, the chief heat-trapper, are expected to increase.

America the Beautiful -- Rate of carbon dioxide increase would slow under a U.S. plan to plant a billion trees a year, according to an unofficial Federal study. Trees absorb carbon dioxide.

Saving Energy -- Further slowing, by 36 million tons, should result from new energy-efficiency measures. While carbon dioxide emissions continue to rise, though less rapidly, U.S. outpourings of other heat-trapping gases are expected to drop. HEADLINE: Bank Profits: Weakest 2d Quarter Since '87

BYLINE: By LESLIE WAYNE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10

 BODY:
The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation today reported the weakest second-quarter earnings for the nation's banking industry since 1987, but it said that the overwhelming majority of banks remained profitable.
In his final report on the quarterly condition of banks, the F.D.I.C.'s chairman, L. William Seidman, characterized the industry as "bumping along the bottom." 
 "Since this is my final appearance in this role, I would have loved to have come and told you that all of the problems in the banking industry were behind us," Mr. Seidman, who will retire in mid-October, said at a news briefing. Instead, he said, the industry "doesn't look like it's getting worse, but it doesn't look like it's getting a whole lot better."
In the 1991 second quarter, earnings of the nation's 12,150 commercial banks dropped 12 percent below a year ago to $4.6 billion. It was the lowest second-quarter result since 1987, when the banking industry reported a loss. The April-June quarter was also 7.8 percent below the industry's earnings in the 1991 first quarter.
 
88% Are Profitable
 At the same time, more than 88 percent of all commercial banks were profitable in the second quarter, and more than half of them -- 54.3 percent -- reported higher earnings than a year ago. Mr. Seidman predicted that year-end earnings should reach $18 billion to $19 billion, a modest rise from 1990.
Despite these bright notes, Mr. Seidman ticked off a series of troubling statistics. He said the number of banks on the F.D.I.C.'s "problem" list had grown to 1,072, with assets of $445 billion, from 1,046, with assets of $409 billion, at the end of last year. The credit crunch continues, he said, as industry loans outstanding have shrunk by $14 billion, and few new loans are being made. And he said that bank reserves against future losses had shrunk to 65 percent of problem loans from 87 percent in 1989, leaving the industry increasingly vulnerable.
In addition, Mr. Seidman repeated his estimate that the fund that insures commercial bank depositors, which grew to about $4.5 billion in the first six months of the year, would dwindle to "one, two or three billion" by the end of the year, because more banks are expected to fail and the F.D.I.C. will have to step in to protect depositors.
This is slightly more optimistic than a recent General Accounting Office estimate that said the fund would "likely be insolvent" by the end of the year. But, in questioning, Mr. Seidman saw any differences between the two estimates as debatable -- and somewhat meaningless.
"Clearly the fund will be in need of recapitalization," Mr. Seidman said. "Whether it's actually down to insolvency or not, it will be below levels at which we can operate effectively."
He took pains, however, to say that the agency had no plans to increase insurance premiums levied on banks and that he opposed such efforts. "I think the banking industry is at or near the maximum premiums that they can pay long run and be competitive," he said.
In statistics issued with Mr. Seidman's presentation, the F.D.I.C. noted that for the first time the bank insurance fund had borrowed from the Federal Financing Bank, which borrows from the Treasury and lends to Government agencies. The $2.9 billion loan, used to resolve failed banks, which had been expected, was the first use of taxpayers' dollars in the banking crisis.
Mr. Seidman said the most severe bank problems still appeared to be in New England, with Washington, D.C., still plagued with large problem loans. And he said that the situation in Southern California, where there are fears of overbuilding, is "not clear." Larger banks continued to be more profitable than smaller banks, although Mr. Seidman said that he was closely watching at least "four or five" major banks to see whether they might cause large losses to the insurance fund.
The economic downturn has created severe problems for the nation's savings banks, hybrid institutions that are part savings and loan and part commercial bank and are primarily in the Northeast. Nearly one-third of the 456 savings banks lost money -- some $506 million -- in the quarter, 85 percent more than a year ago.
Bert Ely, a banking industry analyst who attended Mr. Seidman's briefing, said that numbers showed "a contracting banking industry that is struggling to survive and eventually to prosper." Mr. Ely said he was heartened by statistics from the F.D.I.C. showing that banks had become better capitalized, that "past due" problem loans were tapering off and that pretax earnings at many banks were rising.
"A lot of people who look at the banking problems are quick to see another savings-and-loan situation," Mr. Ely said. "But banks have a lot more resiliency, and there are some good signs."
In a separate matter, the F.D.I.C. proposed that mortgages under $100,000 no longer require a certified or licensed appraisal. Currently all home mortgages under $50,000 are exempt from the requirement for a certified appraisal. But, with little evidence of loss from mortgages under $100,000, the F.D.I.C. proposed lifting the limit. The proposed change was presented at an F.D.I.C. board meeting and will be open for comment for 60 days before final approval.

HEADLINE: Polish Premier, in U.S., Says Austerity Works

BYLINE: By DAVID BINDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10

 BODY:
Facing parliamentary elections in 47 days, Prime Minister Jan Krzysztof Bielecki of Poland made a campaign stop here today.
His schedule, including speeches and calls on businessmen, members of Congress and international bankers, culminates Wednesday in a meeting with President Bush. An Administration official said that the Polish elections on Oct. 27 will in effect be a referendum on Mr. Bielecki. 
 The 4O-year-old former entrepreneur was appointed nine months ago by President Lech Walesa to head a Government of experts. He embarked immediately on a crash program to introduce free-market policies.
Mr. Bielecki's austerity program stirred resistance among workers and rising opposition in Parliament, which took office in 1989 under a formula that accorded the Communist Party 65 percent of the seats.
Last month, Mr. Bielecki sought and was denied powers to make more budget cuts without parliamentary approval. He then offered to resign, but in a vote of confidence the Parliament refused to accept the resignation.
In a speech today, Mr. Bielecki boasted of "miraculous success" in the initial phase of economic stabilization in Poland. But he acknowledged that in his Government's efforts to transform economic structures inherited from the Communists, he had paid insufficient attention to the weakness of Poland's banking system and of its managerial capacities.
"We underestimated two mammoth problems," he said in an address to the Atlantic Council. "We thought we had a banking system and we had nothing of the kind, and we thought enterprise managers would respond to market signals when in fact a lifetime spent in communism meant they were incapable of recognizing market signals, let alone responding to them"
Mr. Bielecki said his Government was using Western banking expertise to help privatize Polish state-owned banks and that "massive programs" were required to train an adequate number of Poles in Western management techniques.
"When I take these two lessons from Poland and apply them to the Soviet Union then I am not optimistic," he said, noting that the Communist economic system had been in place for 70 years there, compared with 45 years in Poland.
He said he did not consider Poland's two years of post-Communist experience to be a model for the republics of the Soviet Union except for the lesson of the Polish Solidarity movement "that peaceful transition is possible."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Is Mixed as Traders Await Reports on Inflation

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar was mixed against leading foreign currencies yesterday in a slow session as most traders and analysts awaited the inflation reports due later in the week.
Many traders said the Federal Reserve would refrain from an expected cut in interest rates at least until tomorrow's release of the producer-price report for August. 
 That report, combined with the August Consumer Price Index, which is due Friday, will provide the latest indication of inflationary trends, said Jim Burtle, manager of foreign exchange service for the Pennsylvania-based WEFA Group.
If the reports show inflation remains low, they will increase the chances that the Fed will cut interest rates to stimulate the economy through more borrowing, he said. Lower interest rates would tend to hurt the dollar's value by making dollar-denominated investments worth less.
Curtis Perkins, a trader at Chemical New York Capital Markets Group, said the sleepy market was jolted after reports that three Iraqi soldiers killed a Kuwaiti security guard in a border clash.
Mr. Perkins said the dollar had risen briefly on the news as some traders sought a safe haven for their investments, but the dollar failed to sustain the gains.
The dollar held steady against the German mark, closing at 1.6935 marks in New York trading, the same as late Monday. In European trading, the dollar held at 1.6945 German marks, unchanged from Monday's level.
In Tokyo, the dollar fell 0.60 yen, to 134.75 yen. Later in London the dollar was quoted at 134.80 yen. In New York, the dollar closed at 134.75 yen, up from 134.625 yen in late Monday trading.
In London, the British pound rose to $1.7298, from $1.6945 late Monday. In New York, sterling cost $1.7295, less expensive than Monday's closing of $1.7325.
Other late New York dollar quotes, compared with Monday's prices, included: 1.4805 Swiss francs, down from 1.4855; 5.7510 French francs, down from 5.7605; 1,267.50 Italian lire, up from 1,266.50, and 1.13995 Canadian dollars, up from 1.13985.

HEADLINE: SOVIET TURMOIL;
Baker Eases Terms for Aid to Soviets

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Sept. 10

 BODY:
Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d softened Washington's conditions for economic aid to the Soviet Union today by dropping its insistence on seeing a free-market program in operation before assistance is extended.
The Bush Administration had demanded that the Soviet Union not only produce a plan for a market economy but also begin to carry it out before the United States and six other major industrialized democracies would consider any substantial increase in economic assistance. 
 Now Washington appears to be saying that the central Government in Moscow and the republics must simply commit themselves to a specific reform plan.
 
First Visit Since the Coup
 Mr. Baker made his remarks on his flight to Moscow for the first visit to the Soviet Union by a senior Administration official since the failed coup last month. The Bush Administration has been under increasing pressure to offer more aid to the Soviet Union now that the Communist Party and hard-liners in the Soviet leadership have been swept aside and the balance of power has shifted into the hands of reform-minded republic leaders.
Asked if he was offering anything tangible in the way of economic assistance, Mr. Baker told reporters, "We will make it clear that if they are prepared to commit to taking the actions that are required, we will join with others in assisting the transformation."
Mr. Baker quickly added: "But if you are asking me am I coming over here and saying, 'If you do X we will have X millions of dollars,' that is not how it is going to work. What needs to be done is to make sure that they understand what we think is required and if they can take those steps, we will be there -- not take the steps first, but commit to taking the steps."
It is apparent from Mr. Baker's remarks that the Administration now feels that it has a greater incentive to be more forthcoming on aid now that the pro-Western reformers have triumphed and that politically it cannot afford to be quite so rigid as before in setting conditions for economic aid.
Both the Democrats and key American allies, particularly Germany and France, have been pushing for more aggressive Western economic help. Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher of Germany, who is also visiting Moscow, said today of helping the Soviet Union and emerging new democracies in Eastern Europe, "We will be judged by whether we just give them applause or really effectively help them."
Mr. Baker is expected to press Soviet and republic officials to take up the West's offer for associate membership in the International Monetary Fund, something Moscow still has not acted upon, so that they will be able to take advantage of the fund's expertise.
Mr. Baker said the main purpose of this trip beyond discussing economic reform was to try to determine the nature of the new political arrangement being worked out between the Kremlin and the Soviet republics. His itinerary clearly reflects the changing relationship.
Mr. Baker will travel for the first time to St. Petersburg, the former Leningrad, and to all three Baltic republics, as well as to the Soviet Central Asian republic of Kazakhstan. In addition to meetings with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, he will hold talks with President Boris Yeltsin of the Russian republic; the new K.G.B. chief, Vadim Bakatin; Mayor Anatoly A. Sobchak of St. Petersburg, Foreign Minister Andrei Kozyrev of the Russian republic and Eduard A. Shevardnadze, the former Soviet Foreign Minister.
 
Political and Economic Changes
 "We will be making the point that there are certain political and economic arrangements that will make it easier for us and for others to assist in the transformation that is taking place," Mr. Baker said.
In the past, meetings with Mr. Gorbachev were always the centerpiece of Mr. Baker's visits; now they will be simply one among many. Indeed, when Mr. Baker was asked what future the United States saw for continued cooperation between Washington and the Kremlin in general, he said:
"Much will depend on the extent to which the center is changed. I said that they had effected a transition. These meetings will give us a better sense of the direction of some of these changes. They would still like to work cooperatively with us on a number of foreign policy issues, but obviously we will also be working with republic foreign ministers and republic leaders."

HEADLINE: Yields on C.D.'s and Funds Continue to Drop at Banks

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH M. FOWLER

 BODY:
Yields on certificates of deposit and money market accounts continued to decline for the week ended yesterday, aacording to The Bank Rate Monitor, the North Palm Beach, Fla., publication that focuses on interest rates.
Robert K. Heady, publisher, said he expected rates to fall further. 
 "The decline is consistent with downward movement on all savings rates including Treasuries," he said. "Banks, like everyone else, are waiting for the Federal Reserve to ease credit further. When that happens, we will see savings rates fall at an even faster clip for several weeks."
At the Treasury Department's weekly bill auction on Monday the three-month bill was sold at an averaage discount rate of 5.29, compared with 5.34 percent at the previous auction, while the six-month bill averaged 5.30 compared with 5.39 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
Mr. Heady noted that the National Westminster Bank was one bank that had bucked the trend. and raised its three-month certificate of deposit yields by 53 basis points, to 5.34 percent.
The two biggest changes were made by the Bank of Tokyo, which reduced the rate on its six-month certificate of deposit to 4.65 percent, and Connecticut Bank and Trust, which reduced its rate by 16 basis points, to 4.59 percent, on its money market account.
Among the commercial banks in New York, the average yield of money market account and six-month certificate was down 2 basis points, to 5.30 percent for certificates of deposit, and 1 basis point on money market accounts, taking them down to down 4.87 percent. Three-month certificates held firm at 5.16 percent.
For depositors at savings institutions, yields were cut on most short-maturity C.D.'s and money market accounts. Money market accounts slipped on average by 1 basis point, to 5.41 percent, while a three-month certificate fell 2 basis points, to 5.55 percent. The six-month certificate came down 4 basis points, to 5.79.
By comparison, 20 large banks outside the New York market cut 2 basis points from the yield on their six-month certificates of deposit to 5.36 percent, while their money market accounts were unchanged at 5.12.

HEADLINE: Main South Korean Opposition Parties Merge

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea, Sept. 10

 BODY:
The two main opposition political parties announced a merger today, aiming to form a unified force to try to defeat President Roh Tae Woo's governing party in national elections.
The new party is a product of the New Democratic Party, led by the top opposition figure Kim Dae Jung, and the small Democratic Party, led by Lee Ki Taek. 
 It includes support from dissidents and workers and is less conservative than the governing Democratic Liberal Party, which itself was the product of a surprise party unification more than a year ago. While Mr. Roh's party has prevailed in recent local elections, its popularity in public opinion polls is low.
Mr. Kim, known as South Korea's most famous dissident throughout the 1980's, is preparing for a renewed attempt at the presidency. With the merger, which created South Korea's first unified opposition party in more than 20 years, "we now can expect to defeat the ruling party in upcoming elections, bringing a peaceful transfer of power," Mr. Kim said at a news conference.
 
Elections Expected Next Year
 The new party, called the Democratic Party, will be functioning well in advance of the parliamentary and presidential elections expected next year. Leadership is split equally between the two components.
Under the merger, the new party will control 80 seats in the 298-member Parliament. Officials said it would continue to expand by absorbing other opposition groups.
Mr. Roh, whose single five-year term ends in early 1993, cannot seek re-election. His party, formed from a merger of three conservative parties in 1990, swept most seats in local elections held earlier this year. The divided opposition was blamed for the outcome. But the governing party's popularity has been declining after a series of scandals and rising inflation and land speculation. Recent polls indicate an all-time low in support, less than 15 percent.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Seoul Dissident's Role at U.N.
 A South Korean diplomat said yesterday that Kim Dae Jung would join President Roh in New York next week, when South and North Korea formally join the United Nations.
Since the end of the Korean War, the North and South have held observer status at the United Nations. But earlier this year, Mr. Roh announced that South Korea would apply for separate membership after it became clear that the North's traditional allies, the Soviet Union and China, would not move to block the application.
North Korea later announced that it, too, would enter the United Nations, although it still maintains that the two Koreas should hold a single Korean seat.

HEADLINE: Ashidowa-teri Journal;
Venezuela Befriends Tribe, but What's Venezuela?

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ASHIDOWA-TERI, Venezuela

 BODY:
Two degrees north of the Equator, an American anthropologist stood in a circular Yanomami lodge here recently and asked a hunter what he thought of Venezuela's new Upper Orinoco-Casiquiare Biosphere Reserve.
A mystified look crossed the young man's brow, already distorted by designs in ocher paint. He consulted a friend dressed only in feathers, then demanded, in Yanomami, "What's Venezuela?" 
 With the 500th anniversary of the arrival of Columbus approaching, Venezuela has begun an unusual effort to cushion one of the final collisions between the modern world and Stone Age America.
To the applause of anthropologists and the dismay of miners and missionaries, President Carlos Andres Perez of Venezuela signed a decree this summer that reserves a stretch of Amazon forest the size of Maine as a permanent homeland for the country's 14,000 Yanomami Indians.
 
A Ban on Economic Activity
 The tribe, which straddles the remote border region of Venezuela and Brazil, is considered to be the hemisphere's last major tribe untouched by modern civilization.
"There will be no economic activity -- no mining, no farming, and no colonization," Mr. Perez said in an interview in Caracas. Encompassing the headwaters of the Orinoco River, the new 32,038-square-mile reserve is bounded on the east by the Brazilian border and on the west by the Casiquiare River.
"The primary use will be to preserve and to learn the traditional ways of the Indians. There will be no religious proselytizing. Existing missions will be subject to controls."
Mr. Perez's action stands in sharp contrast to Brazil, where defenders of the Indians have unsuccessfully struggled for 20 years to set up a slightly larger reserve for Brazil's 9,000 Yanomami.
Venezuela's move has left anthropologists euphoric.
"It's fantastic," said Jason W. Clay, director of research of Cultural Survival, a private Indian rights group based in Cambridge, Mass. "If we can just get the Brazilians to follow suit, we will have a reserve which would allow the Yanomami to survive into the next millennium."
The other day a Venezuelan Air Force helicopter swept over the Yanomami's homeland -- a primeval expanse of dull green forest, broken by gray granite escarpments, winding chocolate-colored streams and blazing yellow palo de arco trees.
"This is one of the last great areas of the Amazon basin that is still pristine," said a passenger, Napoleon A. Chagnon, an anthropology professor from the University of California at Santa Barbara. The author of a best-selling college textbook, "Yanomamo: The Fierce People," he founded a new group in July to raise funds for the new reserve, American Friends of the Venezuelan Indian.
Thundering over the remote headwaters of the Siapa River, the helicopter pilots spotted several openings in the thick forest -- banana gardens and circular, palm thatch lodges of the Yanomami.
After the helicopter descended in a cloud of dust on one garden, a group of 20 excited Yanomami men and boys emerged from the forest. One explained that they had never received non-Yanomami visitors at Ashidowa-teri.
With their clothing largely limited to feather earplugs, body paint and monkey hair armbands, the men curiously touched the expedition members' foreign attire. Peppering visitors with questions, several were startled to discover that there are people in the world who do not speak Yanomami.
 
Household Implements on View
 Moving single file through gardens of plantains and cotton, the party hiked toward the shapono, or circular common house.
"We hope to get basic information on plants used by the Yanomami," Brian M. Boom, a botanist from the New York Botanical Garden, said about the expedition. "For example, there is a toxic Andean nightshade in the gardens here. What is it doing with a people who were supposedly isolated for thousands of years?"
Ducking through a low opening in the shapono wall, the party of scientists and doctors entered an open area of earth beaten hard by bare feet. The women and girls stayed in the shade, tending wood cooking fires or watching from perches in vine hammocks.
Strung from lodgepoles were household implements -- bark quivers for arrowheads, braces of seven-foot-long arrows, dried bones from hunting expeditions, tightly woven baskets, bunches of tobacco leaves and of anato nuts, which provide red pigment for face paint.
A five-day walk from the headwaters of the Orinoco River, Ashidowa-teri is beyond the reach of missionaries who operate three missions for the Yanomami.
The missionaries believe in easing the Indians' adjustment to the outside world through bilingual education, conversion to Roman Catholicism, establishment of craft cooperatives and provision of modern medicine.
Charles Brewer-Carias, a Venezuelan naturalist who organized the expedition, asserted that mission work leaves the Indians disoriented, with one foot in each culture.
As an example, he said the missions' recent distribution of shotguns for hunting game had an unintended effect on a tribal group marked by a long history of internal warfare. Over the last year, the Venezuelan said, "mission Yanomami" had shot to death 21 "wild Yanomami."

GRAPHIC: Photo: In an effort to cushion one of the final collisions between the modern world and Stone Age America, President Carlos Andres Perez of Venezuela signed a decree this summer that reserves a stretch of Amazon forest the size of Maine as a permanent homeland for the country's 14,000 Yanomami Indians. (James Brooke/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Credit Move Set in Florida

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Sept. 10

 BODY:
Florida banks and businesses are preparing to raise credit card interest rates on Oct. 1 when a new state law take effect, abolishing an 18 percent limit on interest rates.
The Burdine's, Bloomingdale's and Maas Brothers-Jordan Marsh retail chains intend to raise the rates on their cards to 21.6 percent. Saks Fifth Avenue and Lord & Taylor said they would follow suit. 
 Some stores are not making immediate changes. Mervyn's, Neiman Marcus and Sears, Roebuck & Company said they would keep rates at 18 percent.
The Florida legislature eliminated limits in the spring after Florida banks threatened to move their credit card operations out of the state.
Many states do not have such restrictions, and 80 percent of credit cards now held by Florida residents are issued by out- of-state banks that charge an average of 19.8 percent.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Saatchi Effort On Refugees

 BODY:
A unit of Saatchi & Saatchi P.L.C., London, has accepted an assignment to persuade Vietnamese "boat people" in Southeast Asian refugee camps to return to the country that they fled.
The European Commission, the executive body for the 12- nation European Community, plans to pay about $600,000 to Saatchi & Saatchi Strategy, the advertising and communications company's government consultancy division. 
 The unit will produce materials about new economic benefits and employment opportunities in Vietnam, said Endymion Wilkinson, the head of the commission's Southeast Asian division.
Leaflets and posters from the effort will begin to be distributed in the refugee camps within weeks, he added.
About 130,000 Vietnamese refugees are in camps in Hong Kong and six nations in Southeast Asia. While many wish to emigrate to Europe or the United States, the majority will not be allowed to do so, Mr. Wilkinson said.
The Saatchi campaign is part of a $12 million program, sponsored by the commission, most of which is being spent in three provinces in Vietnam.
Saatchi executives could not be reached for comment.
