HEADLINE: Salomon Executive Has an Agenda for Cleaning Up the Desk

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
A month after Salomon Brothers was shaken by scandal, profits at the firm's core government-bond trading business have fallen by about 20 percent, the newly appointed head of the firm's trading desk, Eric R. Rosenfeld, said in an interview yesterday.
Since margins in the government-bond business are narrow, a firm's profitability is vitally dependent on trading volume, said Mr. Rosenfeld, a former Harvard professor who gave up academia in 1984 for a new world on Wall Street. And after scarcely three weeks on his new job, Mr. Rosenfeld said: "Volume is down, so profitability is down, but not astronomically. It's not gangbusters. But it's not hopeless." 
 Salomon's admission on Aug. 9 that it exceeded bidding limits established by the Treasury Department at four separate securities auctions since December 1990 has sent a number of clients to other primary dealers.
Whether the business will return depends in large part on what is uncovered in a wide-ranging investigations of Salomon's activities by the Securities and Exchange Commission and the Justice Department.
Much of the business has been lost over the last two weeks, Mr. Rosenfeld suggested.
In the early hours following the onset of the Soviet putsch on Aug. 19, when financial markets around the world were racked with uncertainty, Salomon did "substantial" business, particularly in Tokyo. "Then it slacked off," Mr. Rosenfeld said.
Mr. Rosenfeld has had more pressing concerns than the drop in his department's revenues. These have included overseeing the installation of a computerized bidding system; the carrying out of internal-compliance guidelines outlined in Congressional testimony on Sept. 3 by Salomon's new chairman, Warren E. Buffett, and learning the ins and outs of what for him is a totally new business.
"I am doing a lot to make sure that all the systems are in place," he said. "There are some trading decisions that have to be made, but there is less of that. But I hope that once we have shored up those systems we can get back to business."
 
Career in Arbitrage
 Until he was appointed to the government-bond job, Mr. Rosenfeld, who is 38 years old, had spent his entire career at Salomon on the firm's arbitrage desk, where he devised and put into effect trading strategies involving derivative products like over-the-counter Treasury options and warrants on Treasury securities.
A graduate of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, where he received an undergraduate degree in economics and a doctorate in finance, Mr. Rosenfeld was lured to Salomon's arbitrage desk in 1984 from the Harvard Business School, where he spent five years as an assistant professor.
"I was grading final exams in June, and I got a call from a guy who was working on the hedge-management desk," Mr. Rosenfeld recalled. "He wanted recommendations of students for a job in the arbitrage group. It sounded pretty good, and I said I can give you the best recommendation I can ever think of. He said, 'Who's that?' I said, 'It's myself.' "
 
Foray Into Software
 While still at M.I.T., Mr. Rosenfeld showed that he had talents beyond academia. One day in 1978, he stepped into a computer store in Cambridge, Mass., and met another computer buff, Mitchell D. Kapor.
"I was unemployed and between a master's and a doctorate in psychology. He was at the Sloan School," remembered Mr. Kapor, who later went on to co-found the Lotus Development Corporation and is now chairman of ON Technology, a Cambridge-based technology concern. "We hit it off."
Along the way, the two developed a statistical analysis program that could be used on Apple II computers, a model they both owned.
"We sort of packed the thing together and marketed it via mail order and through computer stores," Mr. Kapor said. "It made both of us a bunch of money. Mine was the seed money for Lotus."
When Mr. Rosenfeld was first interviewed by Salomon's research department, he said he was left cold. "I figured, ugh, this is what I've been doing, there is no way I want this job," he said.
But late in the afternoon the interview, Mr. Rosenfeld met John W. Meriwether, the Salomon vice chairman who was forced out last month as a result of his role in the bidding scandal. Mr. Meriwether didn't talk about a research job. He talked about trading.
It "really sounded like a whole new ball game," Mr. Rosenfeld said. "The research people were talking about what they had been doing and were trying to assess what my skills were. But it was the trading job was the one that intrigued me the most."
 
Rapid Rise
 Mr. Rosenfeld's rise has been rapid. Named a vice president in 1986 and a director two years later, he became a managing director in 1989.
The Treasury bills, notes and bonds that are the staples of the government desk are considerably less esoteric instruments than those Mr. Rosenfeld has been dealing with for the last seven years. But the pace on his new desk is much quicker than in arbitrage.
"This is a totally different business," he said. "On the arb desk you have more time to map out stategy."
Two members of the firm's government-bond desk, Paul W. Mozer and Thomas F. Murphy, were swept away by the scandal. Mr. Rosefeld said he was well satisfied with the core of some 15 traders and 25 salesmen that remained.
"I inherited a pretty good group," he said. "My job is to see if I can maintain it."
He has stayed in contact with Mr. Meriwether, the man who hired him, since he was forced to resign on Aug. 18.
"J.M. really loved this firm," Mr. Rosenfeld said. "This firm was everything to him. I call him up to try and cheer him up, and all he does is try and cheer us up."

HEADLINE: U.N. LEADER VOICES HOPE ON HOSTAGES

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TEHERAN, Iran, Sept. 10

 BODY:
Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar of the United Nations arrived here tonight saying that "some progress" had been made in the negotiations to free the remaining 10 Western hostages in Lebanon. Officials traveling with the Secretary General said privately that the situation was at a critical juncture.
Mr. Perez de Cuellar's emissary on the hostage negotiations, Giandomenico Picco, did not arrive here as expected with the Secretary General and was said by officials to have been dispatched on another secret mission related to the hostage negotiations. Mr. Picco has been working to negotiate the release of Arab prisoners held by Israel to be followed by the release of more Western hostages, United Nations officials said. 
 Mr. Picco was dispatched to Beirut last month when hopes were raised for a final resolution of the hostage problem with the release of two Western captives. He was present when kidnappers turned over the British journalist, John McCarthy, who was held for five years, to Syrian authorities.
 
Fate of Missing Israelis
 Since then, Mr. Picco has shuttled between New York, Jerusalem and Teheran seeking Iranian assistance and working with Israeli officials to gather enough information about seven Israeli servicemen missing in Lebanon to clear the way for Israel to release some of the nearly 400 Arab prisoners it has been holding.
Late last week in New York, an official familiar with Mr. Picco's negotiations said Israel was giving serious consideration to a prisoner release; the official said the "million dollar question" was whether Israel would go ahead even though it was not entirely satisfied with all of the information it had received about its missing soldiers.
One critical piece of missing information was the whereabouts of an Israeli aviator, Capt. Ron Arad, shot down in October 1986 and held prisoner for a time by the Shiite Muslim Amal organization in Lebanon. It is thought that Captain Arad might be the only one of the seven Israelis still alive.
Iran and its pro-Iranian forces in Lebanon have suggested that all of the remaining Western hostages could be freed if Israel responds to last month's release of Mr. McCarthy and Edward A. Tracy, who were held by the Islamic Holy War group. The Iranian Government of President Hashemi Rafsanjani is seeking to restore economic and political ties with the West as it seeks to rebuild the Iranian economy.
 
Talks With Iran's Leader
 "Things are still in motion," a United Nations official said, adding that it was possible that the first release could occur while Mr. Perez de Cuellar is in Teheran for talks with Mr. Rafsanjani.
The official, under instructions not to go beyond the Secretary General's public remarks, said the situation was at a very delicate stage. He indicated that Israeli Government officials were involved in intense diplomacy related to the release of prisoners, a step that Mr. Perez de Cuellar and a number of Western governments have been pressing Israel to consider.
Mr. Perez de Cuellar was greeted at the airport by the Iranian Foreign Minister, Ali Akbar Velayati, who told reporters that the key to progress on the hostage problem was not in Iran, an allusion to Teheran's position that Israel should release some of its prisoners to keep the talks going.
It was still possible for the negotiations to falter, United Nations officials said. They refused to go into detail about how the negotiators were dealing with Israel's demand for an accounting of its seven missing servicemen.
 
Meeting With Families
 In a gesture to the Iranians, Mr. Perez de Cuellar has agreed to meet while he is in Teheran with the families of four missing Iranians who disappeared in Lebanon in 1984. Three of the four were diplomats, and Iran has frequently demanded that the United States and Western nations cooperate in trying to determine the fate of the four men in return for Iran's efforts to win the release of Western hostages.
In the month since the current round of hostage negotiations began, Iranian officials have been frustrated by the apparent lack of public pressure on Israel by the Bush Administration to reciprocate for the release of Mr. McCarthy and Mr. Tracy.
"I can tell you they thought Washington would put some pressure on Israel to respond and they are very disenchanted," said a senior Western diplomat here who has worked closely on hostage related issues.
It is now clear that Mr. Perez de Cuellar, who has been carrying the Bush Administration's proxy in the hostage negotiations, based his own strategy from the outset on the belief that Israel would release some of its of Arab prisoners to keep the negotiations going.
For the first time in weeks, it seemed possible tonight that Israel might be choosing such a course.
One United Nations negotiator acknowledged that his pitch to pro-Iranian Lebanese militants over the past year was tailored along these lines: "We told them, 'Make us credible. Give us two hostages,' " and this would give momentum to a conclusive negotiation.
An aide to the Secretary General, asked if the Bush Administration had made any effort to press Israeli officials privately on the issue, said he preferred not to discuss the subject.
The Secretary General has spoken to Mr. Bush several times by telephone and is known to have expressed gratitude for Mr. Bush's public statements in support for his diplomatic efforts.

HEADLINE: Ames Posts Cut in Losses

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: ROCKY HILL, Conn., Sept. 10

 BODY:
Ames Department Stores Inc. said today that careful spending had helped it cut second-quarter losses despite failing to reach its sales goal.
For the quarter that ended on July 27, Ames's loss totaled $46.5 million on sales of $727.9 million. Those figures compared with a loss of $152.5 million on sales of $563.3 million in the previous year, which included a one-time charge of $73.1 million. 
 Douglas K. Ewing, a spokesman for Ames, said he could not comment on how much the sales figures differed from the second-quarter goals.
"We are making the necessary changes to position Ames for long-term success -- streamlining our organization, improving operational capabilities and upgrading merchandise assortments," Mr. Pistner said.
Ames announced a recovery plan in June, 14 months after filing for protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code. The retailer, which operates 448 discount department stores in 17 Northeastern states, lost $793.5 million after declaring bankruptcy.
Stephen L. Pistner, chairman and chief executive of Ames, attributed the poor sales to the sluggish Northeastern economy. "Although comparable store sales were significantly higher than last year, total sales were below our plan," he said. "Expenses remain well controlled, in line with our plan."
Comparable-store sales, those from stores open at least a year, increased 33 percent, Ames said,

HEADLINE: NO PROGRESS SEEN IN CANADA STRIKE

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TORONTO, Sept. 10

 BODY:
The second day of a nationwide strike of Canadian federal workers disrupted millions of people today, creating a new political challenge to a seven-year-old Progressive Conservative Government that has sunk to new lows in opinion polls.
As more than half of the 155,000-member Public Service Alliance of Canada stayed out of work -- halting grain shipments, tying up air transportation and slowing border crossings -- the union and the Government refused to budge from their positions. 
 The union's 49-year-old chief, Daryl Bean, said his members would stay out until Ottawa backs down from its demand for a wage freeze this year and increases of no more than 3 percent in each of the next two years.
Gilles Loiselle, 62 years old, president of the Treasury Board, the man in charge of doling out -- and cutting back -- the expenditures that keep Ottawa running, said that with the Government's huge deficits it had no choice but to hold the line on wage costs, warning that any pay increases now would lead to job losses later.
Mr. Loiselle, one of the closest advisers to Prime Minister Brian Mulroney, served notice that the Government would have "recourse to legislation" should the strike continue and really wreak havoc.
The Government has enough votes in Parliament to do more or less what it wants, like legislate an immediate return to work in a strike.
 
Political Necessities
 But many analysts say they believe that Ottawa will try to avoid such drastic action, which could further erode its popularity, for as long as possible. Mr. Mulroney must face the electorate in the next two years.
On Monday night, Mr. Mulroney was greeted by jeering pickets in London, Ontario, and his limousine was pelted with tomatoes and placards. He had gone to address Conservative Party loyalists and tell them that he was "not going to be deterred by hooliganism."
Both sides are fighting in the public-relations arena. If the strikers do not cause serious inconvenience, they will not force the Government to improve its offer. But if they do, they risk losing public support.
As in the United States, federal workers, with their relatively good pensions and steady work, have never been able to call up much sympathy. The Toronto Sun said in an editorial today, "There are taxpayers who just don't like bureaucrats -- and think they're neither civil nor servants."
Edward Harvey, a professor at the Center for Industrial Relations at the University of Toronto, said in an interview that the union leadership had calculated that "no matter how unpopular federal workers are, they are nowhere near as unpopular as this Government itself."
The latest Gallup Poll released last week showed support for the Tories at an all-time low of 12 percent. The Government is a lightning rod for much negative sentiment, especially about the economy and the high rate of joblessness -- more than 10 percent, with 1.4 million out of work.
"It's quite a feat to provoke a strike by the entire federal civil service," The Edmonton Journal said in an editorial. "But if anyone could do it, it had to be the Government of Prime Minister Brian Mulroney."
 
Government Optimistic Anyway
 Still, Ottawa is still counting on the strike to peter out. The diversity of federal employees is one of the cards in its hand. Representing everyone from blue-collar workers to highly specialized professionals, they are recognized as a difficult group for union leaders to maintain labor discipline over.
Predictably, there were differences between Mr. Bean and Mr. Loiselle over the strike's effectiveness. Mr. Loiselle said early estimates by the Treasury showed about 50 percent of workers legally able to strike were off the job in eastern Canada.
Mr. Bean said the final tallies were showing 70,000 of a possible 110,000 Alliance members registered for picket duty.
About 45,000 workers are considered essential and are therefore ineligible to strike. They include food inspectors, air traffic controllers, prison guards, airport firefighters and those who process unemployment insurance benefits and pension checks.
Air traffic was snarled for a second day at aiports including Toronto's Pearson International, after controllers were late getting to work because of picket lines.
At many border-crossing points, traffic was slowed because of a lack of customs and excise employees.

HEADLINE: New Paramount Theater to Give Radio City a Run for Its Music

BYLINE: By STEPHEN HOLDEN

 BODY:
When Barry Manilow plays the new 5,600-seat Paramount theater this month, his engagement will open a new era in the concert business in New York City.
Until now, the only multi-use theater in Manhattan of comparable size has been Radio City Music Hall. But with the opening of the Paramount, on the site of the old Felt Forum in Madison Square Garden, the two houses will soon be engaged in fierce competition to present big-name entertainment at a time when the concert business is in recession. 
 Ron Delsener, the promoter who booked the Manilow show, said he expected "concert wars" with Radio City. "We can't wait; we're chomping at the bit," he said. "I'm buying a new suit."
John Scher, a New Jersey-based promoter who runs Metropolitan Entertainment and who has several acts booked into the Paramount this fall, says the new theater poses a serious threat to its midtown rival's concert business. "I think the Paramount will be devastating to Radio City Music Hall," he said. The Paramount, he predicted, will end up with 50 percent of the shows that would normally have played Radio City.
 
Smaller Staff, Lower Costs
 Fueling the competition is the fact that for the last decade, Radio City has produced its own concerts and excluded outside promoters, among them Mr. Delsener and Mr. Scher. The Paramount's owner, the entertainment conglomerate Paramount Communications, welcomes outside promoters. Mr. Delsener and Mr. Scher both contend that acts can make more money playing the Paramount than Radio City because the new theater, with a smaller full-time staff and a lower overhead, will be less expensive to operate. Performers could take home $10,000 or more a night by appearing there, they said.
Moreover, they said, one of the attractions of the Paramount will be its intimacy. It is an amphitheater whose last row is only 174 feet from the stage, much closer than the most distant seats at Radio City.
Scott Sanders, who runs Radio City Music Hall Productions, said he doubted those estimates. He also scoffed at Mr. Scher's and Mr. Delsener's predictions that the Paramount would hurt Radio City business. Citing the prestige of the Music Hall, he said it would be "naive" to think that performers made their decisions about where to play in New York based on money alone.
"What happens at the Paramount remains to be seen," he said. "The fact is that Radio City is a unique theater and a unique experience that can't be duplicated anywhere else. We offer full service to an artist. We provide the venue, the promoter and an in-house marketing team that is larger than all the other promoters' staffs put together. And we can provide staging. The Broadway director and choreographer Joe Layton is a permanent member of our creative staff."
The Paramount has already fired the opening salvos by luring Mr. Manilow, who for the last decade has been a top draw at Radio City. On Sept. 25, he will begin a three-night engagement of his "Showstoppers" salute to Broadway musicals. Mr. Delsener, the show's promoter, said Mr. Manilow had chosen the Paramount "because he likes to open new buildings, and there's going to be a lot of excitement about this new building."
 
Vying for Talent
 Both theaters have booked a formidable array of talent for the fall. In addition to Mr. Manilow, the Paramount has scheduled Santana, James Taylor, Patti LaBelle, Michael Bolton, the Moody Blues, the Andy Williams Christmas Show, "Sesame Street Live," the World Soccer Cup Draw, and the popular children's act, Sharon, Lois and Bram.
Mr. Scher said he had hoped to book Natalie Cole into the Paramount, too, but had been outbid by Radio City, which has also lined up Aretha Franklin, Diana Ross, the Moiseyev Dance Company, Ann-Margret and the Rockettes, Johnny Mathis and Dionne Warwick, and a return engagement by Liza Minnelli, whose two-and-a-half-week run last spring grossed over $3.8 million, setting an all-time record for Radio City.
The competition could conceivably push up already high ticket prices as the two theaters vie for big names. The top price for Ms. Cole's Nov. 1 and 2 Radio City dates is $37.50; for Ann-Margret's shows Oct. 22 to 27, it is $50, the same as Mr. Manilow's at the Paramount.
Although a mood of official optimism prevails at the Paramount, the shaky economic climate and the sharp downturn in the concert business have raised questions as to whether New York can sustain a second hall of this size. Attendance, off this year throughout the country, has been especially poor in New York. "It has been the worst season in 20 years, which is as far back as I go," Mr. Scher said.
For the first time in more than 10 years, there was no summer concert series at Pier 84 at 12th Avenue and 43d Street. Mr. Delsener had promoted concerts there from 1981 to 1988 and the following two summers Radio City Music Productions leased the space and lost over $2 million. Of its 17 scheduled concerts last summer, six were canceled.
 
'A Negative Attitude'
 Though Mr. Delsener pointed out that his concert series at Jones Beach did well this summer, he said: "Realistically, there is a negative attitude about New York at the present time. Business is off, and every time you pick up the papers there's bad news. But I think people will want to go to the Paramount because it's new. We just have to be careful of what we play there."
Mr. Scher said: "Compared to most other cities, New York is dreadfully inadequate in the number of good concert performance facilities. The city has only one multi-purpose 2,000-to-3,000-seat sitdown in the Beacon Theater and one 5,000-to-6,000 seater in Radio City. New York needs the Paramount from both a business and a public perspective. The only bit of caution I have is that the state of the concert business is more serious than just a seasonal dropoff."
The Paramount is part of a $200 million renovation of Madison Square Garden by Paramount Communications. The new theater is named, its owners say, for the movie and entertainment palace at 43d Street and Broadway that closed in 1964 after nearly four decades.
The theater, designed by the architectural firm of Ellerbe Becket, replaces the old Felt Forum, the Garden complex's smaller auditorium, which never established an identity and was never successful. "The Felt Forum was neither fish nor fowl," said Martin S. Davis, chairman of Paramount Communications. "It didn't work for sports or for any other kind of entertainment. We wanted its replacement to be something that could turn Madison Square Garden into a sports and entertainment complex."
Unlike the Felt Forum, which had no flyspace above and behind the stage, the Paramount is part of a new six-story building that will provide ample storage space and allow television specials and Broadway-style shows to be produced there. Also, the former hard-to-find entrance on Eighth Avenue has been replaced by a prominent one on Seventh Avenue.

HEADLINE: The Pop Life;
Just When You Thought Rock 'n' Roll Was Dead

BYLINE: By PETER WATROUS

 BODY:
At 12:01 A.M. on Tuesday, a pop culture explosion is expected to detonate. That is the day Guns 'n' Roses finally releases its two new albums, "Use Your Illusion I" and "Use Your Illusion II," and the advance order for the records is huge -- more than four million copies, according to Geffen Records, the band's label. Anticipating a heavy turnout of buyers, a spokesman for Geffen said, over 1,000 stores across the country will open at midnight.
In New York City, Tower Records plans to extend its normal midnight closing time until about 2 A.M. "or as long as it takes," as one store manager put it. A spokesman for Sam Goody said two of its Manhattan stores (at 1011 Third Avenue, at 60th Street, and 390 Avenue of the Americas, at Eighth Street) would stay open Monday night to sell the album "as long as people keep coming in."
"This is a major event," said Lew Garrett, a vice president of purchasing for Camelot, one of the top three record chains in the country. "We placed the largest single order for a new release in the company's history. That's based on demand all year for this project. Outside of Michael Jackson's 'Thriller,' this will probably be the biggest rock record ever."
The album's initial success represents a boon for the ailing record industry. Following the recent success of albums by Metallica and Van Halen, it also signals a resurgence of hard rock.
"People have been saying that rock-and-roll is dead," said Ed Rosenblatt, president of Geffen. "It's clearly not true. Some of the major names haven't released albums, and there haven't been records by U2 or Springsteen or Def Leppard. I think the industry has put out too many copycat bands, which has put buyers to sleep. I think the tremendous anticipation on these albums shows that the market still exists strongly, if you put something out there worthwhile."
The recession has affected not only the pop touring industry, but pop record sales as well. And one theory has it that advance orders of the Guns 'n' Roses albums are high because retail chains, which are buying on credit, see the album as a quick way to generate cash to pay off old debts.
"Business-wise it's been a tough year; we've had to really scrap for every sale," said Mr. Garrett. "We think we have the potential to sell more than we've ever sold of anything. It will provide a ray of sunshine for everyone."
Part of the pre-release excitement can be traced to a series of shrewd marketing ploys. The group has waited four years to release a new album; its last, "Appetite for Destruction," sold 14 million copies. The two "Use Your Illusion" albums were originally scheduled for a May release, but Guns 'n' Roses refused to let them be issued then because, the company said, the band was not artistically satisfied with them. The delay fueled both publicity and anticipation. Also, a single from the album, "You Could Be Mine," has been a big hit, thanks in large part to its being from the summer's biggest movie, "Terminator 2: Judgment Day."
"We just got out of the way," said Robert Smith, head of marketing at Geffen. "When the record was delayed for a few months, the situation just grew in terms of consumer and retail interest. The band began gigging in May, and the marriage of the biggest movie of the summer and the biggest rock band built up incredible demand. When 800,000 cassette singles of 'You Could Be Mine,' went out the door, without any campaign, we realized that they're bigger than we ever thought."
The record company has planned the release cleverly. Betting that teen-agers couldn't afford a double album that might have a list price near $30, they instead voted to split the release in two, with one album having 16 tracks and the other 14; the total amount of music comes out to nearly two and a half hours and the list price of each is $15.99. The first single, "Don't Cry," can be found on both albums, but in different versions. And the company plans to push singles from alternating albums.
"You can't underestimate the label," Mr. Garrett said of Geffen. "They know how to make something big."
But as much as any label tries, it is impossible to sell a dud. Guns 'n' Roses has clearly built a large constituency that is ready and waiting to buy its music.
 
Out of Africa
 The pianist and composer Randy Weston, who is performing on Friday at Alice Tully Hall as part of Lincoln Center's jazz program and on Sunday in a free concert at the band shell in Prospect Park in Brooklyn, is one of the most imposing improvisers working in jazz. One of the New York-based be-bop musicians who came to prominence in the 1950's, he learned the lessons of Duke Ellington, Thelonious Monk and Bud Powell, turning them into an amalgam of ringing chords, giant open spaces, percussive dissonances and skittering runs.
In 1961 Mr. Weston went to Africa, and his musical life changed. Since then, he has traveled through Africa extensively, living in Morocco and studying all sorts of different musical practices. Friday's show is partly a byproduct of his first trip. Mr. Weston and his orchestra will be re-creating the original music for his orchestral work and album, "Highlife," which came out in 1963.
"A lot of African countries were just getting independence," Mr. Weston said. "I wanted to do an album celebrating the events. I had spent a lot of time in Nigeria in a club owned by Bobby Benson, a drummer, and Fela and other African musicians would come and sit in and play. It was a great experience, so some of the tunes are about that scene. And I'll be doing some material off of a big band album I just recorded for Antilles.
"My interest in Africa had started even earlier, though," said Mr. Weston. "It came out of my wonderful father. When I was a very little boy he had books about Africa, and he loved Marcus Garvey. He always said to me that Africa was the beginning of civilization. He instilled Africa in me, that we had a glorious history, that we were a global people. Since then I've tried to meet my brothers and sisters around the world. And he made me take piano lessons!"
Though Mr. Weston works with larger groups, he rarely performs with a big orchestra. The show will feature the arrangements and writing of Melba Liston, one of the best arrangers to come up in the 1950's. Ms. Liston and Mr. Weston have collaborated over the years -- they've just completed a new big band project -- and they work wonderfully together.
"I love working with a big band because you get all those extra colors and sounds," said Mr. Weston. "And Melba is so so skillful she knows what I'm going to do before I do it. She can take my compositions and get the sounds that the pieces call for. I'm ceally thankful to her, and the incredible musicians who are playing this music."

HEADLINE: THE COUNCIL PRIMARIES;
Apathy May Give New York Council an Old Look

BYLINE: By JOSH BARBANEL

 BODY:
New York City is about to hold its most important City Council primary in memory, but standing outside a supermarket in Flushing, Queens, the other day, Armando Correa said he had other, more pressing things on his mind.
"I don't think about it," he said of tomorrow's primary. "I got my son, my wife and my work, that's what I think about. I'm going to die anyway like everybody else. So what's the point?" 
 Mr. Correa is not alone. On the eve of the primary, political analysts and election officials are predicting the lowest voter turnout in years, perhaps below 25 percent. This campaign for a more powerful, expanded City Council has been widely heralded as a historic opportunity to open politics to minority groups and independent candidates. But to talk to experts, and to potential voters, is to see few signs that all the hoopla and good intentions will be able to break through a deepening disaffection for politics and politicians.
Advocates of the new system say that this apathy threatens to undermine the promise of these Council elections. Low turnouts traditionally benefit incumbents and others who can draw on the resources of well-organized political groups.
"The collective city doesn't care about these elections," said Gene Russianoff, director of the New York Public Interest Research Group, who lobbied for changes on the Council. "There is a saying: The worst thing that can happen to reformers is that they get what they want."
According to Mr. Russianoff and other political experts, a pervasive disaffection with politics is being compounded by a host of more specific problems, from the Council's poor reputation to a dearth of compelling issues. Then there are the logistics: Voters are being asked to choose from often long lists of candidates running in 51 new districts whose boundaries slash through traditional neighborhoods, in a primary held on the wrong day of the week and on the wrong year in the election cycle.
"Even the people who always vote, the Jewish ladies in senior citizens centers and the black women churchgoers, who walk through snowstorms to vote, are being caught unawares this year," said Norman Adler, a political consultant working to elect a slate of incumbent Council members and their allies. "When people get very confused about something in politics, rather than sorting it out they tend to stay home."
The confusion is so deep that many candidates, running in large fields with little money, are all but despairing of getting their names known, let alone their views, to all but a small fraction of the most sophisticated voters.
And where candidates try to beat the odds through sophisticated vote pulling -- identifying potential supporters and getting them to the polls -- they are finding that most of the voters they call are undecided, and don't know who the candidates are.
In 1985, 35 percent of the eligible voters cast ballots in Council primaries, according to the Board of Elections. Four years later, the figure for the Council rose to 40 percent, when many voters turned out for the crucial mayoral primary won by David N. Dinkins.
 
25 Percent Turnout or Less
 This year, Daniel DeFrancesco, the executive director of the Board of Elections, is predicting a 25 percent turnout, while others estimate that the turnout could drop to 15 percent or so -- an abysmal turnout by most standards, but still above the 7 percent turnout reported in school board elections.
And Mr. DeFrancesco said the turnout might be even lower but for the multiplier effect of races with eight or nine candidates. No matter how obscure, each candidate is likely to draw at least a couple of hundred relatives and friends into local voting booths.
Little of this was envisioned when the Charter Revision Commission -- formed after the United States Supreme Court found the city's Board of Estimate unconstitutional -- decided to enlarge the City Council to 51 members from 35, in order to increase the number of minority representatives.
Under pressure to change, the commission decided to hold elections for the new seats as quickly as possible -- only halfway through the four-year terms of incumbent Council members.
 
Impact of Machine Politics
 By holding the election in an off-year, when there were no other significant races -- for mayor, governor or President -- advocates of change thought they would be giving more independent and minority candidates a chance of being elected. Instead they now worry that machine politicians and powerful labor unions could shape the results of an election with very little turnout.
Still, Mr. Russianoff noted that lackluster voter interest in the City Council reflected the poor voter participation in New York; in last year's gubernatorial race the turnout was less than 30 percent across the state.
"You have to judge this election in the context of what is in this state a nearly lifeless democracy," he said. "This won't be the first or last city election with a light turnout."
In the Eighth Council District, which stretches from the upper West Side to the South Bronx, most passers-by whisked past candidates without stopping, or crumpled up campaign literature before they reached the bottom of the subway stairs.
 
Candidates Untangle Maps
 When voters buttonhole the candidates they are as likely to ask about the boundaries of the Council districts as solicit views on city tax policy.
Campaigning at 110th Street and Broadway the other day, Philip Reed, one of eight candidates, said that his biggest obstacle so far had been convincing voters that Carolyn B. Maloney, the popular incumbent Council representative, was running in a different district on the East Side, and would no longer appear on the ballot.
"In the past week more people have become aware that there is a primary coming up," he said.
Across the street, another candidate, Nelson Antonio Denis, said that without money for television and radio, candidates stood little chance of stirring the interest of voters. He blamed the current City Council for this situation.
 
Other News Than Local Politics
 "The Council's reputation is deservedly bad," he said. "It has been the antithesis of activism."
They said they both feared that a low turnout could elect a third opponent, William Del Toro, who is supported by the Democratic organization in East Harlem and may be able to pull many party loyalists.
Other reasons for the lack of interest include the deep local recession and the grim mood in the city this summer, and the distractions of major news events -- a subway crash, racial disturbances in Crown Heights and upheaval in the Soviet Union -- that have pushed local politics off the front pages.
"People are more concerned about whether they have a job or can go home safely at night than who their City Council representative is going to be," said Henry J. Stern, a former Manhattan Councilman, and president of the Citizens Union, a civic group.
 
'There Are No Great Issues'
 Then there is the notion that with buzzwords like land use, equalization rate and resource recovery, and with the city in dire financial straits, the Council has few compelling issues or dramatic conflicts to capture the imagination of the public.
"There are no great issues that divide anybody," Mr. Stern said. "The city is broke and nobody knows what to do about it."
Hubert James, a mayoral aide who is campaign director for an effort to elect a slate of "progressive" candidates, who favor raising taxes on the rich, blamed local television news for all but ignoring the Council primary.
"It is a major failure of the electronic media here," he said. "There is nobody on television talking about the election, and that is where most folks get their news. Voters don't know who their existing Council people are, and they don't know who is running."
But television news executives say that if they tried to cover 51 Council races, viewers would simply turn the channel. "The trend is to not cover particular races and personalities, and cover the broader issues," said Bret Marcus, news director of WNBC-TV. "If they care about it, they know where and how to find out about it."
 
'Nobody Is Really Honest'
 Then there are New Yorkers who would not vote no matter what.
Marty Jenkins, who owns a locksmith store on Kissena Boulevard in Flushing, belonged to a Democratic political club for 20 years, but dropped out and stopped voting, disillusioned, he said, over the lies politicians tell.
"Nobody is really honest, from the councilmen up to the President of the United States," he said. "Sometimes I feel bad that I don't vote -- but I don't want to vote for anybody who isn't giving me a clear-cut program and who I don't know if they are telling me the truth."
And Juan Ruiz, a 44-year-old nurse, said he hadn't voted for eight years. "I work and I survive," he said. "I don't think much about it. I'm tired of people."

HEADLINE: GYMNASTICS;
Soviets Triumph; Americans Place 5th

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 10

 BODY:
There might be uncertainty at home, with all the political and economic upheaval. But here at the world championships of gymnastics tonight, all was calm and orderly for the men of the Soviet Union.
For the fourth consecutive time the event has been held and the sixth in the last seven since 1979, the Soviet athletes proved themselves the best among 30 countries as they won the team competition and led 12 countries automatic qualifying for the 1992 Barcelona Olympics. 
 The United States, which competed with only five athletes because of an injury to Lance Ringnald, its most experienced gymnast, survived a few bumpy performances and finished fifth, a remarkable accomplishment and the team's highest placement since the 1983 tournament in Budapest. There, the Americans were fourth behind China, the Soviet Union and Japan.
 
Never a Major Factor
 But even with so strong and unexpected performance tonight, the United States was never a major factor in medal contention. As the Soviet athletes moved far into a lead early and were never challenged, they finished with 584.425 points and the largest margin of victory for a title at world championships, Olympics or European championships in more than 16 years.
China edged Germany for second, 577.050 to 576.125.
The points represent a total of the five best scores of each team on each of the six apparatuses -- floor exercise, pommel horse, rings, vault, parallel bars and high bar -- through two rounds of competition, compulsories and optionals. The lowest of the scores is dropped.
The Soviet Union's victory was built on the sheer power of consistency and depth of talent. Nothing demonstrated that better than the intra-team competition that left the defending all-around champion, Igor Korobchinski, out of the all-around competition on Thursday.
No more than three athletes from one country can qualify among the 36, and Korobchinski's 116.700 points left him fourth in the overall individual standings behind Vitaly Scherbo (117.175), Grigori Misutin (116.900) and Valeri Lyukin (116.825), the only Soviet performer remaining from the 1988 Olympic team.
Alexei Voropaev scored the fewest points for the Soviet team, 115.150, and he still finished 12th in the overall standings among 212 athletes from more than 50 nations.
The leading American was Scott Keswick, in 15th, with 114.375 points. Keswick, Jarrod Hanks (28th) and Chris Waller (tied for 29th) scored high enough to gain positions in the all-around competition.
 
'Ready Psychologically'
 "We were ready psychologically as well as athletically," the Soviet team coach, Leonid Arkaev, said as his six team members sat beaming at his right. "We are very happy. They showed everybody what they can do."
The silver medal for China represented an improvement from third place at the 1989 tournament in Stuttgart. The bronze for Germany was ironic in that the team represented a united Germany, and all six athletes are from what was once East Germany. In 1989, East Germany finished second, and West Germany was 10th.
The Americans tied for eigth in 1989, so they were not unexpectedly thrilled with their performance. It was particularly more satisfying in that, with Ringnald out after tearing a pectoral muscle during the compulsory round on Saturday, they were left without margin for error.
Yet even though they experienced break downs, like Keswick's inexplicable collapse at the end of his floor exercise routine, they never compounded a mistake with another.
Francis Allen, the team coach, cited a mistake by Patrick Kirksey on the pommel horse to make his point. Kirksey stopped in the middle of his routine, when his weight was too far back, interrupting momentum into his next maneuver.
"But he got back up and finished perfectly and got a 9.2," Allen noted of Kirksey's 9.250 score. "If he lacked concentration and screwed up again, he would have gotten an 8.5, and that would probably have dropped us another spot."
"No," he said, "I couldn't be more pleased. Everything we asked of these guys, they gave it to us."
The team competition also qualified athletes to compete for titles on individual events this weekend, but here, the Americans were less successful. Only Keswick became eligible for his work on the rings and the high bar.
By comparison, the Soviet team advanced two athletes, the maximum allowed, into each of the six events.

HEADLINE: U.S. MOVES TO CURB MEDICAID PAYMENTS FOR MANY STATES

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10

 BODY:
Despite protests from Republican as well as Democratic governors, the Bush Administration today issued new rules intended to eliminate what it described as a "scam" used by states to extract $3 billion to $5 billion a year from the Federal Government for Medicaid benefits.
The move has broad political, fiscal and medical implications. Under the rules, the Federal Government will no longer match spending by states for Medicaid if the state money comes from donations or special taxes paid by hospitals and nursing homes. 
 Medicaid finances health care for 27 million low-income people, with the Federal Government and the states sharing the cost. The state share rises with a state's per capita income from 20 percent in the poorest state, Mississippi, to 50 percent in affluent states like New York and California.
 
37 States at Issue
 The Department of Health and Human Services said 37 states used such donations and taxes to obtain extra money from the Federal Government.
States still use general revenues to pay most of their Medicaid costs and say they use donations and taxes to supplement, not to supplant, state spending. But in the last two years, states have increasingly resorted to creative financing techniques for a number of reasons: Congress has imposed new burdens, expanding Medicaid to cover millions of additional women and children in low-income families, health costs are soaring and state revenues are plunging because of the recession.
The Administration contends that the practice of raising Federal money by counting donations and taxes as part of a state's Medicaid share is a major factor in the "explosion" of Federal Medicaid costs, from $41 billion last year to $52 billion this year and a projected $62 billion next year. And it contends that the increase in Medicaid costs contributes to the growth of the Federal budget deficit, which is expected to exceed $340 billion next year.
 
Effort to Delay Rules
 But in a statement issued on behalf of the National Governors' Association, Gov. John R. McKernan Jr. of Maine, a Republican, warned that hospitals might close, and that "women and children will lose eligibility" for Medicaid because of the new restrictions on states in raising money for Medicaid.
Mike Lawrence, press secretary for Gov. Jim Edgar of Illinois, a Republican, said: "This is a blatant and very unfortunate case of changing the rules in the middle of the game. It affects the ability of nearly 40 states to finance health-care programs for the poor, including many programs mandated by the Federal Government."
Governor Edgar "believes that the Federal bureaucracy has overstepped its bounds and gone way beyond what the law permits," Mr. Lawrence said.
The governors, joined by hospitals, other health-care providers and advocates for the poor, will lobby Congress to delay the new rules.
The regulations, signed Friday by Dr. Louis W. Sullivan, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, were approved Monday by the White House Office of Management and Budget and will be published Thursday in The Federal Register. They are scheduled to take effect, with the force of law, on Jan. 1.
A senior Administration official said: "States will all come in and sue to block these regulations. We knew that from the beginning. They don't like losing money."
 
Moves by Budget Chief
 The new rules were espoused in particular by Richard G. Darman, the director of the Office of Management and Budget, who said that states were perpetrating a scam to obtain extra money from the Federal Government at little or no cost to state treasuries. The substance of the rules on donations and special taxes was known in advance and provoked bipartisan outrage at a meeting of the National Governors' Association in Seattle last month.
Brad C. Johnson, director of the New York State office in Washington, said: "This is an example of Darman waging fiscal war against the states. Rather than seeking cooperation on comprehensive health-care reform, he, in effect, accuses us of stealing from the Federal Treasury to provide health care for the poor." New York has a tax on hospitals and stands to lose hundreds of millions of dollars in Federal Medicaid payments next year, Mr. Johnson said.
The states' financing devices work this way: States collect "voluntary donations" or taxes from hospitals, count these contributions as part of the state share of Medicaid and then get $2 or $3 of Federal matching money for each dollar paid by the hospitals.
The Office of Management and Budget says these devices will cost the Federal Government $3 billion this year and at least $5 billion next year.
 
Started Unveiling in Massachusetts
 These techniques became well known when Kathleen Betts, a 10-year veteran of the Massachusetts Department of Public Welfare, used them this spring to obtain more than $450 million of additional Federal money for the state's Medicaid program.
Dr. Sullivan was traveling today in Africa, but in a statement issued through his office here, he said: "The use of donations and provider taxes increases Federal Medicaid costs without an increase in state expenditures or services, effectively altering the matching rate. These devices are contrary to the cost-sharing partnership that is the hallmark of Medicaid."
State Medicaid officials, hospital executives and members of Congress say the new rules will severely impair the ability of the states to finance health care for poor people.
Robert H. Sweeney, president of the National Association of Children's Hospitals, said: "Both the family that depends on Medicaid for health care and the provider that cares for many low-income families should be alarmed. The Federal Government's new rules will throw state Medicaid programs into financial jeopardy."
"Even the family with private insurance should be alarmed, because crippled Medicaid programs force health-care providers to curtail their services or raise their prices to the privately insured," he said.
 
Predictions of Doom
 In a recent letter to Congress, Gov. Guy Hunt of Alabama, a Republican, contended that the new rules would "decimate the state's Medicaid program." Robert P. Casey of Pennsylvania and Wallace G. Wilkinson of Kentucky are among the many Democratic governors who have objected to the rules. Senators Christopher S. Bond and John C. Danforth of Missouri, both Republicans, have also objected.
Under the rules, the Federal Government will no longer match state Medicaid payments when the state share is derived from either donations or certain types of taxes, imposed exclusively on hospitals, nursing homes or institutions for the mentally retarded.
While the Federal Government would not recognize the cost of such "provider-specific taxes," adopted by at least 29 states, it might help states reimburse hospitals for the cost of some broad-based taxes, like a sales tax imposed on all corporations or businesses in a state.
The decision about which taxes qualify for Federal matching payments will be decided after a close examination of the facts in each case. But the Department of Health and Human Services said that "most current state programs which use taxes to increase payments to hospitals with unusually large Medicaid caseloads" will not qualify.
 
Some Taxes Are Held Acceptable
 State officials said the new rules would disrupt state Medicaid operations because they would take effect in the middle of a fiscal year.
Officials in Massachusetts, California and other states said they believed that, with minor adjustments, some of the unorthodox techniques used by states to raise money for Medicaid might pass muster under the new rules. In a preamble to the rules, the Administration said the new restrictions "will in no way preclude states from increasing their share of Medicaid expenditure from other sources."
The Federal Department of Health and Human Services first proposed the rules in February 1990. It received 79 comments from the public, "only a few" in support of the proposal, the preamble said.
A survey by the American Public Welfare Association in August identified 29 states that had programs to finance Medicaid through donations from hospitals or special taxes imposed on health-care providers. The states were expecting to get $2.3 billion in Federal matching payments for the donations and $4.4 billion in Federal matching payments for the taxes. Some states use both techniques, and some did not respond to the survey.
States with the special taxes included Alabama, Arkansas, Illinois, Indiana, Kentucky, Massachusetts, Maine, Minnesota, Montana, New Hampshire, New Jersey, Nevada, New York, Ohio, South Carolina, Tennessee, Vermont, Washington and Wisconsin, the survey found.
States that raise money through voluntary contributions include California, Georgia, Michighan, Missouri, North Carolina, Pennsylvania, South Carolina and Utah, the survey reported. Florida, Maryland and Mississippi have adopted both techniques, it said.

HEADLINE: EATING WELL;
Major U.S. Survey on Food Use and Pesticides Is Drawing Fire

BYLINE: By MARIAN BURROS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9

 BODY:
The Federal Government's most important food consumption survey, which is instrumental in setting such Government policies as the school lunch program and calculating the tolerance level for pesticide residues in food, is so flawed it is probably useless, according to a scientific panel and the General Accounting Office.
That agency, an investigative arm of Congress, faults both the Department of Agriculture, which conducts the National Food Consumption Survey once a decade, and the company that did the work, National Analysts, a marketing concern, for mishandling the 1987-88 survey, which cost $7.6 million. 
 The Agriculture Department acknowledges the flaws.
The agency's Food and Nutrition Service uses the food and nutrient data to evaluate billion-dollar assistance programs like food stamp allotments and the school breakfast and lunch programs. The Environmental Protection Agency uses it to set pesticide tolerance levels in food. The Food and Drug Administration uses it to calculate nutrient-consumption levels and determine public exposure to pesticides and toxic metals. The Government also uses it to track food trends.
The problem with the survey "really complicates any statement about dietary changes in the population," said Catherine Woteki, director of the Food and Nutrition Board at the National Academy of Sciences.
The worst problem is the survey's low response rate of 34 percent, making it questionable whether the data are representative of the population, the G.A.O. said. Such surveys also require follow-up studies of those who do not respond. National Analysts, which conducted the survey, told both the Agriculture Department and the General Accounting Office that its follow-up data had been lost, but finally acknowledged that no follow-ups were conducted, the report said.
The G.A.O. undertook the investigation at the request of Representative George E. Brown Jr., Democrat of California. It notified the Agriculture Department of the problems and the department asked the Federation of American Societies for Experimental Biology to review the data. The clinical research organization's report said it "does not recommend use of the data" and if the Agriculture Department chose to publish the data, it "should include a strongly worded cautionary statement concerning the potential for nonresponse bias."
Roger Runngen, a spokesman for Edward Madigan, the Secretary of Agriculture, said yesterday that the department is taking steps "to make future surveys more accurate."
Michael McCullough, chairman of the board of Booz, Allen & Hamilton, which owns National Analysts, said the company has "taken a number of steps to insure the quality and timeliness of the work. I'm professionally embarrassed by it."
Agencies that rely on the department's data have two other choices: use data collected by the Department of Health and Human Services in its Health and Nutrition Examination Survey, or Hanes, or keep using the 1977-78 survey. "Within the scientific community there has always been some question about the validity of the 77-78 survey," Dr. Woteki said.
The response rate was 62 percent in that earlier survey, "a very low response compared to other surveys at the time," Dr. Woteki said. The nonrespondents in that survey were not followed up.
The Hanes studies have a response rate of 77 percent to 86 percent and health professionals have always considered them more reliable gauges of food consumption patterns than the U.S.D.A. surveys.
The statistical differences are often serious. The 1977-78 food consumption researchers reported that women 19 to 50 years of age were consuming 41 percent of their calories from fat; the Hanes 1976-80 study found the same group consuming 36 percent from fat.
"We have a big nationwide campaign going on about reduction of fat," Dr. Woteki said. "If the 77-78 survey is not reliable, how can we assess the change?"
Some Government agencies like the E.P.A have decided to ignore the latest Agriculture Department survey. This May, the G.A.O. warned the E.P.A. of serious problems with the data. "The sample was so small for some subgroups that they may not be useful to extrapolate to the entire population," said Kevin Donohue, assistant director of the G.A.O.'s resources, community and economic development division. "The tolerance levels may not be set at levels that will protect all these subgroups," which include nursing infants and pregnant women.
Linda Fisher, Assistant Administrator in the E.P.A.'s office of pesticides and toxic substances, said the agency will to continue to use the 1977-78 data to determine consumption rates despite its flaws because the data were more reliable. "It is out of date," she said, "because eating patterns have changed. People are eating more fruits and vegetables."
But the Food and Drug Administration has decided to use the data from the new survey because "we have to work with what we have," said Jean Pennington, associate director of dietary surveillance in the agency's Center for Food Safety and Applied Nutrition. "We will look very cautiously at the intake of nutrients, heavy metals and pesticides and if the results are consistent with previous years, we will go ahead." alternative, she said, is to use the Hanes study now underway, some of which will be available in 1992.
The Department of Agriculture bases the food plans for the school lunch and breakfast programs, the Thrifty Food Plan and food stamp allotments on the survey data. The school lunches are intended to meet one-third of the Recommended Daily Allowances for various nutrients. The foods in the program are selected on the basis of what the survey says schoolchildren eat most frequently. Mr. Runngen said he did not know what the agency would do about using the data.
"What has happened with the survey is exactly why the nutrition committee has worked so hard to get the Nutrition Monitoring Act passed," said Marion Nestle, chairwoman of New York University's nutrition department, who was editor of the Surgeon General's 1988 Report on Nutrition and Health. "U.S.D.A has always fought it. We have all been aware for a really long time that it is impossible to get any trends. The Surgeon General's report tells everyone to eat less fat, but we have no idea if people are eating less fat."
Representative Brown, who asked for the inquiry, sponsored the Nutrition Monitoring Act that was passed last year by Congress. "One of my efforts," he said, "has been to establish a framework for all such surveys to make them more comprehensive and reliable."
He said there was "considerable evidence of absolute fraud in some areas of the survey" and he has turned over the findings to the Inspector General of the U.S.D.A.
He said the survey should not be conducted every 10 years, but rather should be ongoing. "I am moderately encouraged by the positive response of the U.S.D.A., because they hate to admit mistakes," he said.

HEADLINE: Upscale Down-and-Outers Try Pawning

BYLINE: By NICK RAVO

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA

 BODY:
THE lawyer needed an engagement ring but had lost his credit by filing for bankruptcy. The advertising agency owner couldn't meet her payroll because her clients were paying their bills late. The fifth-grade teacher wanted to trim her credit card balance without her husband's knowledge.
So where did each of these upscale and respectable, though cash-poor, people turn? 
 Not to family, friends or conventional financial lenders. Instead, they used pawnshops, reaching out to an old but fast-growing and rapidly changing industry that until recently was best known for its unsavory characters (from Shylock in "The Merchant of Venice" to Rod Steiger in "The Pawnbroker") and usurious interest rates (as high as 24 percent a month, depending on the state).
"It's just very, very convenient," said the teacher, Angela Lindsey of West Deptford, N.J., who recently pawned a bracelet and a watch for $600 at Carver W. Reed, a 131-year-old pawnshop in Center City here. "The bank gives you such a runaround."
Though pawnshops are often lauded by customers for their easy and speedy transactions, the real lure has been their willingness to act as the lender of last resort for the working poor, who often find themselves abandoned by the mainstream banking world.
But they are being joined by increasing numbers of middle-class and even more affluent customers, hard hit by recession-related layoffs, bankruptcies, foreclosures and tight credit, as well as other modern money maladies, like high medical bills and costly divorce settlements.
"On any given day, you'll see as many suits and ties come in here as blue jeans and T-shirts," said Tod Gordon, the owner of Carver W. Reed.
Pawnshops profit by making loans in exchange for items that serve as collateral. Monthly interest rates, excluding storage fees and other charges, range from 2 percent in some states, like Connecticut, to 24 percent in Mississippi. If the interest is not paid on time, the collateral is forfeited to the pawnbroker, who often sells it at near-wholesale prices. On average, shops hold goods about 60 days before they are forfeited.
No precise statistics are kept on the number of people who receive loans from pawnshops, although John P. Caskey, an associate professor of economics at Swarthmore College, has estimated that one in 10 Americans use them at least once a year.
The number of pawnbrokers in the nation, however, has grown by more than half in the last five years, from 4,849 to 7,354, according to American Business Information, a research organization in Omaha.
The industry is booming most in the South and West, particularly in Florida and Texas, which have more than 2,000 pawnshops combined. "You never know what's coming through that door," said Mike O'Neill, the owner of the Happy Hocker in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. "I did a pawn on a 31-foot Chris-Craft. I lent him $10,000. He said he needed it because they were going to foreclose on his house."
Pawnshops are least numerous in the Northeast, because of state regulations that hold down the interest rates they can charge. In New York City, where state law caps the monthly rate at 3 percent, the number of pawnshops has declined to 15 today from more than 120 in World War II.
Another regional difference is that many shops in the Northeast accept only gems and jewelry, not the television sets, VCR's, personal computers and compact disk players that are commonly used as collateral elsewhere. (Tales of customers' offering items like artificial limbs, false teeth or shoes are generally apocryphal.)
"We did have somebody pawn a python named Sylvia," Mr. O'Neill said. "We had to keep it away from the jewelry area. Planes are big, too."
Pawnbrokers describe many of their customers as young and financially inexperienced. Others work in low-paying nonunion or service industry jobs. A few, of course, are chronic overspenders doomed to a life in debt.
But a sizable new segment appears to be made up of professionals or middle-class homeowners who are pawning the playthings they pursued passionately in the ostentatious 80's.
For example, the Philadelphia lawyer who needed an engagement ring pawned a gold Rolex watch for $1,600. "I don't feel any stigma," said the lawyer, who refused to discuss the transaction without a guarantee of anonymity. "I feel gouged."
Pawnshops are particularly popular with Christmas shoppers looking for bargains. "People come in for everything from skateboards to toolboxes and television sets," said Betty Payton, the executive director of the National Pawnbrokers Association in Fort Lauderdale. "A lot of the items, once they are cleaned and polished, you can't tell if they have been used."
Hoping to broaden this new customer base even further, pawnbrokers are working to change an unflattering image that has often portrayed them as cold-hearted cheats preying on the poor and the unfortunate, or as fences squinting through jewelers' loupes and providing quick cash for stolen goods, no questions asked.
The Rodeo Drive Jewelry Loans Shop in Beverly Hills, Calif., for example, receives customers by appointment only. And the Pawnbrokers Association of New York recently changed its name to the Collateral Loan Brokers Association.
"There has been a gradual image change," Ms. Payton said. "Pawnbrokers realize that more and more, people are stepping into their shops for the first time."
Some pawnshops are even becoming financial centers, cashing checks, taking payment on bills and making loans for tickets from other pawnshops. They promote their loan application process as quick and trouble free and are willing to make frequent and small loans (sometimes as little as $5). They also run ads on television and are moving away from seedier sections to more desirable areas, like suburban shopping centers.
Then there is Cash America Investments Inc. of Fort Worth, the nation's largest pawnshop operator, with 161 stores in seven states. The chain aspires to become the 7-Eleven of pawnshops, in ubiquity as well as in cleanliness and service. It even became a publicly traded company on the New York Stock Exchange in 1987.
"We do a better job of showcasing merchandise," said the company's chairman, Jack R. Daugherty. He added that many customers are attracted to pawnshops because the shops do not require checking accounts, bank cards or other conventional credit arrangements. About 26 percent of the adults in the United States, or almost 50 million people, do not use banks, according to Mediamark Research in New York.
"We're kind of like a bank on one side and a retail store on the other," Mr. Daugherty said.
Often referred to as the world's second oldest profession, pawnbroking can be traced to the Germanic Lombards who established themselves in northern Italy around A.D. 500. The shield of St. Thomas of Lombard included three purses of gold that evolved into the symbol of the three balls that adorn the entrances of many pawnshops and are often inscribed "buy, sell, trade."
The business has other exalted roots: the Medici were among the first pawnbrokers or moneylenders, as they were often called then; Isabella of Castile pawned her jewels to finance Columbus's first voyage; J. P. Morgan was a founder of the Provident Loan Society in New York, the nation's only not-for-profit pawnshop. And a New York socialite, Evalyn Walsh McLean, tried to pawn the Hope diamond to raise ransom money for the kidnapped Lindbergh baby.
Professor Caskey of Swarthmore noted that pawnshops once provided a standard means of moneylending for much of the nation. "At the turn of the century, commercial banks didn't do business with the middle class," he said. "Now I can see, to a much smaller degree, a similar trend because of deregulation."
Mr. Daugherty agreed. "There are more stores now because the business is better accepted, and it's out in the open, and it's fulfilling a need," he said. "We believe that one-third of the people in the country fit the mold of the pawnshop customer."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Tod Gordon appraising a diamond ring offered for a loan. (Bill Cramer for The New York Times) (pg. C9)

HEADLINE: Wine Talk

BYLINE: By Frank J. Prial

 BODY:
THERE are lots of good wine buys around. So many that there is a tendency to get carried away while enumerating them. Consider what happened last week in this space. What was supposed to be an all-encompassing list of good red wines at reasonable prices had barely mentioned a few European wines when there was no more space.
Herewith then, another go at it, this one confined to our own shores and mostly California at that. The search for bargains from vines in the United States is getting tougher. The Italians, French and Spanish continue to turn out a splendid variety of excellent wines for $10 and under. 
 In California, wines in that price range are mostly made by larger wineries -- Beaulieu, Fetzer, Martini, Parducci, Rodney Strong. Smaller producers manage to keep some of their whites -- sauvignon blanc and chenin blanc -- in that range, but the bottom line for quality cabernet sauvigon is now approaching $15. The $30 bottle is quite commonplace, and the $50 and even the $75 bottle are no longer the sole province of the Bordelais. Even the egalitarian Gallo plan to develop a $60 cabernet and a $30 chardonnay from their Sonoma County vineyards.
Happily for most of us, the American vintners have not entirely forgotten their economic roots. The aforementioned Fetzers continue to produce a wide range of affordable wines, including their delicious Barrel Select cabernets. The 1987, a wine with both depth and softness, can be found in most good shops for around $10. Beaulieu Vineyard's Rutherford Cabernet is in the same price category, and the same company's low-priced Beautour continues to be one of the best bargains in good California cabernet, usually from $5 to $7.
Several prominent Napa Valley wineries buy wine in bulk, and blend and bottle it under second labels. These wines never come up to the quality of the estate-bottled wines of these wineries, but they are invariably good. Caymus Vineyard's Liberty School is a good example. Usually sold in vintages, but sometimes nonvintage, the wine sells for around $8 and is an excellent buy at that price.
Stag's Leap Wine Cellars' Hawk Crest is a similar second label line of wines. Since they go out under the imprimatur of Warren Winiarski, the man behind Stag's Leap, they are a safe bet. The Hawk Crest cabernet also sells for about $8.
A bit of tannin gives Parducci's 1987 North Coast Counties cabernet (about $9) a nice edge. Sunny St. Helena's 1988 North Coast Cabernet and Louis Martini's 1988 Sonoma cabernet, both in the same price range, are of diffent styles but both good values. The A. Rafanelli Winery 1988 unfiltered Dry Creek cabernet is a bit more expensive, $12 to $13, but well worth it.
Rodney Strong is not just the name of a northern Sonoma winery; it's the name of the chap who started the whole thing. Years ago the winery was called Sonoma Vineyards, but it has always made good wine regardless of the name. His regular 1987 cabernet, at $10, is a most worthy purchase: a good solid cabernet that has a few years ahead of it and that can hold its own in wines at twice the price.
And if it turns you on, look for the Mr. Strong's 1985 pinot noir with a Russian River Valley appellation. It's a single vineyard wine from his River East Vineyard and it, too, sells for around $10. Chambertin it's not. But it is true pinot noir in the Burgundy style at a truly reasonable price. What more is there to say?
Well, there is this: the late, great Frank Schoonmaker would roll over in his grave if he could see what is happening to grenache rose. Mr. Schoonmaker was a travel writer for The New Yorker turned wine writer, O.S.S. agent and, later, consultant to the California wine industry. He was the first to push for the use of varietal names -- the names of the grapes -- for wines made from those grapes.
One of his first successes was Almaden's rose jug wine made from the grenache grape. Grenache, a workaday grape that gave body and character to many a jug wine in its time, fell out of favor when California decided to concentrate on the so-called noble varieties, like cabernet sauvignon.
More recently, the grapes of the Rhone Valley in France have been much in vogue, the grenache among them. So our old jug wine friend grenache is back, both in its natural red state and also as a rose. History repeats itself. Try the Joseph Phelps 1990 Grenache Rose at $9 or McDowell Valley Vineyards Grenache Rose, made from old vines, at $7.50. Are they much better than the old Almaden jug version? I doubt it. No matter; they are delightful light wines that can serve as a relief from both reds and whites, depending on your mood.
White zinfandel, the darling of the singles bars, needs no introduction. It's wet, cold, fizzy and sweet, and many people love it. Red zinfandel is another matter; it is a serious wine that can reach great heights. Zinfandel may not have the elegance of the best cabernets but not every occasion calls for elegance.
Sutter Home's regular North Coast 1988 zinfandel is a relatively simple wine, soft and accessible, with no harsh tannins but with lots of flavor. For about $5 a bottle, it's hard to beat. Unless you should try the same Napa Valley winery's Amador County Reserve 1987 for about $10. Amador County, in the Sierra foothills, is zinfandel country. It produces solid, tannic wines like this one that will make anyone a zinfandel fan -- red zinfandel, that is.
For a different style, try Cain Cellars' 1989 Contra Costa County zinfandel for about $9. It doesn't have the tannin of the Amador wine but it's full of flavor and easy to drink.
At this time of year, quite a few people are looking for a decent kosher red from California. There are a few, notably the wines from Hagafen Cellars and Weinstock Cellars, but they can be pricey. The Baron Herzog Sonoma cabernet 1986 was an excellent buy for around $10.50, as was the Herzog Special Reserve Sonoma cabernet for about $15. They may have been replaced by newer vintages in some shops; no matter -- they will grace any holiday table.
 
TASTINGS
Chateau Pontet-Canet, Pauillac, 1986; about $17.
 Pontet-Canet, with its magnificent site next to Mouton-Rothschild, its great chai and immense underground cellars, should be one of the important properties in Pauillac. After a long mediocre period, it may be on the way to becoming just that. The estate was owned for many years by the Cruse family, which used it more as a brand name than as a place to make a chateau wine. Back when French trains went slow enough to need dining cars, nonvintage Pontet-Canet was a popular railroad wine. In fact, chateau bottling was not instituted at Pontet-Canet until 1972. The Cruses sold the property in 1975 or, at least, it was taken over by a son-in-law, Guy A. Tesseron, a Cognac merchant who already owned Chateau Lafon-Rochet, a mile or so to the north in St.-Estephe. Pontet-Canet is now run by Mr. Tesseron's son, Alfred, who lives there and who has undertaken a thorough upgrading of the estate. The 1986 has all the richness one expects from a good Pauillac. The color is deep ruby and the bouquet is classic black currant. It may not yet show the breed of more famous Pauillac properties, but at this price it is an exceptional buy.
