HEADLINE: THE THOMAS HEARINGS;
Excerpts From Senate Session on the Thomas Nomination

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from the transcript of today's opening session of Senate Judiciary Committee hearings on the nomination of Clarence Thomas to the Supreme Court with questioning by Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr., the committee chairman; Senator Strom Thurmond and Senator Edward M. Kennedy:
 
Opening Remarks By Judge Thomas
 Mr. Chairman, Senator Thurmond, members of the committee, I am humbled and honored to have been nominated by President Bush to be an Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States. I would like to thank the committee, especially you, Chairman Biden, for your extraordinary fairness throughout this process, and I would like to thank each of you and so many of your colleagues here in the Senate for taking the time to visit with me. 
 There are not enough words to express my deep gratitude and appreciation to Senator Danforth, who gave me my first job out of Yale Law School. I have never forgotten the terms of his offer to me: more work for less pay than anyone in the country could offer. Believe me, he delivered on his promise, especially the less pay.
I appreciate his wise counsel and his example over the years, and his tireless efforts on my behalf during the confirmation process.
And I would like to thank Senators Bond, Nunn, Fowler, Warner, and Robb, for taking the time to introduce me today.
Much has been written about my family and me over the past 10 weeks. Through all that has happened throughout our lives and through all adversity, we have grown closer and our love for each other has grown stronger and deeper. I hope these hearings will help to show more clearly who this person Clarence Thomas is and what really makes me tick.
My earliest memories, as alluded to earlier, are those of Pin Point, Ga., a life far removed in space and time from this room, this day and this moment. As kids, we caught minnows in the creeks, fiddler crabs in the marshes, we played with pluffers, and skipped shells across the water. It was a world so vastly different from all this.
 
Shared Kitchen and Bathroom
 In 1955, my brother and I went to live with my mother in Savannah. We lived in one room in a tenement. We shared a kitchen with other tenants and we had a common bathroom in the backyard which was unworkable and unusable. It was hard, but it was all we had and all there was.
Our mother only earned $20 every two weeks as a maid, not enough to take care of us. So she arranged for us to live with our grandparents later, in 1955. Imagine, if you will, two little boys with all their belongings in two grocery bags. Our grandparents were two great and wonderful people who loved us dearly. I wish they were sitting here today. Sitting here so they could see that all their efforts, their hard work were not in vain, and so that they could see that hard work and strong values can make for a better life.
I am grateful that my mother and my sister could be here. Unfortunately, my brother could not be.
I attended segregated parochial schools and later attended a seminary near Savannah. The nuns gave us hope and belief in ourselves when society didn't. They reinforced the importance of religious beliefs in our personal lives. Sister Mary Virgilius, my eighth-grade teacher, and the other nuns were unyielding in their expectations that we use all of our talents no matter what the rest of the world said or did.
After high school, I left Savannah and attended Immaculate Conception Seminary, then Holy Cross College. I attended Yale Law School. Yale had opened its doors, its heart, its conscience to recruit and admit minority students. I benefitted from this effort.
My career is as been delineated today. I was an Assistant Attorney General in the State of Missouri. I was an attorney in the corporate law department of Monsanto Company. I joined Senator Danforth's staff here in the Senate, was an Assistant Secretary in the Department of Education, Chairman of E.E.O.C., and since 1990 a judge on the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit.
 
Standing on Others' Shoulders
 But for the efforts of so many others who have gone before me, I would not be here today. It would be unimaginable. Only by standing on their shoulders could I be here. At each turn in my life, each obstacle confronted, each fork in the road someone came along to help.
I remember, for example, in 1974 after I completed law school I had no money, no place to live. Mrs. Margaret Bush Wilson, who would later become chairperson of the N.A.A.C.P., allowed me to live at her house. She provided me not only with room and board, but advice, counsel and guidance.
As I left her house that summer, I asked her, "How much do I owe you?" Her response was, "Just along the way help someone who is in your position." I have tried to live by my promise to her to do just that, to help others.
So many others gave their lives, their blood, their talents. But for them I would not be here. Justice Marshall, whose seat I have been nominated to fill, is one of those who had the courage and the intellect. He is one of the great architects of the legal battles to open doors that seemed so hopelessly and permanently sealed and to knock down barriers that seemed so insurmountable to those of us in the Pin Point, Georgias of the world.
The civil rights movement, Reverend Martin Luther King and the S.C.L.C., Roy Wilkins and the N.A.A.C.P., Whitney Young and the Urban League, Fannie Lou Hamer, Rosa Parks and Dorothy Height, they changed society and made it reach out and affirmatively help. I have benefited greatly from their efforts. But for them there would have been no road to travel.
My grandparents always said there would be more opportunities for us. I can still hear my grandfather, "Y'all goin' have mo' of a chance then me," and he was right. He felt that if others sacrificed and created opportunities for us we had an obligation to work hard, to be decent citizens, to be fair and good people, and he was right.
You see, Mr. Chairman, my grandparents grew up and lived their lives in an era of blatant segregation and overt discrimination. Their sense of fairness was molded in a crucible of unfairness. I watched as my grandfather was called "boy." I watched as my grandmother suffered the indignity of being denied the use of a bathroom. But through it all they remained fair, decent, good people. Fair in spite of the terrible contradictions in our country.
 
The Values of My Youth
 They were hardworking, productive people who always gave back to others. They gave produce from the farm, fuel oil from the fuel oil truck. They bought groceries for those who were without, and they never lost sight of the promise of a better tomorrow. I follow in their footsteps and I have always tried to give back.
Over the years I have grown and matured. I have learned to listen carefully, carefully to other points of views and to others, to think through problems recognizing that there are no easy answers to difficult problems, to think deeply about those who will be affected by the decisions that I make and the decisions made by others. But I have always carried in my heart the world, the life, the people, the values of my youth, the values of my grandparents and my neighbors, the values of people who believed so very deeply in this country in spite of all the contradictions.
It is my hope that when these hearings are completed that this committee will conclude that I am an honest, decent, fair person. I believe that the obligations and responsibilities of a judge, in essence, involve just such basic values. A judge must be fair and impartial. A judge must not bring to his job, to the court, the baggage of preconceived notions, of ideology, and certainly not an agenda, and the judge must get the decision right. Because when all is said and done, the little guy, the average person, the people of Pin Point, the real people of America will be affected not only by what we as judges do, but by the way we do our jobs.
If confirmed by the Senate I pledge that I will preserve and protect our Constitution and carry with me the values of my heritage: fairness, integrity, open-mindedness, honesty, and hard work.
Thank you, Mr. Chairman.
 
Questions By Senator Biden
 Q. Judge, as Senator Danforth said, he hopes we have read your speeches. I assure you I have read all of your speeches, and I have read them in their entirety. And, as I indicated in my opening statement, what I want to talk about a little bit is one of the things you mention repeatedly in your speeches so that I can be better informed by what you mean by it.
Whether you are speaking in the speech you delivered on the occasion of Martin Luther King's birthday, a national holiday and whether it should be one, to a conservative audience, making the point that he should be looked to with more reverence or whether or not it was your speech to the Pacific Institute or whether or not it is the Harvard Journal, whatever it is you repeatedly invoke the phrase "natural rights" or "natural law."
And, as I said at the outset, here is good natural law, if you will, and bad natural law in terms of informing the Constitution, and there is a whole new school of thought in America that would like very much to use natural law to lower the protections for individuals in the zone of personal privacy, and I will speak to those later, and who want to heighten the protection for businesses and corporations.
Now, one of those people is a Professor Mesito, a fine first-class scholar at Harvard University. Another is Mr. Epstein, a professor at the University of Chicago. And, in the speech you gave in 1987 to the Pacific Research Institute you said, and I quote: "I find attractive the arguments of scholars such as Stephen Mesito who defend an activist Supreme Court that would" -- not could, would -- "strike down laws restricting property rights."
My question is a very simple one, Judge. What exactly do you find attractive about the arguments of Professor Mesito and other scholars like him?
A. Senator, again, it has been quite some time since I have read Professor Mesito and others. That was, I believe, 1987 or 1988. My interest in the whole area was as a political philosophy. My interest was in reassessing and demonstrating a sense that we understood what our founding fathers were thinking when they used phrases such as "All men are created equal," and what that meant for our form of Government.
I found Mesito interesting and his arguments interesting, as I remembered. Again, it has been quite some time. But I don't believe that in my writings I have indicated that we should have an activist Supreme Court or that we should have any form of activism on the Supreme Court. Again, I found his arguments interesting, and I was not talking particularly of natural law, Mr. Chairman, in the context of adjudication.
Q. I am not quite sure I understand your answer, Judge. You indicated that you find the arguments -- not interesting -- attractive, and you explicitly say one of the things you find attractive -- I am quoting from you: "I find attractive the arguments of scholars such as Steven Mesito who defend an activist Supreme Court that would strike down laws resisting property rights." . . .
A. Well, let me clarify something. I think it is important, Mr. Chairman. As I indicated, I believe, or attempted to allude to in my confirmation to the Court of Appeals, I don't see a role for the use of natural law in constitutional adjudication. My interest in exploring natural law and natural rights was purely in the context of political theory. I was interested in that. There were debates that I had with individuals, and I pursued that on a part-time basis. I was an agency chairman.
 
Theorizing vs. Adjudication
 Q. Well, judge, in preparing for these hearings, some suggested that might be your answer. So I went back through some of your writings and speeches to see if I misread them. And, quite frankly, I find it hard to square your speeches, which I will discuss with you in a minute, with what you are telling me today.
Just let me read some of your quotes. In a speech before the Federalist Society at the University of Virginia, in a variation of that speech that you published in the Harvard Journal of Law and Policy, you praised the first Justice Harlan's opinion in Plessy v. Ferguson, and you said, "Implicit reliance on political first principles was implicit rather than explicit, as is generally appropriate for the Court's opinions. He gives us a foundation for interpreting not only cases involving race, but the entire Constitution in the scheme of protecting rights." You went on to say, "Harlan's opinion provides one of our best examples of natural law and higher law jurisprudence."
Then you say, "The higher law background of the American Government, whether explicitly appealed to or not, provides the only firm basis for a just and wise constitutional decision."
Judge, what I would like to know is, I find it hard to understand how you can say what you are now saying, that you were only talking about the philosophy in a general philosophic sense, and not how it informed or impacted upon constitutional interpretation.
A. Well, let me attempt to clarify. That, in fact, though, was my approach. I was interested in the political theory standpoint. I was not interested in constitutional adjudication. I was not at the time adjudicating cases. But with respect to the background, I think that we can both agree that the founders of our country, or at least some of the drafters of our Constitution and our Declaration, believed in natural rights. And my point was simply that in understanding overall our constitutional government, that it was important that we understood how they believed -- or what they believed in natural law or natural rights.
 
Restricting Property Rights
 Q. . . . You also said in that speech out at the Pacific Research Institute, you said, "I am far from being a scholar on Thomas Jefferson, but two of his statements suffice as a basis for restoring our original founding belief and reliance on natural law, and natural law, when applied to America, means not medieval stultification but the liberation of commerce."
You speak many times -- I won't bore you with them, but I have pages and pages of quotes where you talk about natural law not in the context of your grandfather, not in the context of race, not in the context of equality, but you talk about it in the context of commerce, just like it is talked in the context, that context, by Mesito and by Epstein and others in their various books, a new fervent area of scholarship that basically says, Hey, look, we, the modern-day court, has not taken enough time to protect people's property, the property rights of corporations, the property rights of individuals, the property rights of businesses.
And so what we have to do is we have to elevate the way we have treated protecting property. We have to elevate that to make it harder for governments to interfere with the ability of -- in the case of Epstein the ability to have zoning laws, the ability to have pollution laws, the ability to have laws that protect the public welfare.
Then you say in another place in one of your speeches, you say, Well, look, I think that property rights should be given -- let me find the exact quote -- "should be given the exact same protection as," you say, "economic rights are as protected as much as any other rights," in a speech to the American Bar Association."
Now, Judge, understand my confusion. Economic rights now are not protected as much as any other rights. They are not protected that way now. They are given -- if they pass a rational basis test, in effect, it is all right to restrict property. When you start to restrict things that have to do with privacy and thought process, then you have to have a much stricter test. And so you quote Mesito. You talk about the liberation of commerce and natural law, whatever you want to call it, natural law or not. And then you say economic rights -- and, by the way, you made that speech to the A.B.A. the day after you made the speech where you praised Mesito.
 Can you tell me, can you enlighten me on how this was just some sort of philosophic musing?
A. Well, that is exactly what it was. I was interested in exactly what I have said I was interested in. And I think I have indicated in my confirmation to the Court of Appeals that I did not see a role for the application of natural rights to constitutional adjudication, and I stand by that.

 	 	 		. . .	 	
 
Right to Abortion
 Q. Now, Judge, in your view, does the Liberty Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment protect the right of women to decide for themselves in certain instances whether or not to terminate pregnancy?
A. Senator, first of all, let me look at that in the context other than with natural law principles.
Q. Let's forget about natural law for a minute.
A. My view is that there is a right to privacy in the Fourteenth Amendment.
Q. Well, Judge, does that right to privacy in the Liberty Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment protect the right of a woman to decide for herself in certain instances whether or not to terminate a pregnancy?
A. Senator, I think that the Supreme Court has made clear that the issue of marital privacy is protected, that the State cannot infringe on that without a compelling interest, and the Supreme Court, of course, in the case of Roe v. Wade has found an interest in the woman's right to -- as a fundamental interest a woman's right to terminate a pregnancy. I do not think that at this time that I could maintain my impartiality as a member of the judiciary and comment on that specific case.
Q. . . . Now, let me ask you this: Where does the decision lie? Does it lie with the Court? For example, you quote, with admiration, Mr. Lehrman's article. Mr. Lehrman's article was on natural law and -- I forget the exact title here. Let me find it. "Natural Law and the Right to Life." And you say when you are speaking at a gathering that you think that that is a superb application of natural law. You say, "It is a splendid example of applying natural law." Now, what did you mean by that?
 A. Well, let me go back to, I guess, my first comment to you when we were discussing natural law -- I think that is important -- and then come back to the question of the due process analysis.
 The speech that I was giving there was before the Heritage Foundation. Again, as I indicated earlier, my interest was civil rights and slavery. What I was attempting to do in the beginning of that speech was to make clear to a conservative audience that blacks who were Republicans and the issues that affected blacks were being addressed and being dealt with by conservatives in what I considered a less-than-acceptable manner.
The second point that ----
Q. In what sense? In that they were not -- --
A. That they were not --
Q. ---- invoking natural law.
A. No. The second point that I wanted to make to them was that they had, based on what I thought was an appropriate approach, they had an obligation just as conservatives to be more open and more aggressive on civil rights enforcement. What I thought would be the best way to approach that would be using the underlying concept of our Constitution that we were all created equal.
I felt that conservatives would be skeptical about the notion of natural law. I was using that as the underlying approach. I felt that they would be conservative and that they would not -- or be skeptical about that concept. I was speaking in the Lou Lehrman Auditorium of the Heritage Foundation. I thought that if I demonstrated that one of their own accepted at least the concept of natural rights, that they would be more apt to accept that concept as an underlying principle for being more aggressive on civil rights. My whole interest was civil rights enforcement.

 	 	 		. . .	 	
 
Questions By Senator Kennedy
 Q. Let me move to another subject area, and this is referring to an article about you in the Atlantic Monthly in 1987. You said that hiring disparities could be due to cultural differences between men and women. This is the article "A Question of Fairness," by Juan Williams.
That article states that you said that it could be that women are generally unprepared to do certain kinds of work by their own choice, it could be that women choose to have babies instead of going to medical school. Do you still think that that explains the underrepresentation of women in so many jobs in our economy today?
A. I think, and I think it is important to state this unequivocally, and I have said this unequivocally in speech after speech. There is discrimination. There is sex discrimination in our society. My only point in discussing statistics is that I don't think any of us can say that we have all the answers as to why there are statistical disparities. For example, if I sit here and I were to look at the statistics in this city, say with the example of number of blacks, I couldn't -- and compare the number of blacks that are on that side of the table, for example. I cannot automatically conclude that that is a result of discrimination. There could be other reasons that should be explored that aren't necessarily discriminatory reasons.
I am not justifying discrimination, nor would I shy away from it. But when we use statistics I think that we need to be careful with those disparities.
Q. . . . Let me just move on to your comments about Thomas Sowell, an author whose work you respect and many -- whose ideas you have stated that you agree with. Mr. Sowell wrote a book called the "Civil Rights Rhetoric: A Reality." You reviewed that book for the Lincoln Review in 1988 as part of a review of the works of Thomas Sowell, and in particular you praised Mr. Sowell's discussion, Chapter 5 of his book entitled "A Special Case of Women," and you called it a much needed antidote to cliches about women's earnings and professional status.
 Mr. Sowell explains that women are paid 59 percent of what men receive for the same work by saying that women are typically not educated as often in such highly paid fields as mathematics, science and engineering, nor attracted to physically taxing and well-paid fields, such as construction work, lumberjacking and coal mining, and the like.
As a matter of fact, there were no women employed in the coal mine industry in 1973. In 1980, after the Federal Government had begun an effort to enforce antidiscrimination laws, that 3300 women are working in coal mines.
Does that surprise you at all?
A. If there is discrimination, it doesn't surprise me. There were lots of places I think in our society. You know, I used to when I can remember in my own classrooms looking around and realizing that 7 or 8 of the top 10 students in my classroom in grammar school were the smartest students and wondering at that age, if 8 of the 10 of them are the brightest, then why aren't there women doctors and why aren't there women lawyers.
But the point that I was making with respect to Professor Sowell again is a statistical one. There is a difference between the problem that, say, a 16-year-old or 18- year-old minority kid, female, in this city or in Savannah or across the country, who has dropped out of high school, there is a difference between the problems of that child or that student than there is for someone who has a Ph.D. or someone who has a college degree.
 
Questions By Senator Hatch
 Q. When you are talking about natural law, you are talking about equality?
A. That all men are created equal, that is basic law.
Q. That is right, and you are talking that from the Declaration of Independence.
A. That is right.
Q. And you are saying that is why we needed the Thirteenth, Fourteenth and Fifteenth Amendments.
A. That was the most apparent and grossest contradiction in our society, that you had declaration declaring all of us to be equal, and yet the coexistence with that of slavery.
Q. . . . What I interpret you to be saying -- and maybe I am wrong, and you correct me if I am wrong -- is that when it comes to natural law and the Constitution, the Constitution takes preeminence.
A. The Constitution is our law, it is the law of our land. The natural law philosophy is a political theory, my interest was political theory, it was not constitutional law.
Q. So, when you become a Justice on the United States Supreme Court, and I believe you will, you intend to uphold the Constitution of the United States, is that correct?
A. With every fiber in my body.
Q. Above anything else?
A. My job is to uphold the Constitution of the United States, not personal philosophy or political theories. . . . I do not think the role of the Court is to have an agenda to say, for example, that you believe the Court should change the face of the earth.

 	 	 		. . .	 	Q. Have you made up your mind, Judge Thomas, on how you will vote when abortion issues are before the Court as a Justice on the Court?
A. Senator, there is a lesson that I think we all learn when we become judges, and I think it happens to you after you have had your first case: that you walk in sometimes, even after you have read the briefs and you think you might have an answer. And you go to oral argument, and after oral arguments you think you might have an answer. . . .
And after you sit down and you attempt to write the opinion, you thought you had an answer, and you change your mind.
I think it is inappropriate for any judge who is worth his or her salt to prejudge any issue or to sit on a case in which he or she has such strong views that he or she cannot be impartial. And to think that as a judge that you are infallible I think totally undermines the process. You have to sit. You have to listen. You have to hear the arguments. You have to allow the adversarial process to think. You have to be open. And you have to be willing to work through the problem.
I don't sit on any issues, on any cases that I have prejudged. I think that it would totally undermine and compromise my capacity as a judge.

SECTION: Section A; Page 16; Column 1; National Desk

HEADLINE: Steeped in Past, Faith in Future For a Soviet Sect

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Sept. 8

 BODY:
Leonid Kalenyuk, a former coal miner from the Ukraine, finds in the current turmoil of the Soviet Union a confirmation of the apocalyptic prophecies that he says drove him from his country to join a community of Soviet immigrants here.
"This coup attempt was a warning to believers that they must leave while they can," said Mr. Kalenyuk, who is one of tens of thousands of Pentecostal Christians who have flooded into the United States from the Soviet Union over the past three years. 
 In growing numbers, the Pentecostal believers have gravitated to Sacramento, bringing with them the look and feel of rural Russia, as well as the stern traditions of their persecuted faith.
Mingling recently in the leafy courtyard of their biggest church, with its congregation of 1,500, the immigrants talked of prophecies of a brief period of freedom in the Soviet Union followed by a return to the repression of the past.
"The time of the prophecies has come, but it will be very brief, very brief," said Mr. Kalenyuk who, typically, arrived as part of an extended family. "We left as soon as we could because we know that when the time ends, the Soviet Union will become even worse than before."
 
A Prophet Came
 Viktor Konovalov, another former miner, told of a prophet who came to him in Soviet Kazakhstan 30 years ago and foretold a great exodus from the country. When tanks filled the streets of Moscow three weeks ago, he said, Pentecostals here gathered to pray for the man they call the instrument of these prophecies, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev.
Another immigrant, Grigory Krasnodensky, said: "We believe these events are God's will. The time of the Apocalypse that has been predicted has not yet come. But we believe that freedom will not last long in the Soviet Union, and that when the Apocalypse comes it will affect the whole world."
He said fellow believers in the Ukraine had sent word that the moment news of the coup attempt reached their village, neighbors had turned on them, saying: "Well, you see, your time has run out. You'll never leave now and you'll get what's coming to you."
Pavel Mishin, another recent arrival, said the prophecies were based on the Apocalyptic warnings of the Bible in the Book of Revelation, in which believers are urged to flee Babylon before it is consumed by plagues and fire.
Mr. Mishin said his father, who is with him here, had spent 18 years in labor camps for his religious practices in a country that until recently banned services in unregistered churches and forbade proselytizing and the religious schooling of children.
Pentecostal Christianity is a conservative evangelical denomination that stresses the gifts of the Holy Spirit, including prophecy and speaking in tongues. It was introduced into the Soviet Union from the United States in the 1920's, and its Soviet adherents soon became one of the most persecuted religious groups.
Kent Hill, executive director of the Institute on Religion and Democracy in Washington, said estimates of the religion's membership in the Soviet Union range from 200,000 to 600,000.
Until 1988, fewer than 150 had been permitted to leave, said Serge Duss, who worked for several years with Soviet refugees for World Relief, a Christian aid program. Among these were two families who became known as the Siberian Seven and took refuge in the basement of the United States Embassy in Moscow for five years until they received permission to leave the country in 1983.
Mr. Hill noted that the new, more permissive era in the Soviet Union had removed much of the rationale for admitting Pentecostals to the United States as refugees in imminent danger of persecution and that America's open door for them could be affected.
"The vast majority are not experiencing problems with freedom of religion," he said. "But everything indicates that isolated individuals are endangered or even murdered."
 
Why Sacramento?
 The first Pentecostals may have been attracted to Sacramento by the presence of a small number of Soviet Christian immigrants and by Paul Demetrus, a 75-year-old Pentecostal priest who said he has been broadcasting religious programs into the Soviet Union for the past 36 years.
Those first families sent word to others, and somehow it was this seed community in Sacramento, rather than others in upstate New York, Massachusetts, Oregon, Washington and Illinois, that took deepest root.
"We heard people saying: 'Go to Sacramento. There's a good life there,' " said Mr. Krasnodensky, who was a refrigeration mechanic in the Ukraine. "We didn't know anything about America. We didn't know about its climate or its geography. When they said to us that Sacramento is a good city with a good church, well, why not go there?"
As a result, the number of Pentecostals here has risen to as many as 5,000 of the 30,000 who have entered this country.
It has been impossible for the city, already struggling with growing unemployment, to digest this huge and sudden influx. Few of the immigrants speak English well, and most have been unable to find work and are on welfare, said Nadia Lokteff, who offers social services through the local branch of World Relief.
Wherever they settle around Sacramento, the Pentecostal immigrants re-establish the family or village groups of their homeland. The apartment buildings where they cluster are filled with the smells of cabbage and dill and the shouts of Russian-speaking children.
 
Hearts Still in Old World
 The church building, which the Pentecostals rent for Sunday afternoon services, is the heart of their community, providing its identity and cohesion. Its grounds take on an Old World look as men with shirts buttoned to the neck chat on benches and women with head scarves keep a careful eye on little girls with large bows in their hair.
More than 550 children attend Sunday classes at the church, and few have adopted the ways of their new homeland.
On one recent Sunday, two young immigrants who had met just three months ago were being married: Mikhail Nedoshkolsky, from the Donbass mining region of the Ukraine, and Nadezhda Kovalchuk, who arrived in the United States with the entire congregation of about 100 people from her village in Soviet Central Asia.
For the pastor who married them, Pyotr Tyukayenko, their union was a symbol of the urgent need to preserve the demanding culture that they had brought with them against the American way of life.
"You newlyweds will hear a great deal about family planning; that is a sin," the pastor said. "We already have our own program, God's program, and anyone who strays from that is criminally mistaken."
At the wedding feast that followed, with its loud music and loud declamation of poems, the atmosphere was heartily Russian. But the big plastic bottles of soft drinks and the extra-large American candy bars hinted at the temptations of American bounty.
As the bride and groom sat smiling out at them, few people at the feast seemed prepared to offer prophecies about their futures in America.
Mr. Konovalov, one of the first settlers here, told of his two-year struggle to transform himself from a Kazakhstan coal miner into an American businessman at the age of 50.
"First I took English as a second language, then keyboarding, formatting and computer information science," Mr. Konovalov said in Russian. "Then I took Business 8, Business 20, Business 60 and in the summer I took Accounting 1A and this semester I'm taking English 57."
He said he had no idea how he would be able use all this newfound knowledge in an economy that has offered few jobs to the Pentecostal immigrants. With a shrug, he said, "Maybe I'll sell Pepsi-Cola in Russia."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Soviet Pentecostal Christians gathering in the courtyard of their biggest church, in Sacramento, Calif. Many of the tens of thousands of Pentecostals who have fled the Soviet Union have settled in Sacramento. (Seth Mydans/The New York Times)

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (94%); UKRAINE (88%); RUSSIAN FEDERATION (79%); KAZAKHSTAN (79%); 

STATE: CALIFORNIA, USA (94%); 

CITY: SACRAMENTO, CA, USA (94%); MOSCOW, RUSSIAN FEDERATION (79%);

HEADLINE: Colleges, Seeking More Money, Try to Broaden Restricted Scholarships

BYLINE: By WILLIAM CELIS 3d

 BODY:
Colleges offer scholarships for academic superiority, for athletic prowess and, of course, for financial need. Then there are the types of scholarships awarded to people like Matthew J. Clinton.
Mr. Clinton, an 18-year-old freshman at Iowa State University, won his $1,000 scholarship this year partly because he is majoring in agriculture and his home is south of U.S. 30 in Iowa, a geographic restriction built into his scholarship by its donor. 
 "It was kind of weird, I thought," Mr. Clinton said. "But I didn't say anything."
 
A Scholarship for Murphys
 There are many other, even more peculiar stipulations in the awarding of scholarships that push financial aid officers to their wits' end. An Arizona State University scholarship was once reserved for students with one blue eye and one brown eye, until it was eliminated in a house-cleaning of unusual scholarships. But descendants of the Hugenots can still receive a $1,000 scholarship at Duke University. And at Harvard University, students with the last name Murphy are eligible for a scholarship.
"I must admit I consciously avoid looking at how many Murphys we have," said James S. Miller, director of financial aid at Harvard and Radcliffe. "Whenever someone mentions Murphy, our office blanches."
Even earning an average grade can be reason enough for a scholarship. The University of Oklahoma, for example, awards $1,000 scholarships to students who are deemed average -- a grade-point rating of about 2.0. "It's kind of embarrassing," said Charlotte Gay, a university spokeswoman. "We don't tell them they are getting this scholarship because they are average."
 
Loosening the Restrictions
 Many of these scholarships were established by alumni in the late 19th century or early 20th century and more recently by professional organizations and trade groups. They carry so many restrictions that they have become increasingly difficult to award. And many colleges and universities have sought to eliminate some of the more unusual scholarships, or at least to loosen the restrictions.
At the University of California at Berkeley, for example, a donor left a scholarship for a Jewish orphan interested in pursuing a career in aerospace sciences. But the university had such a difficult time awarding the scholarship that it petitioned the courts to change the donor's will to allow the university to broaden the pool of students eligible for the award.
"We don't have many of these kinds of scholarships left, thank heavens," said Patricia Stewart Harris, director of student financial services at the University of Texas at Austin. In recent years the university has been purging odd scholarships because "they are very difficult to administer," she said.
Thanks to Ms. Harris, gone from the roll of Texas scholarships is an award for students who finished first, second or third in spelling bees at Austin High School. Now the scholarship just goes to students from the high school who need financial help, regardless of their ability to spell.
 
A Very Limited Group
 Sometimes the scholarships carry so many stipulations that they restrict themselves out of existence. At Duke University, a scholarship for daughters of Episcopal naval chaplains who served in the Pacific in World War II disappeared from the scholarship roll in 1981 after 10 years of existence because there were no applicants.
At Iowa State, officials estimate that they recaptured $80,000 to $100,000 from unconventional scholarships for use in the school's general scholarship fund, a strategy used by other institutions. In general, the purging of such scholarships has not resulted in significant sums of additional, unrestricted scholarship money, several university financial aid officials said. But with tighter Federal student aid regulations and higher tuitions at many institutions, every bit of unrestricted scholarship money helps.
"In the last decade, most institutions have worked very diligently to address these scholarships," said Dallas Martin, president of the National Association of Student Financial Aid Administrators. "We have advised most schools to get broader-based criteria for their scholarships. Most donors seem to be amenable to that, but there still are a few out there."
Ryan Watje, for one, is grateful. Mr. Watje won the International Boar Semen Scholarship this year, a $500 award to study pig farming at Modesto Junior College in California.
"I didn't know there was a scholarship for swine management," said Mr. Watje, who grew up on a farm in Salinas, Calif., and has been raising pigs since he was 9. "My mom found out about it and told me about it."
 
Help for Overachievers
 At Marquette University there is scholarship money for Roman Catholic high school students from Arkansas and a one-year, $2,100 scholarship for a senior nursing school student who "was not expected to succeed but overcame great obstacles."
Paul McInerny, a Marquette spokesman, said the obstacles cited in the nursing school scholarship may be either academic or economic. "One could be a potential washout in any number of ways," he said, adding that recipients of this award are not told they were expected to fail.
Many of these scholarships rarely put much weight on academic prowess. "There are an awful lot of 'B' students," Mr. Martin said. "We can't all be Rhodes scholars."
Or poor, worthy women, for that matter. The University of Oklahoma administers a scholarship designated for such women. "Deciding who's worthy and who's not is not an easy task," said Mary Mowdy, assistant director of financial aid, who also oversees a scholarship for single Osage Indian men from Caddo County in west-central Oklahoma. Finding people to fill these scholarships, she adds, sometimes "gets pretty wild and crazy."
Karen Fooks, director of financial aid at the University of Florida, can attest to that. Despite a successful push to broaden restrictions of unconventional scholarships -- the one for "a poor boy who works in the dining hall" has been expanded to a student who works in food services -- she still must contend with an exotic scholarship every now and then.
This year, for example, two students at the university are recipients of a scholarship for the study of macrophytes, or marine plants large enough to be visible to the naked eye.
"I wouldn't know a student who is studying that if they walked through the door," Ms. Fooks said, with a hint of exasperation. "I don't even know what a macrophyte is."

HEADLINE: U.S. Posts Surplus on Trade Again

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10

 BODY:
Record foreign sales and payments by allies in the Persian Gulf war helped the United States post its first back-to-back trade surpluses since 1982 in the first two quarters of the year, the Commerce Department said today.
The nation's surplus of trade with the rest of the world in goods, services and tourism was $2.97 billion in the April-June quarter, the department said, down from $10.5 billion in the first quarter but still in the black. 
 Not since the first and second quarters of 1982 has the country had two consecutive three-month periods when it recorded a surplus in its current account.
 
Expected to Worsen
 The current account is the country's most significant trade measure because it includes not simply trade in merchandise but also services and investment flows between nations.
Analysts cautioned that the balance would worsen later in the year because the foreign cash would dry up and consumer demand for imported products would revive as the economy strengthened.
"We view this as the best it's going to get, and it likely will deteriorate fairly sharply in the third and fourth quarters," said Chris Varvares, an economist with the St. Louis-based forecaster Laurence Meyer & Associates.
War-related cash payments to the Treasury from foreign governments in the Middle East and elsewhere had the biggest impact on trade, although they were far lower in the second quarter than the first.
The deficit for all of 1990 was $92.1 billion. This year's deficit is expected to be less than half that, thanks to stronger exports and the war contributions -- $41 billion in the first 10 months of the current fiscal year, which began last Oct. 1.
 
Recession Hurt Imports
 Another factor in the surplus is that the recession also suppressed Americans' appetites for foreign-made goods like Japanese cars and televisions, further aid to the trade balance.
Foreign sales were a record $104.11 billion between April and June, up from $100.9 billion in the first quarter. As a result, the merchandise trade deficit shrank to $15.62 billion, from $18.39 billion in the first three months of 1991.
The trade deficit with the rest of the world shot to record levels during the booming 1980's, causing billions of dollars to be sent overeas to pay for imported goods. The money came back in the form of foreign investment, which also had the effect of transforming the country into the world's largest debtor.

HEADLINE: With Tearful Nod to a Tired Aide, Dinkins Puts Off a Trip to Africa

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
What was planned as a triumphal pilgrimage to his roots has turned into disappointment for Mayor David N. Dinkins. He announced yesterday that he would postpone his scheduled trip to South Africa because his chief aide had been too busy with turmoil in New York to raise the needed money.
His eyes welling with tears, Mr. Dinkins paused repeatedly at a City Hall news conference to compose himself as he praised the aide, Deputy Mayor Bill Lynch, for his efforts to calm the recent racial tension in Crown Heights, Brooklyn. That tireless work, the Mayor said, left Mr. Lynch unable to raise the $400,000 to $500,000 in private contributions needed for the trip in time for the planned departure on Monday.
"We intend to go," Mr. Dinkins said. "We just can't go now."
 
Difficult Moment
 The scene in the Blue Room was an excruciating political moment for the Mayor. That he was forced to defer yet another of his dreams as the city's first black mayor crystallized just how alone he sometimes is, and how dependent on Mr. Lynch. It also echoed the organizational and fiscal problems that have plagued his administration, even as his plans for going had drawn criticism from some New Yorkers who said he had enough problems in his own backyard. 
 The Mayor defended his goal of taking a delegation of several dozen city officials and business people with him on a charter flight, saying it would foster economic ties with struggling South African blacks. He also defended his effort to raise the money from private individuals and corporations, an effort that some civic groups had questioned. He repeatedly said that his first duty was to run the city, and that he would not have had Mr. Lynch spend more time arranging the trip and less time dealing with Crown Heights.
But underscoring the Mayor's distress was a more personal concern: his apparent realization that his longtime alter ego, Mr. Lynch, had been overworked to the point of exhaustion, and not for the first time.
"I get a little emotional when I talk about Bill Lynch," the Mayor said. "He works like hell."
Mr. Lynch, who routinely works 15-hour days and has diabetes, underwent laser surgery last week for recurring vision problems. He has told friends that the condition could lead to blindness if he does not take better care of himself. Some of them had urged him not to make the trip.
"With the particular problem I have, that is always a problem," Mr. Lynch acknowledged yesterday. "I'm not stupid. I've just got to get my weight under control and my diet back in place, and I assume that with the pressures of the last few weeks, things just got out of kilter. It has had an effect on my focus, that's for sure."
Other mayoral aides said Mr. Dinkins would be very reluctant to make the trip without Mr. Lynch, but Mr. Lynch said that that was not an issue.
Mr. Lynch is officially the Deputy Mayor for Intergovernmental Affairs, but he has actually functioned as Mr. Dinkins's deputy-for-almost-everything since 1986, when Mr. Dinkins was the Manhattan Borough President. In that job and the ones that followed, first as a top mayoral campaign aide and now as Deputy Mayor, the most persistent plaint about Mr. Lynch has been that he tries to do too much.
Other mayoral aides said that the emotion the Mayor expressed at his news conference yesterday was a testament to his singular bond with Mr. Lynch. "It's symbiosis with a capital 's,' said the Mayor's press secretary, Leland T. Jones.
 
Large Contingent Planned
 The collapse of the trip was also a testament to Mr. Lynch's and the Mayor's grand ambitions for it. Both men acknowledged that they could have originally planned a quick trip with only a handful of aides. But they said they wanted to make it more than a ceremonial visit, so they had planned to take a large delegation of people who could advise South African blacks. In addition to business representatives and the Mayor's wife, Joyce Dinkins, those invited included the president of the Board of Education, the Chancellor of the City University of New York, the city's Finance Commissioner and members of the clergy.
To cover the most ground as quickly as possible, the group had planned to take a charter flight, although commercial flights would have cost less. To avoid repeated refueling stops that a smaller plane would require, they had planned to charter a Lockheed L10-11, which seats about 300 people. Mr. Lynch said the cost of the trip primarily reflected the fixed cost of the plane and not the number of people who would have gone.
Last night, Mr. Dinkins spoke by telephone to Nelson Mandela, the president of the African National Congress. Mr. Mandela was to have been the Mayor's host in South Africa. Recounting the conversation, a spokeswoman for the Mayor, Ruby Ryles, said Mr. Dinkins had expressed regret at the postponement and had pledged to make the trip as soon as possible. Mr. Mandela, who was Mr. Dinkins's guest at Gracie Mansion last year, assured him that the return invitation was open-ended, Ms. Ryles said. The Mayor had also planned to stop for a papal audience at the Vatican on the way and to meet with Nigerian officials on his return trip.
The Mayor said he hoped black New Yorkers would understand why he could not make this trip now, and he rejected comparisons with his 48-hour trip to Israel during the Persian Gulf war. That trip angered some blacks, who questioned why he had not gone to Africa first. The trip to Israel, he said, was financed completely by the Jewish Community Ruling Council of New York, a civic group.
Mr. Lynch said that since word of the current fund-raising difficulties began to circulate last week, more contributors had expressed interest. But he said that by yesterday only about $200,000 had been committed, forcing him to tell the Mayor that he would simply have to wait. Mr. Dinkins said he had never considered advancing the money for the trip out of city funds in the hope that the money could be replaced later with private donations.
But the Mayor defended as perfectly proper the administration's private fund raising and said it would continue. The vehicle for such fund raising has been the New York City Business Assistance Corporation, a nonprofit, city-run entity that raised money for the tickertape parade for veterans of the Persian Gulf war in June and for Mr. Dinkins's "Urban Summit" of big city mayors last year. Many corporations made contributions to the parade.
 
Donors Not Identified
 The City Charter bars officials from taking gifts from parties that do business with the city. The city's Conflicts of Interest Board ruled that soliciting money for the meeting of big-city mayors did not pose a conflict. But the administration did not seek a ruling for the South Africa trip, and while pledging to make the names of donors public eventually, it had not done so. Some private citizens who planned to make the trip had said that they would pay their own way.
Gene Russianoff, a senior lawyer with the New York Public Interest Research Group, said he sympathized with the Mayor. "He's damned if he uses public funds and open to criticism if he raises private funds," he said. Mr. Russianoff said the Mayor should try to raise money for the trip from foundations or nonprofit groups and set up a citizens committee to make the solicitations instead of having city officials do it directly.
Among those looking forward to the trip there was keen disappointment, but also understanding.
"I'm disappointed, but I'm not terribly surprised," said the Rev. Herbert Daughtry, pastor of the House of the Lord Pentecostal Church in Brooklyn. "Whenever people would ask me about the trip, I'd say, 'I hope we'll be able to leave.' But I always felt there was a possibility it would not come off. The situation in New York is just so troubled. From day to day you just never know what's going to happen."

Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about Mayor David N. Dinkins's postponement of his trip to South Africa misidentified the group that financed his trip to Israel during the Persian Gulf war. It was the American-Israel Friendship League. The Jewish Community Relations Council of New York only extended the invitation.

HEADLINE: THE THOMAS HEARINGS;
THOMAS DECLINES REQUESTS BY PANEL FOR ABORTION VIEW

BYLINE: By NEIL A. LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10

 BODY:
Judge Clarence Thomas, President Bush's choice to succeed Thurgood Marshall on the Supreme Court, said today that he believed Americans had a constitutional right to privacy. But he declined to tell the Senate Judiciary Committee whether he believed that the Constitution provided for a right to an abortion.
Judge Thomas's remarks came in the committee's first day of hearings on his nomination to the High Court. In their opening statements and initial questioning, several Senators indicated that they intended to challenge the judge on a series of comments and writings that opponents have assailed as demonstrating a hard-edged conservative outlook. [Excerpts from the hearings, page A22.] 
 Many opponents of Judge Thomas's nomination are concerned that he will join the increasingly conservative faction on the Court that has signaled its willingness to permit sharp restrictions on abortion.
 
Childhood Poverty Recalled
 Judge Thomas, who sits on the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit, began his testimony with an opening statement that dwelt on his childhood of extreme poverty in Georgia and how his grandfather and a group of Roman Catholic nuns instilled in him a sense that hard work would create opportunities for him.
"My grandparents grew up and lived their lives in an era of blatant segregation and overt discrimination," he said. His mother, who made only $10 a week as a maid, was forced to send him and his brother to live with their grandfather, each carrying everything they owned in shopping bags. Judge Thomas choked up and seemed close to tears when he recalled how his grandfather was humiliated and called "boy" in front of him.
 
Inherent Human Rights
 But after that statement Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr., a Delaware Democrat who is the chairman of the Judiciary Committee, moved quickly to change the focus of the hearings away from what the committee members said was the judge's affecting story.
Senator Biden engaged Judge Thomas in a sharp colloquy about statements the judge had made, one of which suggested that he favored banning abortion as a violation of natural law, the philosophical tenet that there are inherent human rights that transcend written law.
It was in response to Senator Biden's question that Judge Thomas said that a right of privacy could be found in the 14th Amendment to the Constitution.
He seemed to endorse the Supreme Court's 1965 opinion in Griswold v. Connecticut, a ruling that struck down a state law banning the use of contraceptives by married couples. In 1987, criticism of the Griswold ruling by Robert H. Bork, then a Federal appellate judge and a nominee to the Supreme Court, was a strong element in the Senate's rejection of his nomination.
But Judge Thomas said he would not comment directly on Roe v. Wade, the 1973 Supreme Court opinion that established a woman's right to abortion based on a constitutional right to privacy.
"I do not think that at this time that I could maintain my impartiality as a member of the judiciary and comment on that specific case," he told Senator Biden.
The Roe v. Wade ruling has been widely assailed by conservatives, and the Republican Party platform calls for the appointment of judges who would favor overturning the ruling. In recent years, as President Ronald Reagan and then Mr. Bush have named more members of the Court, the Justices have shown a willingness to trim back the protections of abortion rights provided under Roe v. Wade.
But later in the hearing, under questioning from Senator Orrin G. Hatch, a Utah Republican who is an ardent supporter of Judge Thomas, the nominee said he would have no private agenda on the issue of abortion if he joined the Supreme Court.
He said that as a Federal appellate court judge for nearly two years, he has found that sometimes he thinks he has reached a decision after reading the record of a case only to find his mind can be changed after oral arguments, or even when he sits down to write an opinion.
"No judge worth his or her salt will prejudge a case," he said. "You have to sit to listen, to hear the arguments and allow the adversarial process to go forward. I don't sit on any cases I have prejudged."
In taking such a position, Judge Thomas emulated the approach taken last year by Mr. Bush's first Supreme Court nominee, David H. Souter, who also was a Federal appeals court judge at the time. Judge Souter resolutely refused to even hint at his approach to the issue of abortion, and went on to an easy confirmation.
 
Higher Standard of Specificity
 Judge Thomas's White House strategists have said the committee and the Senate as a whole will not be able to hold him to a higher standard of specificity than they did with Judge Souter.
But some committee members suggested today they would be more demanding of Judge Thomas and would not tolerate a similar response. The mood on the committee, especially among Democrats, seemed more contentious than the White House had anticipated.
Senator Patrick J. Leahy, a Vermont Democrat, complained today about the responses of Judge Souter and others.
"Let me make this clear, Judge Thomas, in recent years we have danced around the question of where nominees stand on a woman's fundamental right to abortion," he said. "This is one of the burning social issues of our time."
The Senator added: "It is the single issue about which this committee and the American people most urgently wish to know the nominee's views, and yet the Senate and the nation have been frustrated by polite, respectful stonewalling."
Under questioning, Judge Thomas dismissed as insignificant a statement he made in 1987 that opponents have said demonstrates he is opposed to abortion. In a speech that year Judge Thomas briefly but pointedly praised an article that cast abortion as immoral and a violation of natural law.
Today, however, he described his praise of the article by Lewis Lehrman, a New York businessman and patron of conservative causes, as "a throwaway line." By praising the article before an audience of conservatives, he said, he thought he could persuade them that natural law was an admirable concept that should be used to press civil rights enforcement more vigorously.
 
'Aggressive on Civil Rights'
 "I felt they would be skeptical about the concept of natural law," he said of his conservative audience. "I was speaking in the Lew Lehrman Auditorium of the Heritage Foundation, and I thought if I demonstrated that one of their own accepted at least the concept of natural rights they would be more apt to accept that concept as an underlying principle for being more aggressive on civil rights."
He also stressed several times that his interest in natural law was only as a political philosophy, not as a basis for deciding constitutional issues.
In responding to Senator Biden's question, Judge Thomas also made a point to mention his grandfather and mother several times. Part of the White House strategy in the hearings is for Judge Thomas to talk as much as possible about his rise from poverty.
Even so, Mr. Biden said he had difficult understanding Judge Thomas's explanation. Later in the hearings, under questioning from Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, Judge Thomas explicitly repudiated the Lehrman article.
"I do not agree with the article," he said. "I did not endorse it and I do not now endorse it."
The judge was also questioned closely about having told a conservative audience in 1987 that he found "attractive" the idea of an activist Supreme Court that would strike down laws restricting property rights. Such a notion has been pressed by a small group of free-market scholars as an extension of natural law and natural rights.
Judge Thomas said it had been a long time since he made those remarks, and he described his interest in such an exotic theory as part of his interest in natural rights "from a political theory standpoint and as a part-time political theorist. I was not a law professor." He said they had nothing to do with his views about how judges should make decisions.
Once again, under subsequent questioning from Senator Hatch, Judge Thomas explicitly repudiated the significance of his earlier remarks and said that as a justice he would not use those theories to be part of an activist Court to protect economic rights, as those scholars had suggested.
 
Alone at the Witness Table
 Judge Thomas spoke while sitting alone at a green-baize covered table in the Senate Caucus Room, an ornate chamber that has been used over the years for special hearings, including the Watergate hearings in 1973 and the Bork hearings in 1987. He fingered a pack of mints as he responded, and did not refer to notes.
Sitting behind Judge Thomas were his mother, Leola Williams; his sister, Emma Mae Martin; his wife, Virginia Lamp, and his son, Jamal, from a previous marriage. Senator Biden joked that the 17-year-old Jamal looked so much like his father that he could take his place at the witness table and few would notice the difference.
Judge Thomas, who was born in Georgia, worked in Missouri and now lives in Virginia, was introduced to the committee by the six Senators from those states. Of the Democrats in that group, Senator Sam Nunn of Georgia was effusive in his praise and in endorsing Judge Thomas. The junior Senator from Georgia, Wyche Fowler Jr., also praised Judge Thomas but stopped short of an endorsement. Another Democrat, Senator Charles S. Robb of Virginia, explicitly withheld any judgment on whether Judge Thomas should be confirmed.
The warmest praise came from Senator John C. Danforth, a Missouri Republican who is the judge's principal patron in the Senate. Senator Danforth said that in Judge Thomas's eight-year tenure at the Equal Opportunity Employment Commission he made the agency one of the most respected in the Federal Government.
Later in the hearings the judge is expected to face critical questioning about his tenure as head of the commission, especially from Senator Howard M. Metzenbaum, an Ohio Democrat who was the only committee member to vote against his confirmation as an appellate court judge.

CORRECTION-DATE: September 12, 1991, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
A front-page picture caption yesterday misidentified one of the family members seated behind Judge Clarence Thomas during his confirmation hearing in some copies. The woman at the right was his sister, Emma Mae Martin, not his mother, Leola, who was seated partially hidden next to Ms. Martin.

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (94%); 

STATE: DISTRICT OF COLUMBIA, USA (79%); DELAWARE, USA (79%); 

CITY: ATLANTA, GA, USA (58%);

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Adweek Plans Overhaul as a Sign It Is Alive and Well

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott

 BODY:
AMID rising speculation about its fate, Adweek is about to get a new look. The nation's second-largest advertising-trade publication, intent on persuading readers and advertisers that it will be sticking around, will include in its ambitious overhaul new and expanded columns and features.
The changes, effective with the issues of Adweek's six regional editions due out on Monday, come as advertising and media executives have been watching the weekly with the morbid curiosity typically devoted to an agency that is losing its largest clients. 
 Adweek has suffered from a severe slump in ad pages this year and rising competition from Advertising Age and Inside Media. This has provoked talk that Adweek has been put up for sale by its owner, the BPI Communications subsidiary of Affiliated Publications Inc., or that one or both of Adweek's sibling publications, Adweek's Marketing Week and Mediaweek, will be closed.
The changes are meant to signal that such talk is untrue, John Babcock Jr., president of BPI's publications group, said in an interview yesterday at Adweek's office in Manhattan. "We're fully behind A/S/M," Mr. Babcock said, referring to Adweek's immediate parent, A/S/M Communications, acquired last year by BPI, which also publishes American Film, Billboard and The Hollywood Reporter.
"We're going to take over the No. 1 position," he added. "I can't tell you when, but we'll do it."
The editorial revamping reflects that "Adweek has grown up" in the 12 years since a group of regional publications merged to form Adweek, said Craig Reiss, who was named A/S/M's editor in chief in April. "No longer is it trying to claw its way into the market."
Mr. Reiss provided a preview of the redesign, which was created by Adweek's design consultant, WBMG Inc. Adweek's giant red front-page logo is unchanged, but inside there will be a fresher, more contemporary layout reminiscent of Business Week's; more variety in the appearance of news pages, and more space for features like Barbara Lippert's "Adweek Critique."
"I thought it was very exciting," said James R. Guthrie, executive vice president of marketing development at the Magazine Publishers of America in New York. It conveys "more urgency," he added, "more of a 'pick-me-up' feeling." Mr. Guthrie was among a small group of media executives who were given an advance look at the changes recently.
Asked if his association would advertise in the new Adweek, Mr. Guthrie answered yes. "Ad Age does very important, comprehensive and responsible coverage," he said, while Adweek's niche is "a kind of hotter journalism."
The Ad Age battle with Adweek has waxed and waned for a decade. In the booming mid-80's -- when Mr. Reiss was New York bureau chief of Ad Age and this columnist was deputy bureau chief -- industry executives characterized Adweek as a "hot book," a Pepsi-Cola of ad-trade publications, to Ad Age's "Bible of the industry" position, a Coca-Cola image.
But while the recession has taken the fizz from both publications' ad results, Adweek has been hit harder. According to figures compiled by the Media Industry Newsletter, Ad Age's ad pages fell 19.1 percent in the first six months of this year, to 1,054.7, while Adweek's fell 39.5 percent, to 392.5.
Also, ad pages for Adweek's Marketing Week, aimed at marketing executives at agencies and consumer-product companies, dropped 39.4 percent, to 378.8. Mediaweek, introduced in January to reach media decision-makers at agencies, carried 229.4 ad pages; Inside Media, a biweekly aimed at a similar audience, carried 292.8 pages, up 2.8 percent.
At Ad Age, "We intend to do what we've been doing all along," said Edward R. Erhardt, associate publisher and advertising director in New York, "to further distance ourselves from the rest of the ad-trade press."
At Inside Media, "Business looks good in a tough year; knock wood," said the publisher, Ellen Flahive-McIntyre, who also once worked for Ad Age.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Advances Overseas But Eases in U.S. Trading

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar rose abroad but ended lower in American trading yesterday, weakened by recurrent expectations of cuts in domestic interest rates.
The United States currency's underlying trend has been weaker, because of trader expectations that the Federal Reserve will ease lending rates to stimulate the economy. Such a move would reduce the dollar's value worldwide, and foreign investors would seek currencies that offer higher yields. 
 Late in the New York session, a series of trades sent the dollar skidding against the German mark after the United States currency had risen overseas. The trades came after the dollar exceeded 170 marks, a level many traders consider too high under economic conditions, said Stephen Flanagan, vice president of Mitsubishi Bank Ltd.
In New York, the dollar fell to 1.6875 German marks, down from 1.6935 late Tuesday. In late European trading, the dollar closed at 1.6965 German marks, up from 1.6945.
Mr. Flanagan said dealers were selling dollars in advance of the August producer price report, scheduled for release today, and the August retail sales figures, due out tomorrow. Both reports are expected to offer fresh insight on the economy's health and inflationary trends.
"I think a very weak retail sales report would give strength to the argument that the Fed plans to go ahead and cut rates," said Earl Johnson, a vice president at Harris Trust and Savings Bank in Chicago.
In Tokyo, the dollar rose 0.02 yen, to a closing 134.77 yen. Later, the dollar was quoted at 135.35 yen in London. At closing in New York, the dollar closed at 134.65 yen, down from 134.75 late Tuesday.
In London, the British pound fell to $1.7255, from $1.7298 late Tuesday. In New York, sterling cost $1.7345, more expensive than $1.7295 late Tuesday.
Other late New York dollar quotes, compared with Tuesday's prices, included: 1.4775 Swiss francs, down from 1.4805; 5.7405 French francs, down from 5.7610; 1,263.00 Italian lire, down from 1,267.50, and 1.13725 Canadian dollars, down from 1.13995.

HEADLINE: American Airlines Reins In Growth

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS

 BODY:
Robert L. Crandall, chairman and president of American Airlines and long a prophet of growth, said yesterday that the nation's largest airline would substantially cut its capital spending over the next several years, including purchases of some new airplanes, because of uncertain profits.
"Unfortunately, while the growth has been helpful, profits simply aren't what they need to be," Mr. Crandall told a gathering of airline stock analysts at a meeting in New York. "As a consequence, although we think we have positioned ourselves very well for the future, we've decided to reduce our capital spending substantially during the next couple of years until we see a correction of some of the things which are preventing us from earning satisfactory returns." 
 Already, he said, the airline has found $500 million in cuts from its five-year growth plan and the amount of the cuts will grow when decisions are made to postpone or abandon some aircraft orders.
American, a subsidiary of the AMR Corporation, had planned to spend $21 billion over the next five years, with $14.9 billion allotted to buy airplanes.
The shift in strategy could have an impact on consumers, because American may begin to concentrate on maximizing its return on its existing routes rather than using promotional fares to open up new markets. Mr. Crandall emphasized the need for carriers to stop eroding their fare structures.
It could also give weaker carriers like Continental, which is seeking to reorganize under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code, a little more breathing room as American tones down its competitive drive.
Mr. Crandall blamed weak carriers like Midway, America West and Continental for eroding fares and making it difficult for the industry to get a decent return.
"Much -- indeed most -- of our problems can be attributed to managements who seem to believe their mission in life is to put every living human being on an airplane at any price and who have failed to do their economic homework on subjects such as price elasticity," he said. "This get-em-on-the-plane-mentality is exacerbated by the fact that more than 25 percent of our industry's capacity is being operated by bankrupt and near-bankrupt carriers."
The Persian Gulf crisis also rattled the airline industry, doubling fuel prices while traffic plunged because of terrorism. American, for example, had a net loss of $185.3 million in the first six months of this year, compared with a profit of $109.9 million in the first half of 1990. Still, revenues were up slightly, to $5.96 billion, from $5.66 billion a year earlier.
American's slowdown in growth will not be felt significantly for a few years. The airline still plans to take delivery of 84 new planes this year, raising its total fleet to 618 planes. In 1992 Mr. Crandall said, it plans to add another 82 new jets and retire only 22 airplanes, thereby increasing its capacity by 16 percent.
 
'Prudent and Positive Move'
 Analysts and investors generally seemed to approve of reining in the fast-paced style set by Mr. Crandall in the last five years.
"I think its a prudent and positive move on the part of American's management," said Julius Maldutis, an airline analyst at Salomon Brothers.
AMR's shares jumped $3.125 to close at $59 in heavy trading on the New York Stock Exchange.
For American, there is the risk that other carriers like United Airlines and Delta Air Lines may continue their own expansion drives in the face of American's cutbacks and thus take the intitiative away from American in some important markets.
Larry Nagin, the vice president of corporate affairs at United, said the airline would have no comment on Mr. Crandall's speech. United and American have been locked in a fierce competitive battle over their hub at O'Hare International Airport in Chicago. United still dominates the Chicago hub, but American has been growing rapidly.
United has taken a conservative approach to expansion. It is taking delivery of far fewer airplanes this year and next year than American.
 
No Changes at Delta
 Neil Monroe, manager of public relations for Delta, said that Delta was also following a conservative growth plan and that it planned no changes.
Mr. Crandall is moving to slow down growth at a time when American has emerged as a very powerful airline, having surpassed United as the largest domestic carrier.
On the international front, American bought the London routes from Trans World Airlines and began to operate them in July. So far, American's planes have been unusually full, flying with about 85 percent of their seats occupied last month.
American also bought the Latin American routes from the defunct Eastern Airlines, and it expects to have 181 weekly flights to Central and South America. Mr. Crandall said the routes were becoming increasingly profitable.
 
Much Lower Pay Scales
 As the airline grew, most of its new employees were hired at much lower pay scales than before, thereby reducing the carrier's labor costs substantially. The lower pay scales went into effect in 1983 when American had 42,500 workers, just before it began its expansion drive.
Of its current 92,800 workers, more than half are on the lower pay scale. American has also built up its hubs in Dallas-Fort Worth, Chicago and Raleigh-Durham, N.C., and has established a strong nationwide route network to compete with United.

HEADLINE: Tenneco Plans Asset Sales And Cuts Dividend in Half

BYLINE: By THOMAS C. HAYES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DALLAS, Sept. 11

 BODY:
Staggered by deepening troubles at its J. I. Case farm- and construction-equipment unit, Tenneco Inc. said today that it planned to sell assets valued at $1.05 billion and that it would report a substantial loss for the second half of the year.
The company also said it would slash its yearly dividend in half, to $1.60 a share, saving $200 million a year. The actions provided a hint of additional cutbacks and asset sales that Wall Street analysts hope to see from Tenneco's designated leader, Michael H. Walsh. 
 After the announcements, Tenneco's shares fell $2.125, to $40.50. With 2.3 million shares traded, it was the fourth-most-active Big Board issue.
Mr. Walsh, who cut bureaucracy and recovered lost market share as chief executive of the Union Pacific Railroad, announced the plan to analysts in New York today even though he will not take the reins as chief executive until January.
At the meeting, he pledged to do "whatever is necessary" to improve Tenneco's financial results, said analysts who attended. "He's starting off pretty aggressively," said David N. Fleischer of Prudential Securities in New York.
Mr. Walsh had been expected to take the president's position, which was vacant, on Oct. 1, but the appointment was rushed ahead to Tuesday so he could speak for the company today. Last month, Mr. Walsh, 49 years old, was also named to succeed James L. Ketelsen, 60, who will retire in May after 14 years as chairman and cheif executive. At that time, Mr. Walsh will also assume the chairmanship.
Case, one of Tenneco's six unrelated businesses, has been Mr. Ketelsen's albatross. The unit lost money in 5 of the last 10 years, generating a loss of $209 million during the period, and could lose $1 billion this year, analysts said.
 
Corporate Dinosaurs
 One of few remaining conglomerates in an era of narrowly focused corporate operations, Tenneco also has operations in natural-gas transmission, shipbuilding, automotive products, packaging and chemicals. Formed in 1943 as the Tennessee Gas and Transmission Company, Tenneco sold its oil and gas production operations and reserves for $7.3 billion to 10 separate bidders in 1988.
Conglomerates have faded because executives are hard pressed to stay on top of fast-changing conditions in unrelated industries, global competition has stiffened and Wall Street rarely gives full market value to conglomerate assets, said Walter D. Scott, a management professor at the Kellogg Graduate School of Management at Northwestern University.
As Tenneco's biggest unit, Case contributed 37 percent of corporate sales last year, which amounted to $14.5 billion. A money-maker the previous two years, Case saw its troubles return in the first half of the year, losing $270 million. Analysts said operating losses for the year will probably exceed $500 million. Also, write-offs suggested by Mr. Walsh could amount to another $500 million in losses.
Mr. Ketelsen, applauded in many circles for his aggressive programs to promote women to top management and as an advocate of corporate fitness programs, had in recent years defended the diversification as a bulwark against falling earnings during recession. Tenneco lost $13 million in the first half of this year.
Mr. Ketelsen introduced Mr. Walsh to the analysts today, then let him do the talking about the steeper loss, asset sales and cost-cutting.
 
Selling 'Non-Core' Assets
 In a statement from Tenneco's headquarters in Houston, Mr. Ketelsen and Mr. Walsh said the company would sell what they described as "non-core" assets valued at $500 million by the end of year.
The auction is to include a plant under construction since May in La Porte, Tex., that is designed to produce at least 12,500 barrels a day of an essential component for cleaner-burning gasoline. Refiners could face a shortage of that component, methyl tertiary butyl ether, under tougher Federal antipollution laws effective next year.
Other businesses on the block include a lubrication unit owned by Case, certain timberlands, three short-line railroads that are linked to packaging plants and Tenneco's gold mining operations. The company plans to sell another $550 million of assets by the end of the year that it did not identify.
Executives said Tenneco would move quickly to reduce yearly costs across the corporation by at least $250 million and that capital spending for 1992 would be pared by at least $250 million, a cut of about 25 percent from the earlier budget for next year.
In spite of the loss, J. I. Case is expected to generate a positive cash flow for the year. Production cuts and deep price cuts have reduced the division's bulging inventories, analysts said. Production will be crimped further to assure Case's long-term competitive position, the company said.
"What we're seeing is an accelerated timetable for events that had a high probability of occurring" at Tenneco, said Eli S. Lustgarten, machinery analyst at Paine Webber. "They have a lot of pain to go through."
