HEADLINE: SOVIET TURMOIL;
Soviet Move Could Heighten Pressure for Change in Cuba

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MIAMI, Sept. 11

 BODY:
The Soviet decision to withdraw its troops from Cuba and end its economic subsidy of the Cuban economy constitutes a powerful shock to the morale of the island's Communist establishment and may intensify pressures for radical change, experts in Cuban affairs said today.
Since the tensest period of Soviet-American cold war jostling over Cuba in the 1960's, Soviet forces have played only a symbolic role in the defense of the island. The Cuban armed forces are estimated to include 180,500 men and woman on active duty and 130,000 reserves out of a total population of more than 10 million. 
 But experts say the Cuban military has continued to rely heavily on Moscow for everything from training and technical support to intelligence and weaponry.
"The people in the general staff command of the Cuban military, most of whom are trained in the Soviet Union, are left wondering, 'What kind of impact is this going to have on us?' " said Christopher Barton, an expert on the Cuban military at the Center for National Security Law at the University of Virginia. "Some of them who have seen what is happening elsewhere in the world will probably begin to say, 'When are we going to start making changes in our society?' "
 
Economic Support Declines
 The direct economic impact of the withdrawal is difficult to gauge, for it is unclear whether the Soviet Union pays Cuba for garrisoning its troops there. But the Soviet force provides jobs to Cubans, either directly or through off-base establishments that cater to the Soviet soldiers.
But an end to subsidized Soviet purchases of Cuban commodities undoubtedly would have dire consequences for the Cuban economy.
"Already the Soviets have cut their subsidized payments from about 40 cents a pound to 25 cents a pound" for Cuban sugar, said Carmelo Mesa-Lago, a professor of economics at the University of Pittsburgh, The current world market price is 9.4 cents a pound.
"An end to subsidies would be like losing 5 percent of the gross social product overnight," Mr. Mesa-Lago said. "It would create incredible problems that would be extremely difficult to surmount."
Cuba has already been hard hit in recent months by a sharp decline in Soviet economic support. For three decades, Soviet governments have supplied more than three-quarters of all of Cuba's imports, including the bulk of its oil. Cuban exports of sugar, tobacco, nickel and citrus to the Soviet Union have never come close to balancing the flow of Soviet goods in the other direction.
In recent weeks, as the list of stringently rationed goods has swollen, new limits have been placed on the consumption of everyday items like tobacco, gasoline, vegetable oil and cooking fuels.
But even as the changing international environment has made life dramatically more difficult for his country, President Fidel Castro has vowed to resist moves to a market economy and political pluralism that could help reinsert Cuba in the world economy.
"The screw will become tighter and tighter now, and something is going to give sooner rather than later," Mr. Barton said. Using the exclamation with which Mr. Castro caps many of his speeches, he added, "You just can't eat the phrase 'Socialism or Death.' "
In a bid to avoid an economic collapse brought on by an oil shortage, Havana has reportedly been paying the Soviet Union in hard currency for the help of about 1,000 technicians building two nuclear power reactors near Cienfuegos, on the southern coast of the island. Experts said it was unclear if the work of these technicians would be affected by changes in the two countries' relations.
Experts said it was also unclear whether the Soviet decision to withdraw its troops would affect a major Soviet-run intelligence center at Lourdes, southwest of Havana. The listening post has been used to monitor air traffic, submarine movements and a variety of electronic communications in the southern United States.
"The next key question will be what interest the Soviets have in maintaining a facility like that in the new context of Soviet-American relations," a United States official said.
But analysts of Cuban affairs said that the Soviet announcement would further complicate the Cuban leadership's management of its growing economic and political crisis.

HEADLINE: CONSUMER RATES;
Money-Fund Yields Show Mixed Changes in Week

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH M. FOWLER

 BODY:
Yields of tax-free money market funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report rose in the week ended yesterday, while yields of taxable funds were mixed.
The average seven-day compound yield of tax-exempt funds was 4.20 percent in the week, while the simple yield was 4.12 percent. Both yields were up 1 basis point, or hundredth of a point, from the week before. 
 The average 30-day compound yield of tax-free funds was 4.15 percent, up from 4.11 percent the previous week, and the average 30-day simple yield was 4.07 percent, up from 4.02 percent.
 
Rise in Assets
 Total assets of the tax-exempt funds rose by $1.4 billion, to $88 billion, and the average number of days to maturity of securities held in tax-free fund portfolios was 59 days, unchanged from the week before.
"The short-term market clearly discounted at least part of any possible Federal Reserve easing of credit," said Walter S. Frank, Donoghue's chief economist, commenting on credit-market expectations of a Fed move to lower short-term interest rates. "The funds have acted as if they think it is coming. If the Fed does not ease, we would expect a slight reversal of the downtrend. However, we do believe the odds slightly favor a move toward further easing."
Mr. Frank said the highest-yielding tax-exempt fund among those with assets greater than $100 million was Calvert Tax Free Reserves, with a seven-day compound yield of 5.02 percent.
In the case of funds investing in individual state securities, Salomon Brothers New York Municipal Money Market fund reported the highest seven-day compound yield, 4.76 percent. In Connecticut, the Prudential Connecticut Municipal Money Market series led with a 4.55 percent seven-day compound yield, while in New Jersey, Calvert New Jersey Tax Free Reserves reported a 4.78 percent yield.
 
Taxable-Fund Results
 The average seven-day compound yield of taxable funds was unchanged from a week earlier, at 5.40 percent, and the simple seven-day yield was unchanged at 5.26 percent.
The average 30-day compound taxable yield was 5.44 percent, down from 5.48 a week earlier, while the 30-day simple yield was 5.30 percent, down from 5.34 percent the week before.
Assets of taxable funds rose by $4.3 billion, to $456 billion. Institutional buying accounted for $1.5 billion of the increase, which raised institutional holdings to $117.1 billion.
Mr. Frank said he thought that some money had moved out of the stock market in the past week into the funds. "It could be that stock market yields are not attractive to investors," he said.
The average number of days to maturitiy of securities held in taxable funds in the week was 59 days, the same as in the previous week.
The taxable fund with the best return, at 6.41 percent, was the Riverside Capital Money Management fund, distributed by the Winsbury Company of Columbus Ohio.
The average yield on bank money- market accounts in the week was 5.12 percent, unchanged from the previous week, according to The Bank Rate Monitor's national index.

HEADLINE: New Line By I.B.M. Is 'Open'

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF

 BODY:
I.B.M. took a significiant step yesterday toward opening its product line so that it could work more closely with its competitors, announcing seven new mainframes and more than a hundred hardware add-ons and software programs.
The company also said that the powerful water-cooled mainframes that it announced a year ago would begin shipping next week. It said these mainframes had top speeds 15 percent faster than I.B.M. had been projecting. 
 Analysts gave the International Business Machines Corporation high marks for its new-found openness, which includes a version of the Unix operating system for its mainframe machines and a strategy called the Information Warehouse, which is designed to ease the process of sharing information stored in a variety of formats. This would enable a company to link together information stored in different, incompatible data bases.
Yesterday I.B.M. said the new Unix, which would initially be attractive to technical users of its machines, would be available sometime during the second half of 1992.
 
Little Short-Term Impact
 "The most interesting part of the announcement is that finally, publicly, across the board, I.B.M. has endorsed open systems and Unix," said Robert Djurdjevic, president of Annex Research, a market-research firm based in Phoenix. But he added that the shift would have little short-term impact on the company. "Clearly I.B.M. is doing a catch-up when it comes to Unix and open system," he said. "But I have to give them the benefit of the doubt because they are doing it across their product line."
Many people in the industry believe I.B.M. is counting on strong sales of its new mainframe systems to help salvage what is becoming one of its most difficult years, with profit margins at historic lows.
Mainframes continue to provide more than half I.B.M.'s profits. Last September, the company introduced a whole generation of mainframes, air-cooled and water-cooled, known as the System/390.
The machines are used by large companies like airlines, banks and insurance concerns.
Executives of I.B.M., which is based in Armonk, N.Y., said that if the economy held up, the company hoped for a generally positive second half of the year, barring surprises.
Nicholas M. Donofrio, the president of I.B.M.'s mainframe division, said analysts' optimistic projections that the company would sell as many as 400 of its top ES/9000 mainframes by the end of the year were in "the general ballpark."
I.B.M.'s stock rose $1.75 a share yesterday, to $101.375, on the New York Stock Exchange.
"This is a lousy year no matter how you slice it," said Stephen Cohen, an analyst who follows the company at the Soundview Financial Group. "I have a short-term buy on the stock on the basis that they will ship more of these systems than people are generally expecting."
 
New Storage Systems
 I.B.M. also announced new optical and magnetic mainframe storage systems and extended the reach of its Escon fiber-optic cabling system, which can now be used to link computer systems as far as 37 miles apart.
But the company is clearly playing a catch-up game with its competitors, which have rapidly turned toward open systems based on industry standards in the last five years.
"This is I.B.M.'s attempt to find a relevant role for the mainframe in a PC-dominated world," said Frank Gens, a computer industry analyst at the Technology Investment Strategy Corporation, a Framingham, Mass., consulting firm. "I.B.M. has recognized that the mainframe is risking becoming completely irrelevant to what has become the core of computing in most corporations."
At the heart of I.B.M.'s strategy is the Information Warehouse framework, a standard model for managing computer data independent of its format or its location. Yesterday, the company said it was forming an international alliance of business partners to back the standard. It said that Information Builders Inc. and Bachman Information Systems Inc. were members of the alliance and that the companies would provide products that complement I.B.M.'s systems.
Analysts warned that one risk inherent in the new strategy was that it permitted other companies to substitute their products for I.B.M.'s inside large corporate data centers.
"If you stand way back and consider this strategy, you realize that corporate data can now be stored on Tandem and Digital mainframes as easily as I.B.M.'s," Mr. Gens said.
I.B.M. also announced a high-end disk drive for its mainframe systems to be called the 3390 Model 3. Each drive will store 50 percent more information than current models in the same floor space -- up to 90 billion characters of data. And the company said its Callpath software, used by telemarketers to display records associated with incoming calls, is now available on the company's mainframe and personal computers. The program was initially available for the AS/400 minicomputers.

HEADLINE: SOVIET TURMOIL: Aid at Any Price;
From Cuba to the Kuriles, the Soviets Hint at Deals for Much Needed Help

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Sept. 11

 BODY:
By offering to remove all Soviet troops from Cuba and hinting that four Kurile islands might after all be returned to Japan, Soviet and Russian leaders have, in effect, abandoned pride and begun begging for economic aid for their collapsing economies.
At the London summit meeting when they met to hear out President Mikhail S. Gorbachev last July, leaders of the seven most powerful capitalist countries concluded that until leaders in Moscow showed that they were willing to undo the Bolshevik revolution and institute a market economy, they should go slow and be cautious. 
 Now, the Communist Party is outlawed in much of the Soviet Union, and a plan for a market economy is promised within weeks. Today, Mr. Gorbachev, sharing the sharply atrophied power of the Soviet Union equally with President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia, seems ready to promise almost anything to keep what remains of the union from falling apart.
They have also succeeded in increasing pressure on the United States and other Western countries to think seriously about much bigger aid packages than they have ever thought about for the Soviet Union before -- perhaps something on the scale of the Marshall Plan, which cost the United States alone $6.8 billion dollars in 1948 and 1949, more than 2.5 percent of its gross national product at the time.
 
Discussion With Baker
 Mr. Gorbachev didn't even seem to ask for a quid pro quo today when he told Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d that the Soviet Union would withdraw its forces from Cuba, and Mr. Yeltsin told the visiting American that he was poised to begin serious discussions with Japan about the return of the four Kurile islands that Stalin seized at the very end of World War II.
Since Nikita S. Khrushchev's day, Cuba has been a thorn in the side of the United States, to remind it that it was not the only superpower, even in the Western Hemisphere. But now it is the only one in either hemisphere.
The Soviet Union still looms large, but now as a problem, much as the exhausted democracies of Western Europe did in the first years after the war. Mr. Gorbachev has in effect broken his sword and cast it down in front of President Bush and the Japanese Prime Minister, Toshiki Kaifu, and said: "Help us."
Mr. Gorbachev had already done as much with Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany in 1990, agreeing to German reunification essentially on West German terms, in exchange for more than $30 billion in German economic aid.
 
A Positive Response
 But now, Germany has no more money to give, and thus the Russian and Soviet leaders have no choice but to turn to the United States and Japan.
"If there ever was a chance to make a contribution, it's now," the German Foreign Minister, Hans-Dietrich Genscher, said here this morning.
Mr. Baker responded positively today to Mr. Gorbachev, and let it be known that the United States would be willing to consider economic assistance through the International Monetary Fund as soon as the Soviets, and any of their former republics, come up with "credible" and "concrete" free-market economic reform plans.
But the real political question, American officials agree privately, is whether the Administration -- or the American body politic -- is ready to give the kind of assistance this country will probably need.
 
Strains in Germany
 The Marshall Plan was spurred on by the Soviet menace to Europe, a threat that has disappeared today. In its first year, it was 16 percent of the federal budget, but it is hard to conceive of that much, in an age of huge budget deficits and domestic spending needs, going to the Soviet Union now. Economic reform plans suggested by Soviet and American academic experts have proposed that the amounts be shared by the United States, the European Community countries, and Japan.
Even in Germany, which had reunification to gain, Chancellor Kohl has found the political and economic strains of raising gasoline and sales taxes to pay for the rebuilding of eastern Germany extremely painful.
So now, he turns out his pockets and tries to work on the United States -- and Japan, which may even have the money the Soviet Union needs.
Mr. Kaifu made clear during Mr. Gorbachev's visit to Japan earlier this year that the Soviet Union couldn't expect any money until it gave back the Kurile Islands. It remains to be seen how much money he will be willing to come up with if the Soviets do so.
 
An Urgent Aid Request
 With the winter fast approaching, and the harvest mostly still lying around in the fields waiting for the rains to rot it because the infrastructure of agricultural machinery and transport equipment has collapsed, the Soviets have already begun asking for help in feeding themselves.
Today, the European Community received an urgent aid request for 5.5 million metric tons of grain, 800,000 tons of meat, and 900,000 tons of sugar for the Soviet Union from the acting Soviet Prime Minister, Ivan Silayev.
The Executive Commission promised to examine the request, and European leaders will convene at a special summit meeting in the Hague, probably early next month, to reconsider the whole issue of Soviet aid.
With the French and the Germans already sympathetic, a British diplomat conceded here, the United Kingdom is coming under increasing pressure to drop its previous position that any large amount of aid is premature until the Soviet economic reformers get their act together.
"We have a unique chance to influence a genuinely hopeful development here," Mr. Genscher said today, before heading off to the Baltic states to view what used to be one of the most economically productive and self-sufficient regions of the Soviet Union but have now become three newly sovereign states.
Whether Mr. Gorbachev's groveling will produce a more forthcoming attitude from the United States or Japan remains to be seen. What is clear is that he has no choice -- and that they will soon be forced to ask themselves whether they do, either.

HEADLINE: Stocks End Mixed as the Down Gains 4.47

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
The stock market ended with a rally yesterday and stock prices were mixed, as investors settled down to await the next round of economic data, beginning with today's release of the Producer Price Index for August.
The Dow Jones industrial average rose 4.47, to end the day at 2,987.03, while the New York Stock Exchange composite index increased by 0.21, to 211.21. 
 Volume of shares traded on the Big Board was a light 148.09 million, up from 143.4 million shares the previous day. The number of stocks declining narrowly outpaced the number of stocks that moved up.
Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks gained 0.53, to 385.09, with the American Stock Exchange composite down 1.51, to 364.68.
Over-the-counter stocks ended higher, with the composite index up 3.48, to 514.76.
The rally helped blue-chip and smaller stocks regain most of their earlier losses.
Gene J. Seagle, director of technical research for Gruntal & Company, said he thought market psychology was reacting to the ghost of past Octobers, but that the Street was forgetting that the Fed's increase of the discount rate in 0ctober 1987 was certaintly not probable at this time.
"The waiting game for Fed action and possible third-quarter earnings disappointment has the market locked in place between the 3,050 and 2,950 levels," he said. "I.B.M.'s strength plus a rate cut might well be the white knights needed to crack the Dow's ceiling. The strong transport index yesterday underscores the bullish potential."
Stocks started the day well enough, with an early round of buying by institutions. But investors still troubled by the prospect of disappointing third-quarter corporate profits found very little to move them toward taking buy positions.
Bond prices were soft after the Fed again did not act to ease interest rates, taking away any technical support for stocks. Afternoon trading turned choppy, and some analysts noted that over the last few trading sessions, few market sectors have been immune to selloffs.
 
I.B.M. Gains 1 3/4
 I.B.M. rose 1 3/4, to 101 3/8. The computer company introduced several mainframe products yesterday that adopted the "open system" approach in which they can work with machines of other companies.
Tenneco fell 2 1/8, to 40 1/2. The company said it expected a substantial loss from operations in the second half and the board adopted a cost-cutting plan that involved a 50 percent cut in the quarterly dividend beginning in the fourth quarter, sale of about $1 billion in non-core business by the end of the year, cuts in 1992 capital spending and plans to raise an additional $300 million of equity.
Citing weak domestic merchandising results, a Prudential Securities analyst, L. Wayne Hood, lowered his third-quarter earnings estimate for Sears, Roebuck, and the stock fell by 1, to 38 7/8. AMR rose by 3 1/8, to 59 yesterday, after the parent of American Airlines announced a plan to reduce capital spending by hundreds of millions in the 1992-95 period.

HEADLINE: Treasury Puts Curbs On Market

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11

 BODY:
Responding to growing criticism over its handling of the scandal at Salomon Brothers Inc., the Treasury Department today announced new rules aimed at combating corruption in the market in which the Government borrows hundreds of billions of dollars annually.
The announcement came as the scandal continued to grow, with new disclosures by Richard C. Breeden, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, that other firms and banks may have misled Government-backed lending agencies -- including the Federal National Mortgage Association, or Fannie Mae -- that raise money separately from the Treasury. 
 The scandal has forced officials and lawmakers in Washington to re-examine the way the Government finances the nation's debt and the informal manner in which the $2.3 trillion market has been regulated.
 
Bids on Paper, Placed in Boxes
 The Treasury's new measures include accelerating plans to automate a market that has relied for nearly two centuries on paper bids placed in wooden boxes by runners in the final minute before an auction of Government bills, notes or bonds closes. They would also require written verification of large winning bids from customers themselves to guarantee the bids' authenticity and prevent the kind of phony bidding that Salomon has said was executed without its customers' authorization in an effort to corner the market in Government bonds.
Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady said in a statement that the steps were being taken to insure the "continued integrity" of the Government securities market.
"In addition to these actions, the Treasury Department will continue to review the auction process to determine what other changes may be appropriate," Mr. Brady said.
 
More Regulation Expected
 Other Administration officials emphasized today that the Treasury was likely to make more recommendations once the magnitude of misdeeds in the securities markets became clearer. The Treasury has said it will take three months to complete its review.
The changes, announced at a hearing of the Senate Banking subcommittee on securities, are intended to stop the mounting Congressional complaints about the market in which about $117 billion worth of Government securities changes hands daily and through which the Federal Reserve conducts the economic policies that have a broad impact on interest rates for commerce and consumers.
But Senator Donald W. Riegle Jr., the Michigan Democrat who heads the banking committee, and other members of the committee who have criticized the Treasury for failing to adequately regulate the market strongly suggested at the hearing today that the measures might not be enough. No one today came forward, however, with a more comprehensive proposal. Mr. Breeden, who testified at the hearing and who has been seeking more power for the S.E.C. to regulate the Government securities market, did not comment on the Treasury changes.
The changes are also aimed at deflecting accusations that the Treasury has been too close to the market's biggest players and has unfairly favored the 39 primary dealers who buy most of the bonds issued by the Government by providing them with confidential information about auctions and the nation's finances.
Treasury officials hold a regular quarterly meeting in Washington with a trade group of the primary dealers to discuss the coming auctions, the financial needs of the Federal Government and the interests of the marketplace. The dealers are asked not to share the information they are given with their companies immediately.
 
Information Will Be Public
 Critics have said, however, that the meetings still give the the industry officials an advantage in the marketplace and offer an easy opportunity to benefit from confidential information. Treasury officials have acknowledged in recent days that participants were bound only by an honor system.
To address this issue, under another of the new measures announced today, the Treasury information on financings and refundings that is normally provided in confidence at these meetings will be publicly released two days before each meeting.
Senator Riegle, said today, "The cozy relationship between the regulators and the primary dealers must be fully examined and I believe ended."
At a subcommittee hearing, he and other Democrats and Republicans closely questioned Mr. Breeden and other industry regulators, as well as Warren E. Buffett, the new chairman of Salomon. "The very informality of this marketplace raises a host of questions," Mr. Riegle said.
 
Inadequacy Is Conceded
 Jerome H. Powell, Assistant Treasury Secretary, acknowledged at the hearing that the existing regulations and their implementation had been inadequate.
"There is no question that it can be improved, and improve it we will," he said, in response to remarks by Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, Republican of New York, who called surveillance of the market inadequate.
In his testimony today, the S.E.C. chairman, Mr. Breeden, discussed how the scandal had expanded beyond the Treasury securities market. He said his agency had discovered a "distressingly large" number of investment houses and banks that appeared to have intentionally misled other Government agencies and federally backed lenders that sell hundreds of billions of dollars in securities to raise money to help finance home purchases.
 
No Names or Motives
 He did not provide either names of investment firms or banks, or their motives, however, beyond saying that the reported infractions were intended to skirt the disclosure rules of the institutions that sell the securities.
"There are a number of primary dealers that may have purchased other types of agency securities based on some falsehoods or another," Mr. Breeden said in an appearance before the Senate banking subcommittee on securities. "I'm not about to issue a clean bill of health to anybody until we have finished our work."
Mr. Breeden said that while the widespread investigation into improprieties in Treasury auctions was only in its earliest stage, the S.E.C. had found no evidence that other investment firms had engaged in misconduct similar to that admitted by Salomon. In early August, Salomon disclosed that it had illegally purchased more than the 35 percent limit at several Treasury auctions by submitting unauthorized bids.
"We are at the point this morning where I cannot tell you that there are any other primary dealers who have to my knowledge engaged in the deliberate falsification of bids in connection with Treasury auctions or participated in the type of events and scope of events that have been announced by Salomon," he said. "That is not to say that there are not other violations of the law."
He said that Salomon's infractions "demonstrate arrogance and disregard for the law."
At today's hearing, Mr. Buffett provided more details about the bonuses that Salomon had given to executives who had earned the firm the most money. The firm disclosed yesterday that Paul W. Mozer, the managing director at the center of the scandal, received more than $11 million in bonuses in the last three years.
Mr. Buffett said that 90 executives had received bonuses of more than $1 million last year and also noted that as a member of the board's compensation committee, he had voted against a plan ultimately adopted that provided $127 million in bonuses.
Mr. Buffett said the firm's compensation system was under review to make it "more rational."

HEADLINE: Mitterrand Urges Talks on A-Arms

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, Sept. 11

 BODY:
Eager to show that France is not losing influence in Europe, President Francois Mitterrand called today for an early meeting of the four countries with nuclear weapons in Europe to tackle nuclear security problems raised by developments in the Soviet Union.
He said Paris had already discussed the idea with Washington and London and would do so with Moscow "when we know which of the Soviet Union's representatives to talk to" in the light of "the collapse of decision-making powers in the former Soviet Union." 
 "The uncertainty comes from Moscow," he continued, "so it's up to Moscow to say where we stand, who is in charge, where the atomic weapons are stationed and where they will go in order to subject them to strict control."
 
Between Two Forces
 France is not the only Western power to have expressed concern about both control of the Soviet nuclear arsenal during the failed hard-line coup last month and the fate and whereabouts of Soviet nuclear weapons as the Soviet Union edges toward possible dismemberment.
But Mr. Mitterrand's move to call a four-power meeting today seemed to reflect his more immediate need to answer domestic critics of his foreign policy by undertaking an initiative in which, as one of Western Europe's two nuclear powers, France could be seen playing an important role.
The French leader also used the occasion of a 95-minute news conference to offer his vision of France's place in a post-Communist Europe in which the European Community should play a central role as part of a looser confederation comprising all European countries.
Noting that Europe was caught between forces leading toward unity and fragmentation, he said France was determined to see the community build common security and defense policies, adding that the 12-nation bloc should be ready to send a peacekeeping force to halt the civil war in Yugoslavia.
Having previously called for preservation of Yugoslavia, he also indicated that he now expected the independence declarations by Slovenia and Croatia to take full effect. "One can think in the light of the experience of the past two months that Slovenia will be independent," he said. "In my opinion, Croatia too."
While much of the news conference today was given over to foreign policy issues, however, it was above all a domestic political occasion, organized by Mr. Mitterrand so that he could respond to a fierce opposition campaign aimed at showing that after 10 years in power he has lost his political touch.
 
The Campaign Heats Up
 The campaign was stepped up after Mr. Mitterrand seemed to hesitate in his initial condemnation of the Soviet coup last month and moved slowly in throwing his weight behind the Russian republic's President, Boris N. Yeltsin, and calling for President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's return to power.
After the coup failed, Mr. Mitterrand appeared on television to dispute charges that he had wavered. In recent days, Mr. Gorbachev and Mr. Yeltsin have also pointedly thanked the French leader for his support. But opposition and press criticism of his performance has continued.
[The Nobel peace laureate Elie Wiesel said Wednesday that Mr. Mitterrand had sent him to Moscow on a secret mission hours after the coup began to assure Mr. Gorbachev and Mr. Yeltsin of his firm support, Reuters reported from Budapest.
Political experts said Mr. Mitterrand was particularly shaken by this latest controversy because it followed months of growing public unhappiness with his Government's economic and social policies as well as complaints of his choice of Edith Cresson as Prime Minister in May.
Today, in what was his first full-scale news conference since May 1989, Mr. Mitterrand brushed aside speculation that he might replace Mrs. Cresson with Jacques Delors, who heads the European Community's executive commission, and that he might cut short his current second seven-year term.
He also noted that he had no intention of renouncing Socialism as a result of the collapse of Communism. "I am convinced that human society needs further liberations," he said. "It is a necessary combat."

HEADLINE: SOVIET TURMOIL;
SOVIET TRADE PACT SENT TO CONGRESS

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11

 BODY:
Administration officials presented Congress with an agreement today offering more favorable trade terms with the Soviet Union, but they said the pact did not include the newly independent Baltic countries and would have little effect on American trade.
Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d is to visit the Baltic countries on Saturday and is likely to announce then the Administration's position on trade relations with them, said Thomas Duesterberg, the Assistant Secretary of Commerce for international economic policy. 
 The Administration insisted until early August that the trade agreement include the Baltic states. But it changed its position when it became clear that the Soviet Union no longer had practical control over the Baltics, said Curtis Kamman, the Deputy Assistant Secretary of State for the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe.
The trade agreement clears the way for the Administration to grant most-favored-nation trade status to the Soviet Union, which allows products to enter the United States at the lower of two sets of tariffs. Mr. Duesterberg told the committee the agreement was needed to insure the United States' long-term competitive position in the Soviet market.
 
No Quick Effect on U.S. Trade
 But in the short run the agreement is likely to have no appreciable effect on American exports to the Soviet Union, which is short of internationally traded currencies, while Soviet exports to the United States, $1.1 billion in 1990, are likely to rise by only $100 million to $400 million annually, he said. United States exports to the Soviet Union totaled $3.1 billion last year.
As the Administration discussed Soviet trade, Prime Minister Jan Krzysztof Bielecki of Poland told reporters at a breakfast briefing today that he feared the Soviet Union might descend into chaos, sending millions of refugees toward his country.
President Bush promised Mr. Bielecki later today that the United States would give Poland $25 million worth of loan guarantees for housing, The Associated Press reported.

HEADLINE: SOVIET TURMOIL;
GORBACHEV SAYS HE'S READY TO PULL TROOPS OUT OF CUBA AND END CASTRO'S SUBSIDIES

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Sept. 11

 BODY:
In an effort to remove a major obstacle to increased American economic aid to the Soviet Union, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev announced today that his country would begin discussions shortly with President Fidel Castro of Cuba about the withdrawal of the 11,000 Soviet military personnel on the island.
Mr. Gorbachev, who announced the decision after a meeting here with Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d, also said that in the future Soviet economic ties with Cuba would be based strictly on free trade, eliminating the effective $2-billion-a-year subsidy that Moscow has been giving Havana by bartering Soviet oil for Cuban sugar on terms that greatly overvalued the sugar. 
 For some three decades, a major goal of American foreign policy has been to remove the Soviet military presence in Cuba and to end the substantial Soviet aid to that Communist outpost, 90 miles from Key West, Fla.
 
'A Very Substantial Gesture'
 In particular, the Bush Administration, to meet the concerns of conservatives, had conditioned substantial economic aid to the Soviet Union on an end to Soviet military presence in Cuba and a cutoff on subsidies to Mr. Castro.
Asked what he thought of Mr. Gorbachev's overture, Mr. Baker said: "I would not characterize that as a small gesture. I think it is a very substantial gesture." He added later, "That will be very important with respect to public opinion in the United States."
[Cuba reacted angrily, saying the Soviet announcements "were not preceded by consultations or any previous advice, which constitutes inappropriate behavior both from the point of view of international norms and of the agreements which exist between the two countries," Reuters reported from Havana.]
 
Desperation for Foreign Aid
 Only hours after Mr. Gorbachev made his announcement, Mr. Baker was told by the Russian republic's President, Boris N. Yeltsin, that he was proposing a compromise solution to Japan for settling a dispute over four islands in the Kurile chain seized by the Soviets at the end of World War II.
Tokyo has made a return of the islands a condition for any substantial economic aid to the Soviets. While not disclosing the Yeltsin proposals, Mr. Baker described them as "very substantive."
The simultaneous overtures by Mr. Yeltsin on the disputed islands and Mr. Gorbachev on Cuba were strong evidence of a new direction for Soviet foreign policy in the wake of the abortive coup against the Gorbachev Government last month. The moves also appeared to reflect the level of Soviet desperation for foreign economic assistance and the degree to which it is ready to dispense with or moderate long-held positions in order to raise cash.
"I reaffirmed to the Secretary that we plan to transfer our relations with Cuba to a plane of mutually beneficial trade and economic ties and we will remove the other elements of that relationship -- elements that were born of a different time in a different era," Mr. Gorbachev said. "In that context I told the Secretary that we will soon begin discussions with the Cuban leadership about the withdrawal of a Soviet training brigade, which was stationed in Cuba some time ago and is still there."
The reference to a "training brigade" appears to have been Mr. Gorbachev's euphemism for the entire Soviet garrison in Cuba, because when he was asked how many men would be involved in the withdrawal he said 11,000, which exceeds the highest State Department estimate for total Soviet personnel in Cuba. Also, a senior Administration official said that Mr. Gorbachev had made clear in his discussions with Mr. Baker that the Soviets would pull out all their forces.
The senior Administration official said the Soviet leader had also left Mr. Baker with the clear impression that in addition to withdrawing all of their military personnel from Cuba -- intelligence officers, advisers and a rifle brigade -- the Soviets intend to phase out their arms sales to Cuba.
Mr. Gorbachev's initiatives, if fully carried out, would be a milestone in the 30-year military relationship between the Soviet Union and Cuba -- a relationship that almost led to a nuclear war during the 1962 Cuban missile crisis and has been a source of tension in Soviet-American relations ever since. It also raises questions about a Soviet-Cuban treaty of friendship and economic cooperation.
Mr. Gorbachev disclosed the policy changes on Cuba during a joint news conference with Mr. Baker, after their talks in the Kremlin. It was the first time that the Soviet leader has appeared with Mr. Baker after a meeting in the Kremlin.
According to the State Department, Soviet military personnel on Cuba fall into three categories: roughly 3,000 attached to the huge intelligence listening post the Soviets have built in Lourdes, to monitor electronic communications in the United States; a rifle brigade of about 3,000 men assigned to protect the other Soviet military personnel in Cuba, and roughly 3,500 Soviet military advisers working with the Cuban armed forces.
 
Credits, Aid and Hidden Subsidies
 In 1990, the State Department says, Moscow gave Cuba about $500 million in trade credits and $800 million more in technical and development aid, including two nuclear power stations the Soviets are building on the island, and $2.2 billion in hidden subsidies through the oil-for-sugar barter.
The new relationship with Cuba will be worked out in the "immediate future," Mr. Gorbachev said, and should not take "many months" to begin.
The more desperate the Soviets become, and the more they meet Washington's conditions for aid, the greater the pressure on the Administration to increase its economic aid to the Soviet Union beyond just humanitarian food and medical aid or technical advice.
The senior Administration official briefing reporters on Mr. Baker's talks with Mr. Gorbachev and Mr. Yeltsin, which each lasted some three hours, said they told him that within four to six weeks they expect to have a concrete, credible plan for transforming the Soviet economy to market principles. American officials want the plan to be worked out in cooperation with the International Monetary Fund and other international lending institutions.
 
Reform Plan Before Allied Aid
 Once that reform plan is completed, Bush Administration officials and American allies have acknowledged, it would be incumbent on them to come up with substantial economic aid. This most likely would be cash and credits for a stabilization program of the sort used in Poland, to cushion the Soviet economy while it moves to a convertible currency and free market.
Mr. Baker told reporters after his meetings that the United States was already prepared to increase humanitarian food aid and technical advice, but was still conditioning any substantial new economic assistance on the adoption of an I.M.F.-backed program.
The senior Administration official said that both leaders told Mr. Baker that they had agreed that Soviet nuclear weapons should remain under the sole control of the President of the Soviet Union, or whatever central authority the republics agree on.
He said the two Soviet leaders were also in agreement that no matter what sort of loose confederation is decided on by the republics. they should retain a single currency, if at all possible. American officials have been advising the Soviets that economic reform will be much easier if they retain a single currency, banking system and fiscal and monetary policies, although some republics are talking about printing their own money.
The same applies to aid requests. The senior official said Mr. Baker had told Mr. Yeltsin and Mr. Gorbachev: "It is important that aid requests come from one source, so if we respond we will not get a competing request from another source."

GRAPHIC: Photo: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d after their meeting yesterday at the Kremlin. (Agence France-Presse)
 
Chart: "Ties That Bind Havana and Moscow"
 As the Soviet Union's only ally in the Western Hemisphere, Cuba got extensive military and economic aid in exchange for its loyal political support and services as a military proxy in Africa.
 
Economic Subsidies
 Discount oil: The Soviet Union delivers oil to Cuba at a fixed price. For years it was below the world market price; the discount was treated as a grant. In recent years Cuba has lost money on Soviet Oil purchases.
 Subsidized exports: The Soviet Union buys Cuba's main commodity exports, sugar and (before 1988) nickel, at above-market prices. The premium is treated as a grant.
 
Net benefit to Cuba:
1961-88 total: $39.6 billion
1989: $4.5 billion
 Other aid: The Soviet Union provides loans on concessionary terms and various other kinds of development aid.
 
Net benefit to Cuba:
1961-88 total: $17.6 billion
1989: $1.4 million
 History: The U.S. was once Cuba's main trading partner, but imposed an economic embargo after Fidel Castro introduced Comunism. The Soviet Union stepped in to prop up theCuban economy and is now by far Cuba's main trading partner.
 
Military Ties
 Soviet troops: Moscow will begin talks with Cuba aimed at withdrawal of 11,000 troops, apparently all the Soviet forces in Cuba. They include:
 
Combat troops: 3,000
Signal inteligence: 3,000
Military adivsers: 3,500
 The remainder includes civilians in military-related roles.
 History: Soviet combat troops have been present in Cuba since 1962, but first came to Western, public attention in 1979. Missiles fired by Soviet troops shot down a U.S. U-2 spy plan in 1962 at the height of the Cuban missile crisis.
 
(Sources: CIA Handbook of Economic Statistics; Internationl Institute for Strategic Studies; State Department) (pg. A12)

HEADLINE: Masur Reaches for the High Notes

BYLINE: By ALLAN KOZINN

 BODY:
Orchestras like to think of their histories in terms of eras, each era defined not so much by occurrences in the outside world as by the tenures of their music directors. For the New York Philharmonic, the Zubin Mehta era came to an end last May, and with last night's performance -- the opening concert of its 150th season, and the orchestra's 11,738th concert all told -- the Kurt Masur era began.
As gala concerts go, the Philharmonic opted for a dignified approach rather than a glitzy one. On the other hand, it did its best to see that the event received the attention that the start of a new era deserves. Above the Lincoln Center plaza facing Broadway flew one huge banner with a bright red M, announcing Mr. Masur's ascent to the Philharmonic podium, and another celebrating the orchestra itself as "107 Great Musicians, OneBrilliant Instrument." 
 Inside Avery Fisher Hall, Philharmonic workers in silver sashes pointed the way. And because the performance was to be beamed across the country as part of the "Live From Lincoln Center" series of telecasts on PBS, the stage was brightly lighted, and eight cameras were located at strategic points in the hall. Most, though not all, of the hall's 2,738 seats were filled, but the Philharmonic was counting the concert as virtually sold out. But those on hand gave Mr. Masur a standing ovation when he first walked onstage, and another lasting about five minutes at the end.
For the occasion, Mr. Masur led a program that was part American and part Viennese, with two Minimalist fanfares by John Adams and Aaron Copland's folksy "Old American Songs" before the intermission, and the mammoth Bruckner Seventh Symphony after it. The concert, a benefit for the orchestra's pension fund, was followed by a party for Mr. Masur, the orchestra and about 950 guests under an enormous white tent in Damrosch Park, with Peter Duchin's orchestra playing dance music by the likes of George Gershwin and Cole Porter. Mr. Masur, who had changed out of his white tie and tails into a dark suit, arrived at the party with his wife at about 10:55 P.M., to applause from the already seated crowd.
 
A Tribute From Leipzig
 Earlier in the day, after the final rehearsal, Mr. Masur's family and a few hundred representatives of the Philharmonic and Lincoln Center were on hand when a delegation the other ensemble Mr. Masur directs , the Gewandhaus Orchestra of Leipzig, surprised the conductor with the autograph score of an unpublished Canon in B minor by Mendelssohn. The work was composed in 1844, when Mendelssohn was director of the Gewandhaus Orchestra.
"Now you are starting to make me nervous," Mr. Masur said. But for a conductor caught without a prepared speech, he seemed surprisingly poised.
"We are starting not with some compromises," he said, "but with open-minded people who want to reach the highest level we can."
 
Looking Beyond the Honeymoon
 It has been many years since a Philharmonic opening night was the focus of so much anticipation, hope and, to a degree, mystery. The last time was probably on Sept. 14, 1978, when Zubin Mehta took up the baton. Like a newly elected president, an orchestra's music director can look forward to at least a brief honeymoon period, during which he and the orchestra find their common ground and persuade the audience that their explorations together will be worth following.
Mr. Masur seems fully aware of that the honeymoon may be temporary, and he has shown every intention of making the most of his first American post. He comes to the Philharmonic at a potentially perilous time. He is facing a recession that has been felt at box offices all over the United States, and an increasingly urgent need to find new audiences in a country where classical music is not a majority concern. The orchestra's future is bound up in the way he addresses these problems once the jubilation of his opening night fades and he takes up the day-to-day running of the orchestra.
Mr. Masur has already taken some steps to address the audience question. He has expressed interest in taking an active hand in the orchestra's Young People's Concerts, and he is conducting three of them this season. And the pair of Adams works that opened last night's program was perhaps a response to those who have complained of the orchestra's hidebound programming.
If Mr. Masur feels the scrutiny he is under, one did not notice it when watching the closeups that the "Live From Lincoln Center" crew was sending to the mobile studio parked on West 65th Street. During both the final rehearsal and the performance, he looked thoroughly at ease and happily wrapped in Bruckner's rich textures. And to hear some of the players tell it, Mr. Masur comes to his new directorship with a confidence and assurance that they find inspiring.
 
A Conductor Who 'Keeps Growing'
 "Every time we've seen the guy, there has been more and more depth and drive in his music-making," said Philip Myers, the orchestra's principal French hornist. "I liked him when he first conducted us, 10 years ago, and with some conductors you don't see much of a change over 10 years. But his interpretation keeps growing.
"Also, he is the kind of director who can make a decision in five seconds. He knows exactly what he wants."
He has, for example, reseated some of the players in a way that helps them hear one another better. The basses have been moved onto 30-inch risers across the back of the stage. The violas, once nestled between the violins and cellos, have switched places with the cellos and are taking the outside edge.
Thomas Stacy, the Philharmonic's principal English hornist, also cited Mr. Masur's assurance when asked what qualities he found in the conductor's work. But he said there was another characteristic he admired equally.
"What I've found working with him," Mr. Stacy said, "is a wonderful balance of orchestral experience and preparation in rehearsal, and the all-important spontaneity in performance that can lead to concert magic."
 
Idealism vs. Inertia
 Many in the musical world have also been impressed by Mr. Masur's campaign to learn about New York City's musical life in the 17 months since he was appointed to succeed Mr. Mehta. He has attended a surprising range of concerts and recitals. He has brought in German acousticians to examine the persistent sonic problems of Avery Fisher Hall, and at last night's concert, some of the sound baffles they prescribed could be seen at the sides of the stage. And in his interviews, he has left the impression that he is coming to the job with a kind of idealism that may overcome the inertia of contemporary American musical life.
Mr. Masur has started this week's rehearsals with pep talks about the importance of working together. But the musicians, when asked their impressions of the week's rehearsals, inevitably brushed past the lectures and the seating changes, and returned to Mr. Masur's musicianship.
"His sense of characterization is so rich," said Joseph Robinson, the principal oboist. "Without naming any names, we have worked with conductors who are traffic cops, or who seem like they are putting together a puzzle. But our experience with Masur has been that he shapes the music in ways that enliven it. From his first meetings with us, he has emphasized partnership. He said that if it isn't a happy collaboration, he'll tear up his contract."
Mr. Stacy, for one, said he does not think that will happen.
"I think the players have been intrigued with his musicianship and depth of knowledge," he said. "It gives us a feeling of confidence that is important and can lead to a 10-year honeymoon."

HEADLINE: Hollywood Called Hypocritical by Actor Who Died of AIDS

BYLINE: By BERNARD WEINRAUB, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 11

 BODY:
The publication of an anguished indictment of the film industry as indifferent and hypocritical toward people with AIDS, written by the actor Brad Davis, who died of the disease on Sunday, has touched a raw nerve in a community that prides itself on openness and tolerance.
Mr. Davis, who starred in "Midnight Express" and other films and plays, wrote his thoughts about Hollywood and AIDS as he drafted a proposal for a book to discuss the six years in which he carried the HIV virus. Mr. Davis kept his illness a secret from everyone but his wife, Susan Bluestein, a casting director, and a handful of friends, largely out of fear that it would shatter his career if Hollywood knew about it. 
 Portions of Mr. Davis's reflections were published in The Los Angeles Times today, after his wife got in touch with the paper. Ms. Bluestein, who could not be reached for comment today, was quoted in the paper as saying that Mr. Davis wanted to have his story told. What emerges is a bleak portrait of an actor desperate to hide his condition and "remain anonymous at all costs."
 
'One More Pariah in Hollywood'
 "I make my money in an industry that professes to care very much about the fight against AIDS -- that gives umpteen benefits and charity affairs with proceeds going to research and care," wrote Mr. Davis, who began work on his proposal in the last months of his illness. "But in actual fact, if an actor is even rumored to have HIV he gets no support on an individual basis. He does not work."
Mr. Davis expressed the fear that "somehow the gossip mill would get hold of me and that would be that: I'd be one more pariah in Hollywood who would never get a job."
Ironically, Mr. Davis's reflections have been made public at a moment when the movie industry is, essentially, celebrating its own contribution and commitment to AIDS. On Sunday, virtually the entire movie establishment is planning to show up at the Universal Amphitheater in Universal City to honor, among others, Bette Midler, the actress, and Sidney Sheinberg, president of MCA, for their involvement with the AIDS issue. Recently, the leading players in the industry appeared at a highly publicized fund-raising event given by a show business lawyer, Alan Hergott, for the National Gay and Lesbian Task Force. At the time, Mr. Hergott called it a "breakthrough."
But Mr. Davis's comments are, some Hollywood film makers say, a reflection of the industry's ambivalence and confusion, even fear, about dealing with AIDS and, for that matter, with homosexuality.
 
'It's Too Close'
 "AIDS is a pariah disease, it's too close to many people in this town, it's too frightening," said Bruce Davison, the award-winning actor who appeared in "Longtime Companion," one of the few films about AIDS. "It's easier, for example, to make films about Vietnam when it's not the 60's or 70's. Someday, when they find a cure for the disease they'll make a movie about AIDS. It'll have a certain nobility then."
Mr. Davison said Mr. Davis's concerns about working were valid. "It's the same as Rock Hudson," he said. "I remember going to the doctor's office to get a physical and there was Rock Hudson. He was trembling. He was frightened. Now I know that he was terrified that he'd be found out and he wouldn't have a job."
Mr. Davis, in his notes, indicated uncertainty about how he contracted AIDS. "I was a total drug addict -- an alcoholic and I.V. drug user -- a user of just about any kind of drug I could get," he wrote. "And I was sexually very promiscuous. I've never known any addicts who weren't."
Certainly, the bleak subject of AIDS is considered financially risky, especially in the aftermath of the summer flop "Dying Young," with Julia Roberts, which dealt with a young man dying of cancer. (On the other hand, "Love Story" and "Terms of Endearment," in which major characters died young, proved to be financially successful.)
 
Economic Distress Cited
 "Look, the economy is depressed, people are struggling financially, it's a hard time in the industry," said Craig Zadan, producer of "Footloose" and other films, who is planning to co-produce with Oliver Stone a film about Harvey Milk, the gay San Francisco politician who was assassinated. "People want to escape. It's not a good time to come in with a film about death."
Mike Medavoy, chairman of Tri-Star Pictures, said: "There's always a pause when you make a film about someone dying. You're afraid to be maudlin or false. It's just a very difficult subject to do well. Even films like 'Love Story' and 'Terms of Endearment' had a very hard time getting made."
But others say dealing with AIDS is especially delicate and complex in an industry where there are numerous gay actors and directors who are not only silent about their sexuality but who also try to hide it. "Hollywood is scared to put money on AIDS films because it's a stigmatized disease and a lot of people here are in the closet who just don't want to be associated with the subject," said Zelda Rubinstein, the actress from "Poltergeist" who was an an early supporter of AIDS education and support. "It frightens a lot of people here."
Several people in the industry agreed that Mr. Davis was right to worry about working. "There's so much competition, there're fewer and fewer projects, if you have any excuse to hire one person over another, you do it," said Mr. Zadan. "I don't think it's an issue of prejudice. All of these decisions are subjective. The slightest thing can influence you."
 
TV More Flexible
 Mr. Medavoy observed: "An actor's health is not a a question that I would consider, unless he had a serious heart condition and we had insurance problems. If a director wants to hire an actor, and he's a good actor, I'm not going to ask what his health is."
Even film executives acknowledge that television has been somewhat more flexible and open about AIDS and gay people than the film industry. Several prime-time series, including "L.A. Law," "Doctor, Doctor" and "Thirtysomething," have included gay characters, and there have been some moving television dramas about AIDS, including "An Early Frost" and "Our Sons." "Longtime Companion" will be shown on PBS on Sept. 29.
A leader in Hollywood efforts to combat AIDS, Helen Gorman Kushnick, who is Jay Leno's manager and who lost a 3-year-old son to AIDS because of a tainted blood transfusion, said: "If everybody takes the position that Brad Davis did -- and believe me, I'm not judging him -- then people with AIDS will remain a minority. If people choose to speak out, they become the majority. People have got to speak out. I've had breast cancer. And I've had nothing but support. I didn't keep it a secret. And NBC just hired me to be executive producer of the 'Tonight' show next year."

HEADLINE: DESIGN NOTEBOOK;
The How-To's Versus the Too-Muches

BYLINE: By PATRICIA LEIGH BROWN

 BODY:
ENOUGH of yard sales, Bain de Soleil and apple wood. September is the time when editors of design magazines show their stuff. For readers craving tchotchkes and advice, there is nothing more intoxicating than the first sighting of the season's shelter magazines in the mailbox.
Imagine what Mars might look like if a well-heeled Martian managed to commandeer the current crop. But the Martian might also get a migraine. These are deeply confusing times for readers of home design magazines. 
 For every photograph of Karl Lagerfeld's villa in Monte Carlo, with its Louis XV sofa upholstered in the same red damask that covers the walls (HG), there is an equal and opposite message.
In the current issue of Home magazine, the actress Melanie Mayron sums up the 90's ideal. "You can put your feet up on the table," she said of her 1,140-square-foot home, "and if you spill something, it's no big deal."
The tension between fantasy and reality, all the more acute in light of the economy, is making itself felt in a gradual drift toward "how-to" articles.
In House Beautiful, Louis Oliver Gropp, the magazine's new editor-in-chief, explained that attitude in describing the magazine's new pared-down lower-case logo. "The 80's are over," he wrote, "along with the clutter and too-muchness."
Those seeking too-muchness need not despair. In its September issue, Architectural Digest gives readers the low-down on antique European barometers and an 8,000-square-foot mansion on Lake Michigan.
But perhaps the most talked-about feature is "Country Spirit on the Coast: A Sun-Washed Setting for Folk Art in California," an airy house for an unnamed client in which a brass fish is suspended from the ceiling.
The client, it has been reported, is none other than Paige Rense, the editor-in-chief of the magazine. Mrs. Rense herself won't confirm this. "It is the policy of the magazine not to reveal the owners of anonymous houses," she said.
It appears that if it is her house, Mrs. Rense is actually a real person. The magazine quotes the anonymous owner as saying, "I didn't want to live in a 'Statement.' " She is described as "a woman who has always shunned sham originality."
Traditionally, House Beautiful favored a more homey, milk-fed decorating approach. Although it is too soon to tell what the "new" House Beautiful will bring, the redesigned September issue seems more stylish and upscale. It includes a story on a rambling John Saladino house with a 22-foot-high entrance hall, a report on the Milan furniture fair and an interview with Robert Venturi and Denise Scott Brown.
The most compelling comment on design circa 1991 is actually found in an article on food. David Bouley of the TriBeCa restaurant Bouley observes that people "are not interested in food as architecture or design, the way they were in the 80's; they want simplicity and taste" (Taste! What a concept!).
Martha Stewart Living, the bimonthly Time Inc. publication, looks like it is stepping into the how-to role abdicated by the home design magazines, wearing Manolo Blahnik shoes, of course.
It's no accident that the magazine is the only one that features a person, rather than an interior, on the cover (the ubiquitous Ms. Stewart, of course). Martin S. Walker, president of Periodical Studies Service, a New York magazine consulting firm, calls it "the first vanity publication Time Inc. has ever published."
This is the magazine many people will hate to love. Its raison d'etre is the elegantly presented how-to story. In contrast to the first issue, which featured an article on croquet and numerous pictures of Ms. Stewart dressed in white, this issue seems down to earth. Deep-sea fishing has replaced croquet.
There is a story on kitchen knives and, in the domestically blissful spirit of 1950's women's magazines, an iron-on transfer for a keepsake pillow. There also seem to be fewer Stewart relations about.
Egoiste, the Chanel men's fragrance, made its American debut at the Metropolitan Home show house, the focus of a self-congratulatory fest in the magazine's September issue.
An admirable AIDS benefit, the show house was also notable, readers are told, for transforming the magazine's staff into heroes, heroes, heroes.
A number of the rooms, especially a study by the designer Jed Johnson and the architect Alan Wanzenberg, seemed a touchstone of the 90's. The idea of creating a glinty, bumpy wall surface by allowing brass mesh and staples to poke through green plaster is just the sort of humble extravagance people seem to be yearning for.
Next month, in the October renovation issue, Dorothy Kalins, the magazine's editor in chief, writes that she has realized her readers want help solving practical problems. But in the meantime they can order a show house video by dialing an 800 number.
The September issue of HG contains a nod to practicality in an article on 39 solutions to the problem of where to put the television set. The ideas included a TV in an ivy-covered designer potting shed and another in sandbags. It's the thought that counts. The report also contained one of the month's more memorable quotes, by the architect Robert A. M. Stern: "Who needs television when you have architecture?"
Perhaps the quote of the month is to be found in Elle Decor, in an article on walls. "I have an easy solution to any wall problem," Paloma Picasso said. "I can always find a Picasso to hang on it."
But let's face it: It is the Palomas of the world who make curling up with design magazines a delicious spectator sport. Which is why this reader's month was made by The World of Interiors. She longed for a ride in the London penthouse elevator containing a half-bottle of champagne, jelly beans and a condom.

HEADLINE: Philanthropists Aid Brooklyn Museum

 BODY:
The art collectors and philanthropists Iris and B. Gerald Cantor have made a challenge grant of $1 million over three years to the Brooklyn Museum, the museum announced yesterday. The grant, to help the museum with its operating expenses at a time when its support from New York City has been reduced because of the city's financial problems, is to be matched by $3 million in private contributions.
"Throughout the past several months the Brooklyn Museum has struggled to maintain its high professional standards as the city has steadily whittled away its support," Mrs. Cantor, who is a member of the museum's board, said in a statement. "That a cultural institution of its stature should have had to close to the public for a week and temporarily lay off its entire staff, as it did in late August, is appalling and untenable." 
 Robert T. Buck, the museum's director, said the grant "assured the stabilization of the museum during the city's financial crisis."
"It has given the Brooklyn Museum the means by which to find other monies to tide us over during this terrible period," Mr. Buck said.
But Robert S. Rubin, the chairman of the museum's board, said the gift was not "a substitute for the loss of 38.6 percent in city support." Rather, he said, it was "one-time-only emergency funding for a specific problem and in no way absolves the City of New York of its responsibility to the Brooklyn Museum."
In April the museum opened a new third-floor auditorium that was finished with a $3.5 million gift from the Cantors, who have made previous gifts to the Brooklyn and Metropolitan Museums. The 460-seat auditorium, designed by Arata Isozaki and James Stewart Polshek, is named for the Cantors.

HEADLINE: Teachers Return, Many Without Contracts

BYLINE: By ROBERT HANLEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LITTLE FERRY, N.J., Sept. 11

 BODY:
After a decade of general harmony between teachers and local school boards, a record number of teachers' contracts remain unsettled at the start of the new school year across New Jersey and New York State.
In New Jersey contracts for teachers in about 140 districts -- including the striking teachers who picketed here today -- remain unsettled out of 256 that expired last June, about twice the usual rate, according to Edward Gallagher, director of communications for the New Jersey Education Association, the state's largest teachers' union. 
 In New York State, of 450 contracts up for renewal for this academic year, 259 are still unsettled, said Robert Rice, deputy director of communications for the New York State United Teachers, who called that an all-time high. At this time last year, he said, 226 contracts were unresolved.
Officials say negotiations have dragged on for a variety of reasons: Albany and Trenton cut out millions of dollars in aid and then delayed telling districts exactly how much they would be getting, taxpayers are increasingly hostile to school spending and towns are uncertain about how long and how deeply the recession will hurt them.
 
Slower and Tougher
 "When the pie is smaller, the bargaining gets more difficult on both sides," said Mr. Rice.
While negotiations have been slower and tougher across the two states, they have broken down completely here in Little Ferry, a working-class town of about 10,000 just north of the Meadowlands Sports Complex. Settlements were reached today in two other strikes in towns in southern New Jersey, Cinnaminson and Willingboro.
Union and school board officials in New Jersey and New York do not think there will be many strikes this year, in part because of the harmony of recent years. But next year, when money is likely to be just as tight, they say, they may not be so lucky.
In Connecticut, all contracts have been resolved. Under a state law enacted after a teachers' strike in Bridgeport in 1978, school boards and teachers who cannot reach a settlement must submit their offers to an arbitrator in time for a binding decision by the end of April.
In New York City, teachers and Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez are negotiating on a contract to replace the one that expires at the end of this month.
In all three states, teachers' contracts signed this year have begun to reverse the 1980's pattern of annual wage increases of 8 or 9 percent. In Connecticut, increases in teachers' pay averaged about 6.5 percent for 1991-92 contracts, down from 7.5 to 8 percent for the 1990-91 year, said Clifford Silvers, director of affiliate services of the Connecticut Education Association, a teachers union.
Across New York State, new increases have ranged from 5 to 7 percent this year, compared with the increases of 7 to 9 percent common in the 1980's, said Louis Grumet, executive director of the New York State School Boards Association.
In New Jersey's schools, increases in contracts reached before the current school year began averaged 9.08 percent. New contracts reached between January and June provided average increases of 8.22 percent for the current school year and 8.18 for 1992-93, said Joseph Flannery, a spokesman for the New Jersey School Boards Association.
"We're seeing isolated instances below 8 percent and some below 7," Mr. Flannery said.
Unions officials say teachers are sensitive to the tighter economic times and are not being intransigent in this fall's bargaining.
"Our teachers live in these towns, too," said Mr. Gallagher of the New Jersey Education Association. "The numbers are flattening out. Teachers are taking less because less is available. They're taking the best deals they can get. But our local people don't feel any obligation to bear the brunt of all the jiggering around with state aid figures at the state level."
 
Being Reasonable?
 "This money is less plentiful this year," said Mr. Rice, the union leader in New York. "I believe we're being reasonable, but in addition to holding the line on salaries, a lot of districts are asking teachers to pay larger and larger amounts of their health insurance premiums."
Of Little Ferry's 54 teachers, 46 struck its two elementary schools, Memorial and Washington, last Friday, complaining that school board negotiators had cut their initial two-year wage offer of 8.8 percent and 8.5 percent three times since last March. The board's latest offer is for a four-year contract, with annual increases of 7, 6.5, 6 and 5.5 percent.
Elaine Shields, president of the local teachers union, said: "We're trying to come down, but they keep going lower. There's no middle ground. How are we every going to catch this mouse?"
Ms. Shields declined to discuss the union's latest proposal, other than to say it was lower than the 8.8 percent it was willing to take last spring.
 
'Economic Calamity'
 The superintendent, Stacy J. Holmes, said the board had reduced its offer because "we've had a continuing economic calamity going on here."
First, he said, the district lost $300,000 in state school aid. Then, just before the school year ended, local voters rejected the school budget for the 10th time in 13 years. After the defeat, the town council cut $700,000 from the $7 million budget.
On Wednesday, a state judge, Kevin M. O'Halloran, ordered the striking teachers fined 1 percent of their gross annual pay for each day the strike lasts beyond today.
Like Little Ferry, scores of towns across New Jersey are struggling with loss of expected state aid for this year and the prospect of further decreases for years to come. In addition, in two years they will be required to take over from the state the payment of millions in teachers' pension contributions. Officials fear this will mean more trouble at the bargaining table -- and perhaps more strikes, despite laws prohibiting them in both states, including New York City.

HEADLINE: Failed Trip Shows Dinkins's Weak Spots

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
The sudden collapse of Mayor David N. Dinkins's trip to South Africa has painfully exposed two of his most acute vulnerabilities: his overreliance on one overworked aide, Deputy Mayor Bill Lynch, and his propensity to reach for the grandest gesture, even when times seem to demand the simplest.
Mr. Dinkins said he postponed the trip because Mr. Lynch had been too busy putting out fires in New York to raise the half-million dollars needed. A charter flight was to have taken the Mayor and several dozen city officials and business executives on a journey that had assumed the proportions of a royal tour. 
 But that disappointment epitomized something much bigger: With a government of a quarter-million workers, and his own top staff of five deputy mayors, Mr. Dinkins still has a hard time getting things done.
"It's a comment both on how tough times are, and on the way he dreams and doesn't plan things," said one of the Mayor's oldest political allies, who spoke on the condition of anonymity. "I think it is a reflection that they don't have a designated chain of command and responsibility, but they expect Bill Lynch to be superhuman at the expense of his own health. Why the trip had to be planned in a way that made it so expensive and hard to pull off, I don't understand."
At the heart of matter is the Mayor's failure, nearly 21 months after taking office, to delegate power unequivocally to his staff. Instead, he has fostered a system in which Mr. Lynch, nominally in charge of politics, is his First Deputy in many other fields. First Deputy Mayor Norman Steisel has the full powers of his title in other areas, with the rest of the staff left in some shifting and ill-defined terrain in between.
"It's gotten better, but it's still there," another deputy mayor said yesterday, speaking on condition on anonymity. "In periods of stress it comes out more."
That would be problematic enough if the Mayor had small aspirations, or faced easy tasks. But he plunges into ambitious projects that would daunt the best-oiled machine, from his plan to hire thousands of police officers to the South African trip.
By his own admission, Mr. Lynch also has great difficulty delegating responsibility, and he held the planning
 
A Citizens Committee
 for the trip close to himself because its goal was dear to him.
But Mr. Lynch, who has diabetes and serious vision problems, was so consumed trying to quell the recent racial violence in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, that he let fund raising for the trip slide, winning commitments for only about $200,000. On Tuesday, Mr. Dinkins was moved to public tears as he reflected on his aide's efforts and the toll they have taken on his health.
Yesterday, Mr. Lynch said he intended to set up a citizens committee to raise funds for the charter flight from foundations, corporations and individuals, which he said would pay special attention to any potential conflicts of interest involving donors who might do business with the city.
 
More Modest Missions
 Asked why he had not done that originally, Mr. Lynch said, "I think the time collapsed on me" and that he had dropped the ball. That was diplomatic, but the truth is more complex. Mr. Dinkins relies utterly on Mr. Lynch's counsel but has also seems to have taken him for granted, and the ball was the Mayor's to drop.
Every mayor adopts his own style, and Mr. Dinkins has struggled to find one that suits him. By turns, he has underestimated his real powers, repeatedly stressing how little he can do amid a fiscal crunch, and has clung fiercely to his ceremonial and symbolic importance, repeatedly making televised speeches with the flags and foofaraw of a Presidential event.
In both respects, the Mayor has been burdened by the insistent skepticism and soaring hopes that greeted his election as the city's first black mayor. He defended his ambitions for taking city finance, health, welfare, housing and other officials with him to South Africa as a way to lend expertise and foster economic ties to the struggling black majority there.
Other mayors have made more modest missions abroad and provoked little comment. Mr. Dinkins acknowledged that he could have made a quick trip with a handful of aides but that it would have left no more than a shadow. He plans much more: a mission of succor to struggling brethren and an effort to forge business links that he called an investment that would yield dividends "to every New Yorker" in a post-apartheid world.
 
A Snappy Immediacy
 "This is about making lasting relationships that will be helpful to this city with a very important country economically and strategically," Mr. Lynch said.
But that is an argument whose merits would have been debated by some if Mr. Dinkins could have pulled the trip off, and he could not, though his aides now say they hope to reschedule it for November.
The paradox is that Mr. Dinkins is seldom more effective than in small moments of personal contact. Lately, he has also grown noticeably more comfortable in the trenches of the mayoralty, buoyed by his visits, at all hours of the day and night, to the scenes of civic disasters, from the recent subway crash to Crown Heights. After such trips, he speaks with a snappiness and immediacy that has eluded him in the past.
Yesterday, the Mayor took pains to praise all his deputies, stressing that Mr. Steisel was the "guy in charge" and defending his diffuse organizational chart. But in doing so, he had an air of trying to persuade himself, too.
"People can complain about the service cuts and what not," he said. "But it is a situation that we face, and I think that we're handling it as well or better than anybody else could."
