HEADLINE: Decline Follows a 2-Decade Boom in Lower Manhattan

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK

 BODY:
After one of the most sweeping urban revivals in the nation in the 1970's and 80's, the southern tip of Manhattan has sunk into an economic morass that has many business executives worried and has prompted a fresh round of study at City Hall.
The area, roughly a square mile of densely packed real estate below Chambers Street, underwent radical change that began with the completion of the World Trade Center in 1972. It quickly became an example of how to mix housing with commercial buildings, and of how to open up a neglected waterfront for recreational use.
 
Towering Glass Structures
 The mammoth development of the 1980's replaced old concrete and brick office buildings -- most of them built before 1930 -- with towering glass structures that dominate an area that was and remains the world's most powerful center for finance. They housed offices, restaurants and nightlife and attracted a much more diverse variety of people to the area than the Wall Street workers who had made it their exclusive domain. 
 "Lower Manhattan is the economic engine which drives our city," Mayor David N. Dinkins said yesterday during a news conference with several corporate executives where he announced plans to study changes in the area, find ways to reinvigorate it and map out its long-term development.
The area, he said, is facing "very real, very difficult problems." Among the many questions are how to attract more residents, how to create greater access to undeveloped parts of the waterfront and what to do with obsolete office buildings.
 
The Initial Phases
 Commercial construction in lower Manhattan boomed in the 80's, when 20 million square feet of space was built, equivalent to that in most small cities. Apartments, restaurants and nightlife, virtually nonexistent before, sprung to life along the area's waterfront with the initial phases of Battery Park City and the completion of the South Street Seaport.
The development of the South Street Seaport, as well as the later renovation of the Statue of Liberty and Ellis Island, brought a surge of tourists to the area.
But now, while tourism shows no sign of slowing down, almost every other economic signal suggests that the resurgence has stopped, if only for the time being.
Office vacancies, which had dwindled to under 3 percent in 1981, rose steadily through the last decade and now exceed 20 percent. Housing construction at Battery Park City and elsewhere in the area is at a standstill. And many lower Manhattan businesses, from large brokerage firms to restaurants and small printing shops, have either gone out of business or are still suffering from the fallout of the 1987 stock-market crash and subsequent cuts in the securities industry.
In announcing the study yesterday, Mr. Dinkins said he had instructed the Department of Planning to prepare a comprehensive plan for the area, the first since 1966. He said the plan would be completed over the next year.
He also said that he had created a nonprofit advisory and research group, known as the "Lower Manhattan Project." The group will be financed by several large corporations, including the Olympia and York Companies U.S.A., the American Express Company, the Chase Manhattan Bank and the J. P. Morgan Company.
"Downtown employers and owners are painfully aware of the recession," said John Zuccotti, president of Olympia and York and chairman of the advisory group, which has obtained a commitment of $350,000 a year in corporate funds, and is looking for more. "We don't intend to sit back waiting for a recovery."
 
Time for an Update
 To be sure, the initiative announced yesterday amounts to little more than a study, and without the beginnings of an economic upturn no one expects immediate results. But if history repeats itself, or even comes close, the officials said, now is the time to update a plan for the area.
The last comprehensive plan for lower Manhattan set zoning guidelines, provided traffic and pedestrian studies and coordinated development plans for the South Street Seaport, World Trade Center and Battery Park City.
Although no huge commercial projects are now on the drawing board, the officials said yesterday that the city's plan needs to be updated if lower Manhattan is to continue to attract more housing and if tourism is to continue to grow. The city and private industry also need to plan for communications technology that will keep Wall Street competitive with other financial centers around the world.
 
A Long Evolution
 "Unlike plans for other eras, the thrust now is to manage and nurture what has happened," said Con Howe, the former executive director of the Department of City Planning, who has been appointed director of the advisory group.
Some of the questions to be addressed by the planners relate to the long evolution of lower Manhattan as a business center, and how to encourage the proper use of outmoded real estate.
Before the 1980's, the last surge of development came during the Wall Street boom of the 1920's. After the 1929 stock-market crash, developers avoided the area for more than three decades. During the postwar boom years, the flight of New York's middle class to the suburbs made midtown office locations, within walking distance of Penn Station and Grand Central Terminal, more attractive.
Because of the age of many of the lower Manhattan buildings, their wiring, low ceilings, small elevators and other limitations disqualified them for use by computer-driven corporations.
 
17 Apartment Complexes
 An alternative that has been discussed for years -- and will be studied by the planners -- is to renovate some of the old office space into housing. Real-estate executives have been lobbying City Hall to create incentives with tax abatements.
But the housing market in lower Manhattan, as elsewhere in the city, remains in a trough. At Battery Park City, the developers of the Cove Club, the latest of 17 apartment complexes completed since 1983, sold 57 of their 163 condominiums at auction in May, receiving only 75 percent of their asking prices. Seventy-eight of the condominiums remain unsold.
Other questions before the planners relate to undeveloped waterfront that is largely inaccessible to the public. Old industrial piers jut out into the East River below the South Street Seaport, and could be demolished or used to support restaurants or other recreational centers.
Mr. Howe said a priority of his group is to plan an esplanade that would run from the Seaport to Battery Park, which would then connect to the esplanade at Battery Park City.
Other recommendations to be considered include improvements in public transportation, the officials said yesterday. One option is to develop a new bus terminal in the Wall Street area, and provide express bus service from one or more midtown locations that would appeal to suburban commuters.

HEADLINE: BALTIMORE MAYOR LEADING IN POLLS

BYLINE: By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BALTIMORE, Sept. 11

 BODY:
After a quiet, even lackluster primary campaign, Baltimore Democrats will go to the polls on Thursday to nominate a candidate for mayor, with the incumbent, Kurt L. Schmoke, the overwhelming favorite among the eight contenders.
Republicans will also choose a mayoral nominee, picking from six names on their ballot. 
 But Mr. Schmoke, the first black ever elected Mayor of Baltimore and the first political outsider to hold that job in almost two decades, has little to fear politically in the fall from any Republican, assuming he wins the required primary plurality on Thursday. Democrats outnumber Republicans almost 10 to 1 in this old port city, which is heavily blue collar and predominantly black.
Further, while Mr. Schmoke won office as an outsider in 1987, refusing to cut deals with the city's entrenched political clubs and arguing that the old politics had left the city broke and burdened with some of the worst urban ills in the country, he has since created his own powerful political organization.
 
Rising Star Is Sidetracked
 The city is still deeply troubled by crime, drugs, dilapidated housing, joblessness, a weak school system and a chronic shortage of money. Those problems have proven so intractable and so all-consuming in a time of national economic recession that Mr. Schmoke, who took office amid speculation that he would soon be one of the nation's most influential black politicians, has all but slipped off the national political scope.
His major moment in the national spotlight came when, to the surprise and concern of many of admirers, he suggested that one way to solve the nation's drug problem might be to legalize some drugs and concentrate on rehabilitation, not incarceration.
Nevertheless, if political experts and polls here are to be believed, Mr. Schmoke has persuaded a majority of voters that he is the candidate best suited to eventually solve the problems of the nation's 12th largest city. Most polls have given him a lead of better than 20 points over his nearest rival.
"I feel good about this election," Mr. Schmoke, who is 41 years old, said this afternoon as he campaigned in a blue-collar neighborhood in eastern Baltimore. "I think people understand that what I've been doing is laying a foundation for the city to move forward in the future. Some people say I'm not very flashy and that this has been a dull campaign. Well, protecting a city's bond rating may not be politically sexy, but it will pay off in the end."
 
Two Old Rivals Return
 Of the seven Democrats Mr. Schmoke faces on Thursday, only two are given even a long-shot chance to beat him. They are Clarence (Du) Burns, 72, a product of the political clubs and church organizations in the city's black wards, and William A. Swisher, 58, a former city prosecutor who came up through the clubs in the city's white, blue collar wards.
Mr. Schmoke, a local high school football star who became a Rhodes Scholar and a lawyer before entering politics, beat both men in earlier election contests with a coalition of blacks and liberal whites.
Mr. Schmoke predicted today that the coalition would hold for him on Thursday. But Mr. Burns predicted otherwise.
"No way it will hold again," he said at his campaign headquarters. "Four years ago I was down by more than 20 points, just like today, and in the last few hours I closed to within four points or so. There were a lot of people holding back then, and it's the same now, and they're my people, people who know I know how to make a city move."
Mr. Swisher, in between making calls to prospective voters, said all the candidates agreed that crime, drugs and schools were major campaign issues. "But they've been talked about so much, without results, that people are turned off," he said. "Voters want somebody who can get action. Schmoke hasn't been able to do that."

HEADLINE: SOVIET TURMOIL: GORBACHEV SAYS HE'S READY TO PULL TROOPS OUT OF CUBA AND END CASTRO'S SUBSIDIES;
Collision With Congress

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11

 BODY:
The Bush Administration said today that it hoped that a Soviet military withdrawal from Cuba would lead to the downfall of Fidel Castro, but collided with Congress over how Washington should now press to achieve that central goal of American policy in the Western Hemisphere.
Clearly, word that the Soviet Union will soon open discussions to withdraw its military from Cuba produced a moment for the Bush Administration to savor. The President's own impatience with the Soviets was obvious. 
 "I wish they'd hurry up," he told reporters in the Oval Office in his only public comment on the development.
Speaking to reporters in Ashland, Ohio, where he was delivering a speech, Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said, "The Soviet withdrawal is an indication that Fidel Castro, who has kept himself in power all these years by brute force, that his own days may be numbered."
But the Administration seemed unclear about how to go about accelerating that process.
Members of Congress immediately began floating proposals to toughen economic sanctions against Havana, make direct economic aid to the Soviet Union contingent on an end to all of Moscow's ties to Cuba, including economic ones, and stall the granting of favorable tariff treatment for the Soviet Union.
The White House tried to fend off those proposals, each of which conflicted with policy goals of its own.
Speaking with reporters outside the White House after a meeting with Mr. Bush, two Republican lawmakers, Senator Phil Gramm of Texas and Representative Newt Gingrich of Georgia, said the Soviet announcement, while welcome, did not go far enough. They insisted that all economic aid from Moscow to Cuba should be ended.
"We can't let this freedom tide wash over the world and not drown Fidel Castro," Senator Gramm said.
Representative Robert G. Torricelli, Democrat of New Jersey, agreed, saying: "It cannot be justified to provide financial assistance to the Soviet Union while they continue to squander their own resources in Cuba."
But the White House insisted that it was not linking Soviet aid to Cuba with American aid to Moscow.
"Our position has been and continues to be to oppose that sort of thing," an Administration official said, adding, "Besides, what's the hurry? It's going to happen in Cuba without our help."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Markets
Long-term bond yields fell to their lowest level since late 1989, as credit market participants reacted to a favorable inflation report and sharp declines in the money supply. [D1.] 
 Stock prices got a solid lift from the better-than-expected report on inflation, with the Dow gaining 20.80, to 3,007.83. [D6.]
S.E.C. officials have concluded that automating the junk-bond market might discourage fraud and insider trading, but that any electronic system should focus on the most active issues. [D12.]
Grain and soybean futures prices rose on the prospect of food shipments to the Soviet Union and the threat of a diminished U.S. crop. [D13.] The dollar fell. [D13.]

HEADLINE: One Aquino's Painful Stand on Bases

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MANILA, Sept. 12

 BODY:
Among the Philippine senators prepared to vote to shut down the largest American military base in Asia, none makes quite the same sacrifice as Senator Agapito Aquino, brother-in-law of President Corazon C. Aquino and younger brother of her slain husband, Benigno S. Aquino Jr.
Since he announced his opposition last month to a new 10-year American lease for the Subic Bay Naval Station, Senator Aquino says his relationship with the President -- a woman he describes affectionately as his "surrogate mother" -- has grown decidedly cool. 
 "I feel she is hurt by what I have done," Senator Aquino said as he sipped coffee today in the lounge just outside the Senate chamber where the debate over the future of the American base began Wednesday. "Our relationship now is civil, only civil."
But at the risk of family harmony, "I feel we must make this historic decision," he said, adding: "The time has come for the Philippines to put an end to the spirit of dependence on the United States. We need to cut the apron strings with America, even though we are scared to do it."
 
Petition Drive Considered
 Mrs. Aquino, in the middle of what she insists is the final year of her presidency, has staked her political credibility on ratification of the treaty, and the decision by her brother-in-law to vote against the pact came as an acute embarrassment.
Her chief aide, Franklin Drilon, said today that if the Senate rejected the treaty, the Aquino administration would consider staging a petition drive to collect the millions of signatures necessary to hold a national referendum on the issue.
It remains unclear whether a referendum on the bases could overturn a Senate rejection of the treaty. Under the Philippine Constitution, the Senate has the exclusive right to ratify or reject treaties.
Mr. Aquino is one of 12 members of the 23-member Senate who have announced their opposition to the base agreement, which would allow the United States to operate at Subic until the year 2001. A vote on the pact is expected sometime before Monday, when the current treaty expires.
Although Mr. Aquino is obviously closer to the President than any of his 11 anti-base colleagues -- he lived in the home of his brother and Mrs. Aquino for a time in the 1950's and describes himself as "like her eldest son" -- other Senators have longstanding ties to the President. Indeed, only two members of the Philippine Senate were elected without Mrs. Aquino's endorsement.
 
'Difficult for All of Us'
 "It's very hard to go against the President you respect and you love," said the 52-year-old lawmaker. "It has been difficult for us all."
Even though opinion polls show overwhelming public support for the treaty, the Senate appears ready to reject the treaty for reasons of national sovereignty and national pride.
Some of the senators say they do not oppose the idea of an American base on Philippine soil so much as they object to what is often described on the Senate floor as the insultingly small compensation package offered by the Bush Administration: $203 million a year, less than a quarter of the original request by Mrs. Aquino's negotiating team.
Senator Aquino's objection is one of strict nationalism, however. He says it is time for the Philippines, while retaining the friendship of the United States, to issue its "declaration of independence" from foreign paternalism.
Mr. Aquino said the nation would somehow deal with the economic consequences of an American withdrawal: the loss of hundreds of millions of dollars injected into the Philippine economy each year from Subic.
"The job dislocation weighs heavily on us," he said, but added: "We also worried about the more than three million other Filipinos who are unemployed across the nation at this time."
Benigno Aquino, a leader of opposition to President Ferdinand E. Marcos, was gunned down at Manila's international airport as he returned from exile in 1983, setting in motion a chain of events leading to the election of his widow as the nation's leader and the downfall of Mr. Marcos when he tried to steal the election.
Senator Aquino said he beleved that his elder brother would have supported the removal of American troops from the Philippines. "I think my brother shared the belief that the bases should go," he said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: "We need to cut the apron strings with America, even though we are scared to do it," said Senator Agapito Aquino, second from right, brother-in-law of President Corazon C. Aquino. He joined other opponents of a new United States lease on bases in the Philippines at a rally this week in Manila. (Reuters)

HEADLINE: Hostage Issue: Test for Iran's President

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TEHERAN, Iran, Sept. 12

 BODY:
Western diplomats here said today that a full solution to the hostage crisis in Lebanon, which now seems possible, will strengthen President Hashemi Rafsanjani against hard-liners.
Mr. Rafsanjani is trying to restore capitalism in Iran and attract foreign investment after years of revolutionary confiscations and a destructive war with Iraq. 
 The climactic hostage negotiations now being directed by the United Nations Secretary General, Javier Perez de Cuellar, come at a time of severe testing for the so-called pragmatic group of revolutionary clerics led by Mr. Rafsanjani. They have been trying to consolidate their power ever since the death in 1989 of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, the Iranian leader.
The economy here after the Iran-Iraq war remains depressed and contorted by artificial controls. The Government's economic reform program is tearing away subsidies and sending food and other basic prices soaring. The birth rate is adding a million Iranians every six months to the population of 57 million. By one estimate, the Government would have to add 500,000 jobs this year and achieve a growth rate of 4.5 percent, considered an impossible goal, just to stand still.
 
Farms and Factories Sag
 Most of the country's $12 billion in annual oil revenues is paying for imported food and other commodities once produced by Iranian industry and agriculture, both of which are moribund after years of centralized mismanagement during the war.
The first postwar development plan calls for $120 billion in spending over five years to rebuild oil, energy and other important sectors. But the plan is staggering under the weight of demands from the swelling population and restrictions during the five years on foreign borrowing, which cannot exceed $28 billion, a fraction of the needed cash.
The Western businessmen who have flocked here in the last two years have found Iran quick to order but slow to pay. Islamic codes on such fundamentals as arbitration of disputes have caused many companies to balk.
But in the short term, the new momentum on the hostage front in Lebanon gives Mr. Rafsanjani an important victory over his still formidable opposition, Western envoys said.
 
Crucial Election Campaign
 Mr. Rafsanjani and his supporters are in the midst of a crucial parliamentary election campaign against the hard-liners, who have held a rough majority since their election in early 1988 during the final days of uncompromising militancy in the Iran-Iraq war.
This Parliament attacks Western aid and influence as "domination," and rejects all but limited Western financing for badly needed projects. It still bristles at any talk of re-establishing relations with the United States. Political fences with Britain were mended last year while Parliament was in recess.
Key hard-liners include militants who helped direct the takeover of the United States Embassy here in 1979 and revolutionary judges who ordered thousands of executions after the overthrow of the Shah.
But Mr. Rafsanjani's policy of bringing the hostage crisis to an end may be on its way to vindication against the hard-liners in the 270-seat Parliament, where many argued that Israel and the United States would fail to respond to Iranian "good will" gestures like the release last month of the hostages John McCarthy and Edward A. Tracy.
The date for the election has not been set, but Iranian officials said it could come as early as February.
"The Parliament still has the means and the power to obstruct his policies," said a Western Ambassador who is among the longest-serving foreign diplomats here. "And if Rafsanjani succeeds to establish a reliable majority in his favor, it will be much easier to pursue his goals."
Until that happens, said one businessman who stayed here through the revolutionary decade, "the situation is still not secure for people to bring their money back into the country."
An attempt this year to persuade Iran's wealthy expatriates to return and invest has so far failed to produce results, according to a wide variety of Iranian and Western officials.
Part of their fear is that Mr. Rafsanjani will somehow fail and Iran will tumble back into the abyss of xenophobic isolation that characterizes the radical style. Therefore, most analysts here agree, to succeed politically Mr. Rafsanjani and the pragmatic mullahs must succeed economically.
"Rafsanjani could be killed at any time, which is in the tradition of Iranian politics, and then what?" asked a Western Ambassador whose government has been at the forefront of supporting Mr. Rafsanjani's policies.
 
'It Will Take Years'
 What is also clear, this and other Western ambassadors interviewed said, is that Mr. Rafsanjani does not have unlimited time to correct the severe dislocations that were built into Iran's once-robust economy by a decade of revolutionary excess.
The Ambassador said that "even after the election, it will still take years" to rebuild industries and attract the kind of investment that will put Iran back on a stable footing.
All of the political handicapping thus far suggests that Mr. Rafsanjani will be able to defeat the so-called radical majority. Still working in partnership with the country's new spiritual leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, the President has defeated several attempts by hard-liners to exploit economic discontent to undermine his Government.
And in a potent political warning shot last fall, Mr. Rafsanjani demonstrated his tactical shrewdness against the hard-liners when he got a number of them removed from the powerful Consultative Assembly of Experts by forcing candidates to take a written test on Islamic law.
Not surprisingly, several hard-liners failed and were ejected from the panel.

HEADLINE: U.S. Reluctant to Move To Hasten Castro's Fall

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12

 BODY:
Although the Bush Administration believes that Moscow's plan to withdraw its military from Cuba may weaken Fidel Castro, it is reluctant to move to hasten his fall because it does not want to make Cuba a sour point in Soviet-American relations or risk antagonizing Washington's Latin American allies, Administration officials said today.
On its face, the Administration's hesitation to make any major policy changes after President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's announcement about Cuba on Wednesday seems odd against the backdrop of history. 
 It has been a virtual obsession of United States policy to oust President Castro and to end the Soviet military presence in the Caribbean, which brought the superpowers to the brink of nuclear war during the Cuban missile crisis in 1962 and provided an ideological linchpin for Ronald Reagan's campaign against Communism in the Western Hemisphere.
Administration officials argued today that there is little the United States can do to interfere in Cuban politics, especially in light of its spectacular failures in Cuba in the past. They said that any attempt to intervene would risk inflaming anti-Washington sentiment in Latin America, where the Bush Administration had to work for months to repair the political damage from the invasion of Panama in 1989.
 
Risks for Bush
 But Mr. Gorbachev's announcement on Wednesday underscored the limits of an American policy that one official acknowledged was "long on declarations and short on actions." And inaction by Washington in the face of a prospective Soviet military withdrawal could pose political risks for Mr. Bush.
Mr. Bush has had the luxury of watching Communism crumble in this hemisphere, without undertaking the kind of overt and covert anti-Communist acts on which Mr. Reagan's Latin American policy stumbled and ultimately foundered.
But Mr. Bush has sometimes been faulted for not moving forcefully in response to world events. Some Administration officials fear inaction on Cuba could alienate Florida's substantial Cuban-American vote in an election year and draw criticism from conservatives as their attention wavers from the Soviet Union.
Administration officials and some outside specialists argue that the decline in the Soviet military threat and the fall of other Marxist governments in Latin America in recent years has reduced the significance of Cuba. Moreover, they said, it is the Cuban military and Soviet economic aid, not the Kremlin's uniformed presence, that keep Mr. Castro in power in this post-cold-war environment.
The Administration officials rejected proposals to link American economic aid and trade benefits for the Soviet Union to a halt in Soviet aid to Cuba. They argued that Moscow would be forced relatively soon to curtail its subsidies to the Cuban economy in any case, and that President Bush does not want to sour Soviet-American relations by attaching such conditions.
"There's this nagging sense that an important moment has come," said Susan Kaufman Purcell, a specialist on Latin America who is vice president of the Americas Society in New York. "Part of me thinks there is something that we should be doing other than let it fall by its own weight. But I can't think what it is."
Some officials are pressing the White House and other agencies at least to step up rhetorical attacks on the Cuban Government and continue their calls for the Soviet Union to cut off all military and economic aid to Cuba.
"The Administration has not really focused on this but we are going to have to start because of what the Soviets announced," one official said.
"There's going to be a lot of interest among conservatives on Cuba and it could become a political problem again," he added. "The trouble is, no one inside or outside the Administration has had a coherent approach outside of saying, 'You have to support human rights, you've got to stop supporting guerrilla movements, you've got to have elections.' "
 
Real Value of Subsidies
 Administration officials said they still believed that only Mr. Castro's death could bring down his Government, unless the eventual withdrawal of Soviet subsidies causes such economic chaos that the military or a popular uprising unseats Cuba's 64-year-old leader.
Wayne Smith, the former head of the American interests section in Cuba and a critic of American policy on Cuba, said the United States has consistently overestimated the value of the Soviet subsidies, which largely take the form of Soviet oil traded for Cuban sugar.
Ms. Purcell said: "It would be different if Cuba's dictatorship were kept in place basically by Soviet troops, but that is not the situation. Cuba's dictatorship has for a while been kept in place mainly by Cuban troops. This is the most highly militarized regime in the hemisphere."

HEADLINE: North Korea Tries to Block Any Effects of Failed Soviet Coup

BYLINE: By STEVEN R. WEISMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Sept. 12

 BODY:
Citing the dangers of a cholera epidemic in South Korea, North Korea canceled a meeting with officials from Seoul last month. Then last weekend, the North Koreans tried to confine presumably diseased delegates from the South to their hotel rooms in Pyongyang.
Cholera, of course, is hardly seen as the problem. What is feared by one of the world's last Stalinist redoubts, it seems, is contamination by the breakup of the old Soviet empire and the final dissolution of its once dependable alliance with Moscow. 
 Since the failure of the hard-line coup against President Mikhail S. Gorbachev last month, North Korea has acknowledged that a "vortex of fast-changing history" is under way. But the Government also declared proudly that no sign of even the "slightest political instability or vacillation" was visible in the country.
"The invincible might of our own style of socialism is being highly demonstrated," Pak Sung Chul, the Vice President, told a rally last weekend, the North Korean press agency said. He called on everyone to unite once more around the 79-year-old self-proclaimed Great Leader, Kim Il Sung.
 
North Is 'Basically Stable'
 Americans, Japanese and South Korean specialists agree that there is no sign of any instability in North Korea, despite the tumultuous recent events in the Soviet Union. No one has ever found any evidence of any dissident movement in North Korea, for instance.
"They're definitely in a state of shock because of the changes around the world," said Rhee Sang Woo, professor of political science at Sogang University in Seoul. "But the political situation in North Korea is basically stable. Nothing there is going to change."
Speculation about the future of Mr. Kim has long focused on his son and anointed successor, Kim Jong Il, known as the Dear Leader. Some in the West say there might be instability once the transfer actually occurs. But again there is no sign that a transition has been affected by recent events.
Japanese diplomats, the only ones from the democratic countries to engage in high-level talks with North Korea recently, say the Pyongyang Government seems to be digging in. The Japanese attempt to improve relations with North Korea thus appears to have reached a stalemate.
 
Push for Nuclear Inspections
 "At first it seemed like they wanted to move ahead," said a Japanese diplomat who met with the North Koreans last week in Beijing. "But now it seems like they are losing some interest in normalizing relations with us."
North and South Korea have remained in a state of war since the end of the Korean War nearly 40 years ago, with more than a million troops facing each other and the West increasingly frightened by evidence that North Korea is proceeding with a program to produce nuclear weapons.
Japanese diplomats are pushing North Korea to agree to a regime of inspections and safeguards for their nuclear sites. They also have held discussion on North Korea's demands for reparations from Japan's colonization of the peninsula until the end of World War II.
North Korea has said it will sign an agreement to accept the safeguards. But Japanese say there is little sign that Pyongyang intends to follow through. Instead, North Korea continues to demand simultaneous inspection of nuclear weapons in the American military presence in the South.
[In Vienna, North Korea said it would not sign an agreement to allow international inspection of its nuclear installations because it still faced a threat from American nuclear weapons in South Korea.
["The question of signing a nuclear safeguards agreement cannot be solved as long as the nuclear threat to our country by the United States persists," a North Korean spokesman told journalists at a meeting of the board of governors of the International Atomic Energy Agency.
[At the meeting, the governors empowered the agency's Director General, Hans Blix, to sign a nuclear safeguards agreement negotiated earlier this year between the United Nations agency and Pyongyang.]
 
U.N. Membership
 For at least two years, North Korea has in fact been buffeted by adverse developments.
Well before this summer, Mr. Gorbachev moved steadily to improve ties with South Korea, ending the special relationship with Pyongyang that has also served as an economic lifeline.

HEADLINE: Inquiry on Texas Crash Focuses on the Airplane

BYLINE: By ROBERTO SURO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HOUSTON, Sept. 12

 BODY:
Federal investigators today focused on the possibility that a mechanical or structural failure caused a Continental Express commuter plane to burst into flame in midair on Wednesday, killing all 14 people on board.
Agents of both the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms were at the site of the crash about 75 miles southwest of here today in an effort to determine whether foul play was involved. 
 But Rolando Moss, a spokesman for the Houston field office of the F.B.I., said this afternoon, "We have found no evidence that would lead us to believe that some kind of incendiary device or bomb caused the crash."
The aircraft, a Brazilian-made Embraer 120 Brasilia, crashed into a cornfield shortly after 10 A.M. Wednesday while on a regularly scheduled flight between Laredo, Tex., and Houston.
Airline and Federal officials said that just before it went down, the aircraft was flying at an altitude of 11,800 feet in clear, calm weather and that the pilot had reported no difficulties to air-traffic controllers.
A senior Federal official at the scene of the crash said this afternoon that investigators were focusing their attention on the aircraft's left wing and its engine, which tore off the wing and landed 75 to 100 yards from the rest of the wreckage. The plane's left wing came down with other major parts of the wreckage and was folded under the right wing, which investigators said was highly unusual.
The official, who asked not to be identified, said that evidence collected on the ground had confirmed reports by witnesses that the plane had caught fire while in the air.
Investigators were still trying to establish the cause of the loud bang heard by those witnesses. The senior official said that after an initial inspection, investigators had concluded that the housing of the left engine showed no evidence of an explosion or of the kind of massive engine failure that would have sent pieces of machinery piercing through the housing.
Officials said that the bodies of all the passengers were found either in the forward or aft sections of the plane and that they were not wearing seat belts. They said this suggested that the passengers might have been trying to move away from a fire on the wing or in the center of the aircraft.
The plane apparently fell in a flat spin after it caught fire in a descent, which would have taken a minute or more, allowing passengers time to move from their seats, investigators said.
 
Diamonds Are Recovered
 Investigators said tonight that they had recovered from the wreckage about $500,000 worth of diamonds that was in the luggage of one passenger. They said that they had looked for the gems after a business associate of the passenger called to inform them that the diamonds were on the plane. The diamonds have been turned over to the Federal Bureau of Investigation for safekeeping. The passenger was not identified.
The Embraer 120 has a history of incidents in which pilots have lost control of the propeller's pitch, the angle at which it bites into the air. A defect believed to be the source of the problem was discovered on an Embraer 120 that crashed April 5 near Brunswick, Ga., killing 23 people, including former Senator John Tower of Texas.
The plane that crashed on Wednesday had been inspected under a Federal directive issued after the Georgia crash and no defects were discovered in it, airline officials said.
A team of investigators from the National Transportation Safety Board arrived at the scene of Wednesday's crash this morning and removed both the voice and data flight recorders from the severely burnt wreckage of the fuselage. The recorders, which take down conversations in the cockpit and various data on the aircraft's movements, including speed and altitude, were sent to an board's laboratory in Washington for analysis.
The names of 11 passengers and three crew members killed were released today by Continental Express, a subsidiary of Continental Airlines. The Associated Press reported that among the 11 passengers was Guillermina Valdes, a noted scholar of the sociology and economy of the United States-Mexican border who was director of the Ciudad Juarez branch of the Collegio della Frontera Norte, a research institute.
Federal law enforcement officials were called into the investigation of the crash on Wednesday because of numerous reports by witnesses that a loud sound like that of an explosion had preceded the aircraft's fiery descent, Mr. Moss of the F.B.I. said.
Their attention was heightened when they were informed by the Drug Enforcement Administration that an informer in on-going Federal drug investigations was supposed to be on the plane, officials of several agencies said. But Bill Ruzzamenti, chief spokesman at drug agency's headquarters in Washington, said, "We have absolutely no information at all to indicate that foul play was in any way directed towards our people."

HEADLINE: Soviet Pullback From Cuba: A Red Letter Day in Miami

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MIAMI, Sept. 12

 BODY:
On the streets of Little Havana and over the airwaves of this city's Spanish-language radio stations, there was jubilation and more than a bit of gloating today, as the news that the Soviet Union plans to withdraw its troops from Cuba was passed from mouth to mouth and analyzed on talk shows.
"This is the best news that Cuban exiles have received in 32 years," said Tomas Regalado, news director at Radio Mambi, a popular Spanish-language station. "There is a tremendous sense of euphoria and the feeling that we have begun a new era in the Cuban drama. People see this as the beginning of the end of the Castro regime." 
 "He'll be gone by February," Juan Gonzalez, an exultant 61-year-old stevedore, forecast this morning as he stood with a knot of fellow Cuban refugees at a fruit stand on Calle Ocho, in the heart of Little Havana.'
Others, however, were more skeptical, made wary by three decades of constant predictions that the end of Communism in Cuba was imminent. Over the years, the more than one million Cuban-Americans, most of whom live in the Miami area, have learned to discount the rumors that Mr. Castro is afflicted with an incurable disease, that a military plot to overthrow him is afoot, or that he plans to step down and ask for asylum in Mexico or Spain.
 
Is This Time Different
 "I have been hearing that Castro is going to fall ever since I arrived in this country nearly 19 years ago," Juan Suquet, a retired physician, scoffed as he sipped coffee in the Casa Sierra diner. "I'll believe it when I see him stretched out horizontally, but not before."
Still, the prevailing opinion seems to be that this time things are different. The failure of last month's coup attempt in the Soviet Union and the end of 70 years of Communism have been followed by a series of events that have undercut Mr. Castro's ties to his former patrons.
"This is the first time ever that the majority of Cuban exiles really believe it when they say 'Christmas Eve in Havana,' " Mr. Regalado said. "It's something people say every year, but now they have reason to believe it."
Just last week, for example, the Cuban American National Foundation, one of the most militant of exile groups, said it has been granted permission to open a Moscow office. The organization helped pay for Boris Yeltsin's visit to the United States in 1989, and its members have cheered as officials close to Mikhail S. Gorbachev suggest that future aid to Cuba be tied to free elections there.
 
Stronghold No Longer?
 "Fidel Castro's stronghold is no longer his stronghold," said Carlos Arboleya, a banker and foundation supporter who last week raised the issue of a Soviet withdrawal with Mr. Gorbachev and Mr. Yeltsin on the "Town Meeting" broadcast on ABC. "We are now in a position to lobby in Moscow as we do in Washington, on a par with Castro, or maybe even stronger."
Some older people have already begun planning their return, dreaming of reclaiming houses they left behind 30 or more years ago and seeing friends and relatives left behind. "I can live in Havana on my Social Security and come back here to visit any time I want," explained Jose Faz, who is 75.
Younger Cuban-Americans, especially those born and educated here, seemed less interested in the news from Moscow, however. Some said they see the possible end of the Castro regime as an opportunity to return and to make their fortune, or they look forward to participating in the reconstruction of the country. But few seemed as enthusiastic as their elders about returning.
"My life is here, and I like it," said Jose Galera, 25, assistant operations manager at a tire dealership. "I can't say I have a lot of loyalty to Cuba, because I've never been there or seen it. I'm curious, because my father was in anti-Castro groups, and my roots are there, but it's not like I'm dying to go back and stay."
 
Castro as a House Guest?
 "I'm staying here, but I'll do anything I can to help bring about Castro's fall," Teresita Avila, the 30-year-old owner of the Casa Sierra diner, said. "If he needs asylum somewhere, he can even come to Miami and stay in my house. I'm willing to make that sacrifice."
"Hush, child, don't you dare say a thing like that," said her mother, a seamstress who helps out at the diner. "He better not show his face here. He wouldn't last a half an hour."
The Soviet decision -- and the accompanying announcement that economic relations with Cuba will be put on a more realistic footing -- immediately intensified the longstanding debate here about the propriety of sending aid in any form to relatives in Cuba. Trade experts estimate that family visits, money and packages sent from Miami created revenues of more than $225 million last year.
As Cuba's credit and trade with the outside world dry up, that lifeline has become increasingly important to the Cuban economy. But those who oppose Castro argue that commerce, permitted for humanitarian reasons despite the trade embargo, should be cut off to hasten the collapse of communism.
"My children, mother and brothers are still in Cuba," said Hector Calzada Duran, 52, a florist who arrived here in 1980 with the Mariel flotilla. "I love them, but I love my country more. I don't want to see any food, clothing or medicine whatsoever going to Cuba. A breach has been opened, and we have to push Fidel Castro through it, for the good of our children."
But Agustin Tamargo, a newspaper columnist and radio commentator, said that to suspend such shipments "would be an act of inhumanity."
And one young woman, who did not want to give her name, said that when "I send a package of medicine to my mother, I'm not helping Fidel, I'm helping my mother. The people over there are already suffering enough.

HEADLINE: School Bells Ring, Nervously

 BODY:
New York City schools reopened this week, welcoming nearly a million children in a mixed atmosphere of uncertainty and optimism. The city's faltering economy has forced cutbacks at a time when promising reforms like school-based management were just starting to take hold. But even though conditions in many schools will be far from idyllic, officials have made admirable efforts to shield students from the worst consequences of the budget cuts.
The opening of school is always marked by promise. It's a new start in a new grade. But in some schools there weren't enough supplies. And 128 teaching vacancies remain, mostly in hard-to-fill subjects like speech therapy. As with other city services, education has suffered; the schools have been forced to cut $430 million from a nearly $7 billion budget. 
 Such austerity recalls the fiscal crisis in 1975, which resulted in layoffs of 14,000 teachers and hundreds of guidance counselors, school health workers and other support personnel.
The present crisis tested the ability of administrators to devise creative solutions. Schools Chancellor Joseph Fernandez has reduced central administrative positions and stressed more collaborative efforts among teachers, parents and the business community. Even so, the cutbacks will mean larger class sizes in some schools, fewer after-school programs and guidance counselors and higher prices for school lunches.
But Mr. Fernandez, the Board of Education and the teachers' and supervisors' unions deserve credit for supporting early retirement plans, thereby avoiding more drastic layoffs that would have seriously disrupted classrooms. Nearly 4,200 teachers and 700 principals and supervisors chose to retire early. About 2,000 new teachers have been hired. While the system has lost experienced professionals, it has also gained new talent that might be more receptive to reform.
Now the system will need all its talent and energy to sustain and improve upon several modest triumphs last year: an increase in reading and math scores, an improvement in elementary school attendance and an increase in the number of high school graduates.
It is difficult to predict how schools will be affected by the city's troubles. But the best way to spare the children is to focus remaining resources on classroom services -- as Mr. Fernandez has wisely done.

HEADLINE: Cuba III

 BODY:
Fidel Castro was not the only person rattled by Mikhail Gorbachev's announcement that Soviet military forces are to be withdrawn from Cuba. Ever since Cuba I, the disastrous 1961 Bay of Pigs invasion, and Cuba II, the horrifying 1962 missile crisis, Cuba has been viewed by Washington as an offshore threat and by Moscow as a strategic toehold in the Western Hemisphere.
But now hard-liners still worried about the last traces of cold war are robbed of yet another verity. If there's ever to be a Cuba III, it's likely to be a strictly homegrown affair in which Cubans decide among themselves the future of their society. 
 Nikita Khrushchev's reckless deployment of nuclear weapons in Cuba brought a shocked world to the nuclear brink in 1962. Disaster was avoided when he removed the missiles and President Kennedy agreed to a compromise that permitted a limited Soviet military presence in Cuba. But for years afterward, angry arguments persisted over the size, equipment and purposes of what Moscow still calls a "training brigade."
Shielded by the Soviet Union's power, Mr. Castro turned Cuba into an arsenal and training camp for hemisphere revolutionaries. He armed a dozen insurgencies and sent his own army to fight wars in Africa.
Washington responded by tightening Cuba's economic blockade and moving against radical regimes in Nicaragua and Grenada and an elected left-wing Government in Chile. "No more Cubas" became a rallying cry that swayed Presidents and Congress.
What proved a fantasy was the belief that Cuba was responsible for every indigenous revolution and that Mr. Castro's doctrines were the true menace. It was the Moscow connection that gave Havana its clout. Soviet subsidies were essential to keep the Cuban economy afloat; the global reach of Communism inspired Latin guerrillas.
Now the Soviet gods have failed Fidel Castro. Without billions in subsidies, Cuban Socialism is bankrupt. And when the last Soviet "adviser" sails home, Cuba will have lost its status as a Soviet outpost lying, in the timeworn right-wing alarum, just 90 miles from Florida. The final humiliation is that Havana was neither consulted nor forewarned about Mr. Gorbachev's statement to Secretary of State James Baker.
Thus Fidel Castro has been shrunk to his actual size, an eccentric autocrat clinging to a crumbling ideology. In 1961, Senator J. William Fulbright argued vainly against what proved to be the Bay of Pigs fiasco. He said in a memorandum to President Kennedy that revolutionary unrest in Latin America predated Mr. Castro and, in the absence of political and economic reforms, would outlive him.
"The Castro regime is a thorn in the flesh," Mr. Fulbright said, "but it is not a dagger in the heart." Fidel Castro lingers on in power, yet with this latest transformation of Soviet policy even the thorn has lost its sting.

HEADLINE: A New C.I.A., Without Gates

BYLINE: By Flora Lewis; Flora Lewis is Senior Columnist of The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW

 BODY:
No matter how the K.G.B. is disassembled, Moscow will retain an active military and political espionage service. And the U.S. still needs an effective, comprehensive intelligence service. But the K.G.B. and C.I.A. have largely kept each other in business as justification for much of their activities. As Communism and the Soviet state structure crumble and as secrets of Eastern European spy networks are disclosed, it has become increasingly evident that none brought their own side that much advantage.
So the U.S. should think carefully before stumbling on with the C.I.A. as it exists. There is an opportunity for a fundamental review of what the C.I.A. can and cannot do well, what it should and should not do. 
 The Congress is preparing the wrong questions for President Bush's nominee to head the agency, Robert Gates. Whatever his role in the Iran-contra debacle, an especially flamboyant but not atypical clandestine caper, Mr. Gates is steeped in the traditional C.I.A. approach.
Weirdly, he is credited for being right in insisting that Mikhail Gorbachev's attempt at reform would not change the Soviet Union and that the U.S. should not take it seriously. True, Mr. Gorbachev failed in his original intention of strengthening the Soviet Union and its Communist Party. But Mr. Gates failed to see the implications of Mr. Gorbachev's policies. He's old school -- hardly a qualification to meet new needs.
He is not alone. An argument is building that the end of the cold war means the C.I.A. should be reinforced and expanded because there is a diffusion of threats to the U.S. without there being a No. 1 enemy. Recognizing the importance of economic challenge, advocates want a big effort to collect economic secrets from allies and friends as well as potential foes.
This is what Stansfield Turner, the former Director of Central Intelligence, says in the current issue of Foreign Affairs. Even Admiral Turner, who tried to clean things up at Langley, Va., clings to the idea that secrecy is the best way to collect and assess information, which, as he rightly says, brings power.
He calls for a "symbiotic relationship" between U.S. intelligence and business, and a willingness, throughout the Government at least, to provide a "cover" for spies. "All agencies should be instructed that human spying is a Presidentially and Congressionally authorized activity and they should have a role in it," he writes. Shades of the K.G.B.!
In the search for new missions, do spooks think they can beat out America's competitors when what is needed is energetic, persistent marketing, long-term investment planning and labor-management cooperation on steady, first-quality production?
Mr. Turner grants major C.I.A. failures: not understanding signs of the invasion of Kuwait, the unpopularity of the Shah and the rise of the Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, the electoral defeat of the Sandinistas in Nicaragua and, above all, the decay of the Soviet economy. These are good examples of things that went wrong, not to speak of the harm done to U.S. interests in justifying protection of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega for a long time. But alert reporters, diplomats and travelers could and did notice the relevant facts in the cases he cites.
Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan has proposed eliminating the agency, separating technical from political intelligence and putting the latter under the State Department. There are two drawbacks to this approach. One is that when responsibility for policy and critical information are combined, established policy tends to force production of the information that supports its case. The second is that diversity is suppressed.
Rather, the C.I.A. should be retained as a technical and analytical service, drastically limiting reliance on secrecy except in such obvious matters as trying to infiltrate terrorist groups, and with a better sense of real U.S. interests in the world. The former deputy director, Bobby Inman, is a professional who would understand this. The directorship is not a job for a swashbuckler like the late, disastrous William Casey or Robert Gates.

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
The Third Side

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL

 BODY:
When the slaughter begins again in China, the West will be horrified and indignant. After all, we are not made of stone.
Of course, this time we will not actually see much of the murders by Communist troops. Beijing's rulers have learned one lesson from their warm-up at Tiananmen Square -- blind the cameras. 
 When three members of the House of Representatives recently placed a few white silk flowers on the ground at the square, a gesture that honored the dead and graced America, the guards rushed to do battle against the cameras.
Still, we will get word about the new slaughter and we will certainly be seriously annoyed. But it will have happened because the third side was silent or passive.
In every political prison, whether it is a single jail or a whole nation, there are three sides. The dictatorship and its police, judges and wardens are one side and the prisoners are the second. The third is the outside world -- when it fights for the prisoners, keeps their names alive, uses the pressures of political, economic and public opinion power against their captors.
Over decades, as Soviet anti-Communist democrats fought and were jailed, as they were released and continued the fight, as changes took place in the Soviet Union, much of the rest of the world watched day by day and spoke out. In all free countries were people of influence and voice who struggled to push Soviet Communists toward the individual freedoms that led to a nation's freedom.
Whatever future Soviet citizens now decide for themselves and at whatever price, the fact is that the anti-Communist revolution was victorious without great bloodshed. Every Soviet democrat and every Soviet Communist knows that one important reason was that the third side was worldwide.
But where is the third side now for China -- for all the Chinese students and workers who still rot in the Chinese gulag, for all their friends and families living in silence and shadow, for all Chinese who despise the Communists and, yes, for all Chinese who say let us be as we are, because they have never known anything but oppression, all their lives?
Absent -- but why? The reasons are in our political and intellectual "leadership" and, I believe, in racism.
Americans have the whole world banging on their brains but pay attention when their elected leaders, particularly the President, speak up for a cause, in decency's name. President Bush's message about this last Communist anchor is oh, let's go ahead and do business with them, and everything will be all right -- trust me, "I know China."
A saddening number of academics and journalists argue against the mildest of sanctions, raising tariffs to push Beijing -- not to give up Communism, Heavens no, but just to let some democrats out of prison and allow them to breathe.
Too many Americans do not seem able to see Asians as real -- certainly not as real as other people who suffer, Europeans if the Americans are white, Africans if they are black.
Beijing hears that tolling bell in the Soviet Union. The old men or their successors will either have to fall back step by step to freedom, knowing the result will be a relatively peaceful end to Communism, or fight the people with tanks.
If the third side remains silent, Beijing will fight. Why not? The Chinese Communists have silenced the U.S. for whatever most peculiar combination of personal and political reasons govern Mr. Bush on China, silenced America even after Tiananmen, through the gulag and slave labor, through genocide in Tibet and now through secret Chinese missile sales to Syria, known to Washington. Most peculiar.
Americans, public and private, can lessen the likelihood of slaughter in China, as they did in the Soviet Union -- by putting economic and political prices on repression. It is too late for guarantees against massacre, but it is the only chance.
With Mr. Bush showing his Chinese expertise by doing nothing, hope rests on Congress. Friends of freedom, please write loving notes to the representatives who spoke their minds to the Communists and then placed the white flowers -- Nancy Pelosi of California and Ben Jones of Georgia, Democrats, and John Miller of Washington, Republican. They were America's third side at Tiananmen Square.

HEADLINE: THE SOVIET TRANSITION;
Gorbachev Asks A Huge Increase In Food Relief

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12

 BODY:
President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union sent urgent letters to the European Community and the head of the Group of Seven industrial democracies today seeking food aid on a scale dwarfing previous Western commitments.
In a letter to Jacques Delors, the president of the European Community, Mr. Gorbachev said the Soviet Union needed $6 billion to $7.3 billion worth of free food for the coming winter, said Ella Krucoff, a spokeswoman here for the community. 
 A spokeswoman for Prime Minister John Major of Britain said that he had received a similar letter but declined to discuss its contents. Mr. Major is the current chairman of the Group of Seven, which also includes the United States, Japan, Germany, France, Italy and Canada.
 
Concern Over Unrest
 The requests underlined increasing Soviet and Western concerns about the adequacy of Soviet food supplies this winter and the possibility that shortages could lead to a breakdown of civil order there.
In another indication of the Soviet Union's potential problems in feeding itself this winter, the Agriculture Department announced today that this year's Soviet grain harvest was likely to be about 20 percent smaller than last year's. The estimate was near the optimistic end of predictions by agriculture experts for a 20 to 30 percent drop.
Soviet officials have been estimating a drop of 23 to 28 percent, said Carol G. Brookins, a Washington agriculture consultant who was in Moscow last week.
Today's letters from Mr. Gorbachev were similar to a letter that Frans Andriessen, the European Community's Commissioner for External Relations and Trade Policy, received on Wednesday from Ivan S. Silayev, the head of Soviet economic planning.
Mr. Gorbachev's letter today asked the European Community for specific quantities of food in 17 categories. These included 5.5 million metric tons of grain, 900,000 metric tons of meat, 900,000 metric tons of sugar, 350,000 metric tons of butter, 300,000 metric tons of flour and 300,000 metric tons of vegetable fat.
Ms. Krucoff said that the European Community had no immediate reaction to the request and that a senior Soviet official would visit Brussels on Sept. 18 and 19 to explain the reasons for it.
Mr. Delors told the European Parliament on Wednesday that the European Community should send $2 billion worth of food to the Soviet Union immediately. In an appeal directed at Washington, Tokyo and Ottawa, he also said that all of the Group of Seven countries should send food.
The European Community is shipping $300 million worth of free food and $600 million worth of food sold with subsidized loans. The community agreed in January to send this assistance and is now preparing another $1.4 billion program including both food and technical assistance.
 
Problem of Distribution
 American officials have said that the distribution of food is just as important as total supply, and the first of two high-level Agriculture Department delegations is in the Soviet Union now to study both problems. Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady and Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve Board chairman, are to travel to Moscow on Tuesday for consultations on the economic problems.
Last year's bumper harvest of 235 million metric tons of grain was not enough to avoid local shortages because of transportation problems, and a smaller harvest this year may worsen local shortages, Agriculture Secretary Edward R. Madigan said last week.
The United States shipped $1 billion of grain in the first half of this year under a program of Federal guarantees for banks that lend money to the Soviet Union for purchases of American agricultural products. President Bush authorized another $1.5 billion worth of loan guarantees on June 11, of which the first $600 million has been committed and most of the food shipped.
The President made another $315 million of the guarantees available on Aug. 26 in response to an urgent Soviet request, but Soviet authorities have had trouble finding banks willing to make the new loans. The guarantees only cover 98 percent of the principal and the first 4.5 percentage points of interest on the guaranteed portion of the principal.
The Soviet Union used $94.4 million of these guarantees on Monday, mostly to buy corn, the Agriculture Department said. The purchase used the remainder of a $694.4 million line of credit set up before last month's attempted coup.
Private experts say that while no decision has been reached, the Agriculture Department seems likely to offer direct loans, financed by the United States Government, to the Soviet Union.
Bankers have become particularly reluctant lately to lend to the Soviet Union because its republics have said they would divide the responsibility for repaying the country's debt but have been unable to agree on how to do so.
The efficiency of food distribution has been drastically reduced this year by the reluctance of Soviet farmers to sell to the state. By Aug. 20 the Soviet Government had bought only 25 million metric tons of grain, down from 40.1 million metric tons on the same date last year, Ms. Brookins said.

CORRECTION-DATE: September 14, 1991, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
A front-page article yesterday about Soviet request for at least $6 billion in foreign food aid misstated terms of the request. A European Community spokesman in Brussels announced yesterday that the Soviet request included an offer to pay for part of the food, beginning in 1994; it would not all be a donation.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Owners Say They'll Review Draft

BYLINE: By CLAIRE SMITH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BALTIMORE, Sept. 12

 BODY:
Major league baseball owners have decided to review the ways in which baseball conducts its annual June draft of high school and college athletes, introducing the possibility of securing more leverage in negotiations and changing the relationship between amateurs and professionals.
Emerging from a joint session of American and National League owners on the final day of quarterly meetings, Commissioner Fay Vincent said major league baseball had agreed to review the rules governing the amateur draft. 
 One of the concerns, Vincent said, is for a team having a draft choice who doesn't sign "and whether that team should be permitted to retain that right for a period of time."
 
The Yankee Case
 Although Vincent said the issue was not new, it was a prime concern of one team this season. The Yankees, fearing the loss of the nation's top draft pick, Brien Taylor, signed the high school star to a $1.55 million contract just before the pitcher was to begin courses at a junior college.
If Taylor had attended one class, the Yankees would not have been able to sign him until next spring. If Taylor had not signed by next June, he would have been eligible to re-enter the draft.
Robert Nederlander, managing partner of the Yankees, said Taylor's name had not come up in initial discussions on the draft. But immediately after the signing last month, owners from both leagues were highly critical of the amount of money paid to Taylor.
 
Union Weighs In
 Donald Fehr, executive director of the Major League Baseball Players Association, said that he could not yet comment on any changes without knowing details. But he pointed out that any change that would affect major leaguers or potential major leaguers is an issue the owners would have to take up with the union.
In another area involving amateurs, Steve Greenberg, the deputy commissioner, said: "Part of what we're exploring is working more closely with the N.C.A.A. to establish jointly a procedure which would further the objectives of the N.C.A.A. and the clubs in terms of how the draft is managed as opposed to the current system.
"It really puts us at loggerheads with the N.C.A.A. in terms of discouraging certain athletes from going to college and playing college ball."
On that point, Fehr said that the union would welcome such an overture. "We are also interested in doing whatever we can to encourage college pursuits rather than discourage it the way the game does now," he said by telephone from New York.
 
Mariners' Troubles
 In other developments, Jeff Smulyan, owner of the financially troubled Seattle Mariners and a string of radio stations, including WFAN in New York, said recession-related worries in the latter field were not motivating him to seek relief in baseball.
"When your core industry is going through a recession, it certainly lessens your fervor to pour more money down the drain," Smulyan said. "But I think that frankly if the broadcasting industry had tripled in the last year I wouldn't view this situation any differently."
Vincent said that no one in baseball could make any predictions about the franchise's future until it is seen what Smulyan and the city's civic and corporate leaders produce. They are making a 45-day effort to find a way for Seattle to equal at least 90 percent of what American League teams average in revenues.
In other business, the owners voted to expand CBS-TV's control over the final two days of the regular season. The network already had the power to choose any games it wished to broadcast nationally. The owners have now voted to have local broadcasts yield rights to CBS on those two days.

HEADLINE: Review/Art;
The Faces of Death: A Multi-Media Meditation

BYLINE: By ROBERTA SMITH

 BODY:
Death is one of art's great underlying themes. But in recent years, it has come to the surface with particular frequency; its daunting profile probably looms larger than it has at any other point since the postwar era, when existentialism seemed the only logical reponse to a Europe that lay in ruins.
This is understandable. On one hand, the re-emergence of the figure, first in painting in the early 1980's, then in sculpture and installation art, has opened the floodgate to such overtly grand subjects as history, sexuality, the body and memory, as well as death. On the other hand, the hard facts of contemporary existence -- from political strife, economic instability and urban violence to the AIDS epidemic -- often seem more intractable than ever before. They have turned artists working in all styles, not just figurative ones, toward darker subjects. 
 Against this backdrop, the New Museum of Contemporary Art in SoHo has mounted "The Interrupted Life," a multi-media rumination on death that alternates between the profound and the superficial, the multi-cultural and the fashionably slick, thanks, in part, to an exhibition design by Massimo Vignelli. With dark gray walls and a preponderance of photographs of the dead creating a nearly sepulchral mood, this show can make you confront your own mortality at certain points; at others, it can leave you feeling emotionally manipulated and a bit numb. Death brings out some artists' strengths; for others, it is simply a monumental facade to hide behind.
The show has been organized by France Morin, the museum's chief curator, and it has some nice curatorial touches. For example, it robustly mixes its various media, which include photography, sculpture, video and installation, rather than ghetto izing videotapes in a separate area. This creates a sometimes infernal amount of noise when contemplative silence would be more welcome, but it also gives every kind of art a piece of center stage.
More important, in true New Museum style, the show evinces a particularly effective juxtapositioning of the little known with the famous among its 40 artists. It includes an impressive new installation by the well-known French Conceptualist Christian Boltanski, whose recent efforts have seemed to be in a bit of a holding pattern. A long narrow space lined on two sides all the way to the museum's high ceilings, with shelves of neatly folded children's clothes, this work creates a much-needed pool of silence in the show and suggests an enormous closet where one might grieve among the belongings of the dead. Present, too, are the requisite works by the cool-handed Andy Warhol, whose frequent evocations of death were based, like most of his art, on newspaper photographs. Here he is represented by a small electric chair painting and a four-image treatment of the widowed Jacqueline Kennedy.
But there is also a moving photo collage by a Chilean artist named Eugenio Dittmore, who has shown very little in this country, and an installation by Mona Hatoum, a London-based artist who has made, out of heating elements, a kind of electric chair whose red lines suggest a circulatory system pulsating in the dark. And beyond the unknown there is the unexpected. Among the inclusions that take the show beyond the strict confines of the art world are two drawings by the French writer Antonin Artaud; a batch of photographs of open caskets by the chronicler of Harlem, James van der Zee, and four vitrines of 19th-century post-mortem photographs of children and babies.
In this manner, the exhibition highlights not just art about death, or works like Genevieve Cadieux's enormous photographs of partly closed eyes that may or may not be about death. It also seeks to emphasize some of the social rituals, attitudes and scientific practices that accompany death. In fact, the more "The Interrupted Life" moves away from the artistic and toward the documentary, the stronger it becomes.
As with the 19th-century post-mortem photographs, some of the most revealing moments are found in photographs that trace the journey of the body after death, images whose quality as art is almost beside the point.
Jeffrey Silverthorne's "Morgue Works, the Woman Who Died in Her Sleep," from 1972-74, shows a beautiful young woman whose lifelike pose is belied by her crudely stitched autopsy incision. Yet this Y-shaped line, crossing her breasts and traveling down her torso, also suggests a kind of low-cut dress. Similarly breathtaking in ways that have nothing to do with art are images by Hans Danuser and Bastienne Schmidt, which show the second life the dead can have as medical cadavers. Meanwhile, Jolie Stahl's straightforward photographs record prisoners of New York City jails at work for 50 cents an hour, burying wood coffins in the city's potter's field.
In several instances, however, artists seem to simply exploit the macabre and freakish, turning death into a handy readymade. Among the worst offenders in this regard are Orshi Drozdik and the team of Gwen Akin and Allan Ludwig, whose large, gloomy photographs feature, respectively, a child's head and a sliced-off face in big jars of Formaldehyde.
These images also underscore that perhaps a bit too much of the work in this show centers on the already dead. The inclusion that especially counters this imbalance is Frederick Wiseman's 1989 film "Near Death," which is being screened continually on a large-screen television near the show's center. A documentary about the intensive-care unit at Beth Israel Hospital in Boston, it relentlessly gropes through the complex thicket of decisions, procedures and emotions that confront patients and their doctors, nurses and family members as death approaches. In this work, death itself, alternately terrifying and mundane, welcome and heartbreaking, is more real than at any other point in this exhibition.

 	 	 		. . .	 	"The Interrupted Life" remains at the New Museum of Contemporary Art, 583 Broadway, near Prince Street, through Dec. 29.

GRAPHIC: Photo: "Parfum," by Genevieve Cadieux, at the New Museum of Contemporary Art in SoHo, part of "The Interrupted Life," a multi-media exhibition on death. (Jack Manning/The New York Times)
