HEADLINE: FEDERAL RESERVE TRIMS LOAN COSTS TO SPUR ECONOMY

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13

 BODY:
Faced with a raft of new evidence that the economy is still weak, the Federal Reserve today drove down the interest rates it controls to their lowest points since the 1970's.
Across the country, large banks responded immediately by reducing their prime rate, the benchmark for many mortgages and other consumer and commercial loans. 
 The Federal Reserve cut the discount rate, the rate it charges banks for loans, to 5 percent from 5 1/2 percent, and acted to lower the Federal funds rate, which banks charge one another for loans, to 5 1/4 percent from 5 1/2 percent.
 
Push for Consumption
 Economic policy makers hope that lower rates will lead consumers to borrow and spend more and give the economy the jolt it needs to move cleanly out of recession. New data released today showed a sharp drop in retail sales and only a modest rise in prices in August. [Page 35.]
The Federal Reserve's actions had been so widely anticipated in the financial markets in light of recent economic data that stock prices fell, apparently reflecting the adage that traders buy on rumor and sell on fact. The Dow Jones industrial average closed at 2,985.69, down 22.14 points, or seven-tenths of 1 percent. Bond prices were off slightly. [Page 38.]
 
Action May Not Be Enough
 Many economists said the steps taken today might prove insufficient to stimulate an economy that is having trouble getting past the recession that began in mid-1990. In general, the recession was not nearly so deep as the one in the early 1980's. But the economy barely grew in the year before this latest recession began, and even if, as most economists now believe, the recession is over, the economy is virtually at a standstill.
"I sense a growing anxiety about the strength of this economic recovery," said Norman Robertson, chief economist of Mellon Bank in Pittsburgh. "In many ways, the recovery is indistinguishable from the recession."
Someone familiar with the thinking on the Federal Reserve Board said the central bank acted today in large part because of figures that came out on Thursday showing that the nation's money supply by the most common measurement fell last week. Growth in money this year is now below the Federal Reserve's target range.
In addition, the data on retail sales reinforced the economic weakness recorded in other recent statistics like those on employment, automobile production and housing construction.
And the policy makers apparently felt that the modest rise in consumer prices indicated that inflation was under control. The main argument against reducing rates is that doing so might lead to worse inflation.
 
Timing the Fed's Action
 Another reason the Fed may have moved today is that the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, is going to Moscow next week to discuss economic reform with Soviet leaders, and the discount rate would not have been reduced in his absence.
The Bush Administration, which has been pressing for lower rates to make the economy stronger as the Presidential election year approaches, expressed pleasure. "It's good news," said Marlin Fitzwater, President Bush's spokesman. "I don't think there's any doubt we're coming out of the recession."
Most Democrats were less upbeat. Senator Donald W. Riegle Jr. of Michigan, chairman of the Banking Committee, said that the Federal Reserve's decision was long overdue and that "its strategy of small, slow steps has not worked."
The Federal Reserve Board met early this morning and announced shortly after 9 A.M. that it had voted, 4 to 0, to cut the discount rate to 5 percent, the lowest rate since February 1973. One Federal Reserve governor, Edward W. Kelley Jr., did not vote because he was out of the country, and two seats on the seven-seat board are vacant.
 
Large Purchases of Securities
 Later in the morning, the Federal Reserve bought large quantities of Government securities to indicate that it wanted to reduce the Federal funds rate to 5 1/4 percent, the lowest since 1977.
No sooner had the discount rate cut been announced than the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company in New York, the nation's fourth-largest bank, announced that it was reducing its prime rate to 8 percent from 8 1/2 percent. Other banks quickly followed suit. This means that interest rates may fall soon on mortgages, auto loans and other consumer borrowing, even though they have been slow to do so up to now.
The spread between the rates the Federal Reserve controls and the prime rate is unusually large, as it has been for a few years. This shows that banks are reluctant to lend money and are wary about taking risks in light of the many bad loans made in the 1980's.
 
Spread Between the Rates
 In the spring of 1987, the last time the prime rate was as low as 8 percent, the Federal funds rate was 6 1/4 percent and the discount rate 5 1/2 percent. In 1973, when the discount rate was last at 5 percent, the prime rate was 6 percent.
This was the third time this year the discount rate has been cut and the sixth time the Federal funds rate has been reduced. The Federal Reserve has been steadily driving rates down since 1989, when the Federal funds rate was nearly 10 percent and the discount rate 7 percent. The prime rate reached 11 1/2 percent in early 1989.
The Federal Reserve Board issued this official statement this morning: "Action was taken in light of weakness in the money and credit aggregates, the improving inflation environment and concerns about the ongoing strength of the economic expansion. The reduction, in part, realigns the discount rate with market interest rates."
 
Concern About Money Supply
 Mr. Greenspan has told Congress that he is extremely concerned about the slow growth in money supply. The only way the money supply will rise is if banks lend more money.
The Federal Reserve's target for growth in M-2, which is primarily cash, checking, savings and money market accounts and small certificates of deposit and is the most common gauge of the money supply, is 2.5 percent to 6.5 percent for the year. Growth is running below that range now. Last week, M-2 fell by $9.7 billion.
Michael J. Boskin, chairman of President Bush's Council of Economic Advisers, said he was especially pleased by the Federal Reserve's action today because it indicated a desire to move the money supply into the middle of the target range.
Some economists believe the Federal Reserve is placing too much emphasis on M-2. For example, Albert M. Wojnilower, a senior economist at First Boston Corporation in New York, said that it was an unreliable figure and that he was disappointed the central bank cited it in its official statement about the rate cut.
 
Embarrassing to the Fed
 But other economists said the inability of Mr. Greenspan and his colleagues to keep the money supply within such a large range was embarrassing.
What worries some experts is that the Federal Reserve may not be able to reinvigorate the economy singlehanded, and there are no other arrows in the quiver.
An expected budget deficit of well over $300 billion next year means that Federal taxes are not likely to be cut or spending increased, normal steps when the economy is weak. State and local governments, which must operate on balanced budgets, are doing exactly the opposite, raising taxes and cutting spending, a drag on the recovery.
"The open question is whether what happened today is too little, too late," said Robert H. Chandross, chief economist at Lloyds Bank in New York. "We just don't know the answer yet."

HEADLINE: Dow Off 22.14 on Signs of Weak Economy

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Despite a cut in the discount rate by the Federal Reserve, stocks closed lower yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average down 22.14, to 2,985.69. For the week, the Dow lost 25.94 points.
The rate cut by the Fed came after statistics were released showing that the rise in the Consumer Price Index in August was less than had been expected and that retail sales had dropped last month. 
 "It was an orderly decline -- there wasn't any tremendous selling conviction," said Eugene Peroni, chief technical analyst at Janney Montgomery Scott. "Many investors are sidelined right now and waiting to see how corporate earnings hold up."
The New York Stock Exhange composite index was down 1.84, to 210.58. Volume on the Big Board was 168 million shares.
The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks was down 3.75, to 383.59. Over-the-counter trading was brisk, with the Nasdaq composite down 4.42, to 516.71.
Blue-chip stocks fell in the morning but had regained some of their losses by afternoon. The realization that the cut in the discount rate is a sign of an economy that is still weak caused many investors to refrain from buying, analysts said.
Peter G. Grennan, senior vice president and head of stock index futures trading at Shearson Lehman, said the market had factored in the rate cut before it came.
"Investors are more concerned with corporate earnings than rates, and in the long term this will be bullish for stocks," he said. "Between now and Thanksgiving investors may want to buy into stocks that are pulling back in price. Strategically, you want to buy groups and stocks that may do well in 1992, and ignore short-term gyrations."
There was action in the securities of Dow Chemical, which announced on Thursday that it would make payments on its outstanding contigent value rights on Sept. 30. Dow issued the rights in December 1989 as a deferred payment when its pharmaceutical unit merged with 67 percent of Marion Laboratories. The value rights stock rose 4 7/8, to 11, while Dow Chemical rose 1/8, to 51 5/8.
Shares of the combined company, Marion Merrell Dow, plunged 8 1/4, to 29 3/4, after the decision to redeem the rights dashed speculation that Dow Chemical would buy the remainder of Marion Merrell, traders noted. Marion Merrell shares were among the most actively traded yesterday.
Largely as a result of the Dow value rights stock, analysts said, the American Stock Exchange was the only composite index that was up, rising 1.12, to 367.34.
Technology stocks were weak, led by Intel, a computer manufacturer, which said it expected third-quarter earnings to drop below analysts' estimates of about $1 a share because of weak demand and soft prices for chips and systems. Intel shares were down 6 3/4, to 43. Other computer companies seemed affected by Intel's news and by anxiety about third-quarter earnings: I.B.M. was down 1 1/8, to 102 7/8; Apple Computer was down 2, to 48 5/8, and Compaq Computer fell 1/2, to 33 7/8.

HEADLINE: THE SOVIET TRANSITION;
Accord Seen as Unlikely to End Afghan War

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13

 BODY:
The agreement to end American and Soviet military support for combatants in Afghanistan's civil war could hasten the fall of the nation's Soviet-backed Government, but it is unlikely to end the war itself, Government and private experts on the conflict said today.
For Washington and Moscow, those experts said, the long-anticipated agreement to wind up their proxy guerrilla conflict is but a footnote to the cold war. Although the Afghan war was said to be the Central Intelligence Agency's single largest operation, Congress had signaled the White House that this fiscal year was the last in which the war would be financed, officials said today. 
 Congress made modest cuts last year in the C.I.A. Afghan program, which cost $260 million a year at its peak, said one official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. The Soviet Union had poured hundreds of millions of dollars in arms into Afghanistan since its military left the country in 1989, but its shipments, too, had declined in recent months.
Regardless, those experts said that the war would drag on, either with other sponsors or as an internal feud among the fundamentalist Muslim groups who are fighting the central Government with American help.
Some 1.5 million people have died and 5 million more have become refugees in the 12-year conflict.
 
Other Aid Likely to Continue
 Pakistan, Saudi Arabia, China and Iran all have aided the Muslim rebels and are likely to continue to do so, several experts said in interviews today.
The central Government, installed by the Soviets when they intervened in 1979 and currently led by President Najibullah, has relied on Moscow for military support. But it also has large stockpiles of weapons and may appeal to other friendly nations, like India and North Korea, for new assistance.
"I think that India is Najibullah's last best hope," Representative Charles Wilson, a Texas Democrat who has been an ardent supporter of the C.I.A.'s Afghan operations, said in a telephone interview today.
"The best thing that can happen is that he will leave," Mr. Wilson said. "The worst, which is possible, is that he will become just another warlord" in a country whose rural areas are already carved into tribal fiefdoms.
Mr. Najibullah's economic and political fortunes have declined in recent months, and it is unclear how long he can survive without Soviet aid, which is set to end on Dec. 31.
Representative Wilson and an American intelligence official who spoke on condition of anonymity predicted today that he would be overthrown or would flee by year's end.
Other more cautious experts noted that United States analysts also predicted Mr. Najibullah's quick downfall in February 1989, when the last Soviet soldier left Afghanistan after 10 years of military occuption. Instead, both Mr. Najibullah and his military proved more popular and more resilient than many outsiders had believed.

HEADLINE: Fund Denies Salomon Tie In Scandal

BYLINE: By KURT EICHENWALD

 BODY:
The Tiger Management Company, in its first public comments on the firm's business with Salomon Brothers, said yesterday that it had no knowledge that Salomon had used its name fraudulently in a Treasury auction until months later. It added that it had engaged in no wrongdoing.
Tiger's role has been under scrutiny because Salomon said in a statement to Congress that it had submitted a $2 billion bid for Tiger at the May auction of two-year notes, although Tiger had authorized a bid of only $1.5 billion. 
 In denying its involvement in any illegal activities, the investment fund provided numerous new details about its relationship with Salomon and with Paul W. Mozer, the former head of Salomon's Government securities desk, who is at the center of numerous investigations.
The Salomon scandal has put an uncomfortable spotlight on Tiger, a hedge fund headed by Julian H. Robertson Jr. Since its founding in 1980 by Mr. Robertson and a partner, Tiger has quietly built itself into an influential force in the market.
Following Mr. Robertson's style of making quick and decisive investment decisions based on fundamental analysis of each security, Tiger has won respect on Wall Street, developing close relationships with some of the biggest investment houses, particularly Morgan Stanley & Company. Tiger was one of two large investors that purchased more than $1 billion of securities through Salomon in the May auction. The Government is investigating whether Salomon colluded with other investors to squeeze the market.
Salomon purchased for itself and its largest customers, Tiger and the Quantum Fund, a financial vehicle run by George Soros, $10.6 billion of the $12.25 billion auction.
In its statement, Tiger said its purchases through Salomon involved no improper activities, and that it had not engaged in any collusion or effort to corner the market. "The evidence shows that in connection with its trading of two-year notes, Tiger at all times adhered to the letter and spirit of every applicable law and regulation," the statement said.
The firm also said that it had begun cooperating early and voluntarily with the Justice Department, the Federal Bureau of Investigation, the United States Attorney in Manhattan, the Treasury Department and the Securities and Exchange Commission. Executives with the firm have provided testimony and documents for the investigations.
 
Discrepancy Noted
 In testimony before Congress, Richard C. Breeden, chairman of the S.E.C., said that in July or August, a customer told investigators examining the May auction that there was a discrepancy between the amount listed on the bid sheets submitted to the Government and the amount of notes they had purchased. Tiger's name was not mentioned, but it was the only large customer whose name was used without authorization to buy securities in the May auction.
Tiger said it had decided to invest in Treasury notes after receiving investment advice from Lehrman Bell Mueller Cannon Inc., an economic consulting firm. In May, the fund purchased $800 million in two-year notes that had been auctioned in April in the secondary market through Morgan Stanley.
After the purchase, on May 16, Morgan Stanley told Tiger that it would not be able to finance a Tiger position in the two-year notes in excess of $2 billion for what were described as internal accounting reasons.
As a result of the decision, Tiger turned to Salomon as the largest primary dealer in the country and also because a trader at Tiger knew a Salomon trader, the firm said.
In a telephone conference on May 16, Salomon told Tiger that it was better to buy Treasury securities at auction than in the secondary market, in part because of what was described as greater liquidity in the auction market.
As a result of the conversation, a dinner meeting was set for May 20, two days before the auction. That meeting has been the subject of Government scrutiny because of concern that Mr. Mozer improperly provided proprietary information to the fund, or persuaded it to collude with Salomon.
At the dinner meeting, held with Mr. Mozer, another Salomon executive and two Tiger traders at Le Refuge restaurant in Manhattan, Tiger was performing what it described as its own due diligence before investing in the auction. "At that meeting, Salomon Brothers did not identify any of its customers, did not represent that Tiger would receive a special -- as opposed to general -- repurchase interest rate," the statement said.
While not promising such a rate, Mr. Mozer discussed the likelihood that the special rate would be available in related trading subsequent to the auction, a Tiger executive said.
Shortly before the auction on May 22, Tiger telephoned the Government trading desk at Salomon Brothers and placed an order for $1.5 billion of securities. Mr. Mozer subsequently placed an order for $2 billion, and purchased the additional $500 million from Tiger at the auction price. Tiger apparently did not know of the transaction, according to Salomon, because its confirmation slip showed only the $1.5 billion purchase.
Also, Mr. Mozer telephoned Tiger after the auction and told its representatives that the fund had been awarded $1.5 billion in notes in competitive bidding. Tiger then sold the $800 million in two-year notes it held with Morgan Stanley.
On May 30, before the settlement date for the securities and after consulting with Lehrman Bell, Tiger sold its position in two-year notes to Salomon, eliminating the need for financing of the position from the firm.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
The Fed drove down the interest rates it controls to their lowest points since the 1970's, and large banks responded by reducing their prime rate. The Fed cut the discount rate to 5 percent from 5 1/2 percent and acted to lower the Federal funds rate to 5 1/4 percent from 5 1/2 percent. [Page 1.] 
 Retail sales tumbled 0.7 percent in August, the biggest decline since January, when the war kept many shoppers at home, the Commerce Dept. estimated. The results were poorest for the automotive and housing-related sectors. [35.]
In its investigation of B.C.C.I., the Fed is reviewing loans to former Government officials by the Washington bank that B.C.C.I. secretly controlled. [35.]
Consumer prices rose a modest 0.2 percent for the third month in a row in August, the Labor Department said in a report seen as confirmation that inflation is still not a big threat. [46.]
The first '92 cars failed to improve demand in the auto industry, as sales of U.S.-built cars and light trucks fell 15.3 percent. [46.] The '92 cars and trucks are more powerful and offer more consumer conveniences than ever before. Consumer's World. [48.]
 
 Companies
Northwest's talks have ended to take over the Trump Shuttle's operation because Northwest could not reach a labor agreement with the machinists' union. [35.]
Intel's shares plummeted more than $6 after the company said earnings and revenues would not reach expectations. [35.]
Tiger Management said it had no knowledge that Salomon had used its name fraudulently in a Treasury auction until months later. It added that it had engaged in no wrongdoing. [35.]
Regulators agreed to disburse Columbia Savings' $4.76 billion in deposits, closing a chapter in a high-profile savings failure. [37.]
Society Corp. agreed to acquire Ameritrust. The move by the owner of Cleveland's third-largest bank will create an institution with more than $25 billion in assets. [39.]
Groupe Bruxelles Lambert said it might invest in Sabena through a consortium that would include Air France. [37.]
The Stealth bomber, built by Northrop, was dealt another setback when a key Democrat who had supported the program in the Senate warned the Air Force that it was in jeopardy. [1.]
A garage that can convert hundreds of vehicles a month to natural gas has been opened in Staten Island by Metropane. [21.]
 
 International
A Japanese advisory panel rejected the idea of an independent agency to regulate the securities industry. The move followed weeks of Government pledges to clean up the markets. [35.]
 
 Markets
Stocks fell in active trading despite the Fed's rate cut, with the Dow at 2,985.69, off 22.14 for the day and 25.94 for the week. [38.]
Credit markets responded to the rate cuts and weak economic reports by pushing bond prices down slightly. [38.]
Soybean futures prices advanced more than 7 cents a bushel in early dealings, but most of the gain was erased on word that the Agricuture Department was a long way from determining the extent of the Soviets' emergency food needs. [43.] The dollar fell overseas but ended higher in U.S. trading. [43.]

Employees must increasingly take responsibility for planning and financing benefits, particularly retirement. Your Money. [36.]
Golden Valley Microwave has developed a popcorn bag it says has much better "pop volume" and far fewer "unfavorable popping experiences." Patents. [36.]

HEADLINE: THE SOVIET TRANSITION;
U.S. AND SOVIETS TO END ARMS SALES TO AFGHAN RIVALS

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Sept. 13

 BODY:
In yet another move to settle longstanding regional disputes, the United States and the Soviet Union agreed today to stop all arms sales to combatants in Afghanistan to help pave the way for free elections and a final settlement of the Afghan civil war.
After a meeting this morning to tie up the details, the Soviet Foreign Minister, Boris D. Pankin, and Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d read a joint statement declaring their intention to cease all weapons deliveries -- and to encourage all other countries to cease theirs -- by Jan. 1, 1992. In the interim, they agreed not to step up current arms shipments to their respective Afghan allies. 
 And in another sign of the times, Mr. Baker visited K.G.B. headquarters and was told by the new K.G.B. chief that it was time for the two countries to curb their spying on each other.
 
New Arms Cut Discussed
 Mr. Baker also met with Gen. Vladimir Lobov, chief of the General Staff of the Soviet armed forces, and won his agreement to an American proposal to discuss cutting both sides' arsenals of short-range nuclear weapons, the official Tass news agency reported.
The United States and the Soviet Union have been negotiating the agreement to "discontinue weapons deliveries to all Afghan sides" for more than two years. It follows Moscow's announcement last week that it was recognizing the independence of the Baltic states, and its announcements Tuesday that it would pull its military forces out of Cuba and explore a settlement of the long-festering dispute with Japan over four Kurile islands, seized by Moscow from Japan at the end of World War II.
The common denominator of each of these regional issues is that they were major irritants to either Soviet-American or Soviet-Japanese relations, and that as long as they remained so they would be political obstacles to any large-scale economic aid from either Washington or Tokyo to Moscow.
Soviet officials, as they returned today from Tokyo after progress on the Kuriles, said they would like a good-will gesture of up to $15 billion in economic aid from Japan, according to Tass.
What the Soviets are now doing, American officials said, is the foreign policy equivalent of a liquidation sale, jettisoning or moderating long-held foreign policy positions to clear away every political excuse the West might have not to grant Moscow economic assistance. This only became possible as a result of the August revolution, which swept most hard-liners out of the Soviet leadership and dissolved the Communist Party. American officials, uncertain as to how long the central Government under President Mikhail S. Gorbachev will last, have been eager to exploit the Soviet desperation as best, and as quickly, as they can.
"Two weeks ago we had some very contentious items -- I call them old agenda items -- on our agenda with the Soviet Union," Mr. Baker said, with Mr. Pankin standing by his side. "One of those was independence for the Baltic states. That is off the agenda. The Baltic states have their independence. Cuba. A very, very difficult issue, a thorny issue in U.S.-Soviet relations for a long, long time. You heard what President Gorbachev said on that issue. That old agenda item is disappearing from the agenda."
"Afghanistan," continued Mr. Baker, "an issue where the Soviet Union and the United States have been directly in confrontation and at loggerheads for quite some time. This agreement this morning -- something we have sought to work out for the last two years -- has now been worked out, at least in terms of a willingness on the part of both of us to say that no more military supplies are going to be shipped in there after the first of January. This removes three of the most contentious and 'old agenda' items that have impeded and obstructed progress in this relationship, and I just have to tell you we are delighted to see these old agenda items being removed."
The Soviet-American understanding on Afghanistan does not settle the long Afghan civil war. What it does do is disengage the superpowers from that conflict, which might help promote a resolution.
The Soviet Union intervened in Afghanistan in December 1979 to replace an Afghan Government whose loyalty to Moscow was growing shaky. In 1988, in Geneva talks sponsored by the United Nations, the Soviets pressed the United States to agree to a cutoff in all arms supplies by Washington, and by its allies Saudi Arabia and Pakistan, to the anti-Soviet Muslim rebels seeking to oust Moscow's Afghan ally, President Najibullah. This would be in return for a Soviet pullout. Washington refused. The Soviets pulled out anyway, but continued to send arms to support the Najibullah Government.
Since then, the two superpowers, each of which has grown a bit disenchanted with their Afghan allies, have been trying to work out an agreement for a simultaneous arms cutoff, as well as an arrangement for the installation of a transitional government to conduct free elections.
Agreement on these latter issues always foundered on the refusal of Mr. Najibullah to step aside early in the transitional process to assure the rebels that elections would be free and fair. The Muslim rebels have refused to take part in such a transition as long as Mr. Najibullah remains in power.
 
Uncertainty About Combatants
 Neither foreign minister was prepared to say for sure that the rebels or Mr. Najibullah would now be prepared to bridge their differences, or that Saudi Arabia and Pakistan would be certain to join the arms cutoff.
What Mr. Baker and Mr. Pankin essentially agreed upon today was to end their own arms sales, for the United States to encourage its allies to end theirs as well, and to turn over the whole question of a settlement of the Afghan conflict to the United Nations.
In a joint commentary on their joint statement, the Soviets and Americans declared: "It is also expected that other countries involved in the Afghan conflict should follow the U.S.S.R. and the United States in limiting their assistance to Afghanistan to humanitarian assistance only. We expect that our joint steps will facilitate launching an intra-Afghan negotiating process and should lead to a pause followed by a complete cessation of hostilities."
The joint statement said the two sides "reaffirm the need for a political settlement in Afghanistan that insures an independent and non-aligned Afghanistan," adding: "To this end, they pledge to support a democratic and free electoral process that is not subject to manipulation or interference by anyone. They request the United Nations, with the support of the concerned governments, including those of Islamic countries, to work with the Afghans to convene a credible and impartial transition mechanism."
 
Mideast Conference Discussed
 Mr. Baker and Mr. Pankin also said that they had discussed the proposed Middle East peace conference, but that they were not yet in a position to agree on the wording or timing for issuing invitations to that conference, which is tentatively scheduled for October. The main holdup is that Israel and the Palestinians have not agreed upon which Palestinians may attend.
In addition, American officials say, the issue of Israel's request for $10 billion in housing loan guarantees could also threaten the talks if Israel and its backers in the United States Congress do not postpone the request until after the conference convenes.
A senior Administration official said Washington's Arab allies had told President Bush that it could jeopardize Arab participation in the conference if the United States were to grant Israel $10 billion in housing loan guarantees now without a firm promise from Israel that none of this money would be spent in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip.
 
Settlement Freeze Sought
 In addition, the official said, because of its own opposition to Israeli settlement activity and its now-total lack of faith in previous Israeli promises not to spend American funds in the occupied territories, the Bush Administration will also want to insure at a mimimum that there is a freeze on new Israeli settlements in return for any American loan guarantees.
A potentially contentious debate on this issue of freezing settlements lies behind the Administration's desire to postpone the Israeli request and its anxiety that if it is not postponed it could block the peace conference, by alienating either Israel or the Arabs.
After his meeting with Mr. Pankin, Mr. Baker visited the office of the new chairman of the K.G.B., Vadim V. Bakatin, who told his American guest that it was time for both the K.G.B. and the Central Intelligence Agency to reduce their spying on each other's country.
"I think that on a mutual basis we will do that," Mr. Bakatin told Mr. Baker. "In the K.G.B., there is a principle question: Who is our adversary? And now the K.G.B. has lost that adversary. So we have to work a lot in order to acquire a new image where we do not have any enemies at all."
 
'A Fantastic Visit'
 Mr. Bakatin and Mr. Baker both appeared to revel in the idea that a member of the American Cabinet was stopping in for a chat with the Soviet spymaster.
"Your visit is a fantastic visit," Mr. Bakatin said to Mr. Baker.
"Well, you know, Mr. Bakatin," Mr. Baker responded, "I don't think anything could symbolize the changes going on in the Soviet Union today any better than the fact that the Secretary of State of the United States of America is meeting here in K.G.B. headquarters."
Mr. Bakatin, who took over the K.G.B. office after its previous occupant, Vladimir A. Kryuchkov, was implicated in the failed coup, responded, "The K.G.B. has changed, or I'm not fit for the post."
As the reporters left the room, Mr. Bakatin gestured at the Soviet security men escorting them out and told the Secretary of State, as if to reassure him, "These are new soldiers since the coup."

HEADLINE: THE THOMAS HEARINGS;
Thomas to Win High Court Seat, Senators Predict

BYLINE: By NEIL A. LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13

 BODY:
Judge Clarence Thomas ended a week of sometimes contentious questioning before the Senate Judiciary Committee today amid a growing sense among committee members that his confirmation to the Supreme Court seems inevitable.
The subtle but unmistakable movement in favor of his prospects was evident both in the tone of questions posed to him during the hearings and in comments by individual senators outside the Senate Caucus Room. 
 "If the Senate of the United States were to vote today, he would be confirmed," Senator Howell Heflin, Democrat of Alabama, said in an interview.
 
Sensing the Inevitable?
 The questioning of Judge Thomas by Democrats today was suddenly less spirited than it had been, as if committee members had come to realize that he was not going to provide any new or salient issues that could be used against him and that the contest was all but over. [Excerpts, page 6.]
Although his stolid performance confounded and exasperated many committee members, they seemed reluctant to go over the same ground again on abortion and other issues lest they seem to be badgering the nominee.
The behavior of Senator Heflin, whose vote would be crucial to confirmation, showed how momentum was gathering in Judge Thomas's favor.
Earlier in the week, Mr. Heflin suggested he was greatly troubled that Judge Thomas might be tailoring his responses and repudiating his extensive record of speeches and writings to win confirmation. Such a "confirmation conversion," he warned, could raise serious questions about Judge Thomas's integrity.
But in his questions today, Senator Heflin brought Judge Thomas back to comfortable territory, inviting him to talk about how he overcame a childhood of crushing poverty in coastal Georgia and left a Roman Catholic seminary after encountering virulent racial discrimination there. At one point, Mr. Heflin praised Judge Thomas for his sensitivity to the nation's racial problems and history and said, "I think that ought to be brought out in fairness to all parties concerned."
Senator Paul Simon, an Illinois Democrat who said he was still undecided on the nomination, seemed to address Judge Thomas today as if his joining the Supreme Court were a foregone conclusion and this was a last opportunity to offer some advice.
In an interview outside the hearing room, Mr. Simon said many panel members thought Judge Thomas's responses inconsistent and troubling. Nonetheless, he said, "the probability is that he will be approved."
 
Wide Margin Predicted
 Senate staff members said that a close vote was possible in the committee, 8 of whose 14 members are Democrats, but that he would be approved and probably be confirmed by a wide margin in the Senate itself.
Ralph Neas, executive director of the Leadership Conference on Civil Rights, a coalition of advocacy groups that has opposed the nomination, insisted this evening that "there is still a good chance this nominee can be defeated." He said in an interview that Judge Thomas's "repudiation of past statements and stonewalling on many issues has caused significant concern among members of the committee."
The committee did not complete its questioning of Judge Thomas today, and he will return Monday for what the chairman, Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr., a Delaware Democrat, promised would be his final day before the panel. Judge Thomas's supporters on the committee had hoped to have him finish today to heighten the appearance that he had satisfied all concerns.
Committee Republicans tried to limit their questions as part of a strategy to allow Judge Thomas to finish today.
But opponents were heartened that Judge Thomas would have to return. They said that would keep the process alive and give them a chance to persuade some senators to reject the nominee.
After Judge Thomas finishes Monday, the panel will hear from officials of the American Bar Association, which has given the nominee a mixed rating on his fitness to serve on the Supreme Court. The A.B.A.'s committee that evaluates judges split on the nomination, with 12 members saying he was "qualified" and two voting "not qualified." There were no votes for "highly qualified," the highest rating.
The panel will then hear from witnesses for and against the nominee.
In formulating a strategy for Judge Thomas, those in the Bush Administration overseeing the confirmation process said they believed the nominee could only harm his chances by engaging in open-ended debate or discussion with committee members over issues. He was strongly counseled to stay as close as possible to answers that would reveal little of his judicial or political philosophy while emphasizing his personal story of overcoming a childhood of poverty.
They reasoned that committee members could not hold Judge Thomas to a higher standard of disclosure than they did Judge David H. Souter last year. Judge Souter refused to even hint how he felt about Roe v. Wade, the 1973 ruling that first found a constitutional right to abortion. Judge Thomas, a 43-year-old member of the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia, was as resolute as Judge Souter in resisting pleas to divulge his views on abortion.
Senator Biden complained today that Judge Thomas was setting a standard for resisting the committee's questions that was worse than what he called "the Souter standard."
After Democrats persisted in trying to learn Judge Thomas's views on abortion, committee Republicans counterattacked, charging that Democrats were badgering him. Senator Orrin G. Hatch, Republican of Utah, even suggested to reporters that Judge Thomas might be facing stiffer questioning because he was black and Judge Souter was white.
Senator Patrick Leahy, a Vermont Democrat who seemed visibly displeased with Judge Thomas's refusal to respond to many of his questions, said he had not yet decided how to vote.
Senator Dennis DeConcini, Democrat of Arizona, said in a C-SPAN television interview that he thought Judge Thomas's performance before the panel was "very positive for me and very positive for the confirmation."
Focusing on how Judge Thomas was admitted to Yale Law School in 1971, Senator Arlen Specter, Republican of Pennsylvania, engaged Judge Thomas in a sharp colloquy today about his views on affirmative action.
Judge Thomas, an outspoken opponent of most racial preference programs and quotas during his career, was admitted to Yale under a program that considered minority applicants in a pool separate from white applicants, with the goal of having minority members make up 10 percent of the class.
His opponents say he opposes for others the very kinds of preference schemes that have benefited him.
In earlier responses this week, Judge Thomas suggested that the Yale program was merely what conservatives like to call "outreach" efforts, that is, making a special effort to find minority candidates but not giving them any preferential treatment in applying admissions standards. Yet Yale officials have explicitly said that theirs was a preference program.
Senator Specter compared Judge Thomas's admission to Yale to efforts to give black youths a preference, thus creating role models to act as a remedy against future discrimination. Judge Thomas has criticized such an approach.
Judge Thomas replied that he favored affirmative action plans that took into account how an individual might have overcome economic disadvantages. Beneficiaries of such programs, he said, could be white.

SECTION: Section 1; Page 48; Column 1; Style Desk; Consumer's World Page

LENGTH: 1060 words

HEADLINE: Passenger Safety and Power Featured in 1992 Vehicles

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Sept. 13

 BODY:
The 1992 model cars and trucks, which officially go on sale Sept. 26, are more powerful and offer more consumer conveniences than ever before; they are also more technically advanced, particularly in passenger safety.
As usual, the new vehicles are also more expensive than the 1991 models, but rebates are being offered on most of them to help them sell, and many dealers are willing to discount the retail price. 
 The choice of makes and models available has been quite broad for several years. But the number of vehicle types, body styles and models still continues to expand. The new small station wagons offered by the Mitsubishi and Chrysler Corporations are examples; they seem to be hybrids of stations wagons and mini-vans.
Nevertheless, the softer economy is claiming some victims. For the first time in many years the number of vehicle nameplates will drop in 1992 because of the exit of the slow-selling Peugeot and Sterling brands from the United States market. Sales of Porsche, Alfa Romeo and Yugo cars have dropped precipitously.
The American automotive industry, which opposed air-bag regulations for years before surrendering in the late 1980's, is now engaged in a bragging contest among auto makers about which company has produced the greatest number of air-bag-equipped vehicles.
The Ford Motor Company says it has about 1.7 million air-bag-equipped cars on the road; Chrysler claims about 1.8 million. A few car models, the Ford Taurus for example, offer passenger-side air bags as an option; the Acura Legend LS is among the models that include them as standard equipment.
 
More Cars Have Anti-Lock Brakes
 Brian O'Neill, president of the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety, an insurance industry trade group in Arlington, Va., said he foresees "virtually all passenger vehicles and light trucks with air bags for passengers as well as drivers by the 1996 model year."
Anti-lock brakes, which prevent wheels from locking and vehicles from skidding during hard braking on slippery roads, are standard on nearly all luxury models and many more modest cars. They will be standard equipment for 1992 on two-thirds of all brands made by the General Motors Corporation and on all but two of its Chevrolet models.
G.M., the nation's No. 1 auto maker, is introducing a batch of 1992 car and light-truck models either with restyled exteriors or completely redesigned mechanical specifications. In the opinion of many automobile experts, the most important of the lot are the new Cadillac Eldorado coupe and Seville sedan, to which G.M. hopes that even its non-Cadillac customers will aspire. G.M.'s Oldsmobile Achieva, formerly called Calais, Buick Skylark and Pontiac Grand Am compact cars now have more aerodynamic styling. Anti-lock brakes will be standard on all three cars.
The Ford Taurus and Mercury Sable, aimed at the huge market for midsize family sedans and wagons, probably are Ford's most important new offerings. Little has changed mechanically in these cars, and the exterior styling has been altered only slightly in order to retain their look, which so many customers have said they like. The vehicles' interior, however, has been restyled with a new dashboard and different upholstery. Earlier in the year the No. 2 auto maker introduced the aerodynamically restyled Ford Crown Victoria and Mercury Marquis, full-size sedans meant for older customers who prefer more room. Chrysler, which brought out its restyled mini-van earlier this year, has little new for the fall except higher prices. Exceptions are the Eagle Summit and Plymouth Colt Vista small station wagons, which are renamed versions of the Mitsubishi LRV sport wagons.
Chrysler's redesigned four-door utility vehicle, the Jeep Grand Cherokee, will appear in early 1993 and three redesigned midsize models will make their debuts by the following summer.
 
Toyota to Challenge Honda's Accord
 Mitsubishi's new, smaller multipurpose sport wagons are the five-passenger LRV and the seven-passenger Expo. The LRV and Expo are taller than vehicles of comparable length and can be arranged in various seating and cargo configurations.
With the introduction of the redesigned Camry, the Toyota Motor Corporation of Japan has adopted the ambitious goal of displacing the Honda Motor Company's Accord as the No. 1 selling car in the United States. The Camry, now built in Georgetown, Ky., has been enlarged to midsize from compact, placing it in direct competition with Ford Taurus, Chevy Lumina and other midsize cars; the new Camry will feature a more powerful four-cylinder engine; a six-cylinder engine is optional.
The new Honda Civic subcompact and new Honda Prelude sports coupe, both of which are redesigned mechanically and stylistically, have been shown in Frankfurt and Tokyo, but will not be shown in the United States until early October. They are said to be larger and more powerful than their predecessors, but the new Honda Civic also has been made significantly more fuel efficient as a result of Honda's sophisticated engine technology.
Several expensive new luxury car models, among them the S Class by Mercedes-Benz and the Audi 100, are arriving. The price of the new Audi has not been announced, but it is believed it will sell for about $30,000. The most expensive Mercedes, which has not been officially priced, may top $100,000. In the never-ending quest to find unusual features to pamper owners, Audi, a division of Volkswagen A.G. of Germany, is introducing a switch on its 100 sedan that tilts the right rearview mirror downward slightly when the transmission is in reverse so the driver can better see the curb during parallel parking.
 
 
 
CHRYSLER OFFERS CUSTOM CHILD SEAT
 The Chrysler Corporation is trying to lure customers to its mini-vans with newly designed child seats that are integrated into the middle passenger bench and sell as a $200 option for a set of two.
Appropriate for children who weigh 20 to 40 pounds and far less trouble to adjust than the portable variety, Chrysler's child seats will also be offered in its new midsize models next year and the price of the option will be $100 a seat.
Chrysler said about 25 percent of its mini-van customers are ordering the child-seat option; the child seat is also proving popular with rental-car companies that buy the vehicle.

HEADLINE: ON HORSE RACING;
The Woodward's Added Race: Win, Place and a Two-Horse Sideshow

BYLINE: By Joseph Durso

 BODY:
Take a star 3-year-old race horse like Strike the Gold, four months after he won the Kentucky Derby, and run him against the best older horses in the land, and see if he can cut it. Whatever happens, said his trainer, Nick Zito, "You can't duck the big boys."
But Strike the Gold will run only one race tomorrow at Belmont Park when he challenges six older handicap horses in the Woodward Stakes. At least two of the other horses on the track, two of the big boys, will be running two races at the same time, the Woodward and one other. 
 D. Wayne Lukas calls it "the race within the race." It is primarily a private race between two of the seven horses in the Woodward. And it illustrates the crazy economics of sports: Both horses could lose the $500,000 Woodward and its first prize of $300,000, and still win $750,000 as the winner of "the race within the race."
Or, if one of them should win the Woodward, he would collect two prizes, bring home a $1 million paycheck and also take some long strides toward the Eclipse Award for Horse of the Year. Not a bad day at the races.
All this is possible because "the race within the race" is the race for bonus points in the American Championship Racing Series. It is a kind of tournament of 10 races from February through September, each with a purse of $500,000 to $1 million, with points awarded on the basis of the finish. Then, after the 10th and last race in the series, the Woodward, the horse with the most points gets the $750,000 bonus.
As luck would have it, two horses are tied with 40 points apiece. They are Farma Way, trained by Lukas, and Festin, trained by Ron McAnally. They are a pair of senior stars from the West Coast, and they have been the most persistent starters in the series and the most consistent winners. Farma Way, a 4-year-old colt who has already earned more than $2 million, will be starting for the eighth time in the 10 races. He has won twice and run second twice. Festin, 5 years old and starting for the seventh time, also has a pair of firsts and seconds.
So, their race within the race in the Woodward is the tie breaker in the series.
Now, that's what you'd call a subplot. But the question is: How much of a subplot did the series supply in its inaugural season? Does the public know or care who's got the most points? Does any trainer enter his horse in too many of the 10 races, trying for the $8.25 million in purses and bonuses?
After all, Jolie's Halo, another of the regulars, hasn't won a race since March and even suffered from pulmonary bleeding after a suicidal speed duel with Farma Way in the Nassau Handicap in June. Farma Way hasn't won a race since May, and Festin hasn't won one since June.
In fact, tomorrow's favorite at 8 to 5 is In Excess, an Irish-bred 4-year-old colt who has skipped the series since running fourth in the Santa Anita Handicap in March. But he shrewdly took the high road to success by winning New York's handicap triple, the Metropolitan, the Suburban and the Whitney. Now, he is three for three, rested and a prime candidate for Horse of the Year.
"I planned on racing him sparingly," his trainer, Bruce Jackson, said yesterday in the Belmont trustees' room during the draw for post position. "I wanted to be running a fresh horse late in the season."
To which Lukas replied by telephone from his barn at Del Mar in California: "In Excess has avoided the championship series."
To which Happy Alter, the trainer of Jolie's Halo, replied: "You can't dance every dance."
"There are three key elements you need for a horse to dominate this series," Lukas said. "First, he must be an excellent shipper to travel around the country to different tracks every month. Next, he must be very sound to handle a grueling schedule. Third, he must be a horse that holds his weight and takes the punishment."
Did the series work, as conceived by Barry Weisbord, the horse owner and breeder?
It groped for effect. But it did focus attention within the horse world. It created a story line for senior horses, and did it on national TV. It helped fill the dramatic lull between the Triple Crown races in the spring and the Breeders' Cup championships in the fall. It provided a revolving stage for stars like Unbridled, Summer Squall, Marquetry and Best Pal. It brought marquee horses to Arkansas in April and to New Hampshire in July, and it brought Farma Way and Festin to New York in September for their "race within the race."
"But even with two horses head to head," Wayne Lukas said, getting back to basics, "there will be no special strategy in trying to race just against Festin. You still have to try to beat them all."

HEADLINE: Plane Workers Did Not Attach Portion of Tail

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: EAGLE LAKE, Tex., Sept. 13

 BODY:
The night before a Continental Express Commuter plane crashed here on Wednesday, killing all 14 people aboard, workers at the airline's Houston hangar failed to screw on a part of the tail that is now missing from the wreckage, Federal investigators said today.
The investigators from the National Transportation Safety Board said they confirmed their finding by examining the wreckage and by looking at maintenance records that showed mechanics unscrewed part of the plane's tail wing, replaced some of the wing, but failed to refit 43 screws that hold the part in place. 
 The part in question is a flexible section of the tail wing that prevents ice from building up. It forms the leading edge of the tail wing.
 
Torn Free in Flight
 Investigators said it appeared that the piece might have torn free in flight, which would have caused the plane to pitch down, possibly stressing other parts of the aircraft beyond the limits at which the plane could fly safely.
James Kolstad, the chairman of the safety board, said that as part of a routine maintenance operation the screws were removed from the top of the wing's left side and the top and bottom of the right side. The right side of the assembly was replaced, but the left side was not changed.
"The plane went back into service without the screws on top of the left-hand side," he said.
Mr. Kolstad also said today that information from the plane's recording devices suggested that the plane had come apart piece by piece in just a few seconds, while its engines operated normally. The pilots apparently had no indication of trouble until that moment, he said.
This afternoon, the safety board's investigators boarded a chartered helicopter and searched from the air without success for the crucial missing part of the plane.
The bulk of the tail wing was found about 200 yards from where the fuselage and main wings landed in a charred heap. By examining this part of the tail wing, investigators concluded that the missing piece had not been properly screwed on.
A separate team of investigators examined the plane's maintenance records at Continental's hangar in Houston. This team will also interview people who worked on the plane, a Brazilian-made Embraer 120 Brasilia, an official said.
 
No Firm Conclusions
 No firm conclusions have been reached at this stage, the investigators emphasized. But the fact that they are looking into maintenance problems poses troubling prospects for Continental Airlines, the bankrupt parent company of Continental Express.
Art Kent, a Continental spokesman, said tonight that further investigation is needed to determine the cause of the crash. "We want to find out what happened more than anyone," he said. "We want to stress that safety is our No. 1 priority."
Mr. Kolstad said a tape recording of noises from the cockpit showed no conversation by the pilots about the accident. But other noises were recorded, he said.
"All of a sudden there was a loud noise, followed a few seconds later by an even louder noise. That was followed by a series of warning horns and messages," he said, referring to the alarms in the plane's cockpit. "Then there was a loud whooshing noise, followed by the end of the tape."
 
Sharp Downward Pitch
 A separate device that tracks the airplane's motions showed that the nose suddenly pitched sharply downward as the plane dropped suddenly. During this time the plane's engines were operating normally, he said.
Mr. Kolstad refused to speculate about what had happened in these crucial seconds.
It seems possible that the plane's rear tail wing, the horizontal stabilizer, was the first part to break, perhaps when its leading edge tore away.
That rupture, making the first noise heard on the tapes, could have caused the plane to drop suddenly, putting immense stress on the forward wings.
The left wing appears to have folded completely under the plane, which might have been the second loud noise heard on the tape.
That damage, in turn, could have broken fuel lines and started the fire aboard the plane before it crashed.
So far, investigators have devoted most of their attention to the tail. But they have not yet been able to fully examine the left wing, because it is still lying on the ground underneath the right wing. It appears that the plane belly-flopped in a cornfield with the left wing tucked underneath the right one.
David Messing, a spokesman for Continental, said the company's EMB-120's are maintained at several locations, with the main work done at the Houston Intercontinental Airport, where Continental Express has a separate hangar for maintaining its fleet of 101 planes, including 34 Brasilias.
There are 85 employees, including mechanics, inspectors and supervisors, at the hangar, which can accommodate two Brasilias at a time and can handle all routine and nonroutine work on the planes, he said.
Employment at the hangar has been stable, with no recent layoffs during the economic downturn, he said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: James Kolstad, left, chairman of the National Transportation Safety Board, said information from recorders aboard the commuter plane that crashed near Houston suggested it had been torn apart while its engine operated normally. He and others removed recorders Thursday from the wreckage. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Natural Gas As Auto Fuel Gets a Push In New York

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
Everyone has agreed for years that it would be good for New York City's air if cars and trucks were converted to run on natural gas, and cheaper for drivers. But who wants a car that uses a fuel that's hard to get? And who wants to sell fuel for cars hardly anybody drives?
Now there are signs that this self-reinforcing obstacle is ending. 
 On Wednesday, an Ohio company, Metropane Inc., opened a garage in Staten Island that can convert hundreds of vehicles a month from gasoline to natural gas. Gas industry executives say it is the first substantial bet by a private company that a market will develop.
"We just created the chicken," B. Vincent Rodriguez, the chief executive of Metropane, said after cutting the ribbon on a converted warehouse. "Or maybe it's the egg."
The other side of the equation is coming, too. In the next few months, nearly 20 filling stations offering natural gas will open in New York City.
All over the country, people who are striving to create a natural-gas vehicle industry face the same roadblocks, but some think that they will be cleared first in places like New York, which have persistent air pollution problems.
The conversion effort is focusing on fleets of trucks and buses or city-owned cars. But the Staten Island shop will handle just plain anybody's car, taking a day or so to switch them over. Mr. Rodriguez's shop, overlooking the oil storage tanks of Bayonne, N.J., will begin with three employees and about $150,000 in equipment and tools. He is focusing on fleet business, too; so far there are prospects but no contracts, he said.
The new fueling stations are also aimed at fleets, but some of them will be open to the public. The Brooklyn Union Gas Company, which already has fueling stations in Greenpoint and Canarsie in Brooklyn and Flushing, Queens, will announce soon that it will open six more stations this year, and seven more within 18 months, in Brooklyn, Queens and Staten Island. And the Consolidated Edison Company, which sells gas in Manhattan, the Bronx and Westchester, will open a fueling station at a company-owned site in midtown Manhattan by December, said a spokesman.
Utility Oficials see the stations and the shop going hand in hand. Robert B. Catell, president of Brooklyn Union Gas, called Metropane's opening "extremely encouraging."
"This is the first commercial establishment on the East Coast to be completely dedicated to the conversion and maintenance of natural gas vehicles," he said.
Daniel Walden, a spokesman for Con Ed, said "the availability of a fueling facility is really a critical turning point in this whole movement."
"We're not going to have a market," he said, "until there are facilities where people can get fuel conveniently and economically."
Making the stations and the shop economical depends on high volume, which is one reason for the emphasis on fleet conversion. The compressors, pumps that squeeze the fuel into vehicle tanks at pressures up to 3,000 pounds per square inch, cost service stations up to $250,000 apiece.
Brooklyn Union Gas has helped New York City convert almost 150 vehicles. It has also converted two private buses and tried to win over fleet owners.
The utility plans to ask the Public Service Commission, which regulates it, for permission to charge its existing residential, commercial and industrial customers for the cost of building stations for vehicle use, on the theory that the clean air benefits everyone.
Con Edison is also encouraging natural gas, if somewhat less aggressively. Mr. Walden said that the Manhattan station would be used by United Parcel Service trucks, city-owned vehicles, and by Con Ed's own fleet, which includes everything from meter-readers' cars to a truck-mounted crane.
 
Clean Air Act Is Incentive
 Another incentive for conversion is the new, more stringent standards in the Clean Air Act passed last year, which makes the use of some other fuel by many cars seem inevitable.
Brooklyn Union's stations are open to corporate and municipal customers. For now, all the customers are likely to be fleet vehicles, but William V. Federici, a spokesman for Brooklyn Union Gas, said that if a private car owner showed up at a station, "I don't think we could turn you away."
Converting a vehicle at Metropane would cost between $2,500 and $3,500, a sum Mr. Rodriguez said would be recovered through lower operating costs within two years.
While natural gas prices fluctuate, Brooklyn Union's stations now charge about 93 cents for enough gas to take a vehicle as far as a gallon of gasoline would -- a savings of about 30 percent.
Natural gas pumps are turning up in other cities, notably Los Angeles, which has the nation's worst air, and Denver, where carbon monoxide from gasoline and diesel engines is a major problem.
Progress in New York has been slow but measurable. Brooklyn Union Gas, by helping to pay to convert 50 Parks Department vehicles, mostly Bronco jeeps, has turned that agency into an enthusiastic supporter. The utility is negotiating with the Fire Department on conversion of passenger and communications vehicles.
 
United Parcel Tests Vans
 United Parcel Service reports good results from a test with 10 delivery vans based in Canarsie, which were converted in September 1989. The trucks travel an average of 28 to 32 miles a day and are fitted with tanks that will fuel them for 90 miles, said a U.P.S. spokesman, Harry M. Winters. In Manhattan, range will be even less of a problem; many trucks there are driven fewer than 10 miles a day.
U.P.S. will convert more when Con Ed opens for business in Manhattan, but may eventually use an engine designed for natural gas, rather than converted from gasoline use, Mr. Winters said.
All three major domestic car manufacturers have announced plans to build "dedicated" natural gas light utility vehicles, meaning that they will run on natural gas alone. But Metropane believes that the market will still be in conversions, because the variety of cars and trucks built for natural gas will always be limited.
And if the auto makers get serious, said Mr. Rodriguez, they may simply build standard gasoline vehicles minus the fuel tank and fuel injector, and send them to a subcontractor like Metropane for finishing.
Metropane has grand plans. The company has drafted a proposal to convert 4,000 of New York City's 24,000 municipal vehicles to natural gas. Metropane would pay for the conversions, in exchange for the right to sell the city the natural gas to run the vehicles at a price equivalent to what the city would have paid for gasoline. Since natural gas is nearly 50 percent cheaper than gasoline, Metropane would earn back its investment and make a profit, said Gene Rodriguez, who is Vincent's brother and also a Metropane executive. Metropane would also build 50 more refueling stations in New York City, at a total cost of about $30 million. The city would own the refueling stations, and after 4 years, could buy the natural gas at market cost, he said.
In the meantime, Vincent Rodriguez said, he is confident of attracting his first customer soon.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Metropane Inc., an Ohio company, opened a garage on Staten Island that can convert vehicles to run on natural gas. A car that has been converted has the natural-gas tanks in its trunk. (William E. Sauro/The New York Times) (pg. 21)

HEADLINE: After the Voting;
The Votes Are In, but There's Still Room for Doubt in a Quarter of the Races

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK

 BODY:
The results of 9 of the 38 City Council primaries held on Thursday were so close that their final outcomes probably will remain in doubt until Sept. 25, after absentee ballots are tabulated and votes are meticulously recounted.
Even then, several elections may be challenged in court, raising the possibility that judges may order new races in districts where there is evidence of impropriety or fraud. 
 That would provide a fittingly chaotic conclusion to the decade-long process of restructuring the city's government, which began with a legal challenge to the constitutionality of the Board of Estimate.
Some candidates in close races wasted little time making claims about voting irregularities perpetrated by their opponents. Several said they were certain to challenge the results in court.
 
Acting as if They Won
 "There are many irregularities that took place," said Adam Clayton Powell 4th, who trailed William Del Toro by 27 votes in the Eighth District in Upper Manhattan. "We have plenty of witnesses, plenty of evidence. It's a fight, but we're confident we're going to win."
Like many of the second-place finishers in tight races, Mr. Powell waged psychological warfare by assuming the stance of the victor. He spent yesterday afternoon traveling East Harlem in his campaign car, thanking voters through a rooftop loudspeaker.
While recounts and court challenges are unlikely to drastically alter the ethnic or ideological composition of the Council, they could determine which newcomers become power brokers at City Hall and whether two longtime incumbents survive.
In the Second District on Manhattan's Lower East Side, Miriam Friedlander, an 18-year veteran of the Council, was trailing Antonio Pagan by 121 votes. In the 44th District in Brooklyn, Noach Dear, a nine-year veteran, was losing to Robert J. Miller by 16 votes.
 
Splitting Small Baskets of Votes
 The combination of an unusual Thursday election, the absence of a top-of-the-ticket race, a confusing array of newly drawn districts and a recession-driven malaise contributed to extremely low turnout. None of the races generated a turnout of more than 26 percent and nine districts had turnouts of 15 percent or less.
Large fields of opportunistic candidates found themselves splitting small baskets of votes. As a result, nine races were decided by a total of 669 votes. The closest race was in the 31st District in Queens, where unofficial results showed Juanita E. Watkins defeating Malcolm A. Smith by 15 votes.
Naomi R. Bernstein, a spokeswoman for the Board of Elections, said that the nine races with margins of fewer than 170 votes were too close to call.
"I don't ever remember an election that had this many close races," said the Council Speaker, Peter F. Vallone.
 
9-Tenths of 1 Percent
 Although the expansion of the Council to 51 seats from 35 was intended to make city politics more democratic, some of the results suggest that the city's brand of democracy was hardly participatory.
Five Democratic candidates won primaries with fewer than 2,000 votes. One of them, Howard Weiss, won the 10-candidate race in the 19th District in Queens with 1,346 votes, or 17 percent of the ballots cast.
Of the 143,943 people who live in the 19th District, according to the 1990 census, 81 percent are of voting age. Of those, 68,965, or 59 percent of the voting age population, are registered voters. Of those, 37,151, or 54 percent of the registered voters, are enrolled Democrats. Of those, 8,100, or 22 percent of the enrolled Democrats, went to the polls. And of those, 1,346, or 17 percent of the voters, cast ballots for Mr. Weiss.
Thus, Mr. Weiss won the Democratic primary, which is tantamount to election in his Democratic district, by capturing the votes of nine-tenths of 1 percent of his district's residents.
 
Leveling the Playing Field
 "It's certainly something that can remind us that every vote counts," said Representative Thomas J. Manton, who also serves as the Queens County Democratic leader. "It's the one who gets out the votes who wins, and in our plurality system you don't always need a lot of votes to win."
At first glance, the elections seem a successful proving ground for the city's new system of public campaign financing, which was first used in 1989.
Of the 38 leaders, according to the unofficial results, 27 chose to participate in the program. In the 19 races without incumbents, 16 were won by publicly financed candidates.
"There were a couple of races where it really leveled the playing field," Mr. Vallone said.
 
Other Contests in Question
 Under the program, candidates receive public money in proportion to the money they raise privately if they agree to restrictions on their campaign fund raising and spending. Fifteen of the 18 candidates in the hotly contested races, including all of the current leaders, participated in the program.
In addition to the races in the Second District, the Eighth District and the 44th District, the contests that remained in question yesterday included the 14th District in the Bronx, in which former State Senator Israel Ruiz Jr. was leading Sandra Ramos-Alamo by 78 votes, and the 25th District in Queens, where John D. Sabini outpolled Helen Sears by 166 votes.
Also undecided were the 30th District in Queens, in which Pamela L. Fisher led Frank Sansiveri Jr. by 72 votes; the 40th District in Brooklyn, where Carl Andrews was ahead of Una Clarke by 49 votes, and the 48th District in Brooklyn, where Anthony David Weiner was leading Michael J. Garson by 125 votes.
 
Gathering Affidavits
 Based on the observations of their campaign aides, who watched election inspectors record vote totals, many candidates disagreed with the Board of Elections tallies. Several, including Mr. Dear and Mr. Sansiveri, expressed confidence that the Board's recounts would show them ahead.
Other candidates rested their hopes on absentee ballots and the courts. Mr. Smith, who was trailing in the 31st District by 15 votes, said he had already gathered 20 affidavits from voters alleging problems with missing voter-identification cards, early poll closings and broken voting machines.
"We're going to push for another election," he said. "Fifteen is just too close."
Ms. Bernstein, the Board of Elections spokeswoman, did not discount the possibility of tabulation errors. But she said there had been "nothing untoward" about the way the polls were operated. "We feel it's one of the best elections we've had," she said.
Assemblyman Sheldon Silver, who waged an unsuccessful court battle after losing a Council race to Ms. Friedlander almost 20 years ago, warned that the legal test is difficult to pass.
Under precedents now widely accepted by the courts, Mr. Silver said, elections are invalidated only when candidates demonstrate that there are three voting irregularities for every vote that separates the top two contenders. "It's very difficult in a multicandidate race," he said.
