HEADLINE: Jump-Starting Sales for New Housing

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON

 BODY:
ARTHUR COLLINS thought he had the market figured in the summer of 1988 when he started building three-story condominiums in Greenwich, Conn., with flats on the first level and duplexes above.
But the market slump that stunted home sales in the region held some surprises. The flats sold to the empty-nesters they were aimed at, but the stairs in the duplexes frightened off the elderly, while their $600,000 prices put them beyond the means of young families. 
 So Mr. Collins, senior partner in Collins Construction Corporation of Greenwich, did what many developers are reluctantly doing these days: He reconfigured his project. He made the duplexes into one- and two-bedroom flats, installed elevators, cut prices to about $300,000 and started selling.
"It's not an easy thing to have to do, but I wasn't selling anything and so I had to go back to my plans," Mr. Collins said. "By the end of the day this will be a $100 million project, and with that much money at stake I don't have the luxury I might have on a smaller project of just sitting back and waiting. There is too much money out there; it was just eating us alive, and we couldn't afford to wait."
All builders of multiphase developments fine-tune their offerings to some extent. They adjust the mix of housing from phase to phase, tinker with their pricing to capture the biggest profit without losing sales, and play around with building configurations within their property boundaries to keep ahead of public tastes and of the competition.
What is new among many of today's developers is the complete break with earlier phases -- building flats instead of duplexes, as Mr. Collins did, or shifting from town houses to detached housing in an effort to jump-start sales in a stagnant housing market.
Such mid-project changes are apparently governed by two universal rules these days: Move away from the expensive to the more affordable, and from attached to detached housing. In the soft real-estate market that followed the boom of the mid-80's, big expensive houses have lost the greatest share of market value overall, real-estate brokers and builders say. This segment depended heavily on move-up buyers and empty-nesters transferring their equity from existing homes to new ones. Now, unable to sell their current high-priced homes, these people are staying away from high-priced new developments.
Another factor is that the condominium town-house market, already heavily overbuilt, is not as attractive to young families with children, who want small, detached homes with private yards.
These are the buyers who dominate today's market. They are the couples, as Patrick O'Keefe, head of the New Jersey Builders Association, put it, who doubled up with the in-laws during the recent cycle of overheated prices, saving their money for a down payment, and who are now ready to buy a modestly priced one-family house.
BUT moving down in price is hard for builders to do, and the difficulties explain why downsizing a development is a last-ditch maneuver, taken only when financial pressures preclude simply letting an unfinished project wait until the market improves.
Changing a project design means having to work the new plans through all the layers of government that stand between builders and their goals, the zoning and planning board, the board of architectural review, the town council.
And the economics of downsizing are tricky. This is because the price of land already bought or contracted for is fixed, and land bought at the rate of $60,000 a unit, a typical price during the boom, is hard to fit under a downsized home aimed at the $160,000 market.
"Some land is just so expensive that you can't just go out and build 125 town houses on land that was priced for expensive single-family homes," said Jay Shackford, a spokesman for the National Association of Home Builders, in Washington. "If the lot costs $100,000, the price of the unit has to be considerably more than that to make it work. Land costs now account for as much as 35 percent of the sale price of a home, and lenders are wary of lending to projects where the land costs more than that."
Richard Mohring Sr. got around the problem of overpriced land by buying a bankrupt project called Longtree Pond, in Eastport, L.I., from the foreclosing bank. While the previous developer was building $375,000 houses on lots he had bought for $100,000 each, Mr. Mohring and his son, Richard Jr., are building $160,000 houses on foreclosure-devalued lots for which they paid the bank $60,000 each.
Although the Mohrings have finessed the financial ramifications of downsizing a project, they have run smack into the psychological problems of putting affordable housing next to the expensive houses built in an earlier phase. His firm, Mohring Enterprises of Sea Cliff, L.I., is being sued by some of the owners of the eight original, $375,000 houses at Longtree Pond for bringing down housing values in the development.
"They think I'm bringing down the market," Mr. Mohring complained. "What people won't accept is that the buyers set the price that they are willing to pay. The competition is fierce, and people will say, 'Well, you want $150,000 and down the road they're selling for $147,000,' you have to say, 'O.K., you got it for one forty-seven.' Either you do that, or you just go deeper in debt with the bank."
If the first buyers in downsized developments complain, there are some obvious opportunities for those who buy after the changes are made.
PRICES in downsized developments are tens of thousands of dollars less per home than in the project's early incarnation. The houses are likely to be smaller and so have lower taxes, and they are likely to be a type of house that builders believe is the product line of the 1990's, the small detached one-family home on a small lot.
So George Davon, the builder of a 123-unit mix of town houses and detached single-family homes in New Milford, Conn., called Sullivan Farm, is planning to shift next spring entirely to detached houses costing $185,000 to $265,000.
"There is far less competition in the modestly priced free-standing homes than in town houses," Mr. Davon said, "so that is what we will be focusing on."
For Mr. Collins, whose project is called Old Greenwich Gables, the shift in marketing strategy since the boom of the mid-80's has been to capture some of the house-hungry young families who are in the market to buy.
Originally, Old Greenwich Gables consisted of three-story structures with a first-floor, one-bedroom flat and a three-bedroom duplex above. The project is being built atop a raised 50- by-400-foot concrete slab left over from the old Electrolux vacuum cleaner plant at the site, a structure that provides for a vast grade-level parking and storage area for owners.
The flats sold well between $250,000 and $300,000, Mr. Collins said, but the duplexes, intended to be the stars of the project, went nowhere at $500,000 to $600,000.
"Two things happened after we changed to flats," Mr. Collins noted. "The pricing went down because the square footage declined, and where we were having difficulty attracting older people to the duplexes, we have them all on one floor in the flats."
Now, each cluster of 12 units is served by an elevator from the garage level to the top flats, thus overcoming the concern among older buyers about having to climb stairs.
For a 900-square-foot condominium with one bedroom or one bedroom and a den, the prices are $200,000 to $300,000. Fifteen units in the new configuration have been built since the spring, and half have already been sold.
But it was not easy. Although Mr. Collins was able to cover his land costs at Old Greenwich Gables, it took him almost a year to get the changes approved by the Greenwich authorites. What made it possible at all, he said, was his keeping the redesigned development within the limits of about 300 bedrooms and 300,000 square feet of space set in the original approval.
INCREASING density by adding more units to help cover the cost of expensive land, Mr. Collins and other developers said, would be all but impossible, because sentiment against growth -- and more traffic, more children to educate, more municipal services to provide -- is so strong that local regulators, having already approved one level of growth, are unlikely to look kindly on approving an even higher one.
New Jersey's Municipal Land Use Law has even institutionalized a bias against letting builders return to the planning table for more density at an already approved project. It requires five votes out of the seven on local planning boards to increase the density of an already approved project.
It was not a step Mr. Collins took lightly, therefore, and one he avoided altogether at other developments, where he has simply stopped construction.
"Greenwich is a special place, and if you have the right product, it will sell," he said. "At other projects where I could have redesigned, I just stopped building. It would be silly to do anything with them. The market just had no depth or strength at all, and I didn't see any future for them for several years."
In some cases, regulatory concern makes changing a project design impossible. New York, New Jersey and Connecticut have been expanding the buffer zones around wetlands in recent years, for example, while allowing construction to continue at projects approved under earlier, less-stringent rules.
Several developers said in interviews that they would lose their grandfathered wetlands permits if they sought to modify their projects.
"It's easier just to wait," said William Becker, head of the Becker Organization of Teaneck, N.J., a prominent development consultant.
MR. BECKER advises his clients to avoid the need for making planning and design U-turns in mid-project by anticipating shifts in the market, and building enough flexibility into planning phases to meet them. To provide this flexibility, he plots out new developments with the care of a supermarket designer putting the milk on the back wall and the candy at the check-out counter.
"Say you got a 300-unit community," he said. "The first thing you learn in today's market is that you can't open a multi-phase community with only one product. You have to give people a choice, say, single-family and garden condos, and you hold your town houses for later, to create new interest."
Mr. Becker tells his clients to open a new project with the worst location first.
"You always have the power line going through the first phase," he said, "because you know you're not going to sell those units for as much as the ones up by the lake or near the front entrance."
So by putting the first units at the worst location, the builder captures the appreciated value of the remaining space that comes with having opened a new development.
Along with having to change a line of housing that is selling too slowly, Mr. Becker said, builders sometimes have to redesign a project that is too popular with buyers.
"There's such a thing as selling too fast," he said. "It means that the people you are attracting have more income than they are using, and they see your development as too good a value to pass up."
In those happy cases, developers should upscale, Mr. Becker said, advising builders to put in more options, perhaps an extra bedroom, and raise prices -- and profits -- accordingly.

HEADLINE: MR. SOFTWARE

 BODY:
The personal computer industry will innovate faster and produce more wealth for society if Microsoft chairman Bill Gates sets the pace and his competitors respond to his moves rather than try to deprive Microsoft of its leading position through lawsuits or other means.
Apple Computers, for example, sued Microsoft because Microsoft's Windows provides cheap software emulations of Apple's high-priced Macintosh line. Apple would like to continue making money by selling old technology at high prices in small volumes. I.B.M. has traditionally followed the same strategy. 
 A century ago, the telephone industry was faced with a similar choice: Should it sell telephones cheaply in very large volumes and maximize the total wealth created for the country? Or should it keep margins high and sell relatively few telephones? The Bell System followed the second option for 20 years, and the development of the telphone system in the United States was held back for half a generation.
Microsoft's competitors today are trying to shift the microcomputer industry onto the same high-margin, low-volume, slower-diffusion track. We will all be poorer -- except for Apple and I.B.M. shareholders -- if they succeed.
 
J. BRADFORD DE LONG
Professor of Economics, Harvard University
Cambridge, Mass.

HEADLINE: Westchester Wetlands At Stake in Debate

BYLINE: States News Service

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
DEVELOPERS and environmentalists in Westchester County are carefully watching a battle in Washington about which environmentally sensitive areas should be protected as wetlands and which should be opened to construction.
The Bush Administration has initiated a proposal to limit what is defined as a wetland -- typically marshes, bogs and swamps that serve as homes for plants and animals and filters for pollution. 
 Congress also wants to loosen some wetlands conservation rules, which in the last two years have been expanded by the United States Environmental Protection Agency to include forests and fallow fields that are dry most of the year. Lawmakers are under fire from industries, home builders and farmers who complain that current laws often don't make sense.
 
How Fallow Land Functions
 Freshwater wetlands are threaded throughout Westchester, and most of the county's undeveloped land serves important wetlands functions, said Laura Tessier, program administrator for the Soil and Water Conservation District in Westchester. Her office reviews environmental-impact statements given to the county by developers who want to build on land designated as wetlands.
What is going on in Washington "is the most outrageous thing to happen in wetlands protection in 20 years," Ms. Tessier said.
But Robert Szabo, executive director of the National Wetlands Coalition, agreed that the process may be painful but stressed that wetlands regulations were adopted in 1989 without public notification.
Mr. Szabo, who represents a group of large industries lobbying for change in the wetlands definition, said the environmentalists now must accept the public pressure to scale back regulations.
"That's America," Mr. Szabo said. "We have to have this debate."
 
Counting the Wet Days
 The Administration hasproposed extending the number of days the soil must be wet each year to qualify as wetlands under E.P.A. rules.
The ground would need to be covered with water for 15 consecutive days or saturated to the surface for at least three weeks to meet the proposed guidelines. The current law requires saturation for only seven consecutive days a year. The new guidelines are under public review and are about six months away from approval, according to the E.P.A.
Environmentalists estimate that the E.P.A.'s new definition by itself would trim the current stock of wetlands to 66 million acres nationwide, from 100 million acres.
In Westchester, no one knows how many acres would lose the designation; the county land that meets the current Federal definition has not been identified. The New York Department of Environmental Conservation has mapped nearly 6,500 acres of freshwater wetlands in Westchester, but Ms. Tessier said that is only a fraction of what exists in the county.
 
Four Bills in Congress
 Congress is considering its own alterations to wetlands regulations. Four bills to regulate wetlands are pending, but the one gaining widest acceptance is the proposed comprehensive wetlands conservation and management act.
The bill, proposed jointly by two Louisiana Democrats, Representative Jimmy Hayes and Senator John B.Breaux, has attracted 168 signatures of support from House members and 24 in the Senate. Hearings are scheduled for next month.
The legislation would categorize wetlands so that only the most valuable marshes and bogs would be left untouched. The bill would also prevent classifying land as too valuable to disturb unless the owner has been compensated by the Federal Government for losing the use of it. At present, no compensation is offered.
Westchester lawmakers are divided on the issue.
Representative Nita M. Lowey, Democrat of Harrison, said she sees the need to streamline the wetlands regulation process and to exclude land that is not environmentally sensitive from the rules.
 
But With a Caveat
 But she said she was worried that loosening the regulations would mean destruction of valuable habitat. And the compensation requirement in the wetlands bill proposed by Mr. Hayes and Mr. Breaux "would be a tremendous cost," she said.
"I don't think protecting wetlands and encouraging economic growth are incompatible," Mrs. Lowey said. "I think everyone realizes there's going to have to be compromise."
Representative Benjamin Gilman, Republican of Middletown, is supporting the proposed wetlands reform bill, said Todd Burger, grants and projects director for Mr. Gilman.
Mr. Gilman heard dozens of complaints from farmers and developers who could not use their land or were stopped in the middle of projects by Federal officials because the soil stayed wet longer than a week, Mr. Burger said. Yet they had been told by the state and local officials that the land was not wetlands.
The Congressman thought the regulations "should be much more uniform," he said.
Representative Hamilton Fish Jr., Republican of Millbrook, has not made up his mind on the issue, his staff members said.
 
The Differing Reactions
 The proposals have generally been criticized by environmental groups and praised by many landowners and developers.
Congress "is making it impossible to protect all but an insignificant portion of what we need to protect," Ms. Tessier said.
More than wildlife and vegetation are at stake, she said. Wetlands help filter out the pesticides that flow off lawns, the gasoline running off streets and other suburban and industrial pollutants common in Westchester, she said.
But turning down a business that wants to move to Westchester just to protect a field or small patch of woods hurts the economy, said Harold Vogt, president of the Westchester County Chamber of Commerce.
"The environment is the excuse for nongrowth advocates," he said.
 
An Issue With Post Office
 Wetlands, for example, are the issue now blocking plans by the United States Postal Service to build a regional mail-sorting plant next to the Westchester County Airport in Harrison. The Postal Service was taken to court by residents who objected to developing the land there because it is adjacent to a reservoir watershed.
To salvage the $10 million it has already spent on planning, the Postal Service is preparing a lengthy environmental-impact statement to support its contention that the new plant will not contribute to water pollution, said Raymond Murphy, field division general manager for the service. An environmental-impact study is also planned for a second possible site.
But meanwhile, plans to spend $90 million to build the mail-sorting plant are on hold indefinitely, Mr. Murphy said. "This is not any different than any business coming to Westchester" would experience, he added. "Everybody goes through this."
Three Levels of Protection
Although there is no firm figure on the total acreage in Westchester, the county's wetlands are protected by more than just the Federal and state programs. About 70 percent of Westchester's towns and villages protect wetlands, and even New York City extends its control into watershed lands in the county.
The state and local programs generally are not as stringent, however, as the Federal one, many officials agreed. And loosening Federal restrictions will put state and local laws at risk, some environmentalists suggested.

HEADLINE: WESTCHESTER GUIDE

BYLINE: By Eleanor Charles

 BODY:

CIVIL WAR SECRETS
A secret Civil War military installation comparable to Alamagordo of World War II fame, now buried under more than a century's worth of debris, is the subject of a talk by Dr. Joel Grossman, Saturday at 8 P.M. The lecture is sponsored by the Putnam County Historical Society in Cold Spring. 
 Dr. Grossman, the head of Grossman Associates of Manhattan, historical archeologists, and his colleagues spent the last three years excavating and recording computer images of the R. P. Parrott gun-testing site of the West Point Foundry in Cold Spring. There, in a 700-by-1,500-foot building constructed in 1818, scientists from the United States and Europe lived during the 1860's while they developed the high-powered, long-distance rifled cannon, which is largely credited with winning the war for the Union.
Dr. Grossman said the current project is "part of a major effort by the Federal Environmental Protection Agency to identify, define and document significant archeological resources that might be eligible for the National Register of Historic Places." The excavation is taking place before the E.P.A. proceeds with Superfund cleanup efforts. The Cold Spring site, which is already on the National Register of Historic Places, is contaminated with cadmium and other heavy metals dumped there by the foundry.
The foundry is no longer there, and the testing site, which is in a valley, was built on in the early 1900's. The industrial buildings that were constructed there were later destroyed by fire. Changes in the water table near the area placed part of the Parrott site underwater, and excavators had to work under pneumatic domes. The ground had to be thawed during the winter months with 600,000 BTU heaters, and so-called rubber ducky suits had to be worn for protection from hazardous substances.
Almost none of the artifacts will be brought to the surface. "It is not the Government's purpose to dig things up, possibly destroying them in the process," said Dr. Grossman, "but to provide enough definition to reproduce them if necessary and to create a public record through advanced camera and computer technology." Remote sensing machines that "see" below the surface and underground maps pinpointed the site for the purpose of taking magnetic pictures.
The lecture will be given at the Foundry School Museum of the society at 63 Chestnut Street. Admission is free. Call 265-4010 for more information.
 
TALL TALES
 If your summer fish stories are not getting the reception they deserve, try them out at Trout Unlimited's September meeting this week. There will be no invited speaker. Instead, members and guests will have the evening free to regale each other with tales of fabulous lures, flies tied just right and fish eligible for the record books. There will also be fly-tying demonstrations, a fly-tying clinic and a discussion of fly patterns that work and those that fail.
The meeting is scheduled Tuesday at 7:30 P.M. in the Fox Lane Middle School, on Route 172 in Mount Kisco. There is no admission charge. For more information about the meeting or about Trout Unlimited, a national, nonprofit ecological organization, call 666-5727.
 
'ART OF MOVEMENT'
 George Rickey is a leading practitioner of sculpture that moves. Thirty of his stainless steel constructions go on display at the Katonah Museum of Art today through Nov. 3. Some were created recently; others have been lent from private and public collections worldwide.
"George Rickey: The Art of Movement," as the show is called, includes models for other larger sculptures, an indoor installation and outdoor works displayed in a tree-lined grove. Their parts do not collide, vibrate or bounce. They can be activated by a touch of the finger or by a breeze, but they can also withstand hurricane-force winds. A video presentation shows the artist at work in his studio, and a visit to his workshop will be conducted by Jill Snyder, the show's curator, on Oct. 5.
The museum, on Route 22 in Katonah, is open free of charge Tuesdays through Fridays, Sundays from 1 to 5 P.M. and Saturdays from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. For more information about the exhibition or the day trip to Mr. Rickey's studio, call 232-9555.
 
PLANTS AND HEALING
 Dr. James A. Duke is an economic botanist with the United States Department of Agriculture in Beltsville, Md. He has a recipe for Oncophobic Onion Soup, which he will share with the audience at a symposium called "Plants for Health and Healing: Their Role in Modern Medicine," to be held Saturday from 8:30 A.M. to 4:30 P.M. at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx. Disease-fighting elements in foods that may prevent osteoporosis and heart attacks and reduce the incidence of breast cancer are the focus of his talk, titled "Food Farmacy."
Dr. Douglas C. Daly, of the Botanical Garden's Institute of Economic Botany, will talk about the search for new medicinal plants and his experiences in Central and South America with local curanderos, or herbal healers. Dr. Russell M. Jaffe, director of the Princeton Biocenter in Skillman, N.J., and Dr. Michael Weiner, an herbalist from Santa Monica, Calif., and author of 15 books on the subject, will discuss heightened interest in the medicinal properties of plants and the future of herbal medicine.
The symposium fee is $90, including handouts, a box lunch and parking. Call (212) 220-8720 for more information or reservations.
 
IN-FLIGHT MOVES
 Flying demonstrations by eagles, hawks and falcons and a spectacular aerial display by an Andean condor are the highlights of a benefit for the Hudson Valley Raptor Center in Rhinebeck. The event will begin at noon Saturday at Winley, an estate on Route 99 in Millbrook, and continue until 5 P.M.
Experts from the center and area naturalists and biologists will lecture and answer questions about birds of prey, many of which are on the endangered species list. The center is licensed to care for injured raptors by the United States Fish and Wildlife Service and the state's Department of Environmental Conservation.
There will be book signings by Dean Amadon, ornithologist from the American Museum of Natural History, and by other authors of books about raptors. There will also be an exhibition of birds of prey in art. Prints by Roger Bateman, Roger Tory Peterson and other nationally known wildlife artists will be raffled off or put up for bid in a silent auction.
Admission will be by donation of $25 and $12.50 for students and the elderly. Each adult may bring one child free of charge. Call 876-2106 for directions or more information.
 
A MARIONETTE CIRCUS
 The Bennington Marionettes touring company will take its life-size characters to the Yorktown Performing Arts Theater Saturday at 1 P.M. in a performance of "The Sorcerer's Circus."
The original story by Cedrick Flower, who directs the troupe, concerns the troubles of an aged, once famous sorcerer who has lost much of his ability to make magic. Having turned himself into a tree, he is unable to change back again, until a little boy and his dog, lost in the forest, come upon him, help him regain his powers and restore him to human form. As a reward for their assistance, he conjures up an old-fashioned circus that performes exclusively for the boy and his dog.
There is music by Dmitri Kabelevsky and Paul Dukas, and the show is performed by 15 hand-crafted, elaborately costumed marionettes. Tickets are $7 and can be reserved by calling 961-6665 or 962-0601. The theater is at 1974 Commerce Street in Yorktown Heights.

HEADLINE: Miss Saffer Weds M. D. Stephenson

 BODY:
Catherine Gail Saffer and Michael Deuel Stephenson were married last evening by Cantor Ted Aronson at the Orange Lawn Tennis Club in South Orange, N.J.
Mrs. Stephenson, 28 years old, is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Saffer of Short Hills, N.J. She is an associate in global markets at Bankers Trust in New York. She is an alumna of the University of Pennsylvania, and she and her husband graduated from the Harvard University Graduate School of Business in 1990. Her father is a lawyer in Short Hills. Her mother, Helen Saffer, is a realtor for Degnan, Boyle Realtors in Millburn, N.J.
Mr. Stephenson, 27, is a son of Mr. and Mrs. John D. Stephenson Jr. of Great Falls, Mont. He graduated magna cum laude from Harvard and recently completed a fellowship in economics given by the Japanese Ministry of Education in Tokyo. His mother, Nancy M. Stephenson, is the executive director of the Neighborhood Housing Services of Great Falls and a director of the Minneapolis Federal Reserve Bank. His father is a lawyer in Great Falls.

HEADLINE: World Markets;
Is the Life Back in Tokyo's Market?

BYLINE: By Jonathan Fuerbringer

 BODY:
After a stock market decline of more than 45 percent over a year and three-quarters and in the face of an economic slowdown that is now worrying business leaders, some analysts are seeing some real opportunity -- and some life -- in the Tokyo stock market.
Although many people have had their investments in Japanese stocks run aground, there are arguments for re-entering these treacherous waters. 
 One is that the signs of an economic slowdown seem to be so clear that the Bank of Japan will have to move to cut short-term interest rates. The reduction on Friday of the discount rate to 5 percent by the Federal Reserve in the United States should make it a little easier for the Bank of Japan to make a move.
And the fall in the stock market in the last 21 months has made many stocks in Japan -- which have long seemed very expensive -- look fairly priced or even undervalued.
Counsellors International Equity Fund, which is managed by Warburg, Pincus Counsellors Inc. in New York, is beginning to increase its holdings in the Japanese market. In just the last two weeks, the portion of the fund's portfolio that is invested in Japanese stocks has risen to 28 percent from 24 percent. The manager of the $67 million fund, Richard H. King, said the percentage would grow. "I am pretty confident that if one buys a Hitachi or a Sumitomo Realty today, a year from now one will have made decent money," he said.
Akira Suzuki, chief strategist in Tokyo for Morgan Stanley & Company, said: "This is the best opportunity in the market in many years. Lower interest rates and bad economic numbers create a high stock market."
But both analysts also sound notes of caution. Mr. King said there was still a chance for a 10 percent sell-off in the Tokyo market. And Mr. Suzuki is concerned about the fragile condition of the economy and the financial system, and this is why he insists that the Bank of Japan must act quickly to cut interest rates. But the bank could wait too long.
Short-term rates, Mr. Suzuki said, need to be cut aggressively or the the stock market will not rally, the economy will continue to slide and land prices will not rise. Without higher stock prices and higher land prices, he argued, borrowers will not have the funds they need to pay off bank loans, and banks will not have the money they need to continue their lending.
Michael Metz, chief market strategist at Oppenheimer & Company, is not optimistic. He has been telling his clients that the Tokyo market, where the Nikkei index of 225 leading stocks closed at 23,134.43 on Friday, might fall through 20,000, and "a target of 18,500 is reasonable."
He said the danger of such a decline would persist for the next four to six weeks. "We are building to a significant bottom or a cascading down," he said. "If it does not happen in the next six weeks, it does not happen."
Mr. Metz's worries include what Mr. Suzuki said Tokyo traders have called "the four trillion yen anxiety." This is the rough total of immediate selling pressure that some analysts feel could fall on the stock market.
Among the sources of the selling pressure are the huge margin accounts that have limited holding periods, which might force investors to sell their stocks. In addition, there are fears that investment trusts will be redeemed because of the fall in the market and that other special funds that have lost favor will be closed.
And some companies need to raise money in the stock market to pay off bonds issued in combination with warrants on company stock. Because the stock market has tumbled, the buyers of the bonds will not convert the warrants to stock. Therefore, companies have to come up with the cash to pay off the bonds.
Mr. Metz also argued that recent scandals have undermined confidence in the market and that the four giant brokerage houses in Japan are no longer "in a position to manipulate the market as they once were." And the outlook for corporate profits, as the economy slows, is worsening.
But on Friday there were some signs of life in the Tokyo market and an indication that some of the anxieties may be diminishing. One worry was that closing out September futures contracts on Friday would lead to massive selling. But it did not happen. Instead the Nikkei 225 rose 604.23 points, or 2.68 percent, on a volume of 1.2 billion shares, far above the recent turnover of around 300 million shares.
Mr. King and Mr. Suzuki contend the selling pressure will not be as great as some people fear. People will not sell aggressively from funds because they are not eager to sustain losses. And companies can meet some of their bond payments by borrowing from insurance companies and cutting capital spending, which is already declining.
But the optimism still depends, almost solely, on interest-rate cuts. Earlier this year, analysts were also hoping for a reduction in rates to spur the market higher. Yet when the Bank of Japan did reduce the official discount rate on July 1, the stock market did not rally. In fact, it is now 4 percent below its close on July 1.

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
If Banks Don't Lend, Credit Is Not Easy

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
Blame it on Friday the 13th. Stock traders got almost everything they claimed to want: a discount rate cut, good inflation numbers and soaring bond prices. But instead of going on a buying spree, they sold, and the Dow Jones industrial average lost 22 points on Friday.
Two possible explanations come to mind. One is the old Wall Street cliche: buy on the rumor, sell on the news. The reduction in the discount rate to 5 percent was widely anticipated, and a number of traders seem to have bought stocks planning to sell them when others rushed to buy on the news. That rush did not materialize, so they sold anyway. And within a few minutes, the bond rally also began to fade. 
 The other explanation is based less on trading strategies and more on an examination of why the Fed is, once again, easing credit. It is not to make life easier for bond traders, a group whose popularity in Washington is not at a high. The Fed, to put it bluntly, is trying to jump start the economy.
Unfortunately, the Fed's batteries appear to be no stronger than its surveillance of Treasury bond auctions. The big moves in the economy -- down last fall and up this spring -- can be traced to sentiment about the Persian Gulf war. The three previous discount rate cuts seem to have had minimal impact.
Those who doubt the Fed's power must contend with history. This is the sixth time since World War II that the Fed has made four consecutive cuts in the discount rate. On average, the Dow has risen 29 percent in the following year, notes Richard Eakle, a technical analyst who runs Eakle Associates.
In 1981 and 1982, the Fed cut the discount rate -- the rate at which it will lend to banks -- nine times, lowering it from 14 percent to 8.5 percent. Seven of those cuts came before the recession ended, but it did end, and the ensuing recovery was a strong one that lasted almost eight years.
With that record, the burden of proof is on those who argue that the Fed's efforts to start a recovery this year will fail. Their argument basically is that this downturn reflects the turning of the credit cycle. The boom left the country with too many office buildings and too few good loans. It will take years to work off the office supply; it may take a generation for the bankers to be so generous again to those who really need the money.
If the pessimists are right, then the fact that the banks cut their prime rates on Friday may mean that they now will not lend money at 8 percent instead of not lending at 8.5 percent.
Lower interest rates help those who are creditworthy and want to borrow money. These days, that is a very small group. Lower rates hurt those who live on interest income -- a lot of consumers among them -- and do nothing for those who are not allowed to borrow. Wall Street has assumed lower rates would be enough to provide a powerful boost for the economy and for corporate profits. Now that faith in the Fed's powers may be starting to fade.

HEADLINE: Wall Street/Diana B. Henriques;
Treasury's Troubled Auctions

 BODY:
The United States Treasury's auction process is fundamentally flawed, says Merton H. Miller, a finance professor at the University of Chicago and a winner of last year's Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science.
His chief objection is its "discriminatory price" auction system, in which Salomon Brothers became ensnared. In that system, bidders willing to take a lower interest rate get their bids filled first, at that rate. Runner-up bids are filled at their rate, on a prorated basis if necessary. A single purchaser is limited to 35 percent of an issue. 
 A better approach, he argues, would be a "Dutch auction," in which all the securities are sold at one price -- the best bid at which the whole issue can be sold. Last week, Professor Miller outlined other lessons he sees in the Salomon Brothers scandal.
Question: When you look at the Treasury market as an economist, what strikes you?
Mr. Miller: First, that the auction arrangements are so peculiar. The Treasury is still doing these discriminatory-price auctions, with all their flaws, flying in the face of the theories that say they are not gaining anything by doing it this way. Secondly, what kind of auction is it where you have to ration how much people get? Anytime an economist sees rationing, he knows something is wrong.
Q. But market participants defend the current system, don't they?
A. People are just comfortable with it. Until the Salomon thing, their attitude has been, if it ain't broke, why fix it? But it is  broken. It is an affront to good economics.
Q. You referred to rationing -- the 35 percent limit. How would you deal with that?
A. When anyone overbids, the Treasury should call their bluff by saying, 'You bid for an extra billion? O.K., it's yours.'
Q. You mean, just keep issuing debt until all the bids are filled?
A. Yes -- but you don't have to actually do it. You just have to threaten to do it! Then you don't have to worry about phony bids.
Q. Treasury officials hinted last week that they are considering a switch to a Dutch auction. What effect would that have?
 A. People will shave their bids down. They'll bid differently in a Dutch auction. In this discriminatory-price auction they use, there is a premium in knowing what other people are going to bid. If you bid too high, you might win and get more than you want, and if you bid too low, you won't get what you want. All of that is eliminated if you use the Dutch auction. You just bid what you think it's worth. You wouldn't need all this discussion beforehand about other people's bids.
Q. So those pre-auction discussions among bidders are, in your view, just an outgrowth of the way the auction is conducted?
A. Exactly! Because of the way the auction is done, you're under tremendous pressure to bid right. If you bid wrong, it can be very costly. With the Dutch auction, you're not so vulnerable to being "gamed" by other people's bids.
m
Q. Can economists say which of these auction methods is best?
A. There is a remarkable theory by William S. Vickrey, who was for many years on the economics faculty at Columbia University, that showed that the revenue to the seller, on average, is the same under all auction methods. So if the revenues are the same regardless of method, you can start to worry about the second-order aspects of these auctions. The Dutch auction simplifies the bidding, it's less costly and it's less prone to manipulative schemes. So, in that sense, it's better.
Q. But some primary dealers responded to the Treasury's trial balloon last week by saying that nobody will bid for these bonds at a Dutch auction. Are they wrong?
A. People who say that just don't understand the logic of markets. If you're selling a product that people want, they'll buy it. And if they don't want it, not all the manipulation in your power can make them buy it.
Q. But doesn't the Treasury need a mechanism to protect it in case people do not want to buy as much debt as it has to sell?
A. That's the argument they always use -- that change would destroy the market. We heard the same thing on Wall Street when people proposed ending the fixed commission system. Economists said it would not destroy the market, and people said, "How can you be so sure?" And we said, a market is a market. The laws of supply and demand work, regardless of the specific context you are given. The only reason I can be sure that the bond market won't disappear is that, in other markets, when you do things like this, the market doesn't disappear.
Q. The political and regulatory machinery is grinding ahead, with promises of tighter supervision and tougher rules. What do you think of the steps so far?
A. Not much. It's like saying, "Take two aspirin and call me in the morning." The Treasury is still captured by this view that we can't tamper with the world's most important market. All that tells me is that they don't really trust markets. And why should they? They're all bureaucrats.
Q. What's the worst thing that could be done, in your view?
A. No matter how bad you imagine something, Congress can make it worse. What I fear is more paper sent to Washington, more examiners coming from Washington, more expense both ways, and the actual economics of the situation won't change one bit. But that's considered progress in Washington.

HEADLINE: Making a Difference;
Mr. Walsh Takes the Field for Tenneco

BYLINE: By THOMAS C. HAYES

DATELINE: DALLAS

 BODY:
Three decades after Michael H. Walsh dislocated both shoulders while charging into opposing linemen as a running back on the football team at Stanford University, he still likes to meet challenges head-on.
Tenneco Inc. rushed Mr. Walsh's planned appointment as president ahead by three weeks so that he could deliver a harsh message last week directly to Wall Street analysts. Hurt by its faltering J. I. Case farm and construction machinery unit, Tenneco would pare its yearly dividend in half, sell assets valued at $1.05 billion and slash capital spending and operating costs by a combined $500 million, Mr. Walsh said. 
 The news came 10 days after Mr. Walsh arrived at the Houston-based Tenneco from the Union Pacific Railroad, where he had been chairman and chief executive for five years. He will replace James L. Ketelsen, 60, as Tenneco's chief executive in January and as chairman next May. The president's position had been vacant.
Mr. Walsh, a Yale Law School graduate and a former United States Attorney in Southern California, learned about global business while running the worldwide manufacturing operations of Cummins Engine before moving to Union Pacific.
Now 49 years old, he posted 23 consecutive quarters of rising earnings at Union Pacific, thinning layers of management and emphasizing sales and service. He gave no signal last week as to which of Tenneco's six operating divisions would take the brunt of his initial cost cutting. The company has 92,000 employees in 33 countries.
The likely candidate is Case, a global maker of tractors, backhoes and other heavy equipment, with 25,000 employees. Case contributed 32 percent of Tenneco's $6.8 billion in sales in the first half of the year. But a $270 million loss at the division during that period ate up the company's profits, producing an overall loss of $13 million, and probably accelerated the early retirement that Mr. Ketelsen, Tenneco's leader since 1978, had planned. Case could wind up losing more than $1 billion this year, analysts said.
Another problem is Tenneco's shipyard in Newport News, Va., the world's largest. That division builds and restores aircraft carriers and submarines. It is expected to post steady earnings into 1994, but orders could fade if Washington further cuts Pentagon spending.
Tenneco's other operations in auto parts, packaging, chemicals and natural-gas pipelines had slumping earnings in the first half, but are expected to rebound with the economy. Yet heavy debt payments take a big bite from earnings, so Mr. Walsh must decide whether to keep the conglomerate intact, or auction one or more divisions to pare the debt.
"It really goes back to defining what is Tenneco," said Eli S. Lustgarten, an analyst at Paine Webber Inc.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 2; Column 3; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1625 words

HEADLINE: Business Diary/September 8-13

BYLINE: By Joel Kurtzman

 BODY:

COMPANIES
 
Sympathy, But Not Credence, as Clark Clifford Explains 

It was a curious defense for a lawyer of such immense stature as Clark Clifford. Mr. Clifford, who has advised every Democratic President since Harry Truman and is a former Secretary of Defense, told the House Banking Committee last week that he had been duped by the Bank of Credit and Commerce International. Mr. Clifford was chairman of First American Bankshares, one of the banks secretly -- and illegally -- owned by B.C.C.I., but he said he did not know that. The Committee was skeptical. B.C.C.I. was a client of Mr. Clifford's law firm for more than a decade. It lent him millions of dollars to buy First American's stock. And there was a memorandum from Mr. Clifford to B.C.C.I.'s chairman warning that First American's link to B.C.C.I. could come to light. "My heart wants to believe you," said Representative Charles E. Schumer, a Brooklyn Democrat who is a member of the commitee (page 11). "But my head says 'No.' "
 
An Ill Wind for American Air
 
As part of his lesson on airline economics, Robert L. Crandall, chairman of American Airlines, told analysts the carrier would cut its aggressive expansion plans. American had planned to spend $21 billion over the next five years with $14.9 billion earmarked for new planes. The airline will still spend, just not as much. The problem, said Mr. Crandall, is that 25 percent of the nation's airline capacity is operated by bankrupt or nearly-bankrupt carriers. The weakened carriers cut fares and offer discounts just to fill seats, pressuring the strong carriers to do the same. Profits tumble. American lost $185.3 million in the first half on revenues of $5.96 billion. Analysts generally agreed with Mr. Crandall's strategy. "Prudent," was the word used by Julius Maldutis of Salomon Brothers Inc.
 
Armani for the Masses?
 
Giorgio Armani is best known for the stylish, soft-shouldered suits and draping dresses he designs in his studio in Milan. Men's suits go for $2,000 and up and the dresses can cost even more. But now Mr. Armani is making a bid to clothe the proletariat. Last week he announced plans to open a chain of about 200 shops. The stores will be called A/X: Armani Exchange. They will stock casual clothes with each item costing $100 or less. The question Seventh Avenue wants answered is this: Will the new lines bring down the value of pricier Armani designs? "People are not going to give up dressing expensively," Mr. Armani said.
 
A Mainframe With a Difference
 
When it comes to its mainframe businsess, the International Business Machines Corporation gets a lot of scrutiny. Those big beasts account for half of I.B.M.'s profits. Last week, when I.B.M. announced its new System/390 series, they were touted as different from anything I.B.M. had offered in the past. They are faster. But they are also more open than other I.B.M. mainframes. And, after years of complaints from its customers, Big Blue decided to listen. It designed the machines to run Unix programs.
 
The Salomon Victims
 
Bond trading is what mathematicians call a zero-sum game. For every winner there has to be a loser. That logic also applies to the scandal surrounding Salomon Brothers Inc., whose every illegal gain inflicted a loss on someone else. Last week, while naming no names, the Big Board said two firms lost millions due to Salomon's manipulation of the market. It did not name the firms. It also said several traders lost their jobs. Once it is determined how much Sal-
omon won illegally, it is believed the Government will ask it to forfeit that money.
 
Paul Mozer, who was head of the government trading desk at Salomon Brothers Inc., is catching most of the heat from the scandal. But Mr. Mozer also made a lot of money. According to Salomon, Mr. Mozer's compensation topped $10 million over the last three years.
 
Out of Focus at Tenneco
 
Lately, Tenneco Inc., which had $14.5 billion in sales last year, has been losing a lot of money. Its biggest problem is its J. I. Case farm and construction equipment unit. It had losses in 5 of the last 10 years. This year its tractors and earth movers could push $1 billion into Tenneco's loss column. To offset those losses Tenneco announced last week that it would sell $1.05 billion in assets. A chemical plant in La Porte, Tex., is on the block, along with a lubrication company owned by Case, three short-line railroads, a gold mining operation and some timberland. That leaves Tenneco -- one of the few companies that never seemed to care about "synergy" -- with shipbuilding, auto parts, gas pipelines and -- yes -- J. I. Case. The sales, the company said, will help it focus its businesses. That may take a while.
 
Merck Workers Have to Wait
 
Merck & Company's stock has been a high flier for years. Now the company is letting its employees in on the action. Each of Merck's 37,000 employees is getting a one-time option to buy 100 shares of its common stock at $127.25 a share -- about $3 below current prices. Employees can sell their options or keep them. If the stock goes up, employees can exercise the options, buy the stock and simultaneously sell it at a profit. But there is a catch: the options cannot be exercised until Sept. 6, 1996.
 
 
 
INTERNATIONAL

 
Off the Gravy Train for Castro
 
For more than 30 years, the Soviet Union has bankrolled Cuba. Last week in Moscow, Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev told Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d that that will soon stop. Mr. Gorbachev said Soviet aid to Cuba -- roughly $2 billion a year -- will be replaced by economic relations on a strictly free-trade basis. The curtailment is likely to cripple Cuba's economy. Mr. Gorbachev also said the Soviet Union will pull out its 11,000 military personnel from Cuba. Left unsaid were the concessions to the Soviet Union that the United States would make in return for cutting Cuba loose.
 
It's Bush Vs. Israel's Lobby
 
Last week President Bush got tough with Israel. With a breakthrough in the peace process close at hand, he said, a contentious debate on Capitol Hill about Israel's request for $10 billion in loan guarantees to help it settle its Soviet immigrants "would raise a host of controversial issues." Those issues, "could well destroy our ability to bring one or more parties to the peace table," Mr. Bush said. But Israel's supporters argued that Israel's request is humanitarian and separate from the peace talks. The contentious debate Mr. Bush feared has already begun as Israel's friends began to walk Congress' halls.
 
Target: Computer Cunning
 
The world may be a more peaceful place now that the Cold War is over, but the Administration still frets about the spread of high-tech weaponry. So the Pentagon has proposed a strict new set of controls on exports of computing equipment. Some products the Pentagon wants to keep at home. It wants others to be equipped with attachments that monitor their use. The computer industry has vowed to lobby against the proposals.
 
 
 
THE ECONOMY

 
When the Low Price Is Right
 
Producer prices have barely budged this year. Most industries have kept their prices flat or let them creep down to lure customers back to the stores and showrooms. Only Detroit has been brazen enough to raise prices in the face of few buyers. According to the Labor Department's Producer Price Index, prices in August rose by a slim 0.2 percent.
 
The Fed's Twin Enemies
 
The Federal Reserve, not the bravest of institutions, would rather not fight two enemies at once. So last week, when news of inflation's busted jaw finally reached the Fed, it figured it could take on the recession. The Fed lowered the discount rate half a percentage point, from 5.5 percent to 5 percent. The discount rate, the amount commercial banks are charged for short-term loans, is the Fed's big lever. By cutting it the Fed is making it easier for banks and their customers to borrow. That prods growth. Morgan Guaranty was quick to follow the Fed. It dropped its prime rate from 8.5 percent to 8. Soon, growth may feel confident enough to show its face.
 
The Antiquated Auctions
 
Bids in the $117 billion market for Treasury bonds are still written on paper and placed in wooden boxes by runners minutes before the auction begins. Last week, the Treasury Department decided 200 years of quaint tradition would have to end. It announced new procedures designed to make it harder to subvert the rules. The measures include using computers for the bidding and demanding written verification from customers of large winning bids to guarantee their authenticity (Salomon Brothers Inc. admitted placing bids in the names of customers. These new measures may be followed by others. But will new procedures stop people from abusing a market as plump with profits as this one?
 
Consumers Shy Away From Debt
 
To economists, debts are claims against future earnings. From that perspective, running up debt means consumers have confidence in the future. They think they will be employed and earning enough to pay back all their loans. But last week the Federal Reserve Board said consumer credit fell by 1.4 percent in July -- the seventh decline in the last eight months. Such a significant decline signals continued wariness about the future.
 
Subduing Inflation
 
Inflation may not be completely tamed, but at least it has lost its churlishness. Last month, according to the Labor Department, the Consumer Price Index rose by 0.2 percent, the same as in June and July. That puts the annual inflation rate at 2.7 percent -- less than the rate in Germany and Japan.

HEADLINE: Mutual Funds;
Getting In on the Latin Boom

BYLINE: By Carole Gould

 BODY:
Forget Eastern Europe. The sizzling area for foreign investment in 1991 is Latin America.
The prices of some funds have more than doubled since the beginning of the year. Through Sept. 6, the Brazil Fund was up 150 percent, for example, and the Chile Fund rose 105 percent, according to Thomas J. Herzfeld, who specializes in closed-end fund investment and analysis. That compares with a gain of 32.8 percent in the Herzfeld single-country fund average, an index of 20 funds. Closed-end funds issue a fixed number of shares that trade on stock exchanges. 
 One new closed-end fund -- the Argentina Fund -- is in the works, and some large fund groups are said to be exploring mutual funds specializing in the region. Last month, in fact, GT Capital Management in San Francisco started the GT Latin America Fund and Merrill Lynch announced its Latin America Fund. Both invest in Latin American stocks and debt.
Analysts say investors' improving perception of Latin America's risk is one reason for the region's recent success. Investors are also encouraged by the trends toward privatization, fiscal discipline and democracy. Then there are the opening of Latin equity markets to foreign investment and Mexico's possible participation in a proposed North American Free Trade Agreement.
Nevertheless, most of the good news is probably reflected already in the prices of the Latin America country funds, which have risen an average of 106.7 percent this year. The biggest winner is the Latin America Investment Fund, whose shares rose 150.6 percent through Sept. 6.
What is more, most of the attractive discounts that the country funds sported at the beginning of the year have narrowed or disappeared. Because prices of closed-end funds are set by supply and demand, the funds can trade at more or less than the value of the securities in their portfolios -- the net asset value of each share.
While prices for closed-end-fund shares are listed daily in the tables of the New York Stock Exchange, the net asset value is published once a week, usually on Wednesday or Saturday, depending on the type of fund. These tables allow the investor to determine if a fund is trading at a premium or discount to its net asset value.
Among Latin funds, the Latin America Investment Fund's 23 percent discount and the Mexico Fund's 20 percent discount in January have both disappeared.
Where does this leave investors who are interested in the region? First, they should understand that country funds are the most volatile sector of the closed-end fund industry.
Indeed, this year's rally follows a miserable year for country funds in 1990, when the Herzfeld average dropped 32.7 percent -- roughly five times more than the decline of the average stock fund, which lost 6.3 percent. The bottom line: country funds are for speculative investors and people who want to fill the high-risk part of their portfolios.
Despite the recent surge of Latin American funds, some advisers say there is still a place for long-term investors. "The prospects are still positive for the region," said Michael T. Porter, an analyst with Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company. He expects a number of national economies to "produce growth rates in the 5 to 6 percent range."
Mr. Herzfeld said "Latin America looks like a great opportunity." But he added, "Investors should remember that the region has a history of boom-bust cycles and surprises -- mostly unpleasant ones."
Right now, Mr. Porter recommends the Chile Fund, which was trading earlier this week at a discount of 15 percent, and the Emerging Mexico Fund, with a discount of roughly 8 percent. He also likes the Mexico Equity and Income Fund, which divides its portfolio between stocks and bonds. The fixed-income component makes the fund less risky than a pure stock play, he says.
W. Douglas Dent, who edits the Capiello Closed-End Fund Digest in Santa Barbara, Calif., likes the Latin America Investment Fund because its diversification among various countries reduces investment risk. But he recommended buying only when the fund's premium is below 5 percent.
Mr. Herzfeld advises buying Latin American closed-end funds when they have discounts of 10 percent to 15 percent.
What about the Latin America mutual funds? Experts say closed-end funds are a more efficient way to invest in illiquid markets like Latin America because managers of closed-end funds do not have to worry that investors may redeem their shares. For its part, GT says it will initially keep 46 percent of assets in Mexico, the most liquid of the markets it invests in.
The two new mutual funds are not cheap. GT's version has a 4.75 percent sales charge. Merrill Lynch investors choose either a 4 percent upfront sales charge with an ongoing fee of a quarter of 1 percent, or a 1 percent fee plus a contingent deferred sales charge of 4 percent on shares sold within a year of purchase, declining one percentage point a year until it disappears. To discourage short-term trading, Merrill also levies a 2 percent fee on shares sold within 12 months.

HEADLINE: The Executive Computer;
An Economical Time for Improving Your Memory

BYLINE: By Peter H. Lewis

 BODY:
New software operating systems like Microsoft Windows 3.0 and Apple System 7.0 demand large amounts of system memory, especially if the machine will be running complex business applications. Luckily, memory prices are at their lowest point in, well, memory. I recently added eight megabytes of random access memory to my elderly Macintosh, and the price worked out to be $39 a megabyte. In the days of the Great Memory Drought of 1988, a megabyte cost 10 times as much.
Memory prices soared that year because semiconductor companies were closing their 256-kilobit chip production facilities and retooling to produce the more efficient 1-megabit chips. Because almost every company shifted at the same time, supplies of 256Kb chips dried up before 1Mb chips reached the market in quantity. 
 Now, the chip industry is again in the process of shifting technologies, this time from 1-megabit chips to more efficient 4-megabit chips. "It could create a bit of a stir," said Mike Frost, president of Technology Works Inc. of Austin, Tex., one of the largest suppliers of add-on memory products for Macintosh, PC and PS/2 computers. "But there's too much supply out there to create the same thing that happened in 1988."
Mr. Frost said he recalled when the market price for a single 1-megabit chip reached $42 in 1988. In the bits-and-bytes world of computer memory, it takes eight or sometimes nine 1-megabit chips to produce 1 megabyte of system memory -- eight bits per byte, and sometimes one more to control the others -- so the cost per megabyte of memory was roughly $378. In contrast, he said, the market price for a 1-megabit chip today is $3.75, or $33.75 per megabyte.
Kipp A. Bedard, vice president of Micron Technology Inc., which is based in Boise, Idaho, and is the only American company to make and sell memory chips, agreed there might be an increase in chip prices because "supply will migrate away from the old-generation chips, making the older 1-megabyte chips more expensive to get."
Although Japanese companies dominate the advanced memory chip business, it appears that South Korean companies, including Samsung, Gold Star and Hyundai, are the driving force in commodity memory chips. "We haven't seen the aggressive shift from one generation to the next that we saw in 1988," Mr. Bedard said. "It's more of a gradual, graceful shift, allowing manufacturers like Micron to better meet customer needs."
Aiding the smoother transition is the fact that 4-megabit chips are the same size and have the same pin configuration as the 1-megabit chips they ultimately will replace.
Many computer companies are designing their models to be able to use memory packaged in modular units called single in-line memory modules, which makes it much easier to add memory to a system. Early computers required the user to plug in memory a chip at a time, which was daunting to casual computer users. Now, memory chips are arrayed on a slim circuit board about the size of a flattened cigarette. The modules typically come in 256-kilobyte, 1-megabyte or 4-megabyte "sticks," and a few companies are offering bulkier 16-megabyte modules as well, using banks of 4-megabit chips.
Some chip makers, including Micron, Hitachi and the International Business Machines Corporation, are already producing 16-megabit chips in limited quantities (all I.B.M.'s production is used internally). When the 16-megabit chips arrive en masse in late 1992 or early 1993, some personal computers could be expanded to hundreds of megabytes of random access memory. A decade ago, the first I.B.M. PC's came with 64 kilobytes of memory (it takes 1,024 kilobytes to make 1 megabyte).
Who needs all those megabytes of RAM? In general, the most memory hungry users are those who work with computer-aided design, electronic publishing, scientific modeling or other graphically intensive tasks. And the introduction of graphical user interfaces, like Windows, System 7 and OS/2, add to the memory burden by permitting users to hold several different applications in memory at once.
Adding to the demand is the feature inflation of new business applications, which are swelling with every new release and consuming memory voraciously. Keeping several memory-hungry applications in readiness at the same time, along with the memory overhead required by the operating system itself, requires lots of RAM.
Several computer makers now consider 4 megabytes of RAM a minimum configuration. Experience suggests that 5 is better, and 8 is better still.
It is a relatively simple procedure to open the computer case, find the memory slots and snap the modules into place. Because chips are extremely susceptible to damage from static electricity, though, it is important to be careful handling them. Some computer stores carry inexpensive wrist straps that connect to a grounding source, like the metal plate around the PC's power supply.
The most common ways to get more memory are to buy it from a dealer or through a direct-sales outlet, like Technology Works (800 897-9739). Starting this week, Technology Works will be selling memory modules in CompUSA discount stores.
The modules "have been available in a number of the, shall we say, nerdier computer stores, like Fryes Electronics in California, but in terms of widespread availability of memory, this is new," said Dean A. McCarron, vice president of technology for In-stat Inc., a semiconductor industry market research company in Scottsdale, Ariz.
Several major personal computer makers, including I.B.M., already make computers that can be upgraded by replacing the central microprocessor. The Compaq Computer Corporation of Houston is expected to introduce such a system this week.
Business customers can also expect to see new forms for computer memory in coming months, especially for palmtop and notebook portable systems. Several companies are planning to use a new generation of memory cards called IC DRAM's (for integrated circuit dynamic random access memory), which are about the size of a credit card but thicker.
From 1 to 8 megabytes of memory chips are encased in the IC DRAM card, which can be inserted into a slot on the outside of the computer, just as one would insert a floppy diskette; in other words, the user does not have to open the case to add memory. Prices for 1-megabyte IC DRAM's are expected to be higher than for internal modules; the 8-megabyte IC DRAM's and modules are expected to be comparably priced.
In the end, more memory is the key to making computers easier to use. "The more friendly the new operating systems and applications are, the more they do behind scenes," said Mr. Bedard of Micron Technology.

HEADLINE: Managing;
Rewarding Employees for 'Wellness'

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH

 BODY:
At Mesa Limited Partnership, T. Boone Pickens' Dallas oil company, employees who take no sick days, file no medical claims, clock in at a decent weight, blood pressure and cholesterol level and exercise at least 13 times a month can make up to $354 extra a year. "Boone understands money as a motivator, and he'd rather motivate people to be healthy than sick," said John A. Durkin, Mesa's fitness manager.
Atco Properties and Management Inc. pays $500 to employees who climb 16 flights to their Manhattan real estate offices every day for a year. (Atco takes their word for it.) Overweight workers get $10 for every pound they lose ($100 a pound for senior staff), and smokers who quit get $500. "I may up the ante to a Caribbean vacation to get our last two smokers to stop," said H. Dale Hemmerdinger, Atco's president. 
 For some time now companies have been paying for weight-loss programs, stress management seminars and other so-called wellness programs for their employees. Yet the corporate landscape remains dotted with overweight, stressed-out smokers with cholesterol-choked arteries. The reason: "Without incentives for life-style changes, employees gain the weight back or start smoking again," said Jesse Bernstein, president of Employee Assistance Associates Inc., a consulting firm in Ann Arbor, Mich.
Slowly, employers are catching on to that fact. A recent study by the Philaldephia consulting firm Hay/Huggins shows that a small but growing number of companies are "making it financially worthwhile for employees to stay well," said Michael Carter, a Hay/Huggins senior vice president.
Many companies, including the Bank of Delaware and U-Haul International Inc., shave the cost of insurance or deductibles for employees who exercise, quit smoking and the like. Others, including Johnson & Johnson and Baker Hughes Inc., will provide a better benefits package for employees who demonstrate healthy habits. Still others, including the Adolph Coors Company and the Control Data Corporation, pay $10,000 more in death benefits if an employee killed in a car accident was wearing a seat belt.
Such programs are new, so no one has calculated their cost or quantified their impact. But incentives rarely amount to more than a few hundred dollars per employee, and that sum can be easily recouped if absenteeism and medical claims are reduced.
Companies vary widely in what they will reward. Some reward the process -- say, exercising. Others hold out for results, like weight loss. Still others only give bonuses to employees who have reached, for example, an ideal weight or cholesterol count.
Johnson & Johnson and Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Michigan are in the process camp. Johnson & Johnson's employees can rack up "Live for Life" dollars, play money that is exchangeable for such items as socks or sweatshirts, for exercising a set amount. The New Brunswick, N.J., company once offered five Live for Life dollars, worth about 50 cents in real terms, to employees who had their blood pressure checked.
Employees in Blue Cross's walking club get a water bottle after they have clocked 35 miles; 100 miles gets a towel, 500 miles a fanny pack, and so on, until the grand prize of a jacket, for 1,000 miles. Every additional 100 miles yields a bar for the jacket.
"Walking is easy, it's safe, so why not give them a little incentive to get into the habit?" asked Dorothy I. Kellerman, who coordinates the employee wellness programs.
The answer, say proponents of pay-for-results, is that habits can be broken and are almost impossible to monitor.
To qualify for a wellness bonus at the Sara Lee Corporation's Superior Coffee and Foods unit in Bensenville, Ill., employees take annual blood tests for anemia, thyroid function and the like. People judged to be in excellent health get $200 to spend for wellness-related items like joining a health club.
"This provides early detection of medical problems, and lets employees choose their own route to health," said Vincent P. Pellettiere, director of human resources.
Companies are usually flexible in defining that "route." Coors employees who suffer from stress qualify for a lowered co-payment by taking a vacation. "Wellness is a broad concept, so we allow a lot of latitude," said Lynn Gilfillan, community wellness representative for the Golden, Colo. brewery.
Similarly, Johnson & Johnson's employees get more benefits if, say, they wear seat belts, or promise to talk to their children about drugs and alcohol. The company accepts an employee's word for both.
"To lie about health, they have to think about health, and that may prod them to do something about it," said Melvin L. Benjamin, director of work and family.
 
 
 
PAYING THE PRICE FOR BEING BAD
 Most companies prefer to dangle a carrot in front of people who demonstrate healthy habits. A few prefer to shake a stick at those who don't.
The Turner Broadcasting Company refuses to hire smokers. Texas Instruments, Baker Hughes and U-Haul International charge smokers more for medical insurance. U-Haul takes a few extra dollars from employees who are 20 percent heavier than what is medically considered to be ideal weight.
More companies are poised to take the punitive approach. Next year, Control Data will charge smokers more for medical and life insurance. A smoker must be off cigarettes for a year before the surcharge is removed.
"Enough has been written about smoking and health so that no one can really object to this kind of life-style premium," said Michael E. Kotten, director of employee benefits.

HEADLINE: With Government Growing, More Spending Won't End Deficit

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Tom Wicker proposes in "Investing in America" (column, Aug. 18) massive Government spending on infrastructure and the return of more Federal money to states and localities in the name of pump priming. Mr. Wicker seems to have fallen for the misguided claim that the 1980's witnessed some sort of rollback in the size of government. Nothing could be further from the truth. 
 Before he advances his spend, spend, spend philosophy any more, he might want to note that Government spending increased faster under Ronald Reagan than under Jimmy Carter. For all Mr. Reagan's laissez-faire rhetoric, he failed to tame our Government run amok; he simply replaced stupid tax-and-spend policies with stupid borrow-and-spend policies. Our Government now consumes more than one-quarter of everything produced in this country.
Mr. Wicker suggests we ignore the "vastly overrated" budget deficit. This would be criminally impossible. As long as we pile up massive deficits, our economy will never become competitive and we will never control inflation. What is our national debt -- $3 trillion, $4 trillion? Why not $10 trillion? The numbers are surreal. What is very real is the more than $300 billion we must spend each year to service this mountain of red ink.
Nicholas Leman, author of "The Promised Land," hardly a conservative Republican, reckons that an effective antipoverty program for our inner cities would require $50 billion a year. This is one-sixth of what we spend on interest on the debt.
Indeed, this mountain of debt, which raises interest rates and inflation and sucks investment from the productive sectors of the economy, is a primary reason behind the lower growth rate of the 1980's relative to the 1960's. Also in the 1980's we did not get bogged down in an inflationary Vietnam War.
Finally, why does Mr. Wicker assume that uncontrollable spending and overdependence on an ever-expanding Government are permanent features of the American condition? They need not be. We might consider whether or not we wish to remain, as Alexis de Tocqueville warned we might, in a state of "perpetual childhood."
 
H. ANDREW SCHWEDEL
New York, Aug. 25, 1991

HEADLINE: Why Eastern Europeans Need Trade Relief

 BODY:
To the Editor:
James Bovard makes an excellent case for removing trade barriers against Eastern European imports ("For the U.S., a Repeated Trade Slip," Forum, Aug. 18.) Our government is protecting us from nonexistent threats. 
 When in Hungary recently, I heard often of the disappointment the Hungarians felt about barriers against Eastern European products in the United States and the European Community. "Why," people asked, "did the E.C. and the U.S. encourage us to turn to free-market economies when their own markets are not free and open? What is the point of a market economy when our products are not even given a chance?"
There is no doubt that we need to make our industries competitive and encourage American companies' growth. Preventing competition is not the method, especially in dealing with countries striving to open their economies. Encouraging the growth of other economies will lead to larger, wealthier markets for United States products in the long run. Let's not defeat ourselves and others with short-term measures.
 
CATHERINE D. ONYEMELUKWE
Stamford, Conn., Aug. 28
 
The author is head of the Trade and Investment Services (Hungary) unit of the International Executive Service Corps.
