HEADLINE: Beijing's Top Priority: Maintain Communism

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BEIJING, Sept. 14

 BODY:
China's leaders have pledged in a series of confidential documents that the Soviet upheavals will neither diminish China's commitment to Communism nor weaken its resolve to open the door wider to the outside world.
At least three classified documents are circulating at various levels in the Chinese Communist Party, outlining the leaders' response to the Soviet events, according to Chinese with access to high-level information. Two of the documents are based on advice from the paramount leader, Deng Xiaoping, that China must act prudently and avoid taking a belligerent stance against the collapse of Communism elsewhere. 
 One of the three items has been previously reported. It is Central Committee Document No. 4, which concludes that the Soviet Union has restored capitalism and that its mistake was that it chose the wrong successor to earlier hard-liners.
The second document, which is stamped "top secret" and has begun circulating to department heads in the central Government and party apparatus, is a revised version of a speech given in July by the Communist Party leader, Jiang Zemin. Mr. Jiang emphasizes that Communism has faced difficulties before and that it will overcome them, and that China will continue its open-door and reform policies.
To avoid the fate of the Soviet Union, Mr. Jiang says, China must adhere to three principles: Communist Party leadership of China, party control over the military and security forces, and disavowal of privatization in the economy.
"The private sector can be only a supplement to the state and collective sectors, and it can never predominate," Mr. Jiang states.
He also takes a dig at the United States, noting that American relief for the devastating flood in central China amounted to only $25,000, while the people of Hong Kong donated some $50 million. Mr. Jiang suggests that the United States knew through satellite information that the flood was a terrible catastrophe and hoped that it would lead to turmoil that would threaten the regime.
Instead, Mr. Jiang says, the Government has handled the relief effort extremely smoothly and has demonstrated the superiority of socialism. Under capitalism, many people would have starved to death or been left uncared for, he says.
While large sums have been raised within China, these have not all been voluntary. Some Chinese are grumbling that they are being told to give four or five new pieces of clothing to their work units to be forwarded to flood victims.
Mr. Jiang's speech also emphasizes that China's foreign policy will be flexible, encouraging warm relations with former Communist countries. The same point is made in the third of the documents now circulating, an analysis by Foreign Minister Qian Qichen.
 
Not Shocked by Soviet Shift
 Mr. Qian's analysis, which is now being distributed to ministers and vice ministers in the central Government, asserts that the central leadership expected since February that the Soviet Union would go capitalist and so was not surprised by developments. It suggests that China's foreign policy will not be greatly affected by Soviet events.
But among Mr. Deng's recent comments now circulating among officials is this: "One cold war has ended; two others have begun." There is no explanation of what the two new ones are, but presumably one is the ideological struggle between China and the West.
While officials are being told that China's open-door policy will open even wider, many are skeptical. The Chinese Academy of Social Sciences is trying to curtail travel by its scholars to the United States, saying there have been too many such trips recently, and some sensitive work units have called meetings in the last two weeks to warn employees to avoid all contacts with foreign journalists.
One Chinese who attended such a meeting said they were told that they would be punished if they were found to be in touch with foreign correspondents.

HEADLINE: THE SOVIET TRANSITION;
BAKER, IN BALTICS, PROMISES U.S. HELP

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: VILNIUS, Lithuania, Sept. 14

 BODY:
Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d made a whistle-stop tour of all three newly free Baltic republics today, promising them help in joining international organizations to solidify their break from the Soviet Union and limited American economic aid.
The Baltic leaders made it clear to Mr. Baker that despite the new independence, 100,000 Soviet soldiers remained on their soil with no firm agreement on withdrawal, American officials said.
 
Leaders Still Wary
 Mr. Baker told republic leaders that Washington was prepared to give them $14 million this fiscal year in the form of assistance programs divided among the three republics. The Baltic leaders were clearly hoping to get more, but the chief issue on their agenda was security issues. 
 American officials said the Baltic leaders urged Mr. Baker to do all he could to help speed their integration into the United Nations, which is already in the process of making them full members, as well as the International Monetary Fund, the World Bank and the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development. The Baltic leaders are still very wary that the triumph of change-minded forces in Moscow over the coup's hard-liners could be reversed, and with it their own independence.
Mr. Baker said Washington was already working to speed Baltic membership in the United Nations and had already helped push the nations into the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe last week. He promised to work on other organizations as well.
Mr. Baker's visit was the first by an American Secretary of State to Latvia, Lithuania and Estonia, three nations that were occupied and annexed by the Soviet Union as a consequence of a secret pact between Hitler and Stalin on the eve of World War II. The three began separate independence drives after President Mikhail S. Gorbachev came to power in the Soviet Union, and finally attained freedom this month by a resolution of the council temporarily governing the Soviet Union in the wake of the coup.
 
No Housing for Troops
 Soviet officials have told both Baltic and American officials that they recognize that Soviet troops will have to leave the Baltic nations. But they add that they are simultaneously withdrawing from Poland and Germany and that the nation lacks the housing right now to accommodate all returning military men. Moscow has told the Baltic leaders and Mr. Baker that they would like to have all troops out by January 1994, but the Baltic leaders want them out sooner.
Asked if he could not do more to get the soldiers to leave sooner, all Mr. Baker would say was: "Everyone agrees that the sooner that would be accomplished the better it would be."
Mr. Baker spent Friday night in St. Petersburg, formerly Leningrad, holding talks with its Mayor, Anatoly A. Sobchak. Then, starting this morning, he hopped from one Baltic republic to the next in a trip that was longer on symbolism than substance. Mr. Baker posed for photos with leaders in Latvia, Lithuania and Estonia, presenting to each the republic's flag that flew in the State Department lobby during their 51 years of Soviet occupation.
Mr. Baker's brief remarks outside the Estonian Parliament in Tallinn were typical of those he repeated at each stop, changing the name of the republic or the president.
"Let me say how very pleased I am to be here in a free and independent Estonia," Mr. Baker said. "We have congratulated all of the officials of this government for the realization after all of these years of a goal we in the United States have shared that is the restitution of your full independence and we have also made clear that without the bravery and courage of the Estonian people this would never have happened."
Although the United States never formally recognized that the Baltic states were part of the Soviet Union, Baltic nationalists complained during their drives for independence that the American desire to support Mr. Gorbachev had prevented the republics from getting the kind of firm public support from Washington that they would have liked.
The Baker visit had the feel of a political campaign swing -- including a 15-minute departure delay in St. Petersburg while Mr. Baker held up his motorcade to wait for the sole American network camera crew accompanying him.
But the trip was lacking one key element: crowds. Latvians, Lithuanians and Estonians paid virtually no attention as Mr. Baker's motorcade sped in and out of their capitals, save for a few hundred Lithuanians who turned out at the Parliament building in Vilnius.
The biggest spontaneous reception Mr. Baker received was a smattering of applause from a crowd gathered for a funeral at the Russian Orthodox Church, just across from the Estonian Parliament in Tallinn.
 
U.S. Followed Mongolia
 The seeming lack of interest by average Balts in their high-level American visitor can be understood, in part because the United States -- although it never formally recognized the republics' annexation by Moscow -- dragged its feet in formally recognizing their independence, being the 37th country to do so, after Mongolia.
When Prime Minister Edgar Savisaar of Estonia was asked by reporters whether he could honestly say that he was pleased by the speed with which Washington recognized the Baltics, he said diplomatically, "We were pleased with the wisdom and the balance with which the United States recognized Baltic independence."
The Baltic people also seemed to be responding to the lack of pressure on Mr. Gorbachev for their independence until after it was a virtual certainty.
"You know," said Ille Grun, a Tallinn reporter, "in the last few weeks so many important people came here. Now we say: When the Queen comes, it will be news."
Mr. Baker began his tour in Tallinn, where he drove to the Estonian Parliament, passing barricades of huge granite boulders built to protect the building from Soviet troops during the coup. He had to negotiate similar barricades at government buildings in Riga, the Latvian capital, and Vilnius.
For the Americans, one important matter of substance at each stop involved assurances that each Baltic country would be prepared to endorse provisions of the Conventional Arms Reduction Treaty and Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty that might apply to them. Both treaties were signed by the United States and Soviet Union in the last year and both might have to be changed to account for the fact that the Soviet military garrison and weapons systems will eventually leave the Baltics.
For the Baltic nations, the biggest item on their agenda besides security is American aid. As the Estonian President, Arnold Ruutel, said with Mr. Baker at his side: "I understand Mr. Secretary that the United States is going to support us and help us in this period we are now facing."
The $14 million in assistance Mr. Baker revealed for this fiscal year would include $2 million in medical supplies, a management training institute and bank training center, livestock feed, scholarships, seminars on legal reform, English language training courses, parliamentary training, assistance to political parties and public administration and rule-of-law programs, as well as advice on developing small business.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d presenting the Estonian flag to President Arnold Ruutel yesterday in Tallinn. The flag had flown in the State Department's lobby during the 51 years of Soviet occupation. Mr. Baker was on a whirlwind tour of the three newly independent Baltic countries. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Despite Growth, Mormons Find New Hurdles

BYLINE: By PETER STEINFELS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SALT LAKE CITY

 BODY:
A century ago the Mormon Church was widely viewed as a morally and politically dangerous sect. Today it is widely seen as a conservative repository of old-fashioned values, an American success story.
One of the nation's fastest-growing major churches, it dispatches nearly 50,000 missionaries a year, many of them 19- and 20-year-olds, to spread its message in the United States and abroad. There are now more Mormons than members of the Presbyterian Church (U.S.A.) or the Episcopal Church, two pillars of the religious establishment. And no other major American religious group is so generously supported by its followers: By church law Mormons give up to 10 percent of their income to the church. 
 But thanks to its very success, the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints confronts a whole new array of problems, some immediate and practical, some touching on the very nature of the faith. Just as it approaches the safe harbor of national acceptance, it is being transformed again, this time into an international religion.
 
More Non-Americans
 By the year 2000, at the church's present rate of growth, only a minority of Mormons will be American. In 1960, the church had 1.7 million members, all but 200,000 in the United States. By 1990, its ranks had swollen to 7.7 million members, but with 3.4 million of them overseas, mostly in Latin America.
The church "is caught in a real bind" by its rapid international growth, said Michael Quinn, a Mormon historian. "Typically the boast and pride of Mormon leadership has been that throughout the world the church is the same, not only in doctrine but even in the building of temples and chapels," he said.
And even with tithing, the mandatory contribution from members, there is not money to recreate the Mormon life and institutions of Salt Lake City in India and Africa, he said.
And the church is not always welcome overseas. In Chile, where 2 percent of the population is Mormon (as against 1.4 percent in the United States), 60 bombs were detonated last year in attacks on Mormon chapels by political groups who view Mormons as agents of American imperialism. In Peru, guerrillas assassinated three Mormon missionaries from that country. A church that was once reviled in the United States is now the recipient of "Yanqui go home" messages, even when local members are not Yankees.
At the same time, the church has barely shed its history of tension with American society.
The church had barely been founded by Joseph Smith in 1830 when persecution drove Mormons from New York to the Midwest, where Smith was lynched by an anti-Mormon mob in 1844, and then to Utah under the leadership of Brigham Young. Until the church renounced its approval of polygamy in 1890, the practice caused decades of cold war, and occasionally armed clashes, with the Federal Government.
But behind the battle lines the church was instilling a code of sober living (no tobacco, alcohol, drugs or gambling), hard work, self-reliance, family stability and organizational efficiency. The church has produced a corps of individuals fluent in foreign languages, familiar with other cultures and trained in salesmanship.
The missionary effort has only one parallel among major Christian groups, that of the Jehovah's Witnesses. Mormonism's emphasis on family solidarity, expressed in the strict morality it preaches for this world and the continuation of the family unit in the afterlife, plays a crucial role in drawing people to the faith.
 
Discouraging Debate
 But the suspicions linger. Tightly governed by a small band of male elders whose decisions are usually made behind closed doors, the church discourages open debate or criticism. Three weeks ago, for example, the highest church officials issued a formal rebuke of an August conference in Salt Lake City at which scholars examined problems of premarital sex, drug abuse and child abuse among Mormons and explored the changing meaning of church rituals.
The conference was sponsored by the monthly Sunstone, one of several independent journals where the swelling ranks of Mormon professionals and intellectuals try to explore their church's history, theology and policies. Church authorities have met these efforts with recurring threats to suspend the religious privileges of critics or bar them from church employment.
This anxiety about maintaining its image enabled a trafficker in forgeries to sell church officials documents purporting to be from Joseph Smith's era that might have reflected badly on Mormonism's origins. In 1985, the scheme was exposed when the trafficker, Mark W. Hofmann, planted three bombs, killing two people and seriously injuring himself.
Inevitably, the church's political influence and economic power in Utah and surrounding states stirs rumors and criticism among Mormons as well as non-Mormons. The church's opposition to the Equal Rights Amendment in the late 1970's stirred a feminist opposition within its ranks, and liberals began to view the church as part of the religious right supporting the Reagan Administration on social issues.
 
No 'Mischief' Found
 Last month, after The Arizona Republic published a series of articles on the church's wealth, Richard Robertson, who oversaw the Phoenix paper's yearlong investigation, said the church's doctrines, its history of polygamy and what Mr. Robertson called a secretive "circle-the-wagons mentality" fostered in the church by past persecution had produced "curiosity and a lot of suspicion and rumors about what Mormons own, control and believe."
Mr. Robertson said the investigators had begun with an expectation of finding "mischief" and misuse of funds and were "surprised not to find anything." According to the series, the church collects $4.3 billion a year in tithes from its members and brings in another $400 million in revenue from more than 100 church-owned enterprises and extensive land-holdings.
Dr. Jan Shipps, a professor of religious studies at Indiana University and a foremost non-Mormon scholar of the church's modern transformation, has noted that although Joseph Smith founded the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints as a "restored" form of Christianity, Mormonism quickly modeled itself on ancient Israel, with patriarchal leadership, a temple and an exodus to a promised land where a people distinguished by special dietary and ritual practices would be gathered.
But with the growth of a permanent Mormon "diaspora" throughout the United States and now of congregations in over 100 nations, Mormonism may have to recapitulate the kind of adjustments Christianity made during the early centuries when it spread from Jewish converts to Gentiles and from the Roman empire to the invading tribes and the rest of Europe.
In 1978, Spencer W. Kimball, then the church's President, announced a revelation revoking the church's longstanding ban on extending the priesthood, an office Mormonism grants to all worthy males over 12, to blacks. The change was crucial both for Mormonism's acceptance in America and obviously for its expansion in Africa and in Latin American nations like Brazil with racially mixed populations.
 
More Inclusive Leadership
 The church has only begun to incorporate non-American representatives into its top leadership. Since 1985 Ezra Taft Benson has been church's President, a lifetime office. Mr. Benson, Secretary of Agriculture under President Eisenhower, is now 92, and church leadership is largely in the hands of his First and Second Counselors, Gordon B. Hinckley and Thomas S. Monson.
All three are Americans. So are all members of the Council of the Twelve Apostles, the next highest level of church authority. Only at the next level, the First and Second Quorums of the Seventy, are there members born outside the United States: 21 out of 73. This level, which supervises the church's geographic subdivisions, seems to serve more as a pool of candidates for higher office than to play a major part in setting policies.
Expansion has also forced the church to systematize and adapt its doctrine and organization. "For a long time, 'simplify and reduce by half' has been a catchword" in church agencies preparing teaching materials, said Elbert Peck, the editor of Sunstone.
 
Curbing Talk of Doctrine
 Discussions of speculative doctrines about the afterlife and the nature of God or humankind have been curtailed, he said, partly to make the religion easier to communicate, partly just to reduce the costs of translating and publishing. Some Mormons describe the new approach as "cut and dried," but Mr. Peck noted that the simplified adult Sunday school manual encouraged discussion of local concerns.
To strengthen oversight and reduce disparities in resources, money that was once collected and distributed locally is now channeled through the church's central office.
One seemingly simple change had an impact that Dr. Shipps said "is impossible to overstate." Meetings and activities that once consumed almost every evening have been condensed into a block of time on Sunday. Partly a response to modern time pressures, the change was also "a crucial response to the diaspora," Dr. Shipps said. "Converts in Latin America might live long distances away from one another. They can't drive, or worse walk, to meetings four or five nights a week."
For some Mormons, often from families in the church for generations, these changes represent a loss in the religion's strong sense of community.
"We're becoming a Sunday church," said Peggy Fletcher Stack, a founder of Sunstone.
Overseas growth accelerates pressures already at work as Mormonism adjusts to its growing numbers outside of highly Mormon areas in Utah, Idaho or nearby states.
"I don't think most church members realize how much the international growth is driving what is happening right here in the United States," Mr. Peck said.
The concentration of activities on Sunday reduces "the chance for communal conversation," he said. "You basically come to church and you're talked to and then you live your lives as individuals according to the ordinances and duties the church teaches."
Other occasions for collective activity by church members have been similarly reduced, he said, noting that the extensive church welfare system that used to maintain farms and canneries to provide work and income for church members now finds it more efficient to distribute funds directly.
Martha Nibley Beck, who teaches sociology at Mormon-run Brigham Young University in Provo, Utah, said that the shift to a world church would enourage a return to Mormonism's most basic religious elements. Purely American "cultural trapping will get peeled away," she said. Other Mormons believe the change will spur Mormon sensitivity to problems of hunger, poverty and global justice.
 
'Changed Me in Every Aspect'
 "This has changed me in every aspect of my life," said Richard Stone, a 21-year-old who grew up Mormon in Scarsdale, N.Y., and who recently returned from 22 months of missionary work in Chile. Working in outlying districts of Santiago and encountering stark poverty and other human problems had left him with a deep appreciation of the Chilean people and a desire "to do good."
Now a sophomore at Brigham Young University, Mr. Stone said that his missionary experience had made him consider work in the foreign service or as a translator.
The church would meet the financial or cultural strains of growth, said Dr. Russell M. Nelson, a distinguished cardiovascular surgeon whose membership on the Council of the Twelve gives him a voice in the church's major decisions.
Many adjustments will be necessary but basic doctrines will remain unchanged, he said. "This is a healthy exercise for us. It make us examine our own performance and assess our priorities," he said.

HEADLINE: Political Memo;
In Spotlight, Jackson Nears Decision

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14

 BODY:
This is the season of decision for Democratic Presidential hopefuls, and few decisions will be more closely watched, or have more impact on the race for the party's nomination, than whether the Rev. Jesse Jackson chooses to run for the third time.
It is now widely believed among Democrats, including some of Mr. Jackson's allies, that he will not seek the nomination next year. Some who follow Mr. Jackson closely, but spoke on condition that they not be identified, say they believe he has made up his mind and is wrestling with the pain of making it official -- particularly to his supporters. 
 In an interview this week, Mr. Jackson dismissed such talk as "just speculation." But he has taken to noting, "Running has always been an option, not an obsession." And he talks willingly about the forces that could keep him from another race for the nomination, including family and personal considerations. This is a very different psychology from the fire, the certainty and the edge that were so strong in Mr. Jackson when he began his Presidential candidacies in 1983 and 1987.
Still, Mr. Jackson is a master at keeping his options open, controlling his timing and building suspense -- perhaps more than any other politician on the scene today. And with a fervent base of supporters always eager to take up the chant of "run, Jesse, run," there are probably some twists and turns ahead before his fellow Democrats finally discover just what Mr. Jackson intends to do.
 
Meeting in Washington
 The endgame could begin Sunday night, when Mr. Jackson meets with supporters and former delegates here in Washington, to discuss "the most effective way to render our public service during the next political season."
Mr. Jackson's plans have major implications for his fellow Democratic hopefuls, including the latest entrant, Gov. L. Douglas Wilder of Virginia, who announced his candidacy in Richmond on Friday. First and foremost, some party strategists say, if Mr. Jackson chooses not to run, it would suddenly escalate the competition for the support of black voters, a critical part of his base.
Black voters accounted for 21 percent of the Democratic Presidential primary vote in 1988, and 24 percent of that vote in the several Southern primaries held on the March 8 "Super Tuesday," according to the New York Times/CBS News surveys. In 1988, the white candidates for the Democratic nomination largely ceded the black vote to Mr. Jackson; his roots, recognition and loyalties among black voters run very deep.
If Mr. Jackson chooses not to run in 1992, "you'd have the most significant bloc in the Democratic primary system up for competition, in play among the existing and probable candidates," said Thomas Donilon, a Democratic strategist. This would be a big plus for Mr. Wilder, the nation's first black elected governor, who has run well among blacks in Virginia but is moving into national politics for the first time. Several party strategists said they expected him to get vigorous competition from the white candidates for this black support.
Much of Mr. Jackson's support among white liberals, some strategists suggested, could fall to Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa. Michael McCurry, former spokesman for the Democratic National Committee, described Mr. Harkin as "probably the closest to an ideological heir to Jackson."
There has long been division among Mr. Jackson's supporters over whether he should seek the Democratic nomination in 1992. Mr. Jackson was roundly criticized last year when he decided not to run for mayor of Washington; his critics asserted that it showed his unwillingness to test himself in elective office.
Instead, Mr. Jackson was elected to the job of what he calls "statehood senator," a lobbyist for statehood for the District of Columbia. But this did little to silence the criticism that Mr. Jackson was more interested in causes and campaigns than governance. Running a third consecutive time, some Democrats suggest, could only feed the image of Mr. Jackson as a perennial cause candidate.
 
'Personal and Family'
 Mr. Jackson, protective of his political accomplishments, said in the interview: "My reasons for not announcing so far have been personal and family. There is no political reason not to run."
Interviewed the day before Mr. Wilder's expected entry into the race, Mr. Jackson bristled at the notion that his decision, his career path, was somehow linked to that of the Virginia Governor. "It is a race-based comparison that is not based upon our base of support, it's not based upon our views, it's not based upon our ratings in the polls, it's not at all a scientific analysis -- it's a racial analysis," he said.
He showed some appetite for the emerging debate, taking aim, with his customary skill, at the buzzwords of his potential opponents. "We do not need fiscal conservatism," he said. "We need fiscal prudence and economic growth."
Regardless of his decision, Mr. Jackson will not leave the public stage. Besides his constant rounds of travel, speeches and organizing, Mr. Jackson has an offer to host a talk show on CNN.
But he is only entering the decision-making season, he noted. And one Democrat close to Mr. Jackson said: "I personally wouldn't be surprised to see things look a lot less decided over the next two weeks. There are a lot of people who are trying to talk him into taking another look."
This Democrat added, "I don't believe he'll run, and I believe he's not going to ever really get close to running, but the path between here and not running can travel a lot of different routes."
And Steve Cobble, Mr. Jackson's delegate coordinator in 1988, said: "If I had to bet today, I'd probably bet he wouldn't run. But one should keep in mind that Jackson is always the first to respond to new events. He's always the most flexible and the most spontaneous about these things."

He dismissed talk that he would not seek the nomination as "just speculation." But he has taken to noting, "Running has always been an option, not an obsession." (George Tames for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
Politicians Take Up The Domestic Issues; Polls Suggest Why

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
BY tacit bipartisan agreement, this is supposed to be the season for politicians to work on domestic issues, everything from abortion to civil rights to education to transportation. Despite the increasingly sharp dispute over housing loan guarantees to Israel, which caught Congress by surprise, leaders of both parties have a compelling reason to concentrate, for now, on the problems of Americans and not those of other countries. In fact, they share the very same reason: President Bush's successes, real and perceived, in foreign policy.
For the Democrats, whether in Congress or launching Presidential campaigns, those successes are a good reason to change the subject. They retain an image of a caring party, one that can best be relied on to improve schools and health care, and look after ordinary people generally. It's not as much to go on as they had until recent years, when polls still identified them as the party of prosperity, too, but it's what they have. 
 So when George J. Mitchell, the Senate majority leader, gathers reporters together as he did Thursday to tell them that the time has come to reduce defense spending and concentrate on domestic priorities, his rhetoric focuses on issues where the public's instinctive trust is with his party:
"We have an education system that isn't teaching, a health care system that isn't taking care of people, an infrastructure that isn't permitting efficient transportation, an unemployment system that doesn't provide insurance to unemployed people."
The Republicans' reason for wanting to change the subject, at least a little, is more intriguing. After Mr. Bush held a campaign strategy session several weeks ago, participants said that the biggest single message they got came from Robert M. Teeter, the President's polltaker, who reported that the public was tiring of Mr. Bush's concentration on foreign policy and wanted him to pay more attention to domestic issues.
There were seeds of the problem even earlier. In a New York Times/CBS News Poll in March, when Mr. Bush had a startling 88 percent approval rating, only 31 percent of the respondents said they thought he was spending enough time on the economy.
Such findings help explain this month's White House travel schedule, with its made-for-television trips to a school to emphasize this year's education program, a drug treatment center to recall the drug policy announced in 1989, and the Grand Canyon to hail last year's Clean Air Bill.
 
Polls and Strategies
 And polls explain some legislative strategy. As Senator Phil Gramm, who heads the Republican Senate Campaign Committee, left the White House last week, he earnestly told the cameras, "The President feels very strongly that we need to adopt the mandatory sentencing provisions of the crime bill."
If promised anonymity, conservatives readily concede there is more symbol than substance in their crime bill and liberals admit that slowing handgun sales will have a minuscule effect on crime. But polls make it clear the public is worrying about crime and likes the death penalties that are scattered through the bill. One skeptic who voted for the bill, Senator John C. Danforth, Republican of Missouri, said it sends the message, " 'Hey, we're going to do this about crime.' It's a great 30-second commercial."
Of course, polls don't control every element of the political agenda. Take Mr. Bush's threat to veto an appropriations bill that would stop the Administration from withholding Federal funds from family planning clinics that discuss abortion with pregnant patients. That came up when the Supreme Court upheld the regulation as constitutional. But the public opposes that policy by a whopping 71 to 23 percent margin, according to this month's New York Times/CBS News Poll. If Mr. Bush sticks to his veto threat, the reason won't be to increase his political appeal, but will reflect his belief that such discussions lead to more abortions, and his political reliance on the zeal of abortion foes who pushed for the rule in the first place.
And if, as the Democrats insist, the Administration has carved its civil rights position in response to surveys that show Republicans can win votes by opposing quotas, the Times/ CBS News Poll suggests that their position is hardly a sure thing. The Administration currently says it opposes the civil rights bill because the measure should allow employers to impose higher educational standards than a job actually requires, even if such standards might discriminate against minorities. The Administration argues that such a provision is necessary in order to encourage youths to complete their education. By a 2-to-1 margin, participants in the poll disagreed.
But as Mr. Danforth's comment on the crime bill indicated, polls and other devices for taking the public pulse may identify problems, but they do not spell out solutions.
 
Fear of Taxes
 They can, however, help rule out solutions. When the House votes this week on a bill to extend unemployment benefits for people out of work for more than half a year, it will get a chance to vote for letting Mr. Bush decide to pay for the extra benefits with higher payroll taxes on employers. Representative Tom Downey, Democrat of New York, acknowledged his colleagues' fear of voting for any semblance of a new tax, estimating its prospects this way: "I believe the Yankees have a better chance of winning the World Series."
There is lots of overlap of subjects that the two parties will focus on this fall. The Republicans have an education proposal; so do the Democrats. Everybody has, or soon will have, his or her crime bill. On health insurance, neither party seems ready to push forward with an overall, national solution. The issue is complicated, expensive, and there is no remotely affordable solution that won't step on some important interests' toes. But it is a serious issue, and the public knows it. So each party offers modest proposals designed to solve some part of the problem.
But there is a big difference between talking about issues and putting them into law. Mr. Bush and Congressional Republicans often seem most comfortable complaining that the Democratic majorities on the Hill do not pass their proposals quickly and with few changes. Mr. Bush last week delighted in blaming "Congressional bickering" for inaction. But divided government gives both parties an excuse. On Thursday, Senator Lloyd Bentsen, a Texas Democrat, said that comprehensive health care reform was impossible without leadership from the White House, which was not forthcoming because there was "very little potential for parades."

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
The Barriers To Western Aid Are Disappearing

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY

DATELINE: MOSCOW

 BODY:
PRESIDENT Mikhail S. Gorbachev was Crazy Eddie last week, offering Cuba, the Kurile islands, even Afghanistan, all at prices that were INSANE.
But there was a method to the madness, and a logic that could soon force the United States to consider not only more economic aid to the Soviets than it has been willing to think about up to now, but bigger nuclear arms cuts than looked possible or desirable only six weeks ago. 
 What Mr. Gorbachev and his new regent, President Boris N. Yeltsin of the Russian Republic, were up to seemed at first like mere mendicancy. Eleven thousand Soviet troops would come out of Cuba, Mr. Gorbachev said; Japan might yet get its "northern territories" -- the four northern isles in the Kurile chain -- according to Mr. Yeltsin, and Moscow would cut off weapons deliveries to the Marxist Government of Afghanistan by the beginning of next year, according to Foreign Minister Boris D. Pankin. All of this was clearly being said in the hope that the United States and Japan would then change their minds and agree to send money -- and lots of it.
Apart from agreement by the United States to stop its aid to the Afghan rebels by the same time, and vague hopes that the United States would cut back its naval presence at and around its Cuban base at Guantanamo Bay, there was no quid pro quo. The angry Cubans denounced the Soviet pullout plans as an invitation for American aggression, but the only thing the Soviets seemed interested in was making Washington more willing to grant economic aid.
Just for the coming winter, Mr. Gorbachev said in a letter to the European Community and the Group of Seven industrial democracies, the Soviet Union will need $6 billion to $7.3 billion worth of emergency food aid -- 5.5 million metric tons of grain, 900,000 metric tons of meat and sugar, and so on, down to cigarettes.
 
Billions from Japan?
 Beyond that, Mr. Yeltsin's Russian government would like to get $8 bilion to $15 billion worth of economic aid from Japan, aid he apparently hopes Tokyo will be more inclined to provide if it gets the Kuriles back, though the request got a cool response last week.
How much the new leaders think the United States can or will provide with the Cuban irritant out of the way, they have not yet spelled out. But apparently they must hope it's plenty, because they are giving up positions that Soviet governments fiercely held onto for decades. Cuba, for instance, has been an expensive drain on Soviet finances, but Moscow stayed on to challenge the Monroe Doctrine and to show that the Soviet Union was a superpower, too. But it is one no longer.
Whether this fire sale will save the Soviet Union from collapse or bankruptcy is hard to tell at this point. But it is clear that the rapid changes in Soviet foreign policy since the failure of last month's coup against Mr. Gorbachev have already created a powerful dynamic that could quickly increase pressure on the United States to consider other changes of its own.
At the London economic summit in July, President Bush, strongly supported by Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu, put off Mr. Gorbachev until he placed the country on the path to a market economy. Now, with the Russian leadership forging ahead and dragging the Kremlin along, Mr. Gorbachev will soon be in a position to say: "O.K., I've done what you asked. Now fulfill your side of the bargain."
At his last meeting with Mr. Gorbachev in Moscow, six weeks ago, Mr. Bush signed what American officials thought would be the last major strategic arms reduction agreement for some time. But as the Soviet Union continues to come apart, concern is growing in the United States and, even more, in Europe about how to make sure that the Soviet nuclear arsenal stays under tight control. Since the fewer Soviet nuclear warheads there are, the easier it will be to assure that they do not fall into the wrong (or too many) hands, some European allies are already stepping up pressure on Washington to agree to a new round of arms talks.
This logic was evident in remarks by Hans-Dietrich Genscher, the German Foreign Minister, who said that he had lobbied Mr. Baker so hard here to start negotiations to reduce American and Soviet short-range nuclear missiles and artillery warheads that the Secretary of State proposed starting such talks when he saw Gen. Vladimir N. Lobov, Chief of the Soviet General Staff, on Friday.
That proposal was taken up right away. But the same logic applies to long-range nuclear weapons, whose elimination has been a goal of Mr. Gorbachev for years. Even France, which has resisted calls to negotiate cutbacks in its nuclear force, has suddenly developed concern about the controls over nuclear arsenals in Europe, and President Francois Mitterrand called last week for a conference of the United States, the Soviet Union, Britain and France to discuss the problem. The French and the British had talked about joining the next medium-range nuclear arms talks, expecting them in the distant future. But the future is suddenly now, and Mr. Gorbachev's dream may come closer to reality.

SECTION: Section 4; Page 4; Column 1; Week In Review Desk

HEADLINE: IDEAS & TRENDS;
In Financial Scandals, Is Blind Greed Meeting Sightless Watchdogs?

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
ON the surface, the recent financial scandals have little in common. But the more that comes to light about such seemingly disparate cases as cheating by Salomon Brothers in the Treasury market, corruption at the Bank of Credit and Commerce International, the nationwide savings and loan debacle and the shaky condition of many of the nation's largest banks and insurance companies, the more an underlying thread becomes apparent:
As national and international finance has become increasingly complicated, the Government's regulatory apparatus, mostly designed about 60 years ago, has proved unable to cope. "Fragmented, underfunded and perhaps not particularly talented regulators find it difficult to outsmart centralized, wealthy and extremely talented crooks," said Robert B. Reich, an economist at Harvard. 
 Donald F. Kettl, a political scientist at the University of Wisconsin who has been studying how the Government and business interact, agreed with that analysis. "A phenomenon sweeping across the society is the lack of Government expertise in dealing with the private sector it is charged with regulating," he said in an interview.
Mr. Reich and Mr. Kettl are liberals. They place much of the blame on the Reagan and Bush Administrations' deep cuts in the staffing and financing of the regulatory agencies, and they would like to see the Government's hand strengthened.
Conservative scholars agree that the scandals grew at least in part out of a failure of Government regulation. But they argue that the solution is not tougher regulation but for the Government to withdraw altogether and let the invisible hand of the marketplace work unfettered.
Existing financial regulation, in the view of Jerry L. Jordan, a member of President Ronald Reagan's Council of Economic Advisers, is based largely on the principle of "permission and denial." Those who want to move in the financial world, said Mr. Jordan, now chief economist at First Interstate Bancorp in Los Angeles, must concentrate on making friends in high places or finding loopholes in the system, and sometimes they cross the line and act improperly.
If, Mr. Jordan argued, the Government did nothing but publish what everyone in the markets was doing, a philosophy he called "information and disclosure," the resulting competition would prevent scandals like those now in the headlines.
Joseph A. Grundfest, a former member of the Securities and Exchange Commission and now a professor at Stanford Law School, cast the problem somewhat differently. "Regulation," he said, "is not something like butter that can be measured in pounds. The question is smart regulation or dumb regulation, good regulation or bad regulation."
Political scientists and economists cautioned against finding too many similarities in the scandals. After all, what Salomon did -- submitting phony bids to acquire more than its legal share of Treasury securities in several auctions this year -- was an isolated case as far as is known. The massive failure of savings and loan institutions, on the other hand, was a systemic disaster that developed over many years and is costing taxpayers hundreds of billions of dollars.
Money laundering and other corruption at the Bank of Credit and Commerce International occurred largely overseas. Although the international bank is accused of illegally controlling a majority of the stock in Washington's largest bank holding company, First American Bankshares, the criminals and most if not all of the victims in B.C.C.I.'s scams were foreigners. By contrast, the failure of the Bank of New England early this year and the weakness of other large banks and insurance companies in the United States could portend danger throughout the American economy.
But however large the differences, a theme running through the scandals was the sense of financial high rollers that they could make big money by taking advantage of the Government's role in the financial world.
John G. Heimann, who was the New York State Superintendent of Banks and the Federal Comptroller of the Currency and is now an executive at Merrill, Lynch, described the connection this way: "When the Government is involved in the marketplace, there's an assumption that the rules are being followed. Somebody who breaks the rules has an advantage."
Thus, B.C.C.I. got itself chartered in Luxembourg and the Cayman Islands so it could avoid many of the regulations that its international competitors in America, Europe and Japan were subjected to. Salomon used its Government-sanctioned position as one of only 39 firms allowed to bid on Treasury notes to corner the market. And greedy savings and loan operators had the money to take wild risks because their depositors had been attracted in part by the protection of Government insurance.
That raises another similarity. Traders at Salomon Brothers and the shady savings and loan operators thought they could make big profits with little risk, a philosophy that defies common sense but typifies the free-lunch attitude that more and more has characterized finance and in some cases politics in recent years.
The regulators eventually wised up, but at least in the case of the savings and loan industry and B.C.C.I., not until heavy damage had been wreaked.
"Regulators," said L. William Seidman, chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, "are always behind the curve, always correcting for last year's folly while people are finding new ways to beat the system."
More than the other financial regulatory agencies, the Securities and Exchange Commission, which has jurisdiction over the stock market, has managed to stay ahead of the curve. Exactly why is not clear, but it seems to have much to do with what Mr. Grundfest, the former commissioner, called "a certain culture, an unmistakable esprit de corps and competence that the other agencies cannot match."
Warren E. Buffett, the new chairman named to clean up Salomon Brothers, told Congress early this month that the main reason why "the United States has the best equity markets in the world" was that the S.E.C. was such a "tough cop."
"I think," Mr. Buffett continued, "that there's a feeling they can attract young people out of school who could probably earn a lot more money elsewhere and that there's a certain Marine Corps mentality about getting the job done."
But as good as it is, the S.E.C. could not prevent the insider trading and other crimes that were so prevalent on Wall Street in the 1980's.
"You can't keep fraud out of the system," said Mr. Heimann, the former comptroller. "The key to good regulation is how quickly you catch it."

HEADLINE: Remedy for Racism of Past Has New Kind of Shackles

BYLINE: By ISABEL WILKERSON

 BODY:
Without the strong arm of affirmative action, Renee Baldwin would not be a police officer in Cleveland, Carlyle Miller of Manhattan would have trained at a segregated medical school instead of an Ivy League college and Jay Walker, a Chicago lawyer, might not have suffered the pangs of uncertainty over why an East Coast law firm had hired him.
They are among the thousands of blacks who are the ambivalent children of affirmative action, the first generation to walk over the threshold of newly opened doors and integrate the nation's offices and classrooms. 
 Now in their mid-20's to mid-40's, they hold down jobs that their grandparents, as brilliant or educated as they might have been, could not have dreamed of. And whether they have benefited from the programs or succeeded without them, their lives have been buffeted by a climate that, once accepting of affirmative action, has turned grudging and hostile toward not only the programs, but them, too.
 
Too High a Price?
 In recent weeks, the nomination to the Supreme Court of perhaps the most prominent son and critic of affirmative action, Judge Clarence Thomas, has put the issue at center stage. And voices of others in his generation are likely to loom even larger in the coming months as debate begins in Congress over the civil rights bill and as the 1992 Presidential campaign begins.
For the most part, these are the reluctant defenders of affirmative action. Many see affirmative action -- programs and policies intended to correct the effects of past discrimination in employment or education -- as an imperfect solution to racism, one that only gives them the chance they and their ancestors deserved all along. Others say the price is too high and resent the presumptions of inferiority that the programs sometimes evoke.
But even those who have felt stigmatized by affirmative action offer painful arguments in favor of it: They see it as vital, but wish they could be assured of a fair shake without it.
 
Who's in the Way?
 In the Memphis Fire Department, for example, blatant racism that once prohibited black firefighters from sleeping in station beds reserved for whites also prevented the department's few blacks from moving beyond the very lowest rungs. Ulysses Jones says he would not have made lieutenant had a 1980 consent decree, settling a lawsuit brought by blacks against the city and the firefighters' union, not forced the department to award 20 percent of its promotions to minorities.
"They have made affirmative action a dirty word," said Lieutenant Jones, 40 years old. "For us it's a word that means fairness. You kept us down for 300 years and now you have to pay. I look at it as insurance and assurance."
But insurance has its price. Lieutenant Jones recalls bitter confrontations with white colleagues who were resentful when they weren't ignoring him.
"They wouldn't view you as a co-worker, but as an infringement that was keeping their relatives from getting jobs," Lieutenant Jones said. "They would say, 'This could have been my cousin's job,' or "The reason my son is not here is because of you.' They don't look at the 45 white people who came on with you. They still look at our jobs as being their positions."
When the words "affirmative action" first appeared 30 years ago in an executive order by the Kennedy Administration requiring Federal contractors to make their work forces represent the population, the words were a phrase in a well-meaning effort to remedy virulent discrimination.
By the time the idea wound its way to the nation's schools and businesses, Maisha Bennett was a high school senior in Cleveland, a straight-A student, valedictorian and on the top of the mailing lists of the best colleges in the country in 1966. "I should have been the kind of person that anybody would have wanted in their college," she said. "But the letters almost read, 'Dear Black Student.' "
 
Lessons on First Day
 She went to Mount Holyoke College. The courtship began anew four years later for graduate school. Harvard, Yale, Stanford, among others, wanted her desperately. They wooed her with offers of full scholarships and personal telephone calls from the department chairmen. She chose the University of Chicago, which awarded her full tuition, room and board and a stipend as a doctoral student in psychology.
But the first day of school offered a lesson in the great paradox of affirmative action: admittance does not guarantee acceptance. As she and a black law student were standing outside a classroom reading a bulletin board, sirens began blaring and the police pulled up, guns drawn. A secretary had called the police to report that black people were in the building.
The suspicions extended to the classrooms, but she rose above them, got her degree and is now a psychologist in Chicago. She only wishes that people like her father, a man she said was born to be a professor but was consigned to being a bricklayer because of his race and times, had had the chance.
"I'm glad I was on the side of the clock I was on," Dr. Bennett, 42, said. "I knew these hundreds of letters were because of Martin Luther King and Malcolm X and the marching. I knew it wasn't just me. I wasn't any smarter than the valedictorian of 1963 or than my father."
 
Sunlight and Shadows
 Blacks on the trailing edge of the generation report very different experiences. In some ways, they say, they are in the worst of all possible worlds, benefiting from neither the bounty bestowed on their older brothers and sisters nor the air of good will and generosity that characterized the early days of affirmative action.
Indeed, as college tuition rises, sources of financial aid dry up and politics and economics seem to make the country less benevolent in general, they find themselves left with little in the way of affirmative action benefits but more and more white resentment.
Jay Walker, a 33-year-old assistant corporation counsel in Chicago, laments that affirmative action has come to taint the hiring process, whether it is being used or not, and casts a long shadow over the legitimate achievements of blacks.
For 18 months, he worked at a law firm in the Northeast as one of three black lawyers of a total of 200. He was never told he was an affirmative action hire, but he said he always felt like one.
"You always want to believe you were hired because you were the best," he said. "You work seven days a week, you wear Brooks Brothers suits, you play golf. But everything around you is telling you were brought in for one reason: because you were a quota."
He said he felt he was under constant scrutiny from his colleagues and always had to justify his being there. He volunteered for the toughest assignments and took to "carrying my resume in my breast pocket," so to speak, but felt dismissed as a nothing more than a quota.
"No matter how hard I worked or how brilliant I was, it wasn't getting me anywhere," Mr. Walker said. "It's a hell of a stigma to overcome. There are only 24 hours in a day."
When he left the firm, another black took his place. "It's a revolving door," Mr. Walker said.
It is because of problems like these that Stephen Carter, a professor of law at Yale University, argues for a rethinking of affirmative action in his new book, "Reflections of an Affirmative Action Baby," published by Basic Books this year, in which he recounts his own experiences being second-guessed and stigmatized under affirmative action.
"There should be a time when we demand to be judged by the same standards as everybody," Professor Carter said. "I don't have an ideal place to draw the line. But there should be a point where everyone understands, this far and no further. Once you've gotten into the web, people can say everything you do is tainted."
 
Memories of Jim Crow
 Supporters argue that it is not affirmative action but centuries-old prejudice that stigmatizes blacks. "White racism existed before anyone ever heard the word 'affirmative action,' " said Mary Frances Berry, a professor of history at the University of Pennsylvania, who is a member of the United States Commission on Civil Rights. "We have always been stigmatized. It would be better if we could all move up without affirmative action. It would also have been better if we hadn't had Jim Crow and segregation. But we did."
Despite their defense of affirmative action, many are haunted by the failures of past efforts, some pathetically naive in retrospect, as dramatized in the 1960's when a few elite East Coast schools took to recruiting black gang members, who then proceeded to rob other students once they got there. They worry that poor choices in affirmative action candidates seem to condemn not only the policy, but anyone who happens to benefit from it.
Indeed, many are among the most ardent of critics of lax standards because they say that affirmative action failures reflect most poorly on them. Many chafe at the word "qualified," which they say is used as a billy club by whites who question their credentials.
 
The 'One-Way Ticket'
 "They don't realize that affirmative action is a one-way ticket," said Dr. Carlyle Miller, a 42-year-old New York gastroenterologist who won scholarships to Columbia University and to Cornell Medical School in the late 1960's and early 1970's. "You're going through the same curriculum as everybody else. But all along the way everyone is questioning you."
Others express a frustration that affirmative action means a ceiling as well as a floor. "They hire a set number and don't hire any more," Mr. Walker said.
Professor Carter of Yale said he detected a restlessness for alternatives. "Students now seem much more resentful than they did before," he Carter said. "The more you find black people resenting the suggestion of affirmative action, the closer you are to the end of it."
Renee Baldwin, a Cleveland police officer who joined the force in 1977 after a consent decree mandated the hiring of minorities, is among those feeling the weight of public opinion against affirmative action. She does not expect it to last much longer. "It's dead, it's a dinosaur," Ms. Baldwin said. "It died with the Reagan Administration. I'm a relic now."
Affirmative action was not around when Arthur Fletcher, the chairman of the United States Commission on Civil Rights, graduated from Washburn University in Topeka, Kan., in 1950. Job recruiters would not even talk to him and the few other blacks in his class. So he drove an ice truck, mowed lawns and worked as a garbage collector to feed his children for four years until he could find work as teacher.
Although discrimination may be subtler now, he says there is still some unfinished business, and it requires affirmative action. "What we have been doing for the past 20 years is sawing the tree at the ground level," Mr. Fletcher said. "The roots are still very much alive."

HEADLINE: Screws Missing on Tail Wing of Plane in Crash Fatal to 14

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HOUSTON, Sept. 14

 BODY:
The night before a Continental Express Commuter plane crashed here on Wednesday, killing all 14 people aboard, workers at the airline's Houston hangar failed to screw on a part of the tail that is now missing from the wreckage, Federal investigators said Friday night.
The investigators from the National Transportation Safety Board said they confirmed their finding by examining the wreckage and by looking at maintenance records that showed mechanics unscrewed part of the plane's tail wing, replaced some of the wing, but failed to refit 43 screws that hold the part in place. 
 The part in question is a flexible section of the tail wing that prevents ice from building up. It forms the leading edge of the tail wing.
 
Torn Free in Flight
 Investigators said it appeared that the piece might have torn free in flight, which would have caused the plane to pitch down, possibly stressing other parts of the aircraft beyond the limits at which it could fly safely.
James Kolstad, the chairman of the safety board, said that as part of a routine maintenance operation the screws were removed from the top of the wing's left side and the top and bottom of the right side. The right side of the assembly was replaced, but the left side was not changed.
"The plane went back into service without the screws on top of the left hand side," he said.
 
Engines Operated Normally
 Mr. Kolstad also said information from the plane's recording devices suggested that the plane come apart piece by piece in just a few seconds, while its engines operated normally. The pilots apparently had no indication of trouble until that moment, he said.
The safety board's investigators boarded a chartered helicopter on Friday afternoon and searched from the air without success for the crucial missing part of the plane.
The bulk of the tail wing was found about 200 yards from where the fuselage and main wings landed in a charred heap. By examining this part of the tail wing, investigators concluded that the missing piece had not been properly screwed on.
A separate team of investigators examined the plane's maintenance records at Continental's hangar in Houston. This team will also interview people who worked on the plane, a Brazilian-made Embraer 120 Brasilia, an official said.
 
No Firm Conclusions
 No firm conclusions have been reached at this stage, the investigators emphasized. But the fact that they are looking into maintenance problems poses troubling prospects for Continental Airlines, the bankrupt parent company of Continental Express.
F.A.A. officials said today that they had increased their surveillance of safety and maintenance programs at Continental and its commuter line after the parent company filed for bankruptcy last year.
"There were no corners being cut," said Roger Myers, an agency spokesman. "We were very happy they were doing things corectly."
A senior F.A.A. safety offical said that because of the accident there would certainly be further reviews of the commuter line's maintenance.
Art Kent, a Continental spokesman, said Friday night that further investigation was needed to determine exactly what happened to the plane. "We want to find out what happened more than anyone," he said. "We want to stress that safety is our No. 1 priority."
Mr. Kolstad said a tape recording of noises from the cockpit showed no conversation by the pilots about the accident. But other noises were recorded, he said.
"All of a sudden there was a loud noise, followed a few seconds later by an even louder noise. That was followed by a series of warning horns and messages," he said, referring to the alarms in the plane's cockpit. "Then there was a loud whooshing noise, followed by the end of the tape."
 
Sharp Downward Pitch
 A separate device that tracks the airplane's motions showed that its nose suddenly pitched sharply downward as the plane dropped suddenly. During this time the plane's engines were operating normally, he said.
Mr. Kolstad refused to speculate about what had happened in these crucial seconds.
It seems possible that the plane's rear tail wing, the horizontal stabilizer, was the first part to break, perhaps when its leading edge tore away.
That rupture, making the first noise heard on the tapes, could have caused the plane to drop suddenly, putting immense stress on its forward wings.
The left wing appears to have folded completely under the plane, which might have been the second loud noise heard on the tape.
That damage, in turn, could have broken fuel lines and started the fire aboard the plane before it crashed. So far, investigators have devoted most of their attention to the tail. But they have not yet been able to fully examine the left wing, because it is still lying on the ground underneath the right wing. It appears that the plane belly-flopped in a corn field with the left wing tucked underneath the right one.
David Messing, a spokesman for Continental, said the company's EMB-120's are maintained at several locations, with the main work done at the Houston Intercontinental Airport, where Continental Express has a separate hangar for maintaining its fleet of 101 planes, including 34 Brasilias.
There are 85 employees, including mechanics, inspectors and supervisors, at the hangar, which can accommodate two Brasilias at a time and can handle all routine and nonroutine work on the planes, he said.
Employment at the hangar has been stable, with no recent layoffs during the economic downturn, he said.

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
How Subic Bay Became A Rallying Cry for Philippine Nationalism

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON

DATELINE: MANILA

 BODY:
EVEN among Filipinos who want the United States military to stay, it is commonly said that this is a nation that has never been allowed to progress beyond adolescence, beyond an immature need to hide behind someone or something else for protection.
When Filipinos go abroad to live -- to Europe, to the Middle East, to the United States -- they thrive, their communities as industrious and self-reliant as any. But at home, on the 7,100 volcano-born islands that make up the Philippines, many Filipinos admit that too often they seek out godfathers rather than take responsibility for their own actions. 
 Led by several fierce, hard-headed nationalists, who say with a touch of pride that they are willing to buck popular opinion, the Philippine Senate seems poised to try to end the country's dependence on what is being portrayed as the biggest godfather of them all, the American military and the thousands of jobs and billions of dollars it represents here.
In a move that many of the 23 senators acknowledge is as impractical as it is terrifying, the Senate is prepared to vote to reject a new 10-year American lease for the mammoth Subic Bay Naval Station on the central island of Luzon, and, it is hoped, force the Philippines into a political maturity denied it since a Portuguese navigator in the service of Spain, Ferdinand Magellan, "discovered" the islands in 1521. In the 470 years since, the Philippines have been under the control or at least the influence of a foreign power: the Spanish for more than three centuries, then the Americans, then the Japanese, and then the Americans again.
The Senate's impending vote is, in many ways, the opening of the second act of the "people power" revolution launched by the brave widow in her trademark yellow dress, Corazon C. Aquino, now the nation's president. With Mrs. Aquino at the head of the crowd, the Philippine revolutionaries forced out the ailing dictator, her predecessor, President Ferdinand E. Marcos in 1986. Now many of the same Filipinos are trying to oust -- with what they insist is much less ill will -- the superpower that many believe propped up the Marcos dynasty.
But Mrs. Aquino is not part of this revolution. Hoping to preserve the jobs of thousands of Filipinos working at Subic and the base's larger contribution to the struggling economy, she is the chief sponsor of the base treaty now facing almost certain defeat in the Senate.
Of the 12 senators who have already declared their opposition to the base agreement, one or two seem to be inspired by little more than a policy of opposing everything that Mrs. Aquino supports. Others do not object to the Americans remaining at Subic so much as they do to the amount of rent being paid by the United States -- $203 million a year, less than a quarter of what Mrs. Aquino had originally sought -- and want the pact renegotiated. Still others, perhaps most of the senators, seem motivated by a desire to end, once and for all, the spirit of colonialism and foreign influence they say has long plagued their nation.
 
'A Primal Scream'
 Alexander Magno, a political analyst at the University of the Philippines, describes the impending vote as a turning point for a country that, with so many advantages, has never truly prospered. "To reject this base treaty is not by any means a practical move," he said. "But the emotional release, the assertion of power and independence will be great. It will be therapeutic, a national primal scream that may mature us."
The Senate vote will almost certainly not put an end to the debate. There is every indication that Mrs. Aquino and her supporters in the Senate will try to delay an American departure, either through a national referendum or by modifying the treaty.
But for the first time since the Japanese invaded the Philippines in World War II -- and before that, since the United States acquisition of the Philippines in 1899 as the victor in the Spanish-American War -- the United States is talking seriously about departing from its former colony. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said last week that the United States military will "pack up and move" from Subic unless the Philippine Senate quickly approves the unmodified treaty. "I mean, that's it," he said with a bluntness that many Filipinos found offensive, and that may not fully reflect the value some American military officials still see in Subic.
While the strategic worth of the base has doubtless decreased with the end of the cold war, the cost of replicating Subic's functions at other military installations has been estimated in the billions of dollars.
To some extent, the Senate's move to try to shut down the base is an answer to a question Filipinos have been asking themselves for generations: How much worse can things get? By some measurements, the Philippines is the poorest major non-Communist nation in Southeast Asia and the South Pacific, with a per capita income of $730, a little less than Papua New Guinea's, about half that of Thailand. The nation is suffering from a 15 percent unemployment rate, the highest in years.
The ailing economy has been further jolted by a series of natural disasters, most recently and most significantly the eruption of Mount Pinatubo in June. The volcano left cities and villages in Luzon smothered beneath a thick crust of volcanic ash and led the United States to abandon Clark Air Base.
A shutdown of Subic would put tens of thousands of jobs in jeopardy and remove from the economy hundreds of millions of dollars in direct and indirect American payments. But in a nation of 59 million people with a $40 billion-a-year economy, the loss of Subic, though painful, could probably be managed. "I think people tend to exaggerate the problem of American withdrawal," said Blas Ople, a Manila newspaper columnist who is often described as the eminence gris of Philippine politics and who was for a time Ferdinand Marcos's labor secretary.
While Mr. Ople actively supports the extension of the American lease on Subic, he, like many other supporters of the base, does not panic at the thought of the treaty's rejection. The withdrawal of the American troops from the Philippines "would not be the end of the world," he says. "The nation would of course survive."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Filipinos opposed to American bases demonstrating last week outside the Senate building in Manila. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: $10 Billion Showdown;
The U.S. and Israel Collide At a Crucial Time in the Mideast

BYLINE: By CLYDE HABERMAN

DATELINE: JERUSALEM

 BODY:
IT is something of a gamble, but Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir seems to have calculated that he can go home with all the marbles:
He would get $10 billion in special loan guarantees from the United States to help resettle Soviet immigrants. He would continue to receive some $3 billion a year in regular aid from Washington. He would go to Middle East peace talks planned for next month with no intention of giving up occupied territory and with the power to dictate which Palestinians would be allowed to sit at the conference table. Most important, he would do all this without having to slow the expansion of Jewish settlement in the West Bank and Gaza Strip that he regards as his country's manifest destiny. 
 With his Likud Party getting set for parliamentary elections in 1992, it would be the political equivalent of hitting a grand-slam home run -- "proof that right-wing policies not only do not harm Israel's vital interests, but pay off," said Akiva Eldar, a political columnist for the independent newspaper Haaretz.
Mr. Shamir may yet win his gamble. But the odds against him lengthened last week when a lectern-thumping George Bush declared that the requested loan guarantees for the Soviet Jews stood in the path of Middle East harmony. If Congress approved them now, the President warned, the fragile peace process that he is trying to keep in motion could fall apart. This volatile region stands "on the brink of an historic breakthrough," he said, and there is no alternative but for Congress to delay debate on the assistance package for 120 days. If it does not -- and indeed it may not, for the formidable pro-Israel lobby is energetically working to have Congress enact the loan guarantees -- he would use his veto to block the aid.
 
A Low Point
 At no point did Mr. Bush use the word settlements. But Israel's pursuit of an ever larger Jewish presence in the occupied lands despite clear American opposition is what this dispute is really about, and it has now brought United States-Israel relations to a level of mutual annoyance and sullenness not seen in some time. It is a particularly delicate time for things to be going sour, because other matters hang in the balance as well -- including hopes for obtaining the release of Western hostages in Lebanon, an intricate effort in which Israel figured pivotally last week.
Mr. Bush's unhappiness with Israeli activity in the occupied territories is hardly new, but his irritation has grown, as the settlements have, since a year ago, when Israel got an earlier batch of loan guarantees worth $400 million. Israeli leaders insist that the money they plan to borrow from commercial banks, with the United States acting as guarantor, is purely for immigrant aid -- for roads, schools, houses and job training; not a dime, they say, will go to settlement-building on lands captured from neighboring Arab states in the 1967 Middle East war.
But critics, and they include many Israelis, consider that a disingenuous assertion. Money, they say, is fungible, an accountant's term that means one dollar looks like every other. Any American-backed loans for projects intended to help immigrants free up Israeli Government funds that can be spent elsewhere for hospitals, for roads, for garbage collection -- and for settlements. In the end, there is no way to tell whether a single dollar, or 10 billion dollars, will wind up in Tel Aviv or the West Bank. As a result, according to this argument, there is virtually no weapon available to Mr. Bush other than a suspension of the requested loan guarantees to get Mr. Shamir to bend to his will.
Even in Israel, many people have had it with settlements. Opposition leaders say that Mr. Shamir has brought the crisis on himself with his intransigence, and economists caution that the Government's construction plans not only stand in the way of hoped-for peace but also impose a serious drain on the economy. Zionist goals, they argue, are best served by making Israel proper a stronger place, and not by spreading thin resources across the Judean hills.
Moreover, some of them ask if it is worth waging a potentially nasty fight with the Bush Administration. Even if Mr. Shamir presses ahead in Congress for the loan guarantees (which he said on Friday he would) and even if he prevails (as some of his aides think he can), Israel will have to contend, probably for another five years, with a White House familiar with the old maxim that you don't get mad, you get even.
Clearly, the Prime Minister, by refusing to make a choice between settlements and American aid, is willing to take that risk.
He is committed both politically and ideologically to the notion that Jews must populate all of the biblical land of Israel that they control, including the West Bank, and he reaffirmed that point last weekend on the eve of the Jewish New Year. Like most Israelis, he is also devoutly committed to the Zionist imperative to bring the world's Jews here. So to him, any money intended for the hundreds of thousands of Soviet Jews is humanitarian aid that should have nothing to do with "political" matters like peace conferences and settlements. If push comes to shove, Foreign Minister David Levy said last week, Israelis would be prepared to live without American aid and get by "on bread and salt," a diet that presumably few of the Soviet newcomers had in mind when they left home.
 
Why Wait?
 There are also practical considerations for Israel's Government. Mr. Bush has given no signal that he will support the $10 billion package even after his 120-day cooling-off period. So why wait, officials here ask, especially when the money is needed right away and has already been counted in the 1992 budget plan?
On an even more fundamental level, Israeli leaders say Mr. Bush has handed the Arabs a gift that will encourage them to escalate their demands. Aside from the Palestinians, who are still mulling whether to bother to attend, the key Arab states agreed to peace talks without making an issue of loan guarantees. Now Mr. Bush is doing it on his own, and the Israelis say they cannot figure out why, even though they know the Arabs are dismayed at the prospect of perhaps as many as a million Soviet Jews arriving and inevitably trickling into the occupied territories. While Mr. Shamir insists that he still supports the peace process, provided that he has veto power over the Palestinian delegation, some of his advisers question the Administration's fairness as an arbiter. The fact is, many here suspect that George Bush, the Texas oilman, is inherently pro-Arab and anti-Israel.
Yet, despite the widening gap, no one rules out the possibility of compromise, and the prospects for that should become plainer tomorrow when Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d makes his seventh journey here since the end of the Persian Gulf war. The two countries remain allies, after all. Still, a senior official here said, there is no getting around the obvious: The skirmishes of recent days "cast a very troubling shadow over this whole process."
