HEADLINE: Political Talk

BYLINE: By Sam Howe Verhovek

 BODY:

Pre-emptive Cocktails
 Albany's legislative leaders and Gov. Mario M. Cuomo engaged in hand-to-hand political combat this spring over the state budget, an exercise that pushed budget adoption two months past its legal deadline and left everyone involved embittered and exhausted. 
 So why were they all mingling over cocktails and canapes together at the Governor's mansion one day last week? So they don't have to go through similar brinkmanship next spring, they hope.
The Governor has convened several bipartisan task forces to discuss big budget issues like Medicaid cost containment and criminal-justice reform, even though it is more than six months before the 1992-93 state budget is to be adopted. Four of the six task forces met for the first time last Wednesday, followed at the end of the day by the conviviality session at the Governor's house.
"Maybe nothing will come of it," the Governor said later to reporters with a small shrug. "But at least we're making a sincere effort."
Legislative leaders seemed amenable to the new approach, though none said that any agreements were reached in the first round. Among them there was something less than optimism that peace would break out at the height of budget time next spring.
"It's like chicken soup," said Saul Weprin, a Queens Democrat and the chairman of the Assembly's Ways and Means Committee. "It certainly won't hurt."
Despite the bonhomie reported by many participants, it wasn't long before there was a bit of bipartisan sniping. Republicans, who control the State Senate, complained that several of their Medicaid cost-cutting ideas produced only glazed eyes among their Democratic counterparts. One idea was to institute a photo-identification system for program recipients in order to cut down on fraud. "We were the only ones who really brought anything to the table," said John Daly, a Republican State Senator from the Niagara Falls area. "The Democrats kept saying that we had to talk about long-term solutions, but there are plenty of things you could do right now."
 
The Price of Incumbency
 Despite the recession, the price of a lot of things keeps going up. Take the price of holding on to a legislative seat in Trenton.
A new study of primary campaign spending by the New Jersey Election Law Enforcement Commission, a state agency, has found that incumbent lawmakers, who spent just over $1 million on their primary campaigns in 1987, spent $1.6 million this year, an increase running above the rate of inflation.
All told, incumbents spent twice what challengers did in the primaries last year, and the disparity appears to be growing. The last time that both the Senate and the General Assembly were up for election, in 1987, incumbents spent 51 percent of the total amount expended; last year it was 70 percent. And while total primary spending by incumbents shot up 63 percent in that period, the spending by challengers actually dropped 23 percent. A report by the agency on general-election spending is scheduled to be issued later.
The top spender in a Senate primary was Thomas H. Paterniti, Democrat of Edison, who spent $198,000, although he wound up losing to a challenger who spent $130,000. Dick Kamin, Republican of Mount Olive, spent the most among Assembly members, $112,000, in a victorious effort.
Even bigger numbers are expected in November, with several candidates having already received $300,000 in donations two months beforehand.
 
Battle on the Thames
 The Thames River in eastern Connecticut, which forms part of the border between the 18th and 20th State Senate districts, has become a skirmish line in the fight over the state's new income tax.
Democrats would like to change the river's political course to repay a debt. District 18 is home to Senator Steven Spellman, a Democrat who provided one of the swing votes needed to pass an income tax and a budget last month after weeks of deadlock with Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. Democratic Party leaders, who mostly backed the Governor's budget overhaul plan, want to reward Mr. Spellman and help his re-election chances next year by changing the district lines. They would move the predominantly Democratic city of New London -- on the west bank of the Thames -- into Mr. Spellman's east bank district.
Republican leaders would like to make the same change, but to settle a score. District 20, on the west bank, is home to Senator Lawrence J. Bettencourt, a Republican who also voted for the income tax, to the deep consternation of his party, which stood mostly united against it. Mr. Bettencourt is vitally concerned about keeping New London in his district because he believes residents there will gain from state programs paid for by the income tax, and thank him for his tax vote in the 1992 elections.
In return for losing New London, Mr. Bettencourt's district could pick up several heavily Republican suburban towns that might not be as favorably disposed toward the income tax. Republican leaders said even before the tax vote that they would do all in their power to see that renegades like Mr. Bettencourt were punished, and their agenda in negotiating the redistricting plan has been driven by the notion that 1992 will mark the voters' revenge on all who strayed from the state's no-income-tax tradition.

HEADLINE: UConn Proposes Higher Fees

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: STORRS, Conn., Sept. 14

 BODY:
University of Connecticut administrators are proposing $356 in new annual fee increases for room and board. The increase, coupled with previously approved increases, would raise students' costs by $673 to attend the university in the 1992-93 year. The administrators said on Friday that they had no choice but to raise fees again to keep pace with inflation and to renovate some dormitories.

HEADLINE: New York on $450 a Night (Sodas and Fruit Free)

BYLINE: By ALESSANDRA STANLEY

 BODY:
At the most expensive hotel in New York City, suitcases are taken to the room by an "associate." Room service is delivered and lint is removed by a personal "maitre d'etage" wearing white tie and tails. Soft drinks, fresh fruit and local phone calls are free.
These are the courtesies that managers cite to explain why the St. Regis Hotel reopened in the middle of a recession and expects guests to pay from $350 to $450 a night when other luxury hotels nearby offer rooms for nearly $100 less. 
 Peter W. Tischmann, the managing director and vice president of ITT Sheraton, which owns the hotel, said there was no contest between the St. Regis and say, the Penninsula ($250 to $385) directly across the street on Fifth Avenue. "If you had a choice between the East Side and the West Side," Mr. Tischmann, a native of Hanover, Germany, asked primly, "what would you choose?"
The St. Regis, the ornate Art Nouveau hotel on 55th Street and Fifth Avenue that was built by John Jacob Astor in 1904, closed in June 1988 for an $100 million renovation. It opened its heavy bronze doors last week to reveal acres of sparkling crystal chandeliers, polished marble, glinting 22-karat gold-leaf moldings and a heavy dose of Old World grandeur. With it comes more than a touch of New World snobbery.
 
Leather Books, Not for Reading
 "Our rates are our rates," Mr. Tischmann said, explaining that the St. Regis would never offer corporate discounts. "Our type of customer is not going to change his life style just because of a recession."
The lobby has been scaled down into a series of smaller intimate public rooms, some oak paneled, some filled with gilded Louis XV furniture, all suggesting the drawing rooms of a French aristocrat -- before the deluge. Guests who use the equipment in the exercise room do so beneath ornate molding and in front of a watercolor mural of an 18th century chateau. Locked bookcases that line a vast second-floor library are filled with $3 million worth of leather-bound editions of Dickens, Emerson, and "The Secret Memoirs of the Royal Family of France."
The books are not for reading, however. "They are really more of our decor, now," said Patricia Jefferies, director of public relations.
The number of rooms has been decreased to 362 from 557 to provide larger baths and rooms. The occupancy rate last week hovered around 27 percent, but Mr. Tischmann said that those prosaic figures were misleading. "I would rather have the right customer than a full house," he said.
 
If You Have to Ask. . . .
 The very first guest to sign in on Tuesday (guests are preregistered and upon arrival, sign a guest book) was an Asian ambassador, who, when informed that he was the first, was feted with a bottle of champagne. The president of Venezuela is another expected guest, as well as "many other foreign dignitaries," Mr. Tischmann confided.
There is a presidential suite ($3,000 a night) and three designer suites ($1,750), but the hotel's bread and caviar is the traveling business executive. All rooms include Bijan toiletries and telephones so high-tech that they can be used to turn on the lights and television. Deluxe suites ($750) come with personal fax machines.
The St. Regis, however, does not plan to welcome conventioneers. "No conventions," Mr. Tischmann said emphatically. "We will do a board meeting if I.T.T. or I.B.M. wants a board meeting, but that is as far as we go."
Mr. Tischmann spoke dismissively of the recession that has wounded even some of New York's finest hotels. "There is always room at the top regardless of what happens." He allowed that middle-level hotels were struggling to undercut one another in the lagging economy. St. Regis customers, he said, might visit New York less or stay fewer days, but they would not stay at a lesser hotel.
 
The Wisdom of an English Butler
 To train the maitres d'etage who are assigned to each floor, the hotel hired the English butler Ivor Spencer, who runs a school for butlers in London, to teach for an intensive two weeks. Mr. Spencer instructed employees in the fine points of hotel etiquette, from extracting a noisy drunk from a public area ("Mr. So-and-So, you have a telephone call.") to the golden rule of never saying to an accompanied female guest, "Mrs. So-and-So, how nice to have you with us again."
"Part of it is natural instinct," said Grant Friedman, the 24-year-old maitre d'etage on the eighth floor, who underwent simulated etiquette crises as part of his training. "They teach us to really read the guest."
All employees are paid union wages and, from the assistant managers to the bellboys, are referred to as associates. This is part of Mr. Tischmann's "philosophy of empowerment." To instill responsibility and independence, he said, "associates must feel ownership of the overall product." He was not, however, referring to any sort of employee profit-sharing plan. "I mean psychological, mental and physical ownership," he said, "not financial."
Fine service, he said, extends even to New Yorkers visiting the Astor tea court or the King Cole Bar, home of a famous Maxfield Parrish mural and birthplace of the Bloody Mary. There were, however, a few opening week snags. When a visitor entering the Lespinasse restaurant for breakfast Friday requested cigarettes, a friendly hostess apologetically explained that the hotel did not yet provide them. When the visitor suggested that she send a bellboy out to buy some, she replied with a radiant smile, "I'm afraid I wouldn't know how to go about it."
Most customers seemed content. Mr. and Mrs. William Pershinsky of Allentown, Pa., arrived on Friday to celebrate their 40th anniversary and said they were delighted by the grandiose face lift given to the hotel they had frequented for 25 years. "Its just beautiful," Mrs. Pershinsky said with a sigh. Mr. Pershinsky looked almost relieved to learn that his favorite hotel was now the most expensive in the city. "I thought New York rates must have really gone up since last month," he said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The St. Regis Hotel, the most expensive hotel in New York City, where guests can pay from $350 to $450 a night, has reopened after an $100 million renovation. Patrons dined at the hotel's Astor tea court. (Jim Estrin for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: CAMPUS LIFE: Yale;
Students Protest Dinner's Demise At the Commons

DATELINE: NEW HAVEN

 BODY:
Several hundred Yale University students, employees and union representatives gathered near the university president's office on Beinecke Plaza in a rally last week to protest the elimination of dinner in the huge white-columned Commons dining hall. Eliminate dinner, they say, and you irrevocably damage the quality of student life.
The closing of the Commons dining hall, which was announced in the summer, is part of universitywide budget cuts of 5 to 10 percent ordered by President Benno C. Schmidt Jr. last November. Other cuts include seven junior varsity and two varsity sports teams, as well as reductions in student jobs and library services. 
 Mr. Schmidt said the budget crunch stemmed from more than the weak New England economy. "Our problem is not that we have fewer dollars but that we have to divert funding into capital investment," he said in an interview last week. Noting that most Yale buildings were built between 1929 and World War II, Mr. Schmidt said they all required extensive renovations, which are straining the university's operating budget.
Gordon Lafer, a spokesman for the Graduate Employees and Students Organization, which sponsored the rally on Wednesday, said "The budget crisis is alleged and not proven." Mr. Lafer, a graduate student in political science from Wayne, N.J., said, "All the information made public shows only one thing, that Yale is doing very well financially."
 
Dining in Individual Colleges
 Yale students say that since the university lacks a student center, dinner provides an opportunity to relax and socialize. And the dining Commons, they say, have been central to freshman dining traditions since residential colleges were established.
Yale undergraduates are divided among 12 residential colleges, each with its own living area, enclosed courtyard and dining halls. While freshmen are affiliated with a residential college, most live together on the Old Campus quadrangle and, until now, ate dinner together in the dining Commons, an arrangement intended to encourage them to get to know others outside their particular colleges.
With the closing of the dining Commons for dinner, freshmen are to eat dinner in their individual colleges. The dining hall is still open for breakfast and lunch.
"The unity of the class of 1995 has been drop-kicked to save a million dollars," said Matthew Warren, a junior from Cambridge, Mass., majoring in history. Mr. Warren spent $700 in the summer to mail 1,500 letters to students to inform them of the loss of the dining Commons. "To a significant extent my freshman year -- what I did, who I talked to -- was shaped by dinner in Commons. That was where friendships were cemented."
But Mr. Schmidt said, "The colleges are much more conducive to students really getting to know each other" because their environments are more intimate than the vast Commons. He recalled that in his freshman year at Yale, 1959, he felt "very much separated" because freshmen did not join in their individual colleges' social life.
 
A 'Haven' for Some
 Many upperclassmen say they use the dining Commons as a meeting place for large groups, like sports teams. And Justin Kim, a senior studying art from Manchester, Conn., said that for some individuals, the dining Commons provided a "haven."
"There are certain students who don't thrive in the residential college atmosphere" because their numbers are small, Mr. Kim said. "This would include students of color, students of different sexual orientations and a variety of other groups."
More than 2,200 students, almost half the undergraduate population, have signed a Yale College Council petition demanding the reinstatement of dinner in the dining Commons, said the council president, Kyu Rhee, a senior from Potomac, Md., majoring in molecular biophysics and biochemistry.
Summer letter-writing campaigns generated another 600 letters of protest, officials in the president's office said, while a hunger strike staged by Odell Huff, a senior studying economics and political science, generated considerable media attention. Mr. Huff, who is from Hemet, Calif., ended his strike last week, saying that alumni and parents "can exert more pressure than my hunger strike will."
Students said they were particularly upset that they had not been consulted regarding the budget cuts. "We live here, we work here, we study here and we know what we need," said Kathleen Newman, a second-year graduate student in American studies from Seattle who spoke at the rally.
Promising to review the changes as the semester progresses, Mr. Schmidt said, "I want to judge this on the basis of experience and not on the basis of what I think is a predictable but perhaps misleading reluctance for change."

HEADLINE: For the Soviets, Not Mere Charity

 BODY:
One way or another, the West will meet Mikhail Gorbachev's desperate plea for food to get his country through the winter. But even then, Soviet citizens will be left with a crumbling economy; they need something beyond charity.
The Soviets are poised, finally, to make the leap to a market system. The West is the only place they can turn for help; and it would be monumentally in the self-interest of the Western powers to give it. 
 Before the August coup, when Soviet hard-liners and reformers were maneuvering for power, there was a compelling case for Western engagement. Experts devised a "Grand Bargain" of targeted aid tied to reforms, intended to tilt the political scale in favor of the reformers. That rationale has dissolved. The reformers won. Yet the case for Western aid remains compelling, as Secretary of State James Baker acknowledged last week.
Economic reform will be traumatic; no country has pulled off a transition from centralized control to markets. The Soviet people, already beset by grim shortages and inflation, might well crack under the strain. As the Russian President, Boris Yeltsin, has warned, they might revert to authoritarian controls, with frightening consequences for world peace and security. By easing the strain of reform, by taking an edge off the fear, the West could help propel the Soviets irreversibly toward markets.
The essential ingredients of economic reform are unchanged. To create markets, the Soviets will have to free prices -- which have already doubled this year. They will also have to plug gaping deficits so they can stop printing money. That will require eliminating subsidies to inefficient businesses, which would throw tens of millions out of work. Then, amid the turmoil, factories, stores and other property will have to be stripped away from government ministries and put into private hands. These are frightening steps, which Mikhail Gorbachev has repeatedly evaded.
The immediate need is for money to import consumer goods during the initial stages of price decontrol and to set up currency stabilization funds. These funds would be used to maintain the exchange value of the ruble, thereby reassuring traders and investors. The reform package would include no blank checks; instead, aid would be directed at specific, irreversible market reforms. And the U.S. share need not exceed a modest $3 billion a year for five years.
For economic reform to work, the republics will have to cooperate. Each will have to forswear the use of internal trade barriers, maintain strict control over currency, protect legal contracts and assume partial responsibility for the union's debt and military costs. If cooperation among 15 republics proves impossible, the West could work with just Russia, the Ukraine and, say, the Baltics. That would cover more than 80 percent of the economy.
Western engagement would incur decided risks. The political revolution is only in its first stage; the old guard still controls key ministries and nearly all the factories. Unless the Western assistance is carefully targeted, it could solidify the power of these bureaucrats.
Yet the best way to release the bureaucrats' stranglehold over the economy is competition. As Western engagement hastens price reform, budget discipline and privatization, the old order will be smashed beyond repair. And that would be in the interest of prosperity, peace and freedom far beyond the boundaries of the old Soviet empire.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: Communism's Unfinished Job, and Capitalism's;
North American Model

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The breakup of the Soviet Union into as many as 15 independent republics will neither ameliorate their deep economic problems nor fail to exacerbate even deeper internal conflicts. The need for some kind of stable, federal structure is obvious. 
 For more than a century in Canada, and for two centuries in the United States, there have been viable models for such a structure. Neither model, Canadians and Americans will quickly affirm, is perfect, but despite periodic crises and chronic complaints, their federal systems have fused stability with freedom and prosperity in vast, diverse territories. The 1780's in the United States, and the 1860's in British North America, though far distant in time, had some of the same desperate features as the Soviet crisis. Those concerned with the crisis, and with the predictable results of its runaway secessionism, could do worse than look closely at these Canadian and American federal models.
 
JOHN SHY
Professor of History, U. of Michigan
Ann Arbor, Mich., Aug. 27, 1991

HEADLINE: Communism's Unfinished Job, and Capitalism's;
Mirror-Image Fallacy

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Anthony Lewis in "E Pluribus Unum?" (column, Sept. 6) reflects the mirror-image thinking about the Soviet Union that has continually contributed to flawed United States policy toward the Soviet Union. The United States cannot and will not serve as a model for a new Soviet Union. Our states were settled by individuals who left their native land. The populations of the former Soviet republics are living on their historic lands with separate and distinct languages, cultures, histories and religions. 
 There is no doubt that the newly independent nations of the former union will maintain economic ties to one another through bilateral and multilateral treaties. A confederation is also a possibility, but on the model of the European Community -- an association of independent nations, rather than the United States.
If the United States is to play a role in the peaceful transition, we must understand that the Soviet Union was never a nation as we know it. It was an empire and now, like most empires, it has disintegrated into true nations.
 
EUGENE M. IWANCIW
Director, Washington Office, Ukrainian National Assn.
Washington, Sept. 6, 1991

HEADLINE: Venice Journal;
Sun City Is Stood Up By Guest Of Honor

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: VENICE, Calif., Sept. 14

 BODY:
In this, the land of the endless summer, summer never came. Where bathing suits and deep tans were once the order of the day, pale skin and long sleeves made a comeback.
This summer, now in its final days, may have been a disappointment for sun worshipers, but for the merchants whose shops and stands line the Venice boardwalk it has been a disaster. Under cloudy skies more typical of San Francisco than Los Angeles, the customary mass exodus to the beach that keeps lifeguards busy, police officers on edge and businesses alive never materialized. 
 "Only thing we worry about is weather," said Yong No, owner of the Mr. No Poster Shop. Gazing in dismay as a handful of people strolled on the boardwalk under a ceiling of clouds that stretched over the ocean, Mr. No said "we're not so good" when the weather is bad. This year, he added, business has been off by about 30 percent.
Mr. No and his neighbors knew the recession would keep away many of the tourists who descend every summer on this Los Angeles neighborhood. But nature dealt them another, and unexpected, blow.
Heat waves are a regular feature of Los Angeles summers, sending temperatures soaring above 100 degrees and baking airborne chemicals into a toxic brown haze. The scorching weather and smog can usually be counted on to drive people by the hundreds of thousands to the sea in search of relief.
But this year the sun barely put in an appearance. Fog enveloped the coast for much of the summer, a pair of rare July storms pelted the parched city with rain, and the temperature in downtown Los Angeles topped 90 degrees only once.
Los Angeles County's lifeguard corps reported that beach attendance in June and July lagged more than 30 percent behind last year's figures, and was about average in August. With fewer people braving the unseasonably chilly water, lifeguards rescued only 3,191 people over the three-month period, as against 5,310 last year and 5,770 in 1989.
Boardwalk merchants, who rely on a summer financial boom to carry them through the winter, said the gray skies were responsible for the decline in business, which they said averaged more than 20 percent compared to last year.
"Usually, I get like 50, 60 people a day," said a psychic who identified herself only as Crystal, a former New Yorker who offers palm, tarot card and crystal-ball readings at her boardwalk apartment. "This year it's more like 20."
At the Sidewalk Cafe, where long lines were a given in years past, an outdoor table with a view of the beach and the Santa Monica Mountains often could be had without a wait this summer.
"We didn't get the early beach crowd that comes in for breakfast, or the usual crowd that comes in after the beach," said Patrick J. Good, manager of the restaurant. "All we got was the tourists, and there weren't many of them. If they do have something to eat, they don't spend as much."
Speaking over the reggae music that blared from the stereo in his All One People clothing shop, Richard A. Nutting acknowledged that this summer his business was the slowest he had seen in the 10 years he had been on the boardwalk.
"The weather affected us a lot," he said. "June and July were just the worst." Even when the weather improved somewhat in August, he added, "for most people it never picked up."
Not everyone was disappointed by the cool weather and thin crowds.
"The incidents of violence were considerably reduced," said Lieut. Jerry C. Szymanski, commander of the Los Angeles police unit that patrols the boardwalk and beach. "We had a remarkably quiet summer."
Labor Day weekend usually produces the last major beach crowd of the summer, but the dreary season ended much as it had begun, with overcast skies. Most boardwalk merchants conceded that as Labor Day passed so did their last chance at a bonanza that might have partially redeemed a dismal year. But a few held out hope.
"California summers are long and winters not so cold," Mr. No said, suggesting that business could get better. Gesturing at the racks in his shop, he added: "We sell clothes. And people need clothes year round, right?"

CORRECTION-DATE: September 22, 1991, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
A "Venice Journal" from California last Sunday, about the cloudy weather that afflicted Los Angeles's beaches this summer, misattributed a quotation. It was Richard A. Nutting of the All One People clothing shop, not Yong No of the Mr. No Poster Shop, who said: "We sell clothes. And people need clothes year round, right?"

HEADLINE: Landmarks of the Loop

BYLINE: By SUZANNE WINCKLER; SUZANNE WINCKLER is the author of the Great Lakes and the Plains States volumes of "The Smithsonian Guides to Historic America" (Stewart Tabori & Chang).

 BODY:
I WAS walking up Michigan Avenue in the shoppers' nirvana that Chicagoans call the Magnificent Mile. Even though it was Sunday, the sidewalk was elbow-to-elbow people, so I didn't have to strain to hear the father say to his son, "There was a big fire, and the city burned down."
"Hot dog!" I thought to myself. Here was at least anecdotal confirmation of some of my cherished thoughts about Chicago. 
 First observation: many of the events that define the city -- and in some cases the nation -- are so compelling that even as the incidents recede in time they retain an indelible, cinematic richness. The Great Fire of 1871 is still a topic of conversation on the streets of Chicago. After all, what could be more dramatic, to child and grownup alike, than a conflagration that turned a boomtown into a heap of ashes?
The Great Fire burned out of control for three days, set ablaze 2,000 acres of Chicago, killed 300 people, left 90,000 homeless and created what is probably the most famous open space in America. A collection of stellar architects -- the list includes William Le Baron Jenney, Daniel Burnham, John Wellborn Root, Louis Sullivan, Dankmar Adler, William Holabird, Martin Roche and Frank Lloyd Wright -- were working in Chicago (or soon to be; Wright was only 4 years old at the time of the fire).
Upon this charred ground they assembled a host of remarkably timeless structures. Numerous grand examples of the works of these architects still stand in the Loop. (This zone in downtown Chicago is generally defined as west of Lake Michigan, east of the south branch of the Chicago River, south of the main branch of the Chicago River, and north of West Congress Parkway.)
These turn-of-the-century buildings are not only beautiful to behold; they also bear witness to the evolutionary history of the skyscraper, the one building form that above all others has come to signify American cities today. I can't imagine taking a trip to Chicago without going to the Loop to pay my respects to these landmarks.
If you are unable to take the Chicago Architecture Foundation's two-hour walking tour of the Loop, wander on your own with a guidebook (Ira J. Bach and Susan Wolfson's "Chicago on Foot" and Richard Saul Wurman's "Chicago Access" are both good). It is difficult, if not impossible, to recommend a must-see roster of landmarks, but such a list would include:
* The Monadnock Building (53 West Jackson Boulevard). The north half, completed in 1891, was designed by Burnham and Root; the south half, 1893, by Holabird and Roche. The newer half of the building uses steel-frame construction; this engineering innovation speeded the construction of buildings and kept costs down; it also allowed engineers to take buildings ever higher. By contrast, in the Burnham and Root portion, the walls are load-bearing, the antediluvian method of construction that was more painstaking, more expensive and that also restricted the height of buildings. The higher the building, the thicker the bases of the walls must be, and the less rentable floor space there will be. Hence, developers trying to recoup their investments started losing interest in structures with load-bearing walls. Burnham and Root's portion on the Monadnock is the tallest of its type. Note the massively thick bases and the odd-sized handmade brick; Burnham and Root not surprisingly experienced cost overruns. Stand at a corner and with your eye follow the edge of the building up to the sky. The graceful, bird-wing curve of the ascending wall is one of the most tranquil spectacles in urban America.
* The Marquette Building (140 South Dearborn Street). Chicago buildings, old and new, are famous for their lobbies, and the one in this classic 1894 Holabird and Roche structure is no exception. The mosaic murals and bas-relief busts commemorate Father Jacques Marquette who, with Louis Jolliet and the help of an Indian entourage, was the first European to set eyes on the Mississippi River in 1673. The space is a symphony of Tiffany glass, mother of pearl and marble. As you enter the revolving doors, note the time-polished panther-head door handles and the tomahawks on the kickplates. The sculptor of the panther heads was Edward Kemeys, who is better known for the lions that stand at the entrance to the Art Institute of Chicago, at Michigan Avenue and Adams Street.
* The Rookery (209 South LaSalle Street). This 1888 Burnham & Root office is one of Chicago's most venerable buildings and a model of the most-difficult-to-pull-off 19th-century rock-pile style, called Romanesque. The Rookery is an elephant en pointe, a pile of rock so ineffably graceful it almost soars. In 1905 Frank Lloyd Wright remodeled the lobby, and his now-famous design is currently being restored.
The handiwork of these post-inferno architects remains a kind of provocation for today's pre-eminent designers, which explains why Chicago continues to be the place where architects and engineers are drawn to display their design prowess. Their work is not all vainglory. It has become almost a design imperative in Chicago that the new achievers pay homage to their antecedents.
Examples: John Burgee and Philip Johnson's brand-new 190 South LaSalle Street, so grand it verges on grandiloquent, pays its respects to the much shorter but still mighty Rookery Building, which stands across the street, as well as to the long-razed 1892 Masonic Temple of John Wellborn Root. The NBC Tower (200 East Illinois Street), a Skidmore, Owings & Merrill building completed in 1989, is embellished with very modern renditions of the Gothic flying buttresses that adorn the nearby Tribune Tower (435 North Michigan Avenue), which dates to 1925. Besides the fact that architectural critics and historians love to bask in historical references of this sort, the allusions are real.
Returning to the father and son, observation No. 2: the history of Chicago is not only vivid; it is so crystalline that one of the city's pivotal moments can be explained in a sentence of monosyllables. "There was a big fire, and the city burned down." You can hardly be more concise.
Of the American cities I have visited, Chicago has always been the easiest to read. I don't mean to imply that its history is simple -- it is not -- but rather that the city reveals its narrative with an amazing degree of ease and grace.
This is partly because Chicago has preserved a wealth of landmarks; partly because, as mentioned, many of its new structures are variations on time-honored architectural themes, and partly because Chicago's original reasons for being -- as a center of trade and transportation -- are still the main engines that drive the city.
When, for instance, you walk from Grant Park, Daniel Burnham's magnificent public space skirting Lake Michigan, along the north side of the Art Institute of Chicago, you cross over the huge Illinois Central Railroad yard. Here commerce and trade and art and culture stand shoulder to shoulder. William Cronon's masterful new book, "Nature's Metropolis: Chicago and the Great West," is about the labyrinthine bond between a city and its outlying countryside. Even with so complicated a topic, Chicago obliges the tourist and the historian with ample proof of the country-city bond.
There is another reason for what you might call Chicago's historical candor. Chicagoans themselves have made their city remarkably accessible to outlanders. On any given day, a visitor can choose from a dozen or so walking, bus or boat tours of the city sponsored by the Chicago Architecture Foundation; (312) 782-1776; after February, (312) 922-8687.
Perhaps my interests in history lean toward the maudlin, but high on my list of first inducements to visit Chicago turned on the tragic fates of two men, the frontiersman William Wells (one of the neglected figures in American history) and the great architect Louis Sullivan.
As a child in the Ohio Valley, William Wells was kidnapped and raised by the Miami Indians. He was fully -- and happily, it seems -- integrated in the world of the Miami, but as an adult decided to rejoin his white kin, in large part, historians believe, because he saw the writing on the wall: that the American Indians' cultures were doomed. He became a scout, interpreter and Indian agent, while maintaining his friendship with the Miami and other tribes.
During the early days of the War of 1812, Wells was summoned to the small frontier outpost of Chicago to try to negotiate with the pro-British Indians for the safe passage of the occupants of Fort Dearborn. He failed. Then, apparently knowing full well he would fail at his next enterprise as well, he dressed in Indian regalia, got on his horse and led the flight of men, women and children from Fort Dearborn on Aug. 15, 1812. He and half the party were massacred several miles south of the fort by Potawatomi Indians.
As much as I wanted to see 19th- and 20th-century masterworks of architecture, I also wanted to visit the town where William Wells died. Nothing remains of Fort Dearborn, but there are historical plaques marking the site where East Wacker Drive meets North Michigan Avenue at the Chicago River in the heart of downtown Chicago. The intersection bustles with pedestrians, cars, taxis and buses. And the landscape is gilded with some of Chicago's most famous architectural specimens: the wedding-cake Wrigley Building (constructed in 1921); the cathedral-like Tribune Tower (1925); the bizarre honeycombed residential towers of Bertrand Goldberg's Marina City (1967), and the cool, calm I.B.M. Building (1971), last work of Chicago's most famous modernist, Mies van der Rohe.
As for Louis Sullivan, the architect was his own nemesis; he drank too much, was prone to tantrums (a colleague once described one of Sullivan's outbursts as an "arrogant fit of absurd petulance") and vexed by a cast of personal demons. Sullivan was born in Boston in 1856; he practiced architecture most of his adult life in Chicago, where he cut a flamboyant swath; he died in 1924 in a Chicago hotel penniless and almost friendless.
Of all the post-inferno architects, Sullivan has always been my favorite. He designed sublime buildings and, with a host of equally talented designers he drew around himself, ornamented these buildings in imaginatively beautiful ways. It is a puzzle how a mortal whose existence was so dark and woebegone could make such exhilarating places. When I am in Chicago, I make the rounds of as many of the Sullivan shrines as I can. They include:
* The Auditorium Building (South Michigan Avenue at Congress Parkway), a Sullivan and Dankmar Adler project completed in 1890, which includes the gorgeous, cavernous Auditorium Theater, one of the most famous performance spaces in Chicago.
* The Trading Room and Entry Arch of Adler and Sullivan's 1893-94 Chicago Stock Exchange Building. Both fragments of the now-demolished structure can be seen at the Art Institute of Chicago.
* Holy Trinity Orthodox Cathedral (Leavitt Street and Haddon Avenue), an intimate stucco church Sullivan designed in 1903 for a Russian Orthodox congregation. The church is well outside of the Loop, and a visit requires access to a car or taxi.
* Carson Pirie Scott (1 South State Street), on Chicago's once-great mercantile boulevard. (Although Carson Pirie Scott is still a department store, upscale Chicago shoppers have been enticed northward to the Magnificent Mile on Michigan Avenue north of the Chicago River.) Carson Pirie Scott, which dates to 1899, is a serene, sophisticated structure to which Sullivan affixed over the entryway a sensational encrustation of cast iron ornamentation.
There comes a time, however, usually an hour or two into hiking on hard pavement, when this pilgrim gets footsore and hungry, when even the handiwork of Louis Sullivan fails to uplift.
The Loop is short on public places to sit down. These are the three I recommend: the steps of the Art Institute of Chicago, where there are many kinds of people to watch and usually some impromptu entertainment; the breakwater of the Chicago Yacht Club, on the east edge of Grant Park, where the fittings of all the moored sailboats jingle like an orchestra of windchimes, and the benches around Marc Chagall's "Four Seasons" mural in the plaza of First National Bank of Chicago, at the corner of West Monroe and South Dearborn Streets.
The Loop and vicinity provide such an impressive selection of restaurants, ranging from the dear to the economical, that you could easily spend all your time and money on the culinary trail. On the western fringe of the Loop, Lou Mitchell's (565 West Jackson Boulevard) is a great Chicago institution for breakfast and lunch. In a nation where a good cup of coffee is increasingly difficult to find, Lou Mitchell's is a historic landmark on the basis of its coffee alone.

HEADLINE: Coming to the Rescue of Vintage Pianos

BYLINE: By PENNY SINGER

DATELINE: GOLDENS BRIDGE

 BODY:
A 1907 Steinway A piano dominates the living room of the Gordon house here. Russell H. Gordon is a piano craftsman and technician and a member of the second generation of his family to ply his trade from a small workshop in the family homestead built by his parents and grandparents 50 years ago.
"This particular Steinway pretty well illustrates the unique aspects of my business," Mr. Gordon said the other day. "It was a shell when I bought it. The pads were completely worn out; it needed everything. But over a period of three to four months I completely rebuilt it." 
 Among other things, he installed a type of key and hammer action that only recently became available. "Now I have a magnificent instrument for about half the price that I'd have had to pay for a comparable piano new," he said. "An added bonus is that the 1907 piano has a much finer case than is available in pianos today."
 
Comparing the Costs
 Although completely rebuilding an old piano takes several months and costs $12,000 to $15,000, a comparable new Steinway costs about $38,000, Mr. Gordon said.
Mr. Gordon, who is 41, recalls that although he helped his father in the shop when he was in high school and college, in those days he had no intention of following in his father's footsteps.
"My dad is Paul Gordon," Mr. Gordon said. "He was a recording engineer for Columbia Records and a fine pianist as well. He started the shop in the early 1950's, mainly because he was interested in sound. He quickly won a reputation for his ability to restore tone to vintage pianos."
 
Rethinking Biochemistry
 But Russell Gordon became a biochemist who worked with the United States Geological Society for several years before he came back to Goldens Bridge and apprenticed with his father.
"I chose to become a craftsman instead of a biochemist because this kind of life better suits my temperament," he said. "I'll never get rich, but I find the work extremely satisfying."
By having a small shop, he added, "I have enough time to pay attention to the details that each piano needs, to restore tone and touch to it for another lifetime of use."
 
Tuning and Restoring
 For private owners, Mr. Gordon has restored an 1820 Clementi piano, an 1899 Mason & Hamlin reed organ and many Steinways, including one owned by the DeWitt Wallaces, founders of Reader's Digest. He also works on the pianos in the Caramoor Music Room in Katonah.
"Most of my business comes from word-of-mouth recommendations," he said. "About half of my income is derived from tuning pianos, the other half from restoring them."
It was the combination of a scientific background and piano craftsmanship that two years ago led him to David C. Stanwood, a piano technician in Vineyard Haven, Mass., who four years ago developed a type of key and hammer action for the grand piano called the Stanwood Action.
"David Stanwood has made a revolutionary advance in piano technology," Mr. Gordon said. "For a pianist, who is dependent on piano action, the Stanwood Action is tremendous because it makes the touch 100 percent uniform and adjustable, which means actions can be customized for individual players and even for different musical styles."
 
Compensating for Wear and Tear
 What is remarkable, he said, is that the uniformity of action can be maintained over time because it compensates for the effects of wear and tear and seasonal changes. "Pianists say that with the Stanwood Action they have exceptional artistic control and responsiveness, especially during soft passages," he said.
Mr. Gordon, who is president of the New York City chapter of the Craftsman Piano Technicians Guild, a professional organization that confers accreditation on its members, is one of the few technicians licensed to use the Stanwood Action method of adjusting keyboard weights and hammer friction.
"I've installed four actions in Westchester, and they have received strong endorsements from everyone who has played on the pianos, including concert pianists and piano technicians," he said, adding that performance pianos modified with the Stanwood Action include a Steinway D at the Manhattan School of Music, a Steinway C at the Old Whaling Church Performing Arts Center of Martha's Vineyard in Edgartown and a Bechstein D at the Fogg Museum at Harvard College. About 35 Stanwood Actions are in private use.
 
'Connected to the Piano'
 After playing on Mr. Gordon's Steinway A with the Stanwood Action, Mary Ann Scialdo, a concert pianist who teaches music at the Todd School in Briarcliff Manor, said, "It's extraordinary. The action is so even that you actually feel connected to the piano. My technical facility was so enhanced that I had the freedom to be a colorist. If it were a car, it would be a Ferrari, not a Ford."
Emphasizing that pianists are very dependent on piano technicians, Ms. Scialdo said, "Russell Gordon just doesn't tune a piano. He's a talented artist dedicated to the art of sound."
Two years ago when she had an important performance on a Sunday, she said, "I was given a dog of a piano. I was so distraught, I called Russell, who came to the hall immediately and adjusted it. He stayed with me during the entire concert, making other adjustments as were needed. What a miserable piano that was!"
Even two pianos of the same age built by the same manufacturer will sound different, Mr. Gordon said. "A good piano technician can evaluate the tone and action and spot some of the flaws in its manufacture," he said. "In the 50's, for example, plastic parts were used, which now may have to be replaced in those pianos."
 
A Recession-Proof Business
 Mr. Gordon advises tuning home pianos twice a year. He charges $80 to $90 for a basic tuning, depending on how far he has to travel. The recession has had a minimal effect on his business, he said.
"I work in a very specialized area," he said. "Few clients have cut back on tunings. Actually, I've been pretty busy. My dad, who lives in Florida most of the year, was here this summer, and I was able to keep him busy working for me."
The cost of installing a Stanwood Action, he said, can be anywhere from $2,500 to $5,500, including parts. "If existing parts can be modified, it will be less," he said, "but if new modified parts have to be installed, it will be more."
As for the electronic-keyboard craze, Mr. Gordon said it has had no effect on his business. "No matter how it's programmed, the sound is still coming through speakers," he said. "No electric keyboard is a substitute for a piano."

HEADLINE: Can American Schools Be Educated?

BYLINE: By Joan Countryman; Joan Countryman, the assistant head of school and director of studies at Germantown Friends School in Philadelphia, is a member of the board of directors of the National Association of Independent Schools.

 BODY:

SMART SCHOOLS, SMART KIDS
Why Do Some Schools Work?
By Edward B. Fiske with Sally Reed
and R. Craig Sautter.
303 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $21.95.  
 Public education in America needs to change. In "Smart Schools, Smart Kids," Edward B. Fiske, the former education correspondent of The New York Times, argues that the prevailing model for education, a model that dates back at least to the beginning of this century, is the factory. In his view, American schools are, in effect, factories for turning out perfect little minds; they are centrally managed, efficient and regulated, and the teachers are supposed to rely on repetitive pedagogical techniques, rigid scheduling and standardized texts and tests. But just as corporations are abandoning rigid and centralized workplaces in favor of decentralized ones that encourage cooperation and allow for flexible schedules and new standards of quality control, so American schools must find a new example to follow. Mr. Fiske, who is now a visiting scholar at the school of education at Stanford University, proposes that schools should now model themselves on "smart" machines.
"Smart" machines are computers that can receive new information and alter their own inner workings accordingly. "The functioning of a modern democracy requires citizens with similar skills" to those of a smart machine, Mr. Fiske writes. And since the economy now demands workers who are "smart" in this sense, Mr. Fiske believes that we need "smart" schools that will turn out such "smart" citizens. In fact, he thinks the transformation of public schools is already taking place. In cities, in suburbs and in rural towns, teachers, administrators, parents and politicians are rethinking and reshaping their schools. The trouble is that most of the reformers are working in relative isolation, only dimly aware of similar efforts in other places.
The strength of "Smart Schools, Smart Kids" lies in its detailed descriptions of the many types of educational reforms across the United States, from Miami to Louisville, Ky., from the Shenandoah Valley to Cambridge, Mass., from Hannibal, Mo. to Silverdale, Wash. Mr. Fiske tells of schools that are managed from the inside rather than by a board of education, schools that stress cooperative learning rather than competition among students, schools that use flexible schedules rather than following the regimented 8-to-3 clock, schools that assess a child's development without traditional tests and schools that use new computers as easily as they once used pencils and paper.
Mr. Fiske, for instance, visits an 11th grade American history class in a school on the outskirts of Louisville taught by Jim Streible, a former coach. Rather than lecturing his students, he splits up the class into clusters. "One group of students," writes Mr. Fiske, "is having an animated discussion about a short play they are writing about life in the 1920's and 1930's. Across the room another cluster of students is putting the final touches on a video documentary on the life of D. W. Griffith. . . . A third group . . . is over near the lockers trying on period costumes to wear when they will dance the Charleston . . . while a fourth group is finishing up a gigantic Hooverville house constructed from cardboard." Mr. Fiske writes that "Jim Streible is raising students, if not from the dead, then at least from deadly apathy."
Some of the changes Mr. Fiske documents are surprising, others obvious. Teachers now use copy machines and telephones in their classrooms, and they are learning, like the new wave of enlightened industrial managers, to become leaders rather than authorities. Students now help shape their educations, and often decide to take more or less than the traditional 12 years to complete their schooling. Multiple choice tests that were used to measure how much material students had covered and how many hours they had sat at their desks are now giving way to "authentic tests" that allow students to demonstrate what they can actually do with their knowledge and skills. And parents, no longer relegated to the sidelines, are now invited to make informed choices about their children's schooling. If these changes sound less than radical, remember that the norm in American public education is about as up-to-date as a Model T Ford.
What is missing in this book is a discussion of how teachers are being prepared for their new roles, how the various teachers' colleges and schools of education are redesigning the teaching profession. Mr. Fiske says there are no such institutions cultivating the new generation of "smart" teachers. Indeed, he argues that teacher education is "the black hole in the movement to create smart schools." But if he had defined his subject more broadly, to include not only the schooling that teachers must go through before they begin to teach but also the variety of ways that they continue to learn while they are working, he might have found enough material to fill another book. Perhaps a book titled "Smart Teachers" will follow.
Still, "Smart Schools, Smart Kids" describes many schools that work -- schools that will help make responsible citizens and good thinkers. And that is a small but significant contribution to the transformation of a basic American institution.

SECTION: Section 12CN; Page 3; Column 1; Connecticut Weekly Desk

HEADLINE: CONNECTICUT Q&A: ALLAN A. CRYSTAL;
State's Tax Chief Welcomes a New Era

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON

 BODY:
ON Feb. 1 Allan A. Crystal was appointed Commissioner of the State Department of Revenue Services. With the implementation of a state income tax on Sept. 1, and withholding scheduled to start on Oct. 1, no other state agency has seen so much change in the way it does business this year.
The 4.5 percent income tax, the first to become effective in state history, has several tax credits and exemptions designed to make it progressive. But critics contend that these provisions will make the tax unwieldy and confusing. Mr. Crystal will also oversee a lowering of the sales tax, to 6 percent from 8, a broadening of the items and services subject to the sales tax and numerous other changes in the tax structure. 
 A certified public accountant and lawyer, Mr. Crystal retired as a vice president for corporate taxes at Pitney Bowes in Stamford, and has held executive positions with C.I.T. Financial Corporation and the accounting firm of Lavanthol & Horvath in Manhattan. Mr. Crystal, who is 62 years old, lives in Westport. He is active in several business and civic organizations, including the Internal Revenue Service Volunteer Income Tax Assistance program.
He answered questions about the implementation of the income tax recently during an interview at his office overlooking Farmington Avenue in Hartford. Here are excerpts from the conversation.
Q. When you agreed to come on as tax commissioner, were you aware you would be embroiled in what will likely be the most controversial issue of Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr.'s first term?
A. It certainly appeared the state had a serious fiscal problem, and one of the possible ways of solving it was an income tax. And it did intrigue me, being involved in such an implementation.
Q. Will the Oct. 1 deadline leave you enough time to get regulations printed and distributed to employers?
A. It depends on what you mean by regulations. The Oct. 1 target date relates to changes in the sales and use taxes and excise taxes. Those are principally announcements that we can get out in time for people to put into effect for Oct. 1. The other issue relates to the income tax itself, and withholding, which commences with payrolls paid on or after Oct. 1. We are gearing ourselves to get every bit of information that we conceivably can by the third week of September. It takes a little time to prepare the tables. Unfortunately, we didn't have all the time we thought we'd need.
Q. Your predecessor began a study of how to implement the income tax. Is that going to help in the process?
A. Jim Meehan had set up a committee to take a look at implementation issues, and I continued that committee, so we built on what he initiated. I think the committee did a lot of good work before I got here and still more good work once I got here.
Q. Will you be monitoring Federal tax returns to make sure people are reporting all the income to the state that they are reporting to the Internal Revenue Service?
A. To a great extent we have been using Federal Internal Revenue data interchange for the purpose of verifying capital gains, interest and dividends taxes that we've had so far. We'll use the same process to check adjusted gross income and make sure they are reporting the same numbers to the state and Federal governments.
Q. Do you have any cooperative agreements with neighboring states to facilitate collection from people who live in one state and work in another?
A. Well, there is not that kind of coordination with New York, Massachusetts and Rhode Island. First of all, people who live in Connecticut and work in New York will be having their tax withheld and may have an estimated tax requirement, and the same thing will now be required of people who work in Connecticut but live in New York.
Each state taxes are based on where you earn the wages. Then in the state where they file a return, they can usually get a credit for the tax that was withheld from the other state. Both states are doing somewhat the same thing. The formulas are a bit different, but the results are the same.
Q. Do you anticipate any confusion over state adjusted gross income and Federal adjusted gross income?
A. There should not be much confusion, because there are only modest changes, and the people who have the changes will probably be using outside assistance -- certified public accountants and lawyers -- who should understand the rules.
Q. Will you be setting up any special telephone lines to answer taxpayer questions?
A. Absolutely. We are setting up, and it is operating today, a hot line. The number is (800) 3-TAXINFO. As a matter of fact, we're adding special hours. Some of our taxpayer service people will be working late Thursday nights and four hours on Saturdays.
Q. Will there be special training for tax preparers?
A. We will be participating in organizational activities, that is to say the Connecticut Society of Certified Public Accountants, the Bar Association, the Connecticut Business and Industry Association, all of those organizations who bring in their members for tax information sessions, we will be appearing before them in one way or another. We have a speakers bureau that we're in the process of training, whose people will be able to go out and review the tax changes in detail. The biggest problem, we feel, is getting the information out to taxpayers who we feel want to comply but need information.
Q. Will you be using the same April 15 filing deadline used by the Federal Government?
A. Ultimately, yes. The filing date for the final annual return will be April 15. In that same way, we have matched a lot of our key dates with the Federal dates. For example, the withholding remittance by employers will be made at the same time as they remit tax payments to the Federal Government.
Q. Connecticut has been accused of having a patchwork of taxes. This doesn't lift any taxes, so isn't it just a new patch?
A. That is, indeed, one way of looking at it. But come back and look at it from the beginning. The patchwork existed because there was no personal income tax. What you should ask is, should there be a revision of some of the patches? That is something that, conceivably, the new Tax Review Board would be looking at.
Q. Is there any indication how much it will cost to implement tax reform?
A. Legislatures make changes all the time. Every time they change the sales tax, there is a cost associated with it. We have, provided to us by the legislature, $8 million for the implementation. That number, maybe, should be a touch higher, but if we have to live within that, we'll live within it. Certainly the $8 million is less than comparable numbers from other states. The income tax is expected to collect just over $1 billion this year.
Q. What do you think will be the most confusing thing for taxpayers this year?
A. Most people are concerned with how much and how am I going to pay. But most people are not thinking about anything beyond that. They should be realizing that in addition to the income tax there is a reduction in their sales tax cost, from 8 percent to 6 percent. Those people who itemize deductions on their Federal income tax returns get the benefit of a tax credit for the state income tax they pay, so that there is a net increase, the actual cost, that people are not focusing on.
Q. The I.R.S. notices an increase of taxpayer protests, some of them involving violence, in a bad economy. Do you anticipate any of that because Connecticut is imposing an income tax for the first time in what is a poor economy?
A. Well, it is certainly possible people may protest in some way, that it could be expected. Connecticut has some advocates of repeal. But I don't believe it's necessary for us to take any precautions. I think people understand taxes are something people need to pay. They may quarrel over how those taxes are raised, they may even quarrel about whether the expenditures are necessary, but neither one of those are a function of this department, and I would hope most people would realize that and not vent their spleen on the tax department.
Q. Is a new income tax likely to force more of the economy underground?
A. I would be surprised if much of that happens on account of the Connecticut income tax.
The biggest bite of all, of course, is the Federal tax, and if they were going to do it at all, they would have already done it because of the Federal income tax. I really don't anticipate much of that.

CORRECTION-DATE: September 22, 1991, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
The Connecticut Q&A column last Sunday, about the state income tax, rendered a sentence incorrectly in a discussion of confusing aspects of the tax by Allan A. Crystal, the State Commissioner of Revenue Services. The affected sentence should have read, "Those people who itemize deductions on their Federal income tax returns get the benefit of a tax credit for the state income tax they pay, so that there is a net decrease, the actual cost, that people are not focusing on."

PUB-DATE: September 15, 1991

SECTION: Section 6; Page 71; Column 2; Magazine Desk

LENGTH: 2012 words

HEADLINE: Beauty/Fashion;
The Mirror Cracked

BYLINE: By Marcelle Clements; Marcelle Clements writes frequently on cultural and political topics.

 BODY:
IT USED TO BE THAT BEAUTY WAS IN the eye of the beholder, but these days the beholder doesn't know where to look.
How do you express fragmentation and still have fun? Mix and match. Many people laughed at fans of the post-modern esthetic for quoting from a hodgepodge of traditions, but now it's permissible to combine elements from many classes, subcultures, erotic types, eras. What's beautiful now is the Composite. In their age-old quest to solve the problem of self-presentation, women have marched into this stylistic breach with both gusto and anxiety. What's more, all kinds of women mix and match: style-obsessed women, offhand women, frivolous women and serious women. 
 Nowadays, there's unprecedented interest in style, and newcomers to the arena add their own remarkable juxtapositions. Some of the new combos are unsettling: octogenarians wearing mascara, once-dowdy suburbanites sporting new breasts, Park Avenue ladies in blaster jewelry. Others, rare until very recently, are now common: female attorneys wear sling-back heels, homemakers wear black lace lingerie and librarians wear foundation.
This development and the deep-structure changes that underlie it are so exciting and confusing that a women's discourse has surfaced around it. Much of the discussion centers on the business of beauty. But the business of beauty is tangential. The purpose of "fashion" is not merely to make money for an anonymous "industry." Aside from the pleasure and pain it gives, what matters about beauty is whether and how it reflects and changes consciousness.
In the bombardment of new female images, it has become impossible to hold on to a unified esthetic. This is in part because the role of women has changed so much in the last several decades that previously undisturbed geological layers of our psyches are being excavated and require expression.
Some of the images do their work subterraneously. For instance, we all talk and talk about "Thelma and Louise," but perhaps more eloquently the daily newspaper shows us photographs of business women, scientists, astronauts and cops. We want to know what they're doing and what they're wearing. And why not? Like myths and dreams, fashion provides texts that are enactments of our realizations about ourselves.
Every change in the culture, certainly in the female culture, is much documented and photographed. Thanks to the plentiful visual record, we are constantly looking at one another. Female firefighters and fashion models and executives and heads of state are looking at one another, and they get their ideas of how they want to present themselves from one another. What's more, we have available to us elements of male archetypes, other ethnic groups and classes and a wonderful grab bag of serendipitous abstractions. Why shouldn't we use them if we feel like it? There's no stopping us now. If there's no stopping us now, there's no resting point for the eye. All is flux.
WOMEN ARE TRYING TO GET THEIR INSIDES TO match their outsides. No wonder they're having trouble.
Women are in the process of a tremendous and very complicated adaptation to an incomprehensible culture. Women are pretty complicated to begin with, and present all sorts of inside-outside enigmas that have yet to be solved, psychologically or physiologically. Certainly, nobody understands women's sexuality. Once unleashed, fashion and beauty, which express sexuality, can eloquently refract its primitive mysteries and modern contradictions. We may not understand it, but we can enjoy it. And the struggle to generate an esthetic system complex enough to encompass and express a woman's innate erotic intricacy can be a worthy (and amusing) task.
To tell the truth is empowering. Even visual expressions of women's passivity, their role as penetrable beings, when acknowledged in a clever or moving way, empowers them. (In our marketplace of images, a nursing mother is as powerful as a warrior.)
CROSS-GENDER referencing, formerly repulsive, frightening, declasse, and illegal (or, at best, decadently elitist), is now universally considered to be cool and sexy.
The September issue of Playboy magazine features a sympathetic piece about a transsexual, "the extraordinary story of a beautiful woman who was born a boy." The text is accompanied by photographs of Tula, who has truly superb breasts and thighs, stripping from a man's business suit to a loosened tie and garter belt. The photographs are endowed with as much erotic power, Playboy style, as photographer and model can muster. Clearly, now that there's been a decade or two of settling in, no institution can resist the tidal wave of change resulting from the tremendous combined impact of the gay and women's liberation movements.
More than ever, cross-gender trespassing entertains and fascinates us, as do all types of disguises, playful deceptions, masquerades. Witness the tremendous impact of Jennie Livingston's funky and compassionate documentary about Manhattan's voguers, "Paris Is Burning," a film in which masquerade is elevated into a passion play.
When we take off the masks, what are we left with? It's anybody's guess. In the midst of all these disturbing questions, it may be true that the sense of self is weakened or even shattered, but the consolation prize is that one's satellite ego fragments get to come out and play.
In her book "Female Perversions," Louise J. Kaplan argues that around the time of the Industrial Revolution, the Western world became preoccupied with sexual normality and gender conformity in order to insure the survival of the bourgeois couple. But that was then and this is now. If established social structures are breaking down, tyrannical gender roles can go, too. And vice versa. "Psychological femininity always includes some degree of identification with the femininity of the father (and the father's mother and father)," she writes, "and some degree of identification with the masculinity of the mother (and the mother's father and mother)." This is turning out to be great for style.
WHAT IT MEANS TO WANT TO BE LOOKED AT, TO BE looked at, to look, have changed, even in the most basic forms.
Take voyeurism. It used to mainly be a secret pleasure. And then, of course, take Madonna, the face that launched a thousand mouths, the living-walking-one-woman theory of beauty fetish. She embodies the shift that has turned the old voyeurism-exhibitionism complicity on its head. Madonna isn't saying, "Here, sweetie, take a peek." She's saying, "Let me stick it in your face." Whether or not this is an attractive strategy has become a topic of conversation from supermarket checkouts to chic book-party territories, accompanied by much acrimony.
Beauty is under attack, from both the right and the left. There is much debate as to whether women are enslaved or liberated by their obsession with appearance. At the center of the brouhaha is Naomi Wolf, the neo-feminist author of "The Beauty Myth." Wolf tries to demonstrate that the fashion, beauty, diet and pornography industries are tools of a patriarchal system used to keep women from reaping the benefits of their social and economic advancements.
"The more legal and material hindrances women have broken through," she writes, "the more strictly and heavily and cruelly images of female beauty have come to weigh upon us. . . . We are in the midst of a violent backlash against feminism that uses images of female beauty as a political weapon against women's advancement."
There's been a lot of published comment on the Wolf book and, in a way, it's great to hear that hubbub of women's voices again. But arguments on both sides tend to be skewed and reductive. If given a chance to respond, I'd bet many women, feminists or otherwise, would say: "My life is complicated and my vision of myself is made up as I go along and it sometimes translates into buying a lipstick or a pair of cowboy boots. Why are you making me feel bad? Give me a break!"
Of course, women are financially exploited by the beauty, fashion and diet industries, but not necessarily more than America is generally by its consumerist ethic, except in exact ratio to the extent that women are more exploited to begin with. All of the institutions in Western society that broker a trade between money and hope are questionable, and they all radically modify the ability of women and men to be powerful and free.
And it's true that these days everything is merchandised: in a magazine, a smile on a pretty young face will almost certainly announce the merits of lip gloss. But cosmetic-surgery addiction or compulsive diets or binge shopping are the symptoms of a personal and societal pathology much more extensive than can be resolved by attacking the marketing of lip gloss.
The huge amount of space occupied by beauty, fashion, models, fashion photography, are only part of a bigger phenomenon in the culture. In a way, making money is only an excuse to "fix" the fleeting, to memorialize it and to try to avoid thinking about death. It's easy and banal to mock vulnerable women for their fear of aging and revile the industries that profit from that fear, but isn't everything that's most lofty and exhilarating in our anxious society (art, religious ritual, philosophy) designed to help us live with or modify the inevitability of decay and death?
And, besides, those of us with no particular ax to grind find the marketing useful. It makes us feel invaded, sure, but so does everything else. Why shouldn't the marketing of beauty reflect the style of our era? At any rate, it hardly deserves so much defensive talk, except perhaps as an unfortunate digression from the main problems, which are women's power, women's earnings and women's control of their own bodies.
IN THE END, ATTACKS ON BEAUTY ARE attacks on women.
In a gigantic flurry of titillating tautologies and stimulating sophistries, the blustering academic Camille Paglia, another player in the new debate, makes no secret of her contempt for feminists (along with liberals and other riff-raff) in her book "Sexual Personae." She proposes that beauty is a defense designed to prevent us from noticing how terrifying women are (a parallel, in her view, to the pitiful humanist displacement which causes us to find nature beautiful, thereby preventing us from noticing how horrible and violent and ugly nature truly is).
"Beauty, an ecstasy of the eye, drugs us and allows us to act. . . ." she writes. "Menstruation and childbirth are an affront to beauty and form. . . . Their ugliness has produced the giant displacement of women's historical status as sex object, whose beauty is endlessly discussed and modified. Woman's beauty is a compromise with her dangerous archetypal allure. It gives the eye the comforting illusion of intellectual control over nature."
The interesting problem of female misogyny aside, the characterization of beauty as a dirty trick is a lamentable and silly desecration of one of humankind's most natural paths to an experience of the sublime.
Beauty transforms consciousness. Paradoxically, even though it is said to be only skin deep, beauty enables us to experience the invisible world that lies just beyond the visible. It is said of love that it is like a seizure. Beauty, similarly, grips the beholder for a moment in a mysterious, small but timeless seizure. For a moment, all other priorities disappear. It's a powerful experience that transcends topical political and esthetic arguments. Try arguing when you're looking into the eyes of someone you love. (Why are the eyes of someone you love beautiful? When we've figured that out, women can stop spending money on mascara, trying to be beautiful, trying to be loved. Meanwhile, why shouldn't they?)
Beauty heightens consciousness, it expands it, it situates you nearer the hub of your animal aliveness and spiritual vitality. It consoles, it disturbs, it excites. It arouses desire, envy, weird energy. It makes you want to do something: kiss, flee, cry, compete, talk, die, live.

GRAPHIC: Photos of fashions. (Photographs by Michel Comte for The New York Times)

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PERSON: CLEMENTS, MARCELLE; ROSSELLINI, ISABELLA; BRAGA, SONIA

LENGTH: 646 words

HEADLINE: FORUM;
Lift the Trade Embargo on Vietnam

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. SCHWARZ and EUGENE A. MATTHEWS; Thomas J. Schwarz is a partner at Skadden Arps Slate Meagher & Flom. Eugene A. Matthews, president of Ashta International, an investment and consulting firm, lives in Hanoi.

 BODY:
If the 16-year-old ban on trade with Hanoi continues, the United States will lose Vietnam all over again. But this time, the defeat will be economic and the winner will be our economic rival, Japan.
In the next decade, Vietnam has the potential to outpace other nations in economic growth. With a population of 70 million, it offers a larger market for American goods than Romania, Czechoslovakia and Hungary combined. Nearly 60 percent of the population is under the age of 21. 
 Despite what is called the "American" war, Americans and American products in Vietnam are looked upon with friendliness and favor -- even in Hanoi. Teen-agers in Hanoi dance to American rock music in cafes owned by the Government; children in Hanoi wear T-shirts imprinted with "United States of America"; their faces light up when they realize an American is in their midst. The tastes of the nearly 42 million consumers under 21 also include such traditional American brands as Juicy Fruit gum and Kodak film.
Asian merchants and manufacturers recognize Vietnam's potential. Aside from the billions of dollars of oil reserves mapped by American companies before the ban and now being exploited by non-American companies, trade in other areas has boomed. Japan is Vietnam's second-leading trading partner, after the Soviet Union. Trade with Japan reached $853 million in 1990, and with Moscow's economic and political difficulties, Japan can be expected to loom much larger in Vietnam's future. JVC, National and Sanyo television sets and tape recorders are being assembled in Vietnam. Toyota, Mitsubishi and Honda have finalized plans to build factories there.
To encourage foreign investment, Vietnam has adopted one of the most liberal foreign investment codes of any developing country. Foreigners can own and manage 100 percent of their enterprises in Vietnam or they can form joint ventures with private companies or individuals there. Generous tax write-offs are available to foreign investors; the Government has eliminated subsidies to state-run businesses, abolished price controls and is openly discussing a stock market.
American opposition to our trade embargo -- both in the business community and among Vietnam veterans -- is widepread. Many blue chip companies, as well as Wall Street investment houses and law firms, have joined the United States-Vietnam Trade Council. The Senate Foreign Relations Committee voted 12 to 1 in June to support a measure that would lift the trade embargo. The measure's chief sponsor is a Republican.
The Bush Administration has not established relations with Vietnam for many reasons, including Vietnam's presence in Cambodia. Given progress on the issue of Americans missing in action, however, the Administration's resistance to stronger economic ties can only be explained by a determination to keep punishing Vietnam for having humiliated the United States in the war.
Recently, under pressure to stop changing its demands on Vietnam, the Administration outlined its "road map" for what Vietnam must do to improve relations with the United States. But as a guide for American businesses, it is essentially a dead end. It essentially would allow American companies to do nothing more than sign contracts that would not become binding for an indefinite period -- six months after peace in Cambodia. By then, the agreements could well have been rendered meaningless.
The White House is scheduled to decide this month whether to renew the Vietnamese trade embargo. But even if it were lifted tomorrow, most American companies would be at least a year away from making investments.
For our benefit and Vietnam's, the United States should let its free-market values triumph in Vietnam, as they have around the world, and it should allow United States companies to participate in the next great Asian economic success story.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Eugene A. Matthews (Jack Manning/The New York Times); Thomas J. Schwarz.
 
Drawing
